HEADLINE: COLLEGES;
A Final U.N.L.V. Season Is Reported for Tarkanian

BYLINE: By WILLIAM C. RHODEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LAS VEGAS, Nev. June 6

 BODY:
Jerry Tarkanian, whose 18 years at the University of Nevada-Las Vegas have been marked by highly successful teams and continuing investigations by the collegiate authorities, will step down as basketball coach after next season, according to a person close to Tarkanian who has knowledge of his plans.
Officials at the university have scheduled a news conference for Friday morning to announce his plans. 
 Tarkanian had said in interviews this week that he was considering resigning immediately. But the person said that the coach's attorneys did not want him to be unemployed. By coaching through next season, they reasoned, he will have time to look for a new position, presumably at the professional level.Tarkanian has also said that he wanted to avoid the appearance of running out on his team.
 
Pro Job a Possibility
 The 60-year-old coach met this afternoon with Robert Maxson, the president of U.N.L.V., to discuss the decision and the way it will be announced. Although Tarkanian indicated today that he had made up his mind, he would not say definitively what he would do. "I'm all set," Tarkanian said this afternoon. "I was all set last night, really. We want to talk about how he wanted to announce it, whether it was a press release or whatever."
According to another official who is close to the basketball program, who also spoke on the condition that he not be named, Tarkanian has already been offered a front-office job with a professional basketball team. Tarkanian declined to comment on the offer, but both the Dallas Mavericks and the Los Angeles Clippers have been mentioned as possibilities.
Tarkanian said he would definitely not want another college job. "I'm too old for anything like that," he said.
 
Team Under Scrutiny
 Tarkanian and the U.N.L.V. basketball program have been under scrutiny by the National Collegiate Athletic Association for many of his years at the university. The basketball program is on probation for recruiting violations dating to the mid-1970's and is the subject of an N.C.A.A. investigation into the recruiting of Lloyd Daniels, a highly touted New Yorker, in 1987.
The final blow apparently came less than two weeks ago when The Las Vegas Review-Journal published photographs showing three members of Tarkanian's 1989-90 championship team relaxing in a hot tub and playing basketball at the Las Vegas home of a convicted sports-events fixer, Richard Perry.
Tarkanian had originally wavered between announcing a decision on Friday or waiting until Monday. But Maxson urged him to do it sooner.
 
'A Brutal 11 Days'
 "I think the concern against waiting over the weekend was the speculation," Tarkanian said. "Every day there are three columns written on it with everybody speculating this and speculating that.
"I'm very disturbed and disappointed by all of this," he said. "This has hurt me greatly. It's never let up. It's been a brutal 11 days."
Speculation about Tarkanian's future had been building since Monday when he met with the University of Nevada Board of Regents and outlined several options for leaving the university.
Tarkanian has three years remaining on a rollover contract that pays him $203,976 a year.

HEADLINE: TV WEEKEND;
Clarence Darrow, Standing to Face the World

BYLINE: By JOHN J. O'CONNOR

 BODY:
"Darrow" is about Clarence Darrow, the legendary lawyer. (Darrow hated his first name, jokingly referring to it as a curse.) The two-hour film, an "American Playhouse" presentation at 9 tonight on Channel 13 and at 10 P.M. on Channel 49, stars Kevin Spacey in the title role, and that's its strongest asset. Mr. Spacey, winner of the Tony Award for best supporting actor on Sunday for his performance in Neil Simon's "Lost in Yonkers," latches onto Darrow and, covering some 30 years of his career, hangs on tenaciously.
Darrow is one of those American originals who believed, as the film puts it, that a person has to "be strong enough to stand alone and face the world unafraid." He was born in 1857 in rural Ohio and began practicing law in Chicago, his home base for more than 50 years. He started out as a lawyer defending railroad interests, but impressed with the labor crusading of Eugene V. Debs, he soon took up the causes of civil rights and workers. He was a Socialist and an agnostic who considered the Bible to be a work of literature falling somewhere between "Aesop's Fables" and "Bulfinch's Mythology." 
 This account, feistily directed by John Coles ("Signs of Life," "Rising Son"), tells something of the private man. His workaholic schedule prompts his first wife, Jessie (Erin Cressida Wilson), to leave him, taking their son with her. His second wife, Ruby (Rebecca Jenkins), becomes a kind of partner, traveling around the country with Darrow as he gives lectures and takes on new cases. Not all of them are triumphs.
In Los Angeles, defending two men accused of triggering a fatal explosion at The Los Angeles Times, Darrow runs up against the fury of the establishment and ends up discovering not only that his clients are indeed guilty, but also that he himself has been implicated in a scheme to bribe prospective jurors. Deserted by his friends and rapidly going broke, Darrow finds his spirit broken as he faces a bitter trial. He delivers his own closing argument, saying in part: "My crime is that I've spent my life fighting for the weak. The rich and powerful would still my voice."
All in all, a fascinating man, but unfortunately, this script by William Schmidt and Stephen Stept fails to do him full justice. The construction is awkward, with Darrow's son, Paul, (Stephen Mailer) sporadically called in to provide the narration. The dialogue is top heavy with cliches. The biographical elements are oddly selective, fastening on a few major cases and ending with the "crime of the century," involving Richard Loeb and Nathan Leopold, privileged young men who had murdered a boy.
Darrow, who vehemently opposed capital punishment ("mercy is the highest attribute of man"), advises the young men to "plead guilty to all charges and rely on the judge to save your lives." The strategy works.
And there "Darrow" abruptly ends, cryptically noting that Darrow would take on the Scopes trial the next summer. Apparently, the producers either ran out of money or decided that there wasn't much point in competing with the entrenched version of the trial widely circulated in the play "Inherit the Wind." In any event, Mr. Spacey's powerful performance is left hanging in a generally solid but irritatingly incomplete production.
 
'The Secret Policeman's Biggest Ball'
Arts & Entertainment
Tonight at 8
This is an hourlong version of a London comedy ball staged to benefit Amnesty International. Some of the humor is very British and doesn't travel easily, but there's no mistaking the inspired zaniness of Dudley Moore and Peter Cook, together again after nearly 20 years, as they sail through a sketch about a one-legged actor auditioning for the role of Tarzan. John Cleese and Michael Palin offer a couple of "Monty Python" skits and the Spitting Image puppets tweak the Royal Family with wicked zest. Oh, those Brits.
 
'Garry Shandling:
Stand-Up'
HBO
Tomorrow at 11 P.M.
Unemployed as a sitcom star for the moment, Garry Shandling takes his genial-worrier routine back to the stand-up circuit, in this instance the University of California at Irvine. His stories range from shaggy dog (literally, about a pooch named Shep who gets to take a bow at the end of the show) to dinner at the White House ("I'm middle-of-the-road politically. I've never burned a flag, but I've never put one out, either.") Mr. Shandling remains a master of dubious defensiveness: "I'm very loyal in relationships. Even when I go out with my mom I don't look at other moms."
 
'I, Claudius'
Channel 13
Sunday at 9 P.M.
Just in time to cope with the summer doldrums, right through Aug. 25, a television classic returns to "Masterpiece Theater." Brilliantly adapated by Jack Pulman from the Robert Graves novels and directed by Herbert Wise, this 13-hour series -- with the first two episodes shown together this weekend -- gives us ancient Rome as it might have been run by a Mafia family. Topping the list of memorable performances are Derek Jacobi as Claudius, John Hurt as Caligula, Sian Phillips as Livia and Brian Blessed as Augustus Caesar. Absolutely outrageous, and irresistible.

HEADLINE: CHRONICLE

BYLINE: By SUSAN HELLER ANDERSON

 BODY:
After teaching stints in Australia and Hawaii, MICHAEL S. DUKAKIS starts a new job this summer as a visiting professor at Northeastern University in Boston.
Mr. Dukakis, who was Governor of Massachusetts until January, will teach political science to undergraduates during Northeastern's summer term, which begins on June 24. In the fall, he will teach a graduate course on health-care policy and an undergraduate course in either American government or public policy, Northeastern officials said. Each course will meet for three hours a week. 
 This summer, Mr. Dukakis will also be a guest lecturer at the John F. Kennedy School of Government at Harvard University, where he taught from 1979 to 1982. He will teach two sessions on economic development to state and local government officials.

HEADLINE: Keep Feeding Women, Infants, Children

 BODY:
It's well and good to talk, as President Bush does, about the year 2000 as the time by which all American children entering school will be truly ready to learn. But it's not going to happen if many of those children grow to school age without minimally decent nutrition.
That was the sensible message of five corporate executives when they testified before the House Budget Committee in March on the wisdom of a 19-year-old Federal program called WIC. WIC, for Women, Infants and Children, provides poor, pregnant or nursing women and their children with diet supplements and formula. 
 WIC works. Those five executives know it, Congress knows it and the Department of Agriculture may know it better than anybody. An Agriculture study issued last fall demonstrated that each dollar invested in WIC's prenatal work saves something like two dollars in Medicaid costs just in the first 60 days after birth. Furthermore, a recent study by the National Bureau of Economic Research suggests that WIC, by reducing the incidence of low-birthweight babies, produces long-term savings in special education costs.
WIC now serves about 55 percent of those eligible. As the first step in a five-year plan to enroll everyone poor enough to meet the criteria, the executives called for increasing financing next year, to $2.7 billion. So have 237 members of the House, in a letter to Jamie Whitten, chairman of the relevant House Agriculture subcommittee.
Today, that subcommittee has a chance to show just how sensible it is -- by voting that $2.7 billion for WIC.

SECTION: Section A; Page 34; Column 4; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 442 words

HEADLINE: Dance Has Given Rise to Some of the Century's Greatest Music

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Bernard Holland's May 21 critic's notebook presents an enticing theory on the re-emergence of the public and the popular in the composition of classical music. It prompts me to expand on two different thoughts.
Some of this century's greatest music, including the post-World War II era Mr. Holland writes about, has come from commissions for dance companies. Dance in this era has had to meet its public head on and has stirred the creative fires in ways few art forms have matched in the last 40 years. Dance artists and institutions have been serious music's most consistent investors. 
 I find it sad to see in times of economic retrenchment that the artistic institutions that most support creativity are themselves most threatened. Dance has never had the resources of academia to support it and remains, even today, a virtually taboo subject in elementary and secondary education.
Globally, dance supports a wider range of creative artists than any other art form, and yet it is institutionally bankrupt. A recent survey indicates that virtually every American ballet company -- along with most modern dance companies -- is seriously in debt and retrenching.
Dance derives a higher percentage of its support directly from its audience. Mr. Holland applauds that, and so do I, but I fear America is too quick to remove the safety net and leave these artists adrift. I fear for the future of dance as a profession and the creative investment it generates.
A completely different response to the article concerns the abandonment of art as a core subject in a modern curriculum. When schools must cut, they need to cut math and English in the same proportion as they cut the arts and libraries. To do otherwise, allows education administrators to underprepare students.
I am not referring to the need to develop the next generation of great artists; I feel the real role that art education plays is to spur creative approaches to problem solving. To compete, each student needs to be creative; no topic explores unfettered creativity better than training in the arts. The arts speak to the very value of subjectivity, and they place a value on the ability to discern quality and to respond to it.
The United States does not have a single support base for art. And that has allowed the arts to flourish independently, but they have never truly been secure. Seeing education retrench from support of artists takes one more prop from a fragile balance of support. I fear America without its creativity.
 
ANDREW R. BALES
Planning and Development Director
Office of Cultural Affairs
San Jose, Calif., May 28, 1991

HEADLINE: ON MY MIND;
Save Those Bases

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL

 BODY:
The question is: How can the United States pull its strength and creativity together in a few months to win a military victory thousands of miles away but keep floundering around for years at home, throwing away one chance after another for social victory?
 The answer is: I don't know but let's not argue about it right now. While we stand around debating, one more opportunity to do the country some good is slipping through our fingers and our minds. 
 There's still time, but not much, for the nation to wake up, shake its head clear and seize a suddenly available asset in the war against drugs.
By July 1, a Presidential commission is supposed to report on how to close down and get rid of dozens of bases around the country that the military no longer needs.
For Heaven's sake, why close them all? Why not do as important anti-drug therapists are pleading, almost unheard? Why not take some of those bases and their already-built houses, school buildings, hospitals and workshops and turn them into what the drug war needs: large centers for the treatment of Americans desperately addicted but still rescuable?
A variety of studies show that for some sections of the population -- happily including high school students -- the allure of hard drugs is beginning to diminish. Anti-drug education in the schools is apparently having an impact. So is the work of the Partnership for a Drug-Free America, which uses millions of dollars of advertising donated by newspapers and television to carry the message against drugs.
Good news, but. But the studies generally leave out the attitudes of Americans serving time in prison, of the homeless, the street children and other victims and victimizers who are part of a drug subculture digging deeper into society while the polls are taking place.
More crack babies are born to more unwed young women. Thebabies will pay forever. So will tax- payers; drug addiction is already a generation-to-generation heritage.
Drug gangsters still casually kill each other, which would be fine except that they take with them those who happen to walk by.
In Japan last month I walked nighttime streets without even thinking about danger. How's that for an economic advantage over America? Is it worth a million cars? Ten million?
Drug addiction helps spread and deepen some of our worst social epidemics: AIDS, homelessness, mental disorder, child abuse, criminal and domestic violence.
The only effective strategy is the one pushed by William Bennett before he suddenly quit as anti-drug administrator. That is to fight against drugs on all fronts at home and abroad -- intervention, law enforcement, education. Oh yes, and therapy.
That always seems to come at the end. But addiction is the one social disease whose victims never cease trying to spread the contagion. Without serious national effort at cure of addicts, neither disease nor subculture will ever die out.
The most effective therapy is the most demanding -- a year or more in therapeutic communities. The addict, who enters himself or is sent by courts, has to do difficult things. He has to face his own truths, struggle with his own weakness, accept the discipline of the community. The counselors, teachers, doctors and fellow addicts lend him strength and give him hope. But in the end he has to do the hardest thing of all -- realize that from now on there will be nobody to blame if he fails to keep drug-free, nobody but the face in the mirror.
Dr. Mitchell Rosenthal, head of Phoenix House, perhaps the best-known therapeutic community in the country, estimates that 70 percent of the addicts can liberate themselves -- provided they stay for a year.
 To build all the centers needed would cost billions and involve endless public hearings. But there they are, with all their buildings for housing and training, on the bases we are about to close and scrap.
Yes, then the Federal Government and the states would have to spend more to help the centers operate. It is expensive -- about $15,000 a year for a patient. And it would take a decade to handle the core drug population.
But put all together it is a deep discount on what jails and drug crime would cost the country -- decades without end, and not even counting the blood.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Latin Population Puts Pressure on the U.S.

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Hispanics' Promised Land's Broken Promises" by the Rev. Joseph A. Fahy (letter, May 25) focuses on "the burgeoning Spanish-speaking population nationwide." He cites 12 unhappy reasons to explain this. Father Fahy ignores a central cause of the phenomenon, of his 12 reasons and of the mass influx of Latino immigrants to the United States. 
 That cause is the too rapid population growth that continues to swamp the economies and imprison the aspirations of Latin Americans.
In 1950, the populations of North America and Latin America stood equally at 166 million. By 1990, North America's population was 278 million, while Latin America's had swelled to 447 million. By the year 2020, United Nations figures project 328 million for North America, but for Latin America 705 million.
If Latin America's unbridled population growth continues, demographic projections will become realities, dooming free trade zones and other economic measures to failure.
So long as the Bush Administration and Father Fahy's church reject this, we can look forward to the continuation and acceleration on both sides of the border of the catalogue of woes that is contained in Father Fahy's letter.
 
DAVID O. POINDEXTER
President, Population
Communications International
New York, May 28, 1991

HEADLINE: Supply Faces Demand in the Ivy League

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Justice Department officials hail as a victory for students the agreement by eight Ivy League schools to stop sharing student financial aid information (front page, May 23). And you quote Attorney General Dick Thornburgh as having said at a news conference, "Students and their families are entitled to the full benefits of price competition when they choose a college." 
 These are both honorable sentiments, but they reflect a fundamental misunderstanding of how tuition levels are determined and how a college education is financed.
The assumption by Justice Department officials that price competition will work to the benefit of students is based on a simple-minded application of economic theory. We all know that in a free market with perfect competition among many profit-maximizing businesses, competition serves to keep prices down to the level at which the market clears.
The problem is that universities have never been profit maximizers. At the schools covered by the consent agreement that you report, tuition covers only a relatively small portion of the actual cost of educating a student. The rest of the cost comes from other sources, such as alumni donations. None of these funds are used to pay dividends to stockholders, because there are no dividends and no stockholders.
That these universities are not in the business of maximizing profits should be clear from the fact that tuitions are as low as they are. The demand for admission to Ivy League colleges is always several times higher than the supply.
If these schools really were the profit maximizers the Justice Department seems to think they are, why haven't they raised tuitions to the level at which the market clears? And why do they offer deep discounts, in the form of financial aid, on a product that is in such high demand?
The answer is that these schools really do believe that they are serving a worthwhile social goal by keeping tuitions as low as possible. Rationing financial aid by avoiding bidding wars for students, including the use of the information-sharing meeting, serves this goal. It insures that the best use possible is made of each school's limited financial aid dollars.
The real irony is that the agreement with the Justice Department will only speed up the increase in tuition. If some students are able to bid up the amount of financial aid they receive, and thus pay less to attend an Ivy League school, someone else will have to pay more.
At that point, either other students will receive less financial aid, or the nominal tuition level will have to increase.
The result either way will be to increase the net cost to qualified students who lack the bargaining chips that count most at Ivy League schools.
 
STEVEN GREENE
Palo Alto, Calif., May 23, 1991

HEADLINE: Sylvia Porter, Financial Columnist, Is Dead at 77

BYLINE: By GLENN FOWLER

 BODY:
Sylvia F. Porter, the author and newspaper columnist who gained wide readership by making business and financial news easy for the general public to understand, died on Wednesday at her home in Pound Ridge, N.Y. She was 77 years old.
She died of complications from emphysema, her husband, James Fox, said. 
 Miss Porter, who wrote more than a score of books on investment, taxes and other economic subjects, also reached 40 million readers through her column on personal finance. It was syndicated by The Los Angeles Times and carried five days a week by 450 newspapers around the world.
From the mid-1930's, when her column began appearing regularly in The New York Post, Miss Porter specialized in reporting events of the financial and business worlds in terms that translated what she called their "bafflegab." Her arrival on the economic scene came at a propitious time: the public was slowly recovering from deep disillusionment with a Wall Street community that many blamed for plunging the country into the Great Depression.
In 1978 she moved her column from The Post to The Daily News, where it continued under the title "Your Money."
 
Molded by 1929 Market Crash
 Miss Porter was born into a Russian-Jewish family in Patchogue, L.I., on June 18, 1913. Her father was a physician, and her mother became a successful milliner. She grew up in Brooklyn and was a freshman at Hunter College who intended to major in English literature and history when the stock market crashed in 1929.
Her mother had invested $30,000 in the bull market of the late 1920's and lost it all. The daughter rethought her career goals and plunged into the study of economics. She earned a Phi Beta Kappa key at Hunter and graduated magna cum laude in 1932, the same year that she and Reed F. Porter, a bank employee, were married.
She went to work for a small investment counseling firm in Wall Street and gained firsthand knowledge of the stock and bond markets, currency fluctuations, business cycles and other financial basics. She also took graduate courses at the New York University School of Business Administration.
She began writing in specialized financial journals, using the byline S. F. Porter to conceal the fact that she was a woman in a field then dominated by men. In 1934 she wrote a weekly column in The American Banker on United States Government securities and soon started her own information service on Government bonds.
 
A Crusader Role Adopted
 In 1935 Miss Porter began an occasional column in The New York Post on financial news. In a matter of months she was a regular writer on Wall Street for the paper, and in 1936 she was appointed financial editor. She wrote a daily column that was published under the title "S. F. Porter Says."
Miss Porter became a crusader against what she perceived as economic injustice. She bluntly criticized Government officials for their fiscal policies, at one point asking in an article in The American Banker whether the Secretary of the Treasury, Henry Morgenthau Jr., had been guily of "obstinacy, stupidity or sheer ill advice" in managing Government bonds.
Mr. Morgenthau, like many other figures in the economic world, was unaware that S. F. Porter was a woman. When he did find out, and when officials acknowledged that many of her barbs were justified, he sent her a bouquet of roses.
Other Washington figures were not so forgiving. When she attacked Senator Edwin Johnson of Colorado for his advocacy of silver, he called her "the biggest liar in the United States."
 
Author of Many Books
 In 1939 she wrote the first of her many successful books, "How to Make Money in Government Bonds." The book combined her inside knowledge with a popular style, making her information useful to professionals and at the same time accessible to the public.
In her second book, "If War Comes to the American Home," published in 1941 on the eve of America's entry into World War II, she drew on the experience of World War I to tell families how they might be affected in a war economy.
A reviewer in The New York Times summed up her approach this way: "Facts, figures, broad word-pictures and succinct arguments are all presented with conversational ease."
Although her books were published under her full name and she had been heard on radio, it was not until 1942 that The Post changed the title of her column to "Sylvia F. Porter." The newspaper's acknowledgement of her sex brought prominence on the lecture circuit and requests for articles from women's magazines and periodicals of general circulation.
Her column was syndicated, beginning in 1947, and she collaborated with the tax specialist J. K. Lasser on financial handbooks for taxpayers, as well as with other specialists on parallel projects in various economic fields.
 
Posthumous Book Planned
 In 1975 she published "Sylvia Porter's Money Book: How to Earn It, Spend It, Save It, Invest It, Borrow It and Use It to Better Your Life." It sold more than a million copies. Her most recent book, "Sylvia Porter's Your Finances in the 1990's," appeared last year, and her last book, "Planning Your Retirement," is to be published in September.
Not all Miss Porter's ventures were successful. In 1984 she started a magazine, Sylvia Porter's Personal Finance, which rapidly became the third largest periodical in its field, behind Time Inc.'s Money and the Kiplinger organization's Changing Times. But the stock-market plunge in 1987 dealt her publication a lethal blow, and in 1989 its list of 400,000 subscribers was bought by Kiplinger.
Miss Porter's second husband, G. Sumner Collins, died in 1977. Besides Mr. Fox, a public-relations counsel, she is survived by a daughter, Chris Del Cuore of Norway, Me.; a stepson, Sumner Collins of Medical Lake, Wash.; a brother, Dr. John L. Feldman, a physician of Palos Verdes, Calif., and two grandchildren.

HEADLINE: Curtis Brewer, 65; Worked for Rights Of Disabled People

BYLINE: By GLENN FOWLER

 BODY:
Curtis Brewer, a lawyer who was a quadriplegic for much of his life and who founded Untapped Resources, a nonprofit legal-services agency for the handicapped, died on Wednesday at Tisch Hospital in the New York University Medical Center. He was 65 years old and lived in Manhattan.
Mr. Brewer was stricken with a viral infection of the spine in 1955, when he was 30 years old, and was left paralyzed from the neck down. He died of complications from stomach surgery necessitated by a progressive weakening of his lungs that stemmed from the initial paralysis, his family said. 
 From his wheelchair Mr. Brewer fought for the rights of handicapped people. In 1964, he started Untapped Resources, for which he served as executive director and general counsel, to study the effects of social and economic conditions on the disabled.
Discovering that many of the disabled were unaware of their rights or prevented by bureaucratic red tape and other barriers from receiving services and benefits to which they were entitled, he set out to help them through legal action.
 
Campaign for Easier Access
 He graduated from Brooklyn Law School in 1974 with a grade-point average of 3.5 and was admitted to the New York State bar without an examination, which would have been difficult for him to take because of his disability.
He was an early campaigner for easier access for the handicapped. Unable to get his wheelchair into Carnegie Hall some years ago to attend a performance by his friend Itzhak Perlman, the violinist, who himself uses crutches, Mr. Brewer began a campaign to secure wheelchair access to public auditoriums. A lift was subsequently installed on the Seventh Avenue side of Carnegie Hall, and when it was remodeled in the mid-1980's, elevators were put in for the first time.
In 1980, Mr. Brewer was named Handicapped American of the Year by the President's Committee on Employment of the Handicapped.
Mr. Brewer, a native of Cambridge, Mass., was a graduate of the New School and studied at New York University before attending law school.
He is survived by his wife, the former Bettie Foster, a New York University administrator; a son, Scott, of Washington, a law clerk to Justice Thurgood Marshall of the United States Supreme Court; two daughters from a previous marriage, Zakia Al-Ghuiyy, director of a geriatric treatment center in Atlanta, and Geraldine Hailstolk, a family therapist in Maryland; two brothers, Garland, of Medford, Mass., and Raymond, of Boston; a sister, Jean, of Roxbury, Mass., and four granddaughters.

HEADLINE: Your Money;
Caution Is Urged On Retiring Early

BYLINE: By Jan M. Rosen

 BODY:
Many employees are seeing the silver lining as companies pare payrolls. Severance pay or early-retirement packages will enable them to strike out on their own and realize dreams of being their own bosses.
But this silver lining is likely to tarnish, financial experts say. Diane V. Schaak, president of the Denver-based Institute of Certified Financial Planners, said a great many of the middle- and upper-level managers and executives she counsels in her practice in Bellevue, Wash., feel they are under great stress and want to retire by age 55. 
 Often they hope to become consultants or do something more fulfilling, perhaps turn a hobby into a business. But, she estimated, only 30 percent have realistic plans; the rest could not take big changes or income reductions.
Alan Nadel, managing partner for Arthur Andersen & Company's compensation and benefits practice, said: "Don't go out today without guarantees" of business and clients. "It's hard to tell the landlord, 'I'll keep you in mind for the future.' "
Yet people caught up in the entrepreneurial spirit are often unrealistic, he said, and push ahead with such vague assurances as "We'll have to get together; I'll be referring people to you." One enthusiastic senior executive took out a home equity loan to set up his own business. "He lost his house," Mr. Nadel said.
Tamara G. Telesko, a vice president of the Chase Manhattan Bank, advises private banking clients to do the opposite: Repay home-equity loans and lock in a diversified portfolio of investments that provide a good cash flow to provide a foundation before building a new career. Nonetheless, George E. L. Barbee, executive director of personal financial services for Price Waterhouse, said: "The happiest retirements are when people are actively engaged in something besides leisure time. It wears thin; you can play golf just so many days."
An alternative career is one choice, volunteer work another, said Mr. Barbee, who is based in Waltham, Mass. It depends on people's finances and their personalities. But the single most common mistake, he said, is that people look at their income level only for the year they retire, failing to project future costs accurately, he said.
"People are living into their 90's," he said. "We're going to be consumers for a long time." So it is essential to make long-term projections in evaluating an offer of early retirement, and deciding that it is feasible, perhaps with supplemental income from a hobby-turned-business.
Assuming an annual inflation rate of 4.5 percent, for every $100 today, it would take $155 to buy the same goods in 10 years, $240 in 20 years and $375 in 30 years. Say a 55-year-old earning $50,000 a year is offered a chance to retire now with a full pension, equal to half his salary. Because most pensions are not indexed to inflation, the buying power of that $25,000 pension would drop to $16,000 by the time he is 65, just over $10,000 at age 75 and less than $7,000 by age 85. If he continues working until age 65, and his salary moves up with inflation, he would be earning almost $78,000 in 2001 and would have a pension of almost $39,000.
These numbers suggest that most people would need a good investment portfolio, a strong basis for believing their entrepreneurial ideas will pay off, an ability to accept a reduced standard of living or a combination if they are going to accept an early retirement offer.
One of Ms. Schaak's clients who enjoyed wordworking wanted to leave his $70,000-a-year job to open a cabinet-making shop, which might earn $25,000 a year after expenses. Combined with a pension and reduced standard of living that might work out for some people, but not for others. "I tell people to live for one year on the budget" they would have after retirement before making the decision, Ms. Schaak said.
Expenses are important in deciding whether self-employment is realistic. Mr. Nadel said medical insurance for a family could cost $5,000 to $7,500 a year, and self-employed people also need disability and possibly life insurance. Some people consider the cost of buying equipment like a photocopy and fax machine, computer and printer, and office furniture, but do not realize until they are doing without a secretary how much they have relied on one, he said, or plan an office at home without checking out zoning laws. And there are taxes, not only income tax but also self-employment tax and in some areas unincorporated business tax and commercial rent tax.
Everything considered, he said, an employee earning $60,000 may well discover it takes self-employment income of $100,000 to have the same net.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Lifted by U.S. Report On May's Increase in Jobs

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar closed higher yesterday after a positive report on job growth increased prospects for firm United States interest rates.
The dollar was helped by the Labor Department's report that 59,000 jobs were added to non-farm payrolls in May. The announcement was good news to currency traders because it indicated that the economy was regaining strength and increased the likelihood that interest rates would remain stable or move higher. 
 Rising interest rates support the dollar because foreigners are attracted to higher yields and they must buy dollars to purchase United States investments.
The market shrugged off the Labor Department's companion report that the unemployment rate rose to 6.9 percent last month from 6.6 percent in April. The sharp increase indicated that the economy remained weak.
Analysts said the economic news was welcomed by a market that has been bullish on the dollar. "The psychology of the market was in any event ready to buy, and the numbers just gave them more reason to act," said Walter Simon, a vice president with Bank Julius Baer & Company.
The dollar has moved higher recently amid growing signals that the economy was emerging from the recession. Mr. Simon said the dollar had reached a crossroads where the market could sell it down or push it even higher. "This is a definite decision-making point," he said.
The British pound fell against the dollar, tumbling to $1.6710 in New York, from $1.6870 late Thursday. In earlier London trading, the pound fell to $1.6710 from $1.6865.
Against the German currency, the dollar rose in New York to 1.7705 German marks, up from 1.7535 late Thursday.
The dollar also rose against the Japanese yen. In New York, it closed at 140.35 yen, up from 139.28 late Thursday. In Tokyo, before the employment figures were released, the United States currency rose to 139.39 yen from 139.25 yen, and later in London it advanced to 139.65 yen.
Other late rates for the dollar in New York, compared with late Thursday's prices, included: 1.5190 Swiss francs, up from 1.5040; 5.9985 French francs, up from 5.9400; 1,312.75 Italian lire, up from 1,299.75, and 1.14775 Canadian dollars, up from 1.14645.

HEADLINE: Consumer Borrowing Increases

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 7

 BODY:
Consumers increased their borrowing in April for the first time in five months, the Government said today. The report was viewed as another sign the economy was pulling out of recession.
Outstanding consumer credit rose $1.7 billion, to a seasonally adjusted $734.1 billion, after falling $4 billion from November through March, the Federal Reserve said. 
 The April increase, if continued for a year, would mean a 2.8 percent increase. Outstanding credit fell at an annual rate of five-tenths of 1 percent in March and three-tenths of 1 percent in February.
Decreases in outstanding consumer debt, which includes all consumer loans except home mortgages and home-equity loans, are rare. The drop in December was the first in nearly two years. And the four-month string of declines beginning that month was the longest period of spending restraint since 1980, when credit controls were in place.
Consumer spending represents two-thirds of the nation's economic activity and its revival is considered crucial to ending the recession that began last July.
The report for April "is consistent with the notion that consumers are coming out of the shell they had slipped into in late autumn," said Robert Dederick, economist at the Northern Trust Company in Chicago.
But he and other analysts cautioned against reading too much into the report.
"It either means the consumer is getting a little bit of confidence," said Robert Brusca, an economist with the Nikko Securities Company International in New York. Or, he said, it means that the consumer is "so desperate" that he "is running up his credit card."
The biggest increase in consumer debt in April came in the category that includes credit cards, where outstanding debt rose at a 6.7 percent annual rate, to a seasonally adjusted $226.1 billion, after a 17.7 percent rise in March.
Bank and credit union loans not secured by real estate rose at a 3.2 percent rate, to $207.4 billion, after a 9 percent drop.
Auto loans were the only category to show a decline, the fourth in a row for that category. They fell at an annual rate of seven-tenths of 1 percent, to $280.5 billion, after dropping 8.2 percent in March.

HEADLINE: Dinkins's Strategy Is Faulted Amid Bickering on Budget Cuts

BYLINE: By JOSH BARBANEL

 BODY:
After a day of bitter confrontations with leaders of the New York City Council and the State Legislature, Mayor David N. Dinkins's strategy to get the city through one of its most difficult fiscal periods appears to be in tatters, labor and business leaders say.
Not only has Mr. Dinkins been unable to avert the $1.5 billion cut in city services called for in what has become known as his "doomsday budget," but after the Legislature failed, according to the Mayor, to provide $250 million in aid he had sought, he may have to slash services far deeper. 
 Some of the accusations flung at the Mayor may in the end turn out to be so much posturing, as when the State Assembly Speaker Mel Miller called the city administration stupid and the Speaker of the City Council, Peter F. Vallone, rapped his desk and asked if anyone was at home at the Mayor's office.
 
Growing Increasingly Alarmed
 But with 18 days left to the start of the next fiscal year, both labor and business leaders say they are growing increasingly alarmed over the continuing failure of a series of negotiating efforts by the city to produce any improvement in the city's fiscal outlook.
The city's best hope now is that budget vetoes by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo will reopen the entire issue of state aid, and force new negotiations. Yesterday, aides to the Governor said he was now considering vetoing as much as $1 billion in state spending to bring the budget into balance. A continuing dispute with Mr. Miller could make this very difficult.
People close to the city's fiscal situation are expressing concern. "Every day that goes by, with the city failing to act, brings the crisis closer," said Felix G. Rohatyn, chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation, which was set up in the 1970's to bail the city out of its last fiscal crisis. "I think there has been remarkably little progress."
Barry Feinstein, president of Local 237 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, said union members are growing increasingly impatient. "You have the City Council and the Mayor and the Legislature fighting like kids in the park," he said, "while the members of our unions are swinging in the wind. These leaders of government can't put anything together."
For its part, members of the Dinkins administration continued to blame others for the stalemate, lashing out at the shoddy work of the City Council, and the unrespon siveness of the State Legislature. "I don't think that saying the Mayor's strategy is in shambles is a fair way to describe it," said Philip R. Michael, the city's budget director. "It is fair to say there is a further complication in a very complicated situation."
 
Crippling Service Cuts
 Last month, in a series of elaborate formal meetings at Gracie Mansion, Mayor Dinkins presented a $29 billion city budget with crippling service cuts -- closing pharmacies in city hospitals, turning off one of every four street lights -- but promised he would do his best to avert the worst of the cuts through a series of parallel negotiations.
But efforts to win concessions from city unions have been stalled from the first and a plan to get $350 million from the Municipal Assistance Corporation next year foundered, after bond rating agencies raised objections.
The administration was also hoping to get additional state aid to avert cuts. But on Thursday, Mayor Dinkins said he was "more than a little distressed" that the state budget passed by the Legislature not only failed to provide this extra lift, but did not even provide $250 million in aid the city was counting on to balance its budget.
And hours later, the City Council, rebuking the Mayor for his handling of the budget, said that the Council would not pass $476 million in property taxes called for in the city budget.
 
'Manageable to Unmanageable'
 If these negotiations remain stalemated, and if the economy continues to worsen, Mr. Dinkins may have to find hundreds of millions of dollars more in cuts, something that some of his advisers say may not be practical.
"The Mayor's budget could go from doable, to undoable, from manageable to unmanageable," said one business adviser to the Mayor.
The most immediate issue for the city is the $250 million it says it needs from the state budget. While Mr. Miller said that the Legislature provided $223 million in aid, the city said that most of this was earmarked for specific programs, and, could not ordinarily be used for general budget relief. Other aid was offset, the city said, by increased costs mandated by the Legislature.
This prompted Mr. Miller to call the city stupid, and for First Deputy Mayor Norman Steisel to complain yesterday that Mr. Miller asked city officials to simply ignore the costly impact of the mandates and accentuate the positive.
"It was a shock to hear him say it was stupid to put together a real budget," Mr. Steisel said. "Maybe they don't do it that way in Albany, but that's the way we do it in New York."

HEADLINE: Dow Off 18.12; Week's Loss at 50.76

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH M. FOWLER

 BODY:
Stock prices continued their retreat yesterday, with analysts citing weak bond prices and profit taking after the record close earlier in the week. The latest reading of the economy's pulse, the monthly job numbers, received a mixed reaction.
After sinking even lower earlier in the day, the Dow Jones industrial average closed for the weekend at 2,976.74, off 18.12 points for the day and 50.76 for the week. 
 In May the jobless figures rose to 6.9 percent, from 6.6 in April. In Chicago, Anthony Karydakis, an economist for the First National Bank of Chicago, said it was an optimistic sign that manufacturing payrolls rose 12,000 in May. "The next step will be hiring," he added.
 
 'We Need More Time'

But the Commissioner of Labor Statistics, Janet Norwood, was not so optimistic. "It is too soon to say the recession is over," she said at a Congressional hearing yesterday. "We need more time."
Stock turnover was moderate at 168.1 million shares, down a bit from the 168.3 million shares traded on Thursday. Declining stocks totaled 1,121 while 465 rose. Forty-six stock reached 52-week highs and seven 52-week lows.
Time Warner's stock rights offering, innovative though it is, is getting a long round of boos from Wall Street, and its stock dropped 4 7/8 points yesterday, to 94 5/8. The shares have now lost 22 3/8, or nearly 20 percent of their value, in just three days. One analyst said that the offering would sharply dilute the value of the shares.
I.B.M., which showed some strength last week, dropped sharply during the week, and yesterday it closed at 102, off a point for the day, and well under the 106 1/8 of a week ago. The company has been talking with Apple Computer, which wants to license a chip from I.B.M. At the same time I.B.M. is showing interest in some of Apple's software technology, indicating a possible working partnership. Apple closed at 46 1/8 in over-the-counter trading, off 1/2.
Sales of two large blocks of BankAmerica and First Interstate Corporation shares depressed their prices. Analysts said the selling probably came from Citicorp. BankAmerica closed at 39, off 3/8, while First Interstate fell by 3 to end at 38 3/8.
A hotel and casino operator, Promus Companies, said it was offering seven million shares of stock, six million in the United States and a million abroad. Its shares closed at 19 7/8, up 7/8.
The shares of RJR Nabisco, the food and tobacco company, rose by 1/4, to 10 3/8. David Adelman, an analyst at Dean Witter Reynolds, cited its earnings potential and strong cash flow.
TransCanada Pipelines Ltd. priced a new common stock offering yesterday at $17.25 a share in Canadian dollars, and its shares closed at 15 1/8, up 1/2. The funds will be used for construction and investments in other pipeline projects.
 
Shares of Pfizer Decline
 A new drug, Norvasc, made by Pfizer for heart and hypertension problems, won approval by a Food and Drug Administration advisory committee, but its stock declined by 1/4 point to close at 56.
The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index closed at 379.43, off 4.20 points for the day, compared with 389.83 a week ago, when it was less than a point under its April record.
The American Stock Exchange's market value index closed at 369.98. A week ago it stood at 371.99. Its 1991 high came in April at 373.40 and its all-time high was reached back in 1989 at 397.03.

HEADLINE: U.S. AND KREMLIN FAIL TO CLOSE GAP ON NUCLEAR ARMS

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: GENEVA, June 7

 BODY:
Foreign Minister Aleksandr A. Bessmertnykh and Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d failed today to resolve Soviet-American differences over a new nuclear arms treaty. Both officials cautioned that the remaining problems might not be solved in time for a planned superpower summit meeting in Moscow in June or July.
At a hastily arranged meeting at the Soviet mission in Geneva, Mr. Baker presented Mr. Bessmertnykh with a letter from President Bush containing what he said were new American proposals and Mr. Bessmertnykh reciprocated with "fresh" ideas from his Government. But afterward the two men sounded more cautious than ever about the prospects for completing the nuclear arms reduction treaty in the next few weeks. 
 It was impossible to say whether this was usual diplomatic caution or reflected a realization after the latest ideas were put on the table that the problems remaining, although technical, might not be easy to solve.
 
Bush Wants Treaty Ready
 The conclusion of the strategic arms reduction talks has been linked to the summit because Mr. Bush has said he did not want to attend such a meeting unless the treaty was ready for signing. President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, on the other hand, has made it clear that he would like an early summit to gain support for the Soviet economy, as part of his effort to solicit Western aid.
As a result, the Administration has been refusing to set a firm date before the arms control accord is completed for fear of losing its most important leverage on Moscow.
It is unclear, however, how long Mr. Bush will continue to deny Mr. Gorbachev his meeting if the arms control treaty is not ready for signing. In fact, White House officials have said Mr. Bush is eager to go to Moscow, and will probably hold a summit this summer with or without the treaty.
 
Details Not Known
 The details of the new proposals included in Mr. Bush's letter were not known. The President called a high-level White House meeting on Thursday to work out differences between his advisers, principally Mr. Baker and Brent Scowcroft, the President's national security adviser, over the American negotiating position.
Mr. Baker, speaking after his two-and-a-half-hour meeting with Mr. Bessmertnykh, said that "we did not even discuss specific dates" for the meeting between Mr. Bush and Mr. Gorbachev.
"We did discuss some of the substantive problems remaining and how we might best proceed procedurally to deal with those issues and come to closure," Mr. Baker said. "There is still a fair amount of work that has to be done before we conclude a Start agreement."
Today's meeting comes amid a flurry of diplomatic maneuvering, mainly involving Moscow's requests for Western aid for its crumbling economy. Western leaders, including Mr. Bush, have indicated a willingness to help, and arrangements are being made to have Mr. Gorbachev address the leaders of the Group of Seven industrialized democracies at their meeting in London next month. Aid would also be an important topic at a Soviet-American summit meeting.
But any large-scale Western assistance is expected to be conditioned on sweeping economic reform in the Soviet Union. Similarly, the United States could hold up a summit meeting in an effort to force Soviet concessions at the strategic arms negotiations.
 
Not Ruling Anything Out
 Asked whether the issues that needed resolving could be completed in June or July, the original target date for a summit meeting, Mr. Baker said: "We don't rule anything out or anything in. Both Presidents would very much like it if we could meet the time frame of the first half of the year, but we still have work to be done."
Mr. Bessmertnykh added: "We are realists. We have started the job, that is why we look so serious."
The two men presented each other with new proposals to overcome the main obstacles holding up the treaty. They are said to be the question of how many nuclear warheads can be deployed in each missile, and how each side monitors compliance with treaty limits. Both men declined to disclose publicly their new proposals.
In addition, they also established several means for stepping up their negotiations, either by increasing the number of experts working on specific issues or the number of meetings that their lead negotiators will hold in Geneva, where the treaty has been under negotiation since 1982. They said they had agreed to appoint a special team of experts to work on the monitoring issue.
"The two Governments," Mr. Bessmertnykh said, "have decided to concentrate on completing work on the Start treaty. The two ministers have agreed to follow the work of technical experts very closely on a daily basis for completing the Start agreement. We have outlined the objectives and ways to proceed so that the objectives can be met."
 
Working Out U.S. Differences
 Mr. Baker said the letter from Mr. Bush "evidenced the commitment of President Bush to work hard to resolve the issues remaining in the strategic arms negotiations so that the two Presidents can participate at the earliest opportunity in a summit that both hoped would take place in the first half of this year."
The Soviets have asked that a missile that can carry, for instance, 10 warheads may carry only 5 and that the remaining warheads be deployable elsewhere -- provided that the total number of warheads remains beneath the ceiling that will be set by the strategic arms treaty at 6,000.
In the past, American officials have rejected this proposal on the grounds that if the Soviets want to violate the treaty in a crisis, they would be able to use the excess capacity in some of their missiles to deploy more than 6,000 warheads.
Soviet-American differences over monitoring are less clear. What sort of transmissions the Americans seek from the Soviet missile tests, and vice versa, is a delicate matter because both sides are probably already getting data through covert means that neither Government wants to reveal.
 
Compromise on NATO Dispute
 Earlier in the day, Mr. Baker attended a closing session of a two-day NATO foreign ministers' meeting in Copenhagen, where the 16 allies managed to forge at least a temporary, face-saving compromise to bridge the widening differences between France on one side and Britain and the United States on the other over the alliance's role.
The French have essentially adopted the view that NATO's primary function has been and should remain deterrence of Soviet aggression. If that threat is diminishing, they say, then NATO's role in European defense and security should also diminish.
The United States, which dominates NATO, opposes this approach on the grounds that it is not a member of either the European Community or the Western European Union -- the principal alternative forums for developing a European defense entity. American officials say Europe cannot expect Washington to take part in its defenses without representation.
In compromise language worked out primarily by French and American officials, the NATO ministers' declaration today stated: "The creation of a European identity in security and defense will underline the preparedness of the Europeans to take a greater share of responsibility for their security and will help to reinforce trans-Atlantic solidarity."
The statement added: "However, the extent of its membership and of its capabilities gives NATO a particular position in that it can perform all core security functions. NATO is the essential forum for consultation among the allies and the forum for agreement on policies bearing on the security and defense commitments of its members."

HEADLINE: Computer Export Ban To Change

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times


DATELINE: The informal agreement is another move by the United States to create new security arrangements to address the strength of regional powers as well as any long-term strategic threat from the Soviet Union.
WASHINGTON, June 7 The Bush Administration announced today that the United States and Japan would revise their export controls on supercomputers to discourage the spread of nuclear weapons in the third world but would ease controls on sales to Western Europe.

 BODY:
 The main instrument for American-led export controls for many years has been the Coordinating Committee for Multilateral Export Controls. This 17-member organization drafts rules to limit the shipment of high-technology products to the former Soviet bloc and Communist countries.
The United States and Japan are the world's only two major producers of high-speed mainframe supercomputers. They had agreed in 1984 to consult with each other before exporting supercomputers, to reduce the risk that the Soviet Union would obtain the machines.
 
 Two Broad Categories
 The export restrictions agreed upon in 1984 were applicable to all other countries, including the nations of Western Europe. The changes agreed upon in talks that ended on Thursday in Tokyo created two broad categories of countries.
Most Western allies will now be able to import supercomputers with less delay and fewer controls, said James M. LeMunyon, the Deputy Assistant Secretary of Commerce for export administration. The remaining controls will focus on barring the re-export of supercomputers without the producing country's permission and on blocking access to the computers by citizens of countries that represent a national security or nuclear threat.
Shipments to these high-risk countries, particularly countries that have not signed the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty, will be subject to stricter safeguards than before, Mr. LeMunyon said. Examples of these stringent safeguards may include limitations on access, restrictions on the types of computer programs to be used and constant monitoring by security personnel.
The United States and Japan also agreed to seek the cooperation of several European countries whose industries have also developed the ability to make supercomputers. The extension of the agreement is intended to reduce the risk that third world countries will import supercomputers and use them to design nuclear weapons.
 
Talks With Other Nations
 Shinsuke J. Sugiyama, the first secretary of the economics section at the Japanese Embassy in Washington, said that American and Japanese negotiators would soon begin talking to officials from Britain, France and Germany about expanding the current agreement. Later negotiations may include Italy and the Netherlands, he said.
The current agreement does not give either country the ability to veto the other country's exports, and it is unlikely that an expanded agreement including European countries would include a veto provision, Mr. Sugiyama said. But, he added, the United States and Japan have a gentleman's agreement to respect each other's objections under the agreement, and an expanded agreement will probably allow a single country to block a shipment, even if every other country favors it.
Douglas A. Davidson, a deputy White House press secretary, said that "reaching mutually satisfactory decisions through consultations on supercomputer exports is not a problem."
American officials have repeatedly criticized Japan in recent years, contending that country had allowed the export of sensitive technologies, including the Toshiba Corporation's sale a few years ago to the Soviet Union of technology that could make submarines harder to detect.
 
Japan More Conservative
 But Japan has been more conservative than the United States about allowing exports of supercomputers to third world countries like Brazil and India, said Stephen D. Bryen, who was Deputy Under Secretary of Defense for trade security policy throughout the Reagan Administration.
"We have tended to push politically a little harder than the Japanese themselves to promote sales of these kinds of machines," he said.
Mr. LeMunyon attributed the recent sales to successful marketing by United States companies, rather than to a greater willingness by the United States than Japan to sanction such exports.
The United States and Japan also agreed in the talks in Tokyo to create two categories of supercomputers, with the fastest supercomputers subject to more controls than the merely quick. Advances in computer technology have brought rapid increases in the speed of calculations, and some computer designers doubt that the techniques involved will remain indefinitely the exclusive domain of a handful of highly industrialized countries.
The State Department and Japan's Ministry of Foreign Affairs led the negotiations.

HEADLINE: One-Two Punch for PC Makers

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF

 BODY:
For years, the personal computer industry has been regarded as one of America's most vibrant businesses. It seemed to embody the American corporation's ability to innovate and to capitalize on cost-cutting research. As the industry brought powerful computers within the reach of businesses and households, bountiful profits were generated for the companies and their investors.
But now the industry, and particularly its leaders -- Apple Computer, Compaq and I.B.M. -- face a real test. A squeeze at both ends of their market has sent their profits plummeting. The question is whether they can define strategies that will help them break out of the industry stall and produce the kind of growth and profitability they are used to.
 
'The Desktop Is Dead'

"The secular problem is the desktop is dead," said Roger McNamee, an industry analyst at T. Rowe Price in Baltimore. "The PC industry is mature, and MS-DOS is aging," he added, referring to the operating system that is used by the majority of I.B.M. and I.B.M.-compatible personal computers. "The only things that are growing are graphical interface, portable computers and network computing. If you don't have two out of three, you're dead." 
 Of course, personal computers -- the boxy desktop variety -- continue to sell in some numbers, but they are rapidly becoming commodity products. Buyers are frequently passing up the name brands for less expensive models. This has forced Apple, Compaq and the International Business Machines Corporation, which have commanded premium prices, to slash prices to compete with the likes of the Dell Computer Corporation and AST Research Inc., which make powerful, reliable clones.
"In the last few months we've started to see little companies like Northgate and Zeos and DTK in our survey questionnaires," said Dan Ness Jr., a researcher at a company that tracks corporate computer buyers, the Computer Intelligence Corporation of La Jolla, Calif. "A year ago if you asked me if it's a commodity market, I would have said, 'no way.' Now that people are realizing that standards are well established they are shifting whom they buy from."
As the leading desktop makers are being undercut at the bottom, they are also encountering problems at the high end of their lines. The new Intel 486 microprocessor chip has allowed them to produce desktops fast and powerful enough to compete with work stations, which are more powerful desktop computers that in the past have generally been used for engineering and scientific tasks. But the desktops are still losing out to the work stations, since the software and operating systems available for work stations are superior.
For a while, the slowdown in desktop sales was seen by many as a function of the weakening economy. But as it became increasingly apparent that the market softness was tied to more fundamental changes in the industry, the computer makers began to focus on reshaping their strategies.
"There is no question that there has been a slowdown in the industry and we don't see any signs that it's really coming back soon," said James A. Cannavino, an I.B.M. vice president and general manager of the company's personal systems division. "We're ending one era and heading into another."
One sign of that change is that archrivals I.B.M. and Apple have begun discussing a potential alliance. Last month, I.B.M.'s president, Jack D. Kuehler, visited Apple's headquarters in Cupertino, Calif. The companies discussed a variety of possible technology exchanges in personal computers. These included licensing by I.B.M. of its RS/6000 chip technology to Apple, and Apple licensing some of its software to I.B.M.
Each of these is a strength the other needs. The RS/6000 is a microprocessor I.B.M. uses in its work station business that may have applications for future personal computers.
For I.B.M., using Apple's software would allow it to try to differentiate its machines more from those of competitors. Until now, it has used software jointly developed with Microsoft, but has been unhappy that Microsoft has had so much control over the direction of personal computer software.
The source of many of the industry's current problems can be tracked to limitations found in the microprocessor chip that was the heart of the first I.B.M. personal computer introduced in 1981. At that time, I.B.M. chose the 8088 chip produced by the Intel Corporation, even though many computer experts considered an alternative chip, the Motorola Corporation's 68000, to be technically superior.
The 8088 chip could use only a limited amount of computer memory, and it seemed adequate at the time. Later, however, it became the Achilles' heel of the I.B.M. and compatible computer makers.
Microsoft's MS-DOS operating system was designed around those limits. By contrast, early work stations were built around chips made by Motorola, without the memory limits. As a result, the work station world has been able to develop more advanced software.
The conventional wisdom once was that the MS-DOS operating system, on which Microsoft and I.B.M. built the business marketplace, would last forever. But that has proved inaccurate. The traditional MS-DOS market has trailed off rapidly and the remaining upgrade business from 16- to 32-bit computers and from character-based to graphical systems based on programs like Microsoft's Windows has not covered the decline.
 
Shift Was Predicted

Many veteran industry executives said that the upheaval had been long overdue.
"I've been predicting this for some time," said Gordon Bell, a leading industry computer designer. "The surprise is that it took so long before the brutality of it happened. The guys who have gotten less efficient, like Compaq, were obvious targets."
While personal computer makers have continued to innovate, many have been slow to push beyond the original single-application uses like word processing and spreadsheets, which drove the industry in the early 1980's.
"There is a shift inside the industry," said Andrew Grove, Intel's president. "The center of gravity is increasingly moving to group or community computing."
No one seems to have been well insulated from the changes, although some of the companies hurt most say they see opportunities. For the moment, though, they are all scrambling to refashion their strategies -- restructuring, as well as looking for markets with high growth potential like mobile notebook and pentop computing.
 
Leaders Aren't Leaving
 The three industry leaders are not leaving the field. In fact all are trying to either create new markets or expand existing ones. Each is taking a somewhat different tack.
I.B.M., the most broadly diversified of the PC manufacturers, is hoping that it will be able to use sophisticated software to differentiate it from the pack of clone makers. It is gambling that a new version of its OS/2 operating system, which has languished until now, will eventually be an industry hit and permit the company to tie personal computers more closely to its large commercial systems. It has also recently entered the notebook market and re-entered the home computer market.
But Mr. Cannavino, the I.B.M. vice president, argues that his company should benefit if corporate customers shift their buying to systems that work together. "Computing in the future will require a systems and support structure that is more substantial," Mr. Cannavino said. "We have lots of experience doing this."
If I.B.M. sees its future in moving upscale, Compaq has a different vision. The rapid shift in the industry appears to have caught the Houston-based company by surprise.
Compaq originally made its name by cloning I.B.M.'s personal computer, but it has been slow to differentiate itself from the commodity part of the market. Now it is attempting to re-create the phenomenon of the clone companies with a new line of machines that will match the abilities of the work station makers.
To do this, it has struck up an alliance with 20 other computer and software companies, including the Digital Equipment Corporation, the Microsoft Corporation, Silicon Graphics Inc. and the MIPS Computer Company, to define a new standard for advanced personal computers. The group, known as the Advanced Computing Environment, has defined a new standard aimed at creating a new generation of personal computers that will share information effectively and have powerful graphics features.
Apple has yet another strategy. In October 1990, it embarked on a quest for growth in the low-cost consumer market, a strategy it has consciously avoided since its founding in 1977.
To accommodate this strategy and still squeeze out the kind of profits it made when it had the freedom to price its computers above those of other PC makers, it has had to push down costs. It has already announced that it will cut employment 10 percent. And on Friday, the company confirmed that it is considering cutting executive pay by 10 percent.
But it is exploring other new markets, too, from palm-top computers to mobile consumer appliances. It has invested in General Magic Inc., a Silicon Valley start-up led by former Macintosh developers. The company is trying to develop a portable software system that will have the same influence that the Macintosh has had on the desktop.
 
 New Uses of Computers

What will determine the success or failure of all of these efforts, industry executives say, is the degree to which these companies are able to offer significant technical innovations that permit new uses of computers. For example, with the introduction of its System 7 operating system earlier this month, Apple has a substantial advantage in developing new applications.
I.B.M. will introduce a new version of its OS/2 operating system later this year. Microsoft's competing version of OS/2 will not be available until sometime next year.
As these companies pursue their strategies, one thing seems certain: profit margins will continue to erode before new approaches bear fruit.
In fact, declining profitability is likely to be a persistent problem in the personal computer industry for the foreseeable future. The Gartner Group forecasts that beginning this year, the volume in personal computer shipments will rise 16 percent annually, from the 10 percent annual growth seen over the last five years. But it expects revenues to grow by only 13 percent, down from 21 percent annually from 1985 to 1990.

HEADLINE: Guide to the Future?

BYLINE: By SARAH BARTLETT

 BODY:
The fiscal problems that led Bridgeport, Conn., to file for bankruptcy protection yesterday in the Federal courts are common to many other cities and states across the nation. But municipal finance experts said it was unlikely that others would risk taking such a drastic step until it becomes clear whether Bridgeport suffers severe legal and financial repercussions.
"This is going to be a landmark case," said Robert J. Froehlich, vice president of research at Van Kampen Merrit, a Chicago-based municipal banking firm. "People will watch closely to see what happens to Bridge port." 
 It is no secret that cities like Philadelphia and New York and states like Massachusetts, California and New York face serious fiscal problems.
Short-term economic difficulties linked to a depressed national economy have coincided with a long-term shift in the mix of Federal, state and local funds. Sharp cutbacks in Federal and state aid to cities have coincided with an increase in the number and range of programs, like Medicaid, that local governments are required to provide. Over the last decade Federal aid to states and cities, adjusted for inflation, has been cut in half.
"There's a structural failure in city and state financing across the whole country," said Robert Lamb, a professor of management and finance at New York University. "This is not an isolated incident."
 
 Other Cities' Ratings

Mr. Lamb said that in the last year there have been four or five reductions in the credit ratings of cities and states for every one that has been raised.
Until this recent development, Bridgeport was rated one notch above high-yield, high-risk "junk" bonds, BBB by the Standard and Poor's Corporation and BAA by Moody's Investor Service. Richard P. Larkin, a managing director at S.&P. said other governments that carried a BBB rating include Detroit, St. Louis, Yonkers and Massachusetts. (New York City is rated A-. Philadelphia is rated CCC, a junk bond category.) Daniel N. Heimowitz, an executive vice president at Moody's, said about 15 percent of municipalities that his firm rates shared Bridgeport's BAA rating.
While Bridgeport is not alone in its financial difficulties, it is distinguished for its willingness to use the bankruptcy courts as a tool to address its financial problems. Mayor Mary C. Moran said yesterday that she did not expect the city to default on any principal or interest payments or any payments to the city's vendors, as often occurs in bankruptcy situations.
 
 San Jose School District

Instead, the filing under Chapter 9, the section of the Federal bankruptcy code that applies to local governments, seems intended as a way to renegotiate labor contracts with its municipal unions under the auspices of the bankruptcy courts.
In 1983, a school district in San Jose, Calif., also filed for protection under Chapter 9 of the bankruptcy code. It continued to make its interest and principal payments. Under the direction of the bankruptcy court, the school district's contracts with the unions were renegotiated. It eventually emerged from bankruptcy and is now rated single-A by Moody's Investors Service.
It is unclear whether a municipality can get away with such a tactic, especially when it is putting at risk its general obligation bonds, which are not tied to any specific stream of revenue and which carry the city's pledge of its full faith and credit. Bridgeport is the largest city ever to file for bankruptcy protection, according to Mr. Froehlich of Van Kampen Merrit.
"I don't think bankruptcy is very attractive to most municipalities," said Mr. Heimowitz from Moody's. "Virtually all the governments we speak to would rather face up to the tough decisions and not have to turn to the courts." If, on the other hand, the court forces changes in the city's collective-bargaining agreements and the city is able to emerge untarnished from the process, "It will change the complexion of municipal-labor relations forever," Mr. Heimowitz said.
The market reacted calmly to to the news about Bridgeport's filing, perhaps because the state is challenging whether the city can make such a filing. And few municipal bond experts thought the filing would cause any long-term damage.
"The municipal bond market has been ignoring these problem cities for years," said James F. Lynch, the Santa Fe-based editor of Lynch Municipal Bond Advisory, a monthly newsletter. "We told people to sell Philadelphia three years ago."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
 The unemployment rate climbed to 6.9 percent last month, offsetting an April drop viewed as a likely aberration. But corporate payrolls rose slightly in May after seven straight substantial falls. Economists and the securities markets largely disregarded the unemployment rate, which historically has tended to keep rising for some time after a recovery has taken hold. [Page 1.] 
 Outstanding consumer credit rose $1.7 billion, to a seasonally adjusted $734.1 billion, after falling $4 billion from November through March, the Fed said. [36.]
The U.S. and Japan will revise their export controls on supercomputers to discourage the spread of nuclear weapons in the third world, the Administration announced. [35.]
The computer industry faces a big test to see whether it can define a strategy to break out of its slump. [35.]
The Mayor of Bridgeport, Conn., defied the state by seeking relief for the city under bankruptcy law. [1.]
A high-tech taxi meter that accepts American Express cards is being tested in New York City. [25.]
A major reorganization of the F.D.A. is being readied by Dr. Louis Sullivan, the Health and Human Services Secretary. [10.]
 
 Companies
Macy's withdrew its challenge to California's Proposition 13 in the Supreme Court after taxpayers' advocates called for a boycott and customers started returning destroyed Macy's credit cards to the company's chairman. [35.]
With investors angry and confused about Time Warner's rights offering, the company's stock plummeted for the third day in a row, falling $4.875, to $94.625. [35.]
Baltia Airlines has no planes, no flight crews and no financing. But it does have valuable rights to fly from New York to Leningrad and Riga, Latvia. [35.]
Conductus, a small Silicon Valley company, said it had demonstrated the world's first integrated circuit made by using newly discovered high-temperature superconductors. [39.]

 Markets
Long-term interest rates continued to climb, following further indications of an economic revival. The job numbers eroded prices of Treasury securities from the start. [35.]
