PUB-DATE: June 8, 1991

SECTION: Section 1; Page 1; Column 5; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 1189 words

HEADLINE: After the War, a New Battle (May the Best Parade Win)

BYLINE: By LINDSEY GRUSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 7

 BODY:
In New York City, the consumers' paradise, a mark-up is the amount added to something before it is offered for sale; in Washington, it's legislators' wrangling over a bill.
In New York, where bicoastal is a measure of status, L.A. is instantly recognized as Los Angeles; in Washington, it's a legislative assistant. 
 In New York, a continuing resolution is sticking to a diet after Feb. 1; in Washington, it's a way to keep Federal checks from bouncing.
Different cultures? Perhaps. Rival cultures? At least on one side. Take the parade, or rather, parades.
Washington originally planned its parade to honor the Persian Gulf war veterans for July 4. But when New York announced it would honor the country's warriors with a ticker-tape parade on June 10, Washington tried to steal the thunder by moving its celebration to June 8 -- although the official reason was to hold the festivities while Congress was in session.
New Yorkers like to say the move has backfired.
A long list of celebrities, starting with Bob Hope, said they couldn't make the capital's new date. Now the gala's headliners are a few billion dollars in military hardware; Barbara Mandrell, who is fast making something of a career of greeting returning soldiers with her song "Sleeping Single in a Double Bed," and the talk-radio personality Blake Clark, whose theme, according to a news release, is, "If you aren't homeless, if you aren't sick, if you have all your body parts, if you have a job, then just shut up."
But the shortcomings of its own march hasn't stopped Washington from denigrating New York's parade. Sure, New York's parade will be longer, three times as long. And almost half again as many people are expected to attend. But Harry N. Walters, president of the foundation running the capital's homecoming, dismissed New York's homecoming as little more than Podunk's effort, only bigger. "A community parade," he said with a sniff. Washington's is the national victory celebration, he said.
The jibing and jostling are only half in jest. Washington's real enemy isn't Bagdad, Beijing or some other devil of the moment, say many New Yorkers who live and work here. It is a foreign culture just 250 miles to the north: Gotham. "Some people here take a perverse delight in sticking it to us," said Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, the New York Republican. "They revel in it."
Even the two cities' corporate cultures clash. New York's monuments are icons of the great business enterprises of the 20th century; Washington's great pretension is that personal wealth does not count.
Washington's celebrities are mainly Administration officials, regulators, lobbyists and journalists -- people who populate televised public-affairs programs that few outside the capital watch. In New York, where fame and notoriety can be interchangable, celebrities are drawn from a wider pool of glitterati and are often on everyone's lips, even while sometimes being disparaged on the programs that nobody is watching.
Anti-Gotham feelings run deep and strong here. In this football-mad town, the Giants' recent domination of the Redskins is reason enough to despise New York. But the Northeast's economic travails have raised the stakes.
 
Unabashed Schadenfreude

Instead of sympathizing with a city sharing similar urban traumas, Washington more often seems to react to New York's trials with an unabashed display of Schadenfreude. That, some legislators say, undermines New York's efforts to obtain Federal help to overcome its fiscal crisis.
Senator D'Amato said colleagues relish voting against the city, portraying their decisions as principled stands against "Sodom and Gomorrah." Bills viewed as favoring New York start off with a strike against them, while legislation that hurts the city rides an antiurban tide that has aggravated the financial problems of cities across the country.
Washingtonians concede that New York's unparalleled cultural wealth make the city a nice place to visit. "There's a love-hate relationship," said Representative Ted Weiss, the Manhattan Democrat. As usual, the annual weekend visit last month to New York by 30 members of the Congressional Arts Caucus and their spouses was a popular outing, he said. "But when we have votes for the benefit of New York, there can be difficulties."
In part, New Yorkers say, Washington's antipathy toward their city is the natural outgrowth of the cities' proximity and their distinct geographies. New York is built vertically. People are piled on top of each other, making daily confrontations between rich and poor inescapable. But Washington works horizontally. It is easier for the comfortable to isolate themselves in their well-preserved neighborhoods. As a result, New York's problems often seem more dangerous and more pressing, even though they simply may be more obvious.
So even while Washington has become a municipal Murder Inc., Washingtonians have dubbed New York "The City From Hell." "Most New Yorkers live under conditions that would cause riots elsewhere," Howard Kurtz of The Washington Post wrote last summer in a 5,378-word article celebrating his return after three years as a correspondent in New York.
 
It Started in 1790

A Brooklyn native, he confessed he would miss his hometown "terribly," but nonetheless described it as nothing less than a cesspool of greed, in which blindly ambitious cutthroats ceaselessly pursued money and were, in turn, ceaselessly pursued by criminals.
While New York politicians have recently made a mantra out of Washington's bias against their city, it dates to the political deals surrounding the Republic's founding. Under the Compromise of 1790 -- hammered out by Hamilton, Jefferson and Madison over a dinner in downtown Manhattan -- the nascent national Government assumed the debt incurred by the states during the Revolutionary War. In return, southern interests were rewarded by moving the capital to the malarial banks of the Potomac.
Separating the country's Government from its largest municipality, the emerging center of culture, commerce and finance, spawned a national schizophrenia, according to Daniel P. Moynihan, who as New York's senior Senator owes allegiance to both cities. "The culture in the largest sense was in New York; Government was somewhere else," he wrote in an essay on the subject.
In an admittedly "scrupulously prejudiced evaluation" of the relative claims to greatness, Newsweek magazine declared Washington the hands-down winner. The magazine, which has its headquarters in New York but is owned by a Washington corporation, concluded that the Big Apple is, well, the Big Apple: more fun, more diverse and more vibrant. But Washington, the magazine decided, is more powerful, has more "cosmological significance" and is a much nicer place to live.
Even Senator Moynihan now sees the competition between the two cities as lopsided: New York may have the Stock Exchange, but Washington's decisions determine the price of the country's stocks. "New York is still a great city, but slowly, inexorably, Washington becomes the greater one," he said.

HEADLINE: House Vote Sets Stage for Conflict Between Two Allies in Space Program

BYLINE: By WILLIAM J. BROAD, Special to The New York Times

 BODY:
In voting Thursday to save the space station at the expense of space science projects, the House of Representatives has set the stage for a potentially bitter fight between two uneasy allies: the supporters of the manned and unmanned space programs.
The ensuing scrap may be so divisive that the space station will perish anyway. Or, all projects will grind forward with sharply reduced financing.
"It's a watershed," Dr. Bruce Murray, a former director of NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory who is now a planetary scientist at the California Institute of Technology, said yesterday. "It's the end of a set of relationships that go back more than 30 years." 
 After the vote, Adm. Richard H. Truly, administrator of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, conceded that much work remained to produce a space agency budget that was well balanced between science, manned space flight, aeronautical research, earth observation and technology development.
 
'I Remain Committed'
 "I remain committed to work toward that end," he said in a statement, implying that a better balance of competing interests would be struck in the course of the budget cycle.
The Senate, with no money to spare, faces the prospect of endorsing the same compromise as the House, killing the space station in order to let the unmanned space projects proceed with full financing or finding some new solution.
Trade-offs seem to be an inevitable prospect because of last year's budget agreement between Congress and the White House. The agreement put a cap on discretionary spending and, within NASA's budget, left various space projects, each with fast-growing budgets, competing for pieces of a fixed dollar amount.
The House Appropriations Committee solved the problem by scuttling the $30 billion manned outpost, the centerpiece of NASA's plans for this decade and the next century. The Bush Administration wanted $2 billion for the station this year.
But the committee's strategy was rejected by the House on Thursday night after more than seven hours of impassioned debate and weeks of intense lobbying by the White House, officials of the space agency and thousands of contractors for the station project.
Both sides in the debate cast it in terms of having the courage on the one hand, to make hard budgetary choices in a time of financial crisis, or, on the other, to uphold a vision of national grandeur and the proud heritage of the manned space program. The latter won by a landslide, 240 to 173.
 
Pure Science Would Pay
 If the move to restore the station prevails in the budget process, the price for pure science and environmental research is likely to be high. A number of projects for which budget increases had been promised are now slated for reductions, threatening to throw them into disarray.
Under the House plan, NASA's space science and applications program for the 1992 fiscal year would be reduced $463.5 million, or 16 percent. That would be a serious blow to the $30 billion Earth Observing System, an array of satellites meant to discover how the global environment works and to document how it is damaged by human activity; to the $1.8 billion Advanced X-ray Astrophysics Facility, a large space-based telescope intended to peer at the most violent events in the cosmos; to the $800 million Comet Rendezvous and Asteroid Flyby, a planetary probe; and to the $800 million Cassini mission to explore Saturn, its rings and its 17 moons.
There would also be cutbacks in NASA's aeronautical research, down $79 million; academic programs, down $11 million; space shuttle operations, down $233.6 million; and other ongoing projects.
Also thrown into limbo would be proposals with no significant financing yet, including the $1.3 billion Space Infrared Telescope Facility, the fourth and last of NASA's great observatories, meant to peer into the heart of galaxies through cosmic dust.
Even before the vote on Thursday, scientists around the country were mobilizing to lobby for their favored projects.
On Monday, the University of Arizona sent out a news release warning that science cuts could leave its projects severely damaged and could have a profound impact on the university's research and training of students. Arizona scientists who watched the House debate on television were angry and dejected.
 
Science a Dirty Word?
 "The sense of the debate was that science is a dirty word," said Dr. Marcia J. Rieke, an astronomer at the university's Steward Observatory, which is working on two NASA science projects.
"That's a very depressing message," she added. "The scientists in this country have been working hard to do a good job. To have that kind of message come back -- that the country doesn't care about what you're doing or its future -- is demoralizing in the extreme to faculty and students."
In the wake of the House vote, attention will shift to the Senate, which is considered a fairly strong supporter of the station but will now be buffeted by waves of irate scientists.
Washington analysts had hoped that a bruising Senate battle could be avoided and all NASA's warring factions satisfied by a larger overall allocation for the Senate Appropriations subcommittee that oversees the space agency. But that hope was dashed Wednesday when it got only $50 million more than the House -- far short of the station's financial needs.
In their campaign against the station, scientists say a key argument will be that it represents more of a welfare program for engineers than a contribution to the cutting edge of knowledge.
"Mediocre problems result in mediocre industries," said Dr. Murray of Caltech. "Building the station will require no technical breakthroughs. Even 'Star Wars' was better than this since there was no question it was a hard problem."
 
Case for the Station
 The station's backers, including those on the House floor on Thursday, argue that in space it will be a boon for medical and industrial research and on the ground for the contractors and communities that build it. NASA says the project employs nearly 100,000 people, directly or indirectly.
An unstated rationale is that the station will keep aerospace contractors strong in a time of declining military budgets, allowing their skills to be directed back to weaponry if East-West rivalries should flare up.
If the station is endorsed by the Senate and financed in the budget now under debate, pressures on the smaller science programs are likely to get worse as work on the outpost presses ahead. Including operating expenses over its 30-year lifetime, the station's total cost has been estimated by the General Accounting Office to be $118 billion.
"Big science is really knocking out little science here," Representative Bob Traxler, the Michigan Democrat whose subcommittee originally called for the outpost's elimination, told the House on Thursday. "The space station is going to eat your dinner next year."

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times;
Arthur Ashe Confronts Apocalypse

BYLINE: By GEORGE VECSEY

 BODY:
We are all living in the next Spike Lee movie. To pay for the national compulsive gambling in the 80's, the New York City is talking of closing down swimming pools just in time for summer. Will the last librarian to be furloughed please turn off the reading lamp? And on the border of our city, a young black man goes to party with white friends and is hit from behind by punks, cowards, racists.
The damage, economic and physical, goes around in circles. Asians, Hispanics, whites and blacks are all being hit from behind, but one group most appears to be an endangered species from violence, from lack of jobs, from poor education, from rootlessness. 
 "I don't have to tell you there is a theory that an entire generation of young black males is being totally written off," said Arthur Ashe.
Arthur Ashe is a black man, no longer young, a tennis champion, a historian, a heart-bypass patient, husband and father. He has even been the captain for Jimmy Connors and John McEnroe in the same Davis Cup round, so we know he is a survivor.
He has always been a model American, so we cannot say that Arthur Ashe has suddenly decided to get involved. What we can say is that Arthur Ashe has a new idea. He would like to fight the apocalypse by concentrating on one very specific segment of the population: the young athletes around New York.
The beginning took place yesterday with the announcement of the African-American Athletic Association. Dick Barnett, the former Knicks star, with his doctorate in education, will be the first president. Evander Holyfield, the heavyweight champion, cared enough to appear, and the National Basketball Association cared enough to be a charter member. "This association will set a new tone for the ethos of sports in the five boroughs and the contiguous counties," Ashe said. "This is a local thing."
Why athletes? Good question. Ashe said he gets letters from black parents who resent that their children cannot get into good colleges while athletes with 700 on their Scholastic Aptitude Tests are accepted by compliant admissions directors.
"Seven hundred is ridiculous," Ashe said. "I read an article the other day about a star high school athlete who was happy he had just scored 700 so he wouldn't have to sit out a year. He shouldn't be happy with 700. He could do better. We will not hold up 700 or a 2.0 grade average as the ideal."
The way things work now, Ashe said, if you multiply the approximately 10,000 black football and basketball players in college by an average cost of $10,000 a year by an average of five years in college, "that's half a billion dollars, and only 18 percent of those athletes are graduated," Ashe added. "Something is wrong."
It is significant that more Americans know Bo Jackson, the commercial, than John Hope Franklin, the historian from Duke University who wrote the association's mission statement.
"The closest thing to a big man on campus is the athlete," Ashe said, although he's probably wrong. In some urban schools, the big man on campus probably carries a beeper and drives a Mercedes and delivers drugs. But you've got to start somewhere. And start small and local.
In The New York Times yesterday was the heartening story about Herb Crossman, a black man who gave Sam Perkins, a young man on the edge, enough stability for him to go from Brooklyn to high school to North Carolina to Dallas to the Lakers. Nice story. But does it have any relevance for all the young black men and women?
"We're going to look at three areas," Ashe said. "One, we're going to start with public policy, the budget cuts, the sponsorship by liquor and tobacco companies, and whether Proposition 48 is the right way to go. Two, we're going to do mentoring and counseling. Every study we have seen says there is a lack of black male role models. Studying is seen as a whitey thing. We are going to talk about proper speech, about the macho male image."
"And third, we are going to work in career development," Ashe said. "Our members will be people who work for a living. You know how you always hear, 'If I only knew somebody qualified, I'd hire him?' Well, we'll come up with 'em."
The association is talking to a few colleges about setting up programs. There are plans to find a few high schools that will cooperate. A few companies think they can do something.
Where could the money come from? Elliott Denman, a sports columnist with The Asbury Park Press in New Jersey, recently proposed a "sports tax" of 1 percent of all professional athletes' income. Before you could even talk about it, this new association must prove it can accomplish something. First serve, Mr. Ashe.

HEADLINE: Consumer Complaints Up, Relief Down

BYLINE: By MICHAEL deCOURCY HINDS

 BODY:
The recession has brought a steep rise in consumer complaints, but fewer and fewer of them are being addressed because financially troubled states and cities across the country have sharply reduced the budgets of their consumer agencies. The cuts are the deepest since the agencies were set up in the 1960's and 70's.
"Just at the time when we need to increase consumer protection for people getting ripped off by all kinds of phony credit-card and employment offers, consumer agencies are having their staffs and budgets cut way back," said Sara Cooper, executive director of the National Association of Consumer Agency Administrators. The association, in Washington, has members in many of the nation's 400 public consumer agencies. 
 Consumer officials say that every category of complaint tends to increase in a recession. People complain more when money is tight, businesses are less apt to make goodwill adjustments and advertisers are more inclined to stretch the truth.
"I can't tell you when we'll have money for consumer affairs," said Allan A. A. Seifullah, the press secretary to Mayor Michael R. White of Cleveland. "It depends on what happens with the economy, and the projections haven't been encouraging."
 
A List of Closings
 Cleveland's consumer agency stopped investigating consumer complaints last month, joining Boston, Dallas, Anchorage and Fairbanks, Alaska, in eliminating this service. Alaska has closed all seven of its state-financed consumer agencies. Suffolk County on Long Island has closed its consumer affairs department for 10 Fridays as part of countywide furloughs. Palm Beach County, Fla., has laid off two of its five investigators.
And in efforts to balance next year's budget, New Jersey has proposed reducing by 75 percent the $2 million of the state Public Defender's budget devoted to handling more than 15,000 complaints each year involving housing, education, health, AIDS discrimination, banking, children's issues, employment, civil rights and the environment.
"I tell you there is no end to the madness," said Ralph Nader, who said consumer agencies save consumers far more money than they cost to operate.
Some consumer agencies support themselves. New York City's Department of Consumer Affairs, for example, expects to collect $800,000 more in fees and fines this fiscal year than it will spend. And it projects a 1992 budget of $12.6 million and revenue of $15.7 million, said Linda Sachs, an agency spokeswoman. "We raise more than we spend, so we're not facing the kinds of devastating cuts that other city agencies are facing," she said. But the department did eliminate 16 vacant positions.
The financial problems in other states have begun to spawn solutions. Last month Massachusetts decided to make owners of automobiles that they say are defective pay $250 to $300 for the arbitration of their complaints under the state's Lemon Law.
Some branches of the Better Business Bureau, the business-supported complaint mediators in 180 cities, are proposing novel arrangements under which the bureaus would process complaints and collect fees from businesses and possibly consumers.
"In tough budget times, when governments are having to choose between basic needs, they should rely more on the private sector," said Steven J. Cole, a vice president and senior counsel to the Council of Better Business Bureaus in Washington.
 
No Help With Routine Problems
 Officials justify reductions in state consumer services by saying that consumers can seek help at other levels of government. But as local consumer agencies close their doors or reduce services, most people with routine consumer problems will have nowhere to turn for help.
Local district attorneys and state attorneys general investigate and prosecute only the most egregious cases, usually ones involving patterns of fraud or deception. In areas served by Better Business Bureaus, the bureaus are trying to pick up the slack, but many of them have also been weakened by the recession. The bureaus, moreover, have neither the power to enforce consumer laws nor the authority of a public agency to pressure a wayward merchant to provide a refund, replacement or repair.
Sylvia Director, a retired legal secretary in Palm Beach County, Fla., expressed consumer concern. "We shouldn't be reducing funding for the immediate needs of people and spending billions on things like the space station that may never benefit anybody," she said.
The county's division of consumer affairs recently resolved Mrs. Director's complaint about a camera store that had falsely advertised a sale. She objects to the county's closing a branch office of its consumer agency and reducing the agency's staff of investigators to 3 from 5.
At greatest risk are the consumer protection services in Massachusetts, which is embroiled in a two-year-old fiscal crisis. The state House of Representatives has eliminated $618,000 for 19 local consumer agencies and 5 local mediation centers.
"Nearly all consumer agencies in the state are about to close," said Susan Grant, chairman of the Massachusetts Consumers Coalition, which represents the 19 agencies. She said the agencies had answered 91,000 telephone queries this year, handled 13,000 complaints and recovered $3.2 million for consumers in refunds, replacements or repairs of defective products and shoddy services.
Ms. Grant, who is also director of consumer fraud prevention in the Northwestern District Attorney's Office in Northampton, presides over a nearly empty office. Her staff of five has been reduced to one person and a very busy answering machine, which directs callers to other agencies.
For several years Dallas has been reducing consumer services ranging from inspections of butchers' scales to reviews of charitable organizations' books. Last year, the city became the nation's first to contract with a local Better Business Bureau to handle consumer complaints, with the city paying $75 for each case.
But the city broke the contract this year to save $25,000. Now the city refers consumer complaints to state and Federal agencies as well as to the Better Business Bureau, and the bureau does the work for nothing.
 Ron Barry, president of the bureau in Dallas, said that in the first three months of this year the bureau handled 3,586 complaints, 17 percent more than the 2,960 in the same period last year. In the same period, the bureau's income from its members declined by 9 percent, to $248,000 from $275,000. Most bureaus around the country face the same pressures.
Dallas consumers find little solace at the office of the State Attorney General, where consumer complaints have trebled in recent years, to more than 800 a month, while the office's budget has remained constant, said Stephen Gardner, the assistant attorney general for consumer protection.
"Our resources are so strapped we can't sue everybody who breaks the law," he said, "and the cases we do bring are just the tip of the iceberg of criminal cases that we know about."

 
 
SMALL CUTS, BIG PAINS
Budgets for consumer agencies around the country are under review as public officials try to balance their books for this fiscal year and prepare budgets for the 1992 fiscal year, which starts July 1 in most cities, counties and states.
The reductions affecting consumer agencies are not, in most cases, disproportionately larger than those affecting other public services. But consumer agencies are extremely vulnerable because their budgets have always been so small that a major reduction in funds hurts them badly.
And when a consumer agency does cut its services, the savings to cities and states are often quite small. In Texas, for example, the city of Dallas saved only $25,000 this year when it stopped mediating consumer complaints on the repair of automobiles, homes and electronic appliances.

HEADLINE: New Rayon Clothing Ruffles Some Wearers

BYLINE: By TRISH HALL

 BODY:
Theresa Jakubik, an aspiring actress in Manhattan, recently went to brunch with some people she wanted to impress. "I put on these adorable little culotte shorts," she said. But by the end of the day, she didn't look adorable. The rayon culottes were so wrinkled, she said, "I looked like I had rolled out of a 90-hour flight."
It wrinkles, it's no bargain, it has to be dry-cleaned, it spots easily and trees die for its birth. 
 This is the fabric of the 1990's?
Rayon, once considered a second-class fabric to be used in lieu of silk, is showing up in every kind of clothing for both women and men. Designers talk ecstatically of its drapability, of the way it follows the line of the body. They are putting it in everything from $39 blouses sold by Express to $2,000 suits by Giorgio Armani.
"We all love rayon," said Robert Abajian, senior vice president for sportswear design at Liz Claiborne .
Apparel manufacturers rediscovered rayon about five years ago and have been using it as styles have become more fluid and slinky. Its use in apparel increased by 34 percent from 1987 to 1990, rising to 150 million pounds from 112 million, according to the Fiber Economic Bureau , a company that tracks the industry.
 
The Role of Trees
 While synthetic fabrics like polyester come from petroleum, rayon comes from trees. The wood is treated with chemicals to extract cellulose, which is spun into thread. Rayon, the first fabric produced synthetically, was made commercially starting in 1891 in France. It was widely used until the 1950's, when synthetics like orlon and polyester captured the interest of manufacturers.
They fell from grace in the 1970's, when natural fibers became the rage. But synthetic fibers have been making a comeback with the resurgence of rayon and the interest in the new microfibers, which are soft, ultrathin versions of polyester.
Rayon can be found in inexpensive clothes, but it is no longer a cheap fabric. Imported rayon is subject to large duties, so clothes made from it often cost more than linen or cotton. Italian rayon is especially expensive. Production in the United States has dropped, while imports have soared, rising to 28 percent of the market in 1990, from 4 percent in 1987, the Fiber Economic Bureau said.
Designers and manufacturers say consumers like rayon for its comfort and style. And they do. But ask those who read labels for an opinion about rayon and the story gets complicated.
Michael Moore, a student at the Fashion Institute of Technology, recently wore a rayon shirt to a crowded party in a warm room. "I crossed my arms at my waist," he said, "and when I took them away, it had wrinkles." He went home and changed.
Rayon's desire to wrinkle is hardly a secret. Textbooks on textiles note that it wrinkles "when worn or crushed." The fabric lacks what experts call "memory": it doesn't spring back to its original shape.
Some rayon clothes are washable, but many must be dry-cleaned, which annoys people who believe that fake things ought to be washable. "It's the worst of all possible worlds," said Nancy Sills, a Manhattan lawyer. "It's synthetic, and you have to take it to the cleaners."
Rayon is the most difficult fabric to care for, said Jacqueline Stephens, a textiles analyst for the International Fabric Care Institute, an association of dry cleaners. "Most of the dry cleaners have a problem with rayon," she said. The most frequent difficulty involves the stiffening agents, called sizing or finish, that give the fabric its drape. Some are water sensitive, she said, and thus easily lead to permanent stains and discoloration. Rayon also tends to shrink, which is why dry cleaning is often necessary, she said. The agitation in a washing machine can contribute to shrinkage.
Manufacturers say rayon is now more practical and adaptable. But work remains. Manufacturers like the Fibers Division of BASF in Williamsburg, Va., a large maker of rayon fibers, are working on finishes that will make the fabrics more washable. Aside from their complaints about washability, consumers are very happy with rayon, the company said.
Already, the rayon clothes made for boys and young men by the H. Cotler Company are washable. That's a good thing, said Pamela Gelson, the marketing director, because otherwise, "rayon is a mother's nightmare." Whether a rayon garment is washable depends on the kind of finish, the styling and whether the rayon is blended with other types of fiber.
As recently as 1988, Cotler, a New York company, used very little rayon. Now, nearly 80 percent of all its suits, jackets, dress pants and shirts are made of rayon or rayon blends.
"The reason is the drapability," Miss Gelson said. "It feels expensive, but isn't. And it dyes beautifully. It's just gotten to be the contemporary fabric, as opposed to cotton or linen."
Rayon shows up in $20 shirts as well as in $200 ones. Mondo Inc., whose Mondo de Marco shirts retail for $95 to $150 at places like Saks and Bloomingdale's, used no rayon a few years ago but now puts Italian rayon in 30 percent of its shirts.
 
Price-Tag Shock
 Shoppers who remember rayon as an inexpensive fabric now have to look twice when they read some price tags. A simple black shell blouse from the designer Jean Muir is $770 at Bergdorf Goodman, for instance. Women's suits by Armani that are mostly rayon cost $2,045.
But in the Armani boutique at Bergdorf, the word rayon is nowhere in sight. The clothes are made of viscose, a word that refers to a solution from which rayon is made. "Viscose is a nicer word for rayon," said T. LaRossa, the boutique manager. When Armani started using viscose in blends with other fabrics, shoppers were unhappy. "They felt they should get 100 percent whatever," he said. "But over the years, customers have become more savvy."
Rayon is so popular that even its detractors feel they have to use it. Joel Benedek, whose company, Sherbrouck Ltd. , makes blouses for stores like Barneys New York, has ordered 10,000 yards for the fall, making it his leading fabric. "I have a huge demand for it," he said. "If it were up to me, I would hesitate."
Mr. Benedek said rayon doesn't clean as well or last as long as cotton, silk or linen. But maybe that doesn't matter. "No one is interested in holding anything that long," he said.

HEADLINE: Military Targets, Close to Home

 BODY:
The commission on military base closings has heard the same message from virtually every community near a base on the Pentagon's hit list: Don't close ours. But that's exactly the commission's job, to recommend which bases to shut, reduce or restructure. The commissioners have handled their unhappy task with admirable fairness so far. Now comes the hard part.
There are more than 400 major military installations in the U.S. With the coming cutbacks in forces, many will become superfluous -- if indeed they are not already so. Protective members of Congress have forced the Pentagon to keep them going at tremendous, wasteful cost. 
 Finally conceding that the waste was inexcusable, Congress created a commission in 1988 to make the first cut. Following that commission's recommendations, 86 bases are in the early stages of being closed or realigned. Now a second commission is making up a second list.
The commission is required by law to operate more publicly than the first one; that's fairer, but harder. It must make its recommendations to President Bush by July 1. He may approve or reject the entire list, or seek reconsideration on some points. If he approves, the list goes to Congress for an all-or-nothing vote.
In mid-April, Defense Secretary Dick Cheney gave the commission his proposal to close 31 bases and realign 40 others. In mid-May, the General Accounting Office skewered the Navy for not playing ball. The G.A.O. found U.S. bases with thousands of feet -- indeed, several miles -- of excess space for berthing ships, even as new home port facilities are being built.
After crisscrossing the country to hear local protests and undertaking some probing on its own, the commission published a list of 35 additional installations it would consider for closing. Following the G.A.O.'s lead, half of these were naval installations. The longer list did not mean the commission would recommend more closings than the Pentagon wants. It was mainly a public notice that the commission is weighing alternatives, which it did in more hearings this week.
The reaction of Senator Alfonse D'Amato, Republican of New York, is a sample of the heat the panel must endure. He called the new list, which included six bases in New York, "a clear and present danger to our national security." Such bombast is no help to the commission, whose task is made even more painful by the recession. Communities whose welfare has been rooted for decades in the employment and business generated by the military's presence are suddenly faced with losing it all.
That's a traumatic prospect. But the slow pace of the 1988 closings demonstrates that there is time for communities to plan the transition to other activity, and the Pentagon stands ready to help. Keeping useless bases open, whether in New York or any other state, was and is inexcusable.

HEADLINE: White House Sleaze Is Back

BYLINE: By George Miller; George Miller, Democrat of California, is chairman of the House Committee on Interior and Insular Affairs.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
The sleaze factor is slipping back into the White House.
During the Reagan Administration, the number of ethical transgressions by high-ranking Presidential advisers resulted in dozens of resignations, dismissals and indictments. The Bush Administration repudiated such conduct, vowing it would tolerate no impropriety in the behavior and financial interests of its high officials. 
 The credibility of that repudiation was first rocked by disclosures of personal use of military aircraft by John Sununu, President Bush's chief of staff.
We have also learned that Attorney General Richard Thornburgh, whose Justice Department negotiated the settlement among Exxon, Alaska and the Federal Government stemming from the Exxon Valdez oil spill in 1989, invested $32,296 in two companies that are members of Alyeska, the consortium that owns and operates the Trans-Alaska pipeline. Coincidentally, department negotiators absolved Alyeska of all liability in the now defunct settlement.
Alyeska, which is responsible for responding to tanker accidents in Prince William Sound, has been widely criticized for its actions during the spill. Apparently, the Justice Department was unaware of, or unconcerned about, memos -- newly disclosed -- demonstrating that Alyeska misrepresented to Congress and Alaska its ability to respond to a calamitous spill, and knowingly failed to upgrade that ability.
In rejecting the proposed settlement, Judge Russel Holland said the department's inclusion of Alyeska in the settlement was "inappropriate."
Mr. Thornburgh, who calls his $32,296 "insignificant," sought and got a waiver from the Ethics in Government Act from President Bush one week before he signed the settlement. Questions about his sensitivity to ethics won't be assuaged by his dubious decision to remain as Attorney General while seeking a Senate seat from Pennsylvania.
And what about the flagrant conflicts of interest that riddle the Presidential commission on military base closings? Five of the eight members had financial links with companies that are directly tied to the Pentagon, among them military contractors and companies that clean up toxic pollution on many bases. One member, Alexander Trowbridge, has already resigned because he sits on the boards of two companies that service military bases. Two others agreed to divest themselves of investments in Waste Management Inc., a waste-removal company.
It was dismaying to learn that Jim Courter, the former New Jersey Republican Representative, while serving as commission chairman, has simultaneously been a $3,000-a-month lobbyist for Grumman, one of the largest military contractors. Moreover, he negotiated to become a consultant with yet another contractor, the scandal-ridden Northrop Corporation.
Only after public disclosure did Mr. Courter and others suspend their questionable financial relationships. If Mr. Courter had to persuade a legislator to vote favorably on a military contract, how would this wooing affect Mr. Courter's decision to close a base in that legislator's district or state?
Conflict of interest runs the risk of tainting the commission's work, because economically sound closings and reductions of bases may well be stymied.
Members of Congress, who have expressed concerns about political scheming in the Pentagon's process for selecting bases for closing, will surely question whether the commissioners made decisions free of the interests of those who have paid them salaries and dividends.
As for the sleaze factor, did the White House know of the conflicts of interest that permeate the commission and cavalierly dismiss them -- or not even bother to look in the first place? Whatever the answer, evidently the pernicious influence of private financial interest remains a problem for Republican Administrations.

HEADLINE: Corporation Payrolls Inched Up In May, After Seven Big Declines

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 7

 BODY:
In a report supporting the growing view that the economy has already begun to pull out of the recession, Government figures showed today that corporate payrolls edged up in May after seven straight substantial declines.
At the same time, the nation's unemployment rate climbed three-tenths of a point, to 6.9 percent last month, offsetting an April decline that was viewed as a likely aberration when it was released. As in March, the jobless rate is the highest in four and a half years.
But economists and the securities markets were largely unimpressed by the unemployment rate, which historically has tended to keep rising for some time after a recovery has taken hold, and focused instead on a new-found, broad stability in payroll jobs, which rose by 59,000. 
 The survey of business and other non-farm payrolls is usually considered more reliable in depicting the state of the economy than the report's survey of households, from which the jobless rate is calculated.
Interest rates rose, dragging stock prices down, on the assumption that an expanding economy could nudge inflation up and that the need for further monetary easing by the Federal Reserve has now disappeared.
 
'The Recession Is Bottoming'

"The numbers do suggest," said Karen L. Moeller, an economist for the Prudential Insurance Company, "that the recession is bottoming."
But leading Democrats, joined by various religious and antipoverty groups, seized on the rising jobless rate to express doubts about a recovery and to press legislative efforts to bolster both the economy and employment.
"The economic recession continues unabated," asserted George J. Mitchell of Maine, the Senate majority leader, citing 8.64 million people without work and another 5.93 million part-timers who want more work.
"Each and every one of these people represents a failure of policy and it's time that President Bush acknowledged he has a responsibility to respond," Senator Mitchell said.
At the White House, the spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, said that the rise in the jobless rate was unfortunate, but that the Administration continued to believe "the recession is ending and we're on the road to recovery."
Most economists are increasingly inclined to this view, with Norman Robertson, chief economist at Mellon Bank in Pittsburgh, contending that "either April or May" will prove to have been the turning point. He pointed, among other things in today's report, to the increase in non-farm payrolls and to a hefty, 18-minute expansion in the length of the average workweek.
Janet L. Norwood, the Commissioner of Labor Statistics, declined today during her usual session with the Joint Economic Committee of Congress on the day the jobs data are released to say the recession had ended, but she noted marked improvement in the labor market. When the payroll and household figures are viewed over the latest two months, conditions are better today, she said, than earlier in 1991 and it is now clear that the jobless rate, after rising since last October, has steadied.
Most of the largest states posted statistically insignificant changes in their jobless rates last month, including New York and New Jersey, but there were big jumps in Massachusetts, to 9.6 percent from 8.3, and in North Carolina, to 6.7 percent from 5.7. The rate for Ohio dropped to 5.6 percent from 7.2.
 
 Big Drops in Past Months

The small gain in non-farm payrolls followed a revised drop of 180,000 in April and declines averaging 240,000 a month for the first three months of the year.
Goods-producing jobs, which had fallen every month for more than a year, edged up 19,000 as manufacturing and construction firmed. Total factory payrolls rose for the second straight month as laid-off auto workers returned to their jobs.
In services, job growth rebounded, with business services up 15,000 and the irrepressible health sector adding another 30,000. Employment in real estate was about unchanged, "a positive sign" for an industry that has had steady losses for a year, the Labor Department stated.
The Government's household survey showed the ranks of the jobless climbed 370,000, but to a level only slightly above that of March. The household survey is considered to be subject to greater fluctuations than the payroll data, and much of the drop in unemployment shown in the April survey was thought to be the result of a quirky set of circumstances, including an unusually large increase in people who said they were working.
Much of the overall job decline in May was among the self-employed, whose ranks swelled in April but fell back last month to January levels, on a seasonally adjusted basis. Most population groups also reversed the survey results from April, but the jobless rate for blacks has moved up steadily for three months, reaching 13 percent in May.
The number of the hard-core unemployed -- those jobless for more than six months -- continued to creep higher in May, reaching 1,028,000, compared with 628,000 a year earlier. Among the groups that today urged expanded or extended unemployment benefits were the National Council of the Churches of Christ in the U.S.A. and the Women and Poverty Project.
The department also announced that starting next month it would no longer provide employment data on military personnel because of difficulties, pointed up by the war with Iraq, with timeliness and reliability.
In all, 118,049,000 Americans held jobs last month -- 116,591,000 civilians and 1,458,000 domestically stationed members of the armed forces.

CORRECTION-DATE: June 11, 1991, Tuesday

 CORRECTION:
A table in Business Day on Saturday with an article about Government data on employment misstated the military employment figures. Military employment, which reflects domestic land-based forces, was 1,602,000 in February, 1,460,000 in March, 1,456,000 in April and 1,458,000 in May. The figures shown were for civilian and military employment combined.

HEADLINE: Anguished Plea From Bridgeport For Fiscal Relief

BYLINE: By GEORGE JUDSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., June 7

 BODY:
Connecticut officials vowed today to block the state's largest city from becoming the first in the nation to escape the recession's pressures by seeking protection in Federal bankruptcy court.
After the city filed for bankruptcy suddenly Thursday night, state officials, who have overseen the city's troubled finances for three years, resolved to do everything in their power to have the bankruptcy papers thrown out. They then imposed their own municipal budget today, one that would close a $12 million gap by sharply cutting services and raising property taxes by 18 percent. 
 The bankruptcy papers filed by Bridgeport amount to an urban manifesto of grievance against the Federal and state governments, accusing them of leaving economically depressed and racially isolated cities to struggle alone with costly social problems.
Cities across the country share problems of this fading industrial city, but municipal finance experts said it was unlikely they would risk taking such a drastic step until it becomes clear how severe the legal and financial repercussions are. [News analysis, page 26.]
Bridgeport's Mayor, Mary C. Moran, surprised aldermen at a budget session Thursday night with her announcement that bankruptcy papers had been filed in an effort to cut through a budget crisis that threatened to slash essential services on July 1.
"Our fiscal crisis of many years has been addressed this evening in an unprecedented way," Mrs. Moran said, in announcing that Bridgeport had become the nation's first major city to seek relief under Chapter 9 of the Federal bankruptcy code, a provision written to protect local governments.
In going to court in an effort to avoid the kind of tax increase that the state board imposed today, Bridgeport said it intended to continue full payment to its bondholders and creditors. Its aim, it said, was to use bankruptcy to renegotiate "onerous and economically burdensome" union contracts.
The root causes of Bridgeport's fiscal crisis, officials said, are a state tax structure that forces cities to rely on local property taxes; binding-arbitration laws that result in expensive labor contracts; services mandated by the state but not financed by it, and the refusal of surrounding suburbs to contribute to and share the cost of social services, from affordable housing to homeless shelters to hospitals and other institutions that do not pay taxes. Bridgeport's property taxes are the highest in the state.
"The state has abdicated its responsibility to the city," the Common Council President, James E. Tansley, said today as the Council chambers were filling for a scheduled meeting of the state board, the Bridgeport Financial Review Board, which was to act on the city's budget. "Cities are becoming an anachronism in this state.
"And wherever cities in this state are going," he said, "Bridgeport is getting there first."
 
Sought State Help in 1988
 Bridgeport's finances have been overseen by the review board since 1988, when the city, facing a $60 million deficit, sought the state's help. In 1989 the city sold bonds to cover the deficit and entered a three-year plan to attain financial stability.
Unions accepted no pay increase for one year, and since then the work force has been cut by 1,000 positions, to 3,500. The Council's budget for the year beginning July 1 eliminated street sweeping and snowplowing, closed all but two parks, eliminated all recreation programs and lifeguards for the city's mile-long beach on Long Island Sound, cut the library budget by 60 percent and cut services for the city's large elderly population by 50 percent.
Still, the $308.3 million budget was $12 million out of balance. State aid had been cut, welfare costs were rising (15 percent of the city's population is on welfare), bonds had to be paid, and the Northeast's recession increasingly seemed like a final blow to a city that the economic boom of the 80's had almost entirely bypassed.
Other Connecticut cities, especially New Haven and Waterbury, were struggling with deficits, but Bridgeport had struggled so long, and had paid such high taxes for seemingly so little in services, that the initial shock of many residents to the bankruptcy news was quickly followed by relief.
"My first, gut reaction, was, 'Well, thank God, maybe we'll get out of this mess'," said Susan Powley, a part-time office manager who has kept her two children in the city's public schools and is active in the North End Association, a community group in the largely suburban area north of downtown.
"When I thought about it," she continued, "no one knows where this is leading. My personal view is, 'We will not go bankrupt -- it's a cry for help.' "
The review board had planned to meet today to act on the city's budget for the next fiscal year and, if necessary, impose one of its own. The $12 million gap in the proposed budget was the amount the Mayor had hoped to win in reduced pensions and fringe benefits for union members.
The review board sharply rebuked Mrs. Moran in January for mentioning even the possibility of bankruptcy. Today the state Attorney General, Richard Blumenthal, said he would seek to dismiss the city's bankruptcy petition as soon as a judge was assigned to the case.
The board authorized him to take any action necessary to block the city.
 
Says Creditors Will Be Paid
 The state maintains that Federal and state laws require a city to be insolvent to seek bankruptcy protection, and to have authorization by its state. Bridgeport, rather than seeking protection from creditors, is assuring them that they will be paid. There is no state law authorizing a bankruptcy filing. The review board, in fact, is intended to make such relief unnecessary.
Lawyers for the city argue that they can project insolvency because of the large tax increases forecast for coming years, and that there is no law expressly blocking them from bankruptcy court.
Bond-rating agencies, on hearing of the action, lowered some of Bridgeport's $208 million in outstanding bonds to below investment grade. The Standard & Poor's Corporation, for example, lowered its rating on $77.7 million of general obligation bonds to CCC, from BBB, and placed the city on its Creditwatch list.
The rating agency took no action on $100 million more in bonds with AAA ratings, however, because they are insured.
Chapter 9 of the Federal bankruptcy law has been used mainly by small towns, utility districts and other special taxing districts.
James E. Spiotto, an expert on municipal bankruptcy law and a partner with the law firm of Chapman & Cutler in Chicago, said 1988 amendments to the Federal law allowed cities to project insolvency, if they can foresee an inability to pay debts as they mature.

CORRECTION-DATE: June 11, 1991, Tuesday

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article on Saturday about a bankruptcy filing by Bridgeport, Conn., misstated the way in which a $12 million gap would be filled in the budget imposed by the state. Property taxes would be raised by 18 percent.

Chart: THE ROAD TO FISCAL PARADISE
 
Some major steps in Bridgeport's road to a bankruptcy petition.
 
1988 -- The State Financial Review Board is set up to oversee Bridgeport's finances.
PUB-DATE: March 2, 1990
April 2 -- The Mayor submits a 1990-91 budget to the City Council with an $8.3 million gap between revenues and expenditures, but does not address deficits from the past.
May 7 -- The board says it wants to review any budget before the City Council adopts it.
May 9 -- The General Assembly extends the board's tenure and expands some of its powers.
June 1 -- To satisfy the board's concerns about the budget's being out of balance, the city submits a revised plan, which the board approves.
Oct. 1 -- The city projects a $4.9 million deficit for the fiscal year.
Dec. 13 -- The city projects a $5.5 million deficit, while the board staff projects a deficit of $7 million to $10 million and warns the city that it must act urgently to address the deficit.
Jan. 10, 1991 -- The board asks the Mayor to unequivocally renounce bankruptcy as an option to deal with the city's financial problems. She refuses.
June 6 -- The city files for protection under the bankruptcy code. (pg. 26)

HEADLINE: Argentina's President, Praised Abroad, Finds Himself in Trouble at Home

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BUENOS AIRES, June 7

 BODY:
Within months of assuming the presidency of Argentina in mid-1989, Carlos Saul Menem began surprising Western officials with proclamations that he planned to reorient his country away from the inward-looking, protective policies of its former leader, Juan Domingo Peron, and open its doors to the first world.
Mr. Menem, who visited Washington soon after taking office, began referring to President Bush as his "good friend." Plans to privatize sacred Government-owned companies were announced. Relations with Britain, severed as a result of the 1982 Falklands war, were restored. Two Argentine supply ships were sent to the Persian Gulf to join the coalition against Iraq. Argentina, at least in the President's opinion, was on its way to regaining its status among the dominant countries of the world. 
 But Mr. Menem is at a crisis point in his political career. While his popularity has soared abroad, it has plunged at home. Continuing inflation, plus a series of personal scandals and allegations of corruption in his Government are leading political analysts and businessmen to wonder if his political and economic vision -- which in broad sweep has few detractors among major political figures here -- will be undermined.
 
Ratings in a Poll

"There is a danger that the public is beginning to think that perhaps he is really a frivolous man, involved in little scandals almost every day and paying attention to the irrelevant and trivial, and not to the main public programs," said Manuel Mora-y-Araujo, a political analyst and poll-taker here.
Mr. Mora-y-Araujo's polls showed that from an approval rating above 70 percent in late 1989, Mr. Menem fell as low as 24 percent in March, although he has rebounded to around 40 percent recently.
The strain on Mr. Menem and his top aides has been obvious. At one news conference in April, he said he was insulted by the barrage of questions about his personal and family life: his penchant for showing up at parties with glamorous women from around the country; the divorce proceedings with his estranged wife, Zulema Yoma de Menem, whom he locked out of the presidential palace last year; his claims that his swollen face one weekend was the result of a bee sting, instead of collagen implants to remove wrinkles.
"My life is my life and I don't want anyone to meddle," he said in a recent interview.
 
A More Contrite Approach

Still, Mr. Menem seems to have adopted a somewhat more contrite approach. In his state of the union address before Congress this year, he admitted to "having committed serious mistakes and having debts with my people" while asking for "the right to mend these errors."
"Right now we are in a time of regaining credibility," he said in the interview. "If we continue concentrating on the economic and social progress, I don't have the slightest doubt we will return to the previous numbers. If we make mistakes, we are going to fall."
Against the backdrop of decades of high inflation, the flight of private capital, huge debts, coups and guerrilla warfare, Mr. Menem's program had a rocky beginning. Only since he appointed Domingo Felipe Cavallo as Economy Minister in January have economists had any hope that chronic inflation could be brought under control, the budget deficit eliminated and economic stability restored.
He has also taken steps that have infuriated segments of the population, like pardoning former officers convicted of human rights abuses in the dirty war against leftist guerrillas in the 1970's. Many Argentines say the move was intended to placate the military establishment and provide critical military support -- the kind of backing he needed to overcome an uprising of mid-level army officers in December just before Mr. Bush's visit here.
 
Charges of Corruption

But it was not until a spate of troubles this year, particularly charges of corruption in his administration, that public opinion began to turn against him. For the first time, polls found that opposition party leaders had higher positive ratings than did Mr. Menem.
In January, there was the disclosure of a letter from the United States Ambassador, Terence A. Todman, reporting charges by the Swift-Armour Company that Government officials had solicited payoffs so the company could bring in $115 million in equipment for a meat-packing plant.
Then there was the red Ferrari 348 Mr. Menem received from Italian friends last fall, which he only reluctantly agreed was improper for him to keep.
But perhaps the strongest blow has been an investigation by Spanish and Argentine courts into allegations of money laundering by Amira Yoma, the President's sister-in-law and appointments secretary; Ibrahim al-Ibrahim, her former husband and a senior customs official; Karim, her brother, plus other close Menem aides.
Though hard evidence has yet to be disclosed publicly, "there is so much smoke, it's hard to believe there is no fire," a senior Western diplomat said.
The charges have rumbled through the Menem Government. The Vice President, Eduardo Duhalde, attacked the Yoma family, calling it a "clan," and saying it was making the Menem Government look like "a situation comedy."
For his part, while Mr. Menem has defended the Yomas, he has urged them either to leave their Government posts or take leaves of absence. Other associates and friends who have been implicated in wrongdoing have been dismissed.
He has launched a major antidrug initiative with the help of the United States Drug Enforcement Administration, and an anticorruption campaign, including a large-scale investigation into the country's customs office.
In late April, he cut off one of his longstanding friends, Ramon Saadi, Governor of the northwest province of Catamarca. By presidential order he removed him from office and replaced him with a Government conservator.
The action came after Mr. Saadi failed to investigate fully the murder and rape of a 17-year-old woman, a case that has become a cause celebre here. After being ousted in Catamarca, where his family has been the dominant political force for generations, Mr. Saadi called Mr. Menem a traitor and said he should be tested for drug use.
 
'He at Least Gets Things Done'

Some analysts predict that Mr. Menem will weather the current storm, provided he is not personally implicated in any wrongdoing.
"Remember, in Argentina, what is a scandal today is outdated in two weeks," said Jorge Balan, director of research at the Center for Study of the State and Society. "Maybe we don't like the clownish things he does, but he at least gets things done. He has shown a lot of executive authority."
Some of Mr. Menem's boldest moves have been on the foreign policy front, especially the effort to reverse the country's recent history of chilly relations with the United States.
Taking on an issue delicate for any Latin country, Mr. Menem has shaped an oratory that stops short of proclaiming a desire for outright military and political alignment with the United States and Europe. Instead, he uses Mr. Bush's own term for a United States-dominated world community, the "new world order."
"Argentina was a country that was aligned with what was called the third world," he said. "But for me, there is no reason for that world to exist. We have resolved to align ourselves with the only world that does exist. And at this point, everyone knows that within the context of the United Nations, there is one country that is the leader and that is the United States. There is no doubt of this. We are in a spirit of harmony, of excellent relations. It's the best level that Argentina and the United States have had."
 
Urges Inquiry Into Cuban Rights

In addition to re-establishing ties with Britain and sending two ships to the Persian Gulf war, Argentina decided in March to support a United States-backed measure to have the United Nations investigate human rights abuses in Cuba. Argentina was the only Latin nation to support the move and met with intense criticism.
"Menem is very clever and should find a way out of this," said Jose E. Rohm, a banker who says he worked against Mr. Menem's election. "In the primaries, he had the Peronist party machinery against him. Even today, in the middle of a tough economic adjustment program and having done seemingly improper things as re-establishing relations with the U.K., privatizing the telephone company, voting against Cuba, still he is a very popular man.
"This guy has a chance to go down in Argentine history as the leader who opened this country to the outside world after a long sleep," Mr. Rohm said. "My gut feeling is that he is not so stupid as to gamble that away for girls, Ferraris and some cronies."

SECTION: Section 1; Page 35; Column 3; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 994 words

HEADLINE: No Funds, No Planes: It's Baltia Air!

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS

 BODY:
Igor Dmitrowsky, the founder of Baltia Air Lines, looked over his bare new office yesterday in Terminal 1 of John F. Kennedy International Airport. Soon it will have a phone and desks, so this Latvian immigrant will no longer have to run his international airline out of his apartment in Rego Park, Queens.
 Baltia as yet has no planes, no flight crews and no financing. But it has had, as of Wednesday, valuable rights from the Department of Transportation to fly from New York to Leningrad and Riga, Latvia, with connections from Riga to the Soviet cities of Kiev, Minsk and Tbilisi. 
Baltia is largely the creation of Mr. Dmitrowsky, 37 years old, who left Latvia 15 years ago. An amateur pilot, his main business experience has been working for a small producer of garden tools and plumbing equipment, and founding the American Kefir Company, which makes a yogurt drink of the type popular in parts of the Soviet Union and the Middle East.
 
Job One: Raise Some Cash
 Now, he is set to join Pan American, T.W.A. and American Airlines in flying between the United States and the Soviet Union.
 As the president, chairman, chief executive and 64 percent owner of an upstart airline, Mr. Dmitrowsky's first task is to attract financing. Steffanie J. Lewis, the airline's general counsel, said Baltia had persuaded the Delaware Department of Insurance to authorize a $50 million loan from insurance companies that have contributed to an economic development fund. Baltia might locate some of its operations in that state.
 She said the insurance companies themselves had not yet agreed to extend the money. She added that other groups, including one called Eyes of Texas Aviation, had expressed an interest in giving financing to Baltia, with enough money to buy, perhaps, several year-old Airbus A310's.
 "Baltia is not keeping its eggs in one basket," she said.
 Although Mr. Dmitrowsky has no airline experience himself, failures and cutbacks among other carriers have left many seasoned airline executives ready to take a chance.
 Anthony J. Hanson, the executive vice president of Baltia, worked for Orion Air, a cargo carrier, as chief pilot and vice president of flight operations. Harold J. Pareti, who helped start People's Express and Presidential Airlines, both start-ups that failed, is vice chairman and acting vice president of finance.
 Ms. Lewis herself founded Parkair, an Alaskan carrier that had 25 small planes, she said, before it was taken over by another airline. She said she was among 23 employees, who have been working for stock in the company rather than salaries.
 Mr. Dmitrowsky said he was a maverick even as a youth in Latvia. Unlike his classmates, he said, he did not join the Young Communist League, and he dreamed of emigrating to the United States and striking it rich. "I was a nonbeliever, which was a rarity among young people then," he recalled.
 Mr. Dmitrowsky at first saw himself as more a technician than an entrepreneur. When he came to New York, he took science courses at Queens College at night. During the day he worked at Durst Industries, a small maker of garden tools and plumbing equipment, helping to develop new products and manage its plants.
 But he decided science and technology were not for him. "I wanted to be a businessman," he said, "not an engineer."
 He set out on his first venture in 1979, founding the kefir company. He employed about 30 people before he sold the company in 1981. "I'm well-off," he said, but no millionaire.
 In recent years he has tried without success to develop a new single-pilot aircraft. Since 1989, he has devoted all of his time to setting up Baltia, working from his home. "I didn't want to pay $50 a square foot" for offices, he said.
 
Judge's Recommendation
 So far, the airline's only assets are its hard-won routes. A Federal administrative law judge, Robert Barton, recommmended in February that new routes go to American Trans Air, an experienced charter line that had planned to fly from Philadelphia to Riga three times a week.
 Baltia, the judge said, had "no operating experience, no name recognition and no marketing organization." He added, "It does not behoove the U.S. to select an inexperienced, fledgling airline to compete in such a highly visible market with entrenched and strong foreign carriers."
 The judge did say he was attracted by the number of flights and destinations that Baltia was planning. Baltia said it would lease two Boeing 767's to fly from New York to Leningrad and Riga, plus two Boeing 737-200's for connections from Riga.
 In his ruling on Wednesday, Patrick V. Murphy, a Deputy Assistant Secretary of Transportation, said Judge Barton's concerns had been misplaced. Mr. Murphy saw Baltia's application as a chance to start a new airline and increase competition.
 Under an aviation agreement reached by the United States and the Soviet Union in 1990, he also gave Soviet routes to Trans World Airlines and American Airlines.
 Several airline analysts give Baltia a chance to get off the ground by next year, but questioned whether there were enough Americans of Baltic descent to make a hub in Riga profitable. The analysts did say that a new airline would benefit from a surplus of aircraft available for leasing on generous terms.
 But the record for start-ups has been dismal. Only two carriers of any significance -- Midway and America West -- remain of the nearly 200 that began operating after deregulation took effect in 1978.
 
SOFIA-NEW YORK FLIGHTS
 WASHINGTON, June 7 (AP) -- A new Bulgarian airline will begin direct service between New York and Sofia, the capital of Bulgaria, under an agreement announced today by the Transportation Department. The agreement allows Jes Air to fly the new Sofia-to-New York route, providing the only direct service. No United States airline serves Bulgaria. Jes Air has one Airbus A320 aircraft.
