The New York Times

 

PUB-DATE: June 9, 1991

SECTION: Section 6; Part 2; Page 14; Column 1; Business World Magazine

LENGTH: 5170 words

HEADLINE: COVER STORY;
WHEN A.T.&T. PLAYS HARDBALL

BYLINE: BY L. J. DAVIS; L. J. Davis is a frequent contributor to this magazine.

 BODY:
Standing on the stage of the Arie Crown Theater in Chicago's McCormick Place convention center on April 17, addressing his stockholders, the 56-year-old chairman of A.T.&T. sounded a plaintive note as he described the uneven course of his attempt to buy the NCR Corporation. "What we had hoped for," said Robert E. Allen, "was a heady courtship of wine and roses, and a quick elopement." What he had experienced, far from a smooth romance, was a very public dust-up in which the object of his affection had told him in no uncertain terms to get lost.
Yet even on this April morning, several months after A.T.&T. had made its first concrete offer and been turned down, one could detect a note of surprise in Allen's voice. The leaders of American Telephone and Telegraph had expected that NCR would welcome their bid, and some of them were said to believe that NCR might be tailoring itself for an A.T.&T. merger -- a notion that Charles E. Exley Jr., the 61-year-old chairman of NCR, attributes to "self-hypnosis." 
 Such surprises and confusions were commonplace during the long struggle, which ended May 6 when NCR agreed to be acquired for some $7.4 billion in A.T.&T. stock. Sometimes the action seemed drawn from Saturday morning television as the giant A.T.&T., like Wile E. Coyote, lunged at its much smaller target, only to crash in a heap on the spot the NCR Road Runner had just vacated.
In November 1990, Exley flew into New York from his Dayton, Ohio, headquarters for an appearance before the A.T.&T. board, hoping to persuade the directors to drop their takeover efforts. "I explained our program for the 90's," he recalls, "and I must have gotten carried away with enthusiasm. When I sat down, one of the directors said something like, 'This presentation has certainly convinced me that the acquisition of NCR is a very good idea for A.T.&T.' "
For the business community in general, and Wall Street in particular, the merger raised a number of intriguing questions. Did it signal a return to the proxy contests that gathered steam in the 70's and gave way to the junk-bond-fueled raids of the late 80's? Has the country entered a new period of strategic "industrial" mergers in which companies are purchased to be kept and nurtured rather than to be sold piecemeal for short-term gain? How will institutional investors, major players in the A.T.&T.-NCR battle, use their ever-growing power?
But there is another question of far broader import. NCR was a well-managed, highly profitable enterprise, the fifth largest computer manufacturer in the nation. During the 1980's, the 106-year-old company, long known as National Cash Register, had done what American companies are supposed to do, and so few actually did. The foreign sales of its respected products contributed substantially to the nation's lagging balance of trade, it had bet the company on the development of a widely admired new series of computers -- and all without sinking into major indebtedness.
To an important degree, NCR's defense against A.T.&T. centered on the theory that the company was responsible to its "stakeholders" -- not just shareholders, but customers, employees, suppliers and the Dayton community. In Exley's view, the success of his company stemmed directly from its success in satisfying the needs of all these constituencies. The question: Why does an NCR have to lose its independence?
A.T.&T. just wanted to be friends. The dignified and image-conscious company long known as Ma Bell had never attempted a hostile takeover. In July 1988, Allen and Robert M. Kavner, the head of A.T.&T.'s computer division, brought Exley a proposal to merge the two companies. "They said we were the key to their success in the computer business," Exley recalls. Since 1984, A.T.&T. had lost well over $1 billion in its computer operations. The division had never enjoyed a profitable year; it had never even had a profitable quarter. "We didn't see that they would add anything to the picture," Exley says.
Kavner was back in Dayton in June 1989 and received the same answer. Eighteen months passed. Then, on Nov. 8, 1990, a press report stated, inaccurately, that the two companies had entered merger discussions. At NCR, the suspicion grew that the story had been planted by A.T.&T. (though to this day, A.T.&T. professes its innocence). The suspicion also grew that A.T.&T. was trying to buy NCR on the cheap. NCR's stock price had been depressed since the 1987 market crash, and had been further depressed in the general decline of stocks following the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait. The possibility of a merger acted as a positive tonic: Over the next several days, the price of NCR shares, which had been languishing at 48, jumped to 53 7/8.
Six days later, A.T.&T. invested the rumors with substance. Meeting through dinner, the board approved Allen's plan to acquire NCR in a friendly $85-a-share stock swap. At 9:30 the next morning, Allen telephoned Exley in Dayton and asked for a meeting on "an urgent basis." When Exley suggested sometime the following week, Allen responded, "I mean urgent. Today or tomorrow."
Exley obligingly booked a room in his secretary's name at an airport hotel in Cincinnati, and drove to the 3:30 meeting that same day in his wife's Lincoln. Allen, slight and tense, a professional manager who had spent his working life with A.T.&T. or its regional telephone companies, made his pitch over coffee and cookies. The urbane Exley, who had come up through the financial side of the business, was normally the most communicative of men. Today he was noncommital.
Back at the A.T.&T. complex in Basking Ridge, N.J., a highly placed executive interpreted Exley's use of the family car, rather than a company car, as a sign of his eagerness to strike a deal; it was hailed as a "buying sign." But Exley, as it happened, almost never used a company car. He had driven his wife's Lincoln because it had a telephone.
When the NCR board met on Nov. 21, the cash register emphatically rang up "no sale." The board approved enhanced golden parachutes to Exley and his top talent; if A.T.&T. bought the company, these executives and scientists so essential to the future of NCR would now have additional incentive to bail out.
In 1884, A young merchant named John H. Patterson received his mother's permission to use part of his legacy to buy the patent for a machine called Ritty's Incorruptible Cashier, the first practical cash register, and to manufacture it. He proved to be a progressive employer, building a light and airy factory, pioneering in health care and employee education and weaving NCR tightly into the life of his home city. During the great Dayton flood of 1913, one of the city's defining events, Patterson ordered his workmen to build boats out of packing cases and transport survivors to the highest spot in town. Over the years, the company generously supported local institutions; volunteerism was an important part of the company culture. With 5,400 local employees (out of 55,000 worldwide), NCR is Dayton's largest corporate headquarters.
Like Singer with its sewing machines and Gillette with its razors, NCR was an American icon. But in the 1970's the company almost missed the market in electronic cash registers. Executing an abrupt 180-degree turn into the new technology, NCR closed factories and dismissed more than 12,000 employees, another defining event for Dayton. But the maneuver was successful.
By the end of the decade, the company had introduced its point-of-sale terminals and automatic teller machines, which today account for 25 percent of NCR's business. The company went on to manufacture lines of personal computers and minicomputers and dabbled, none too successfully, in mainframes. "We have reinvented ourselves several times," says Exley.
He had accepted the presidency of NCR in 1976 after 22 years at Burroughs, the Detroit office equipment manufacturer. And as the 1980's progressed, and Exley rose to be C.E.O. and chairman, it became clear that the company would have to come up with something entirely new in computers or it was going to have to get out of the business entirely. "In a sense, they were on the verge of collapse," says Judith Hurwitz, an analyst with Patricia Seybold's Office Computing Group. "They had mainframes that nobody wanted anymore. The minicomputer business was dying. They had no software to speak of."
In the beginning, a company computerizing its operations would buy a costly mainframe, usually from I.B.M. or the Digital Equipment Corporation. The software used by the computer was proprietary, which meant that machines manufactured by one company could not work with machines manufactured by another.
There had to be a better way, and the rapidly evolving computer industry (where product cycles can be as short as nine months) eventually found one. Instead of the mainframe, which served as an electronic office manager, small desktop computers could be linked together in a network. The participants in the network, no matter how widely scattered, would share the services of small, speedy, comparatively inexpensive computers that specialized in a particular task or in data storage.
This "open-systems" approach was adopted by NCR, among others. In its latest reinvention, the company set about developing a line of machines -- the Series 3000 -- an extended family of products ranging in price from $2,500 to $10 million. The open operating system NCR selected, as it happened, was based on the popular Unix software that A.T.&T. had invented. Indeed, NCR chose the very version of Unix that A.T.&T. was using in its own machines, a circumstance that not only made NCR an attractive merger partner for A.T.&.T. but also suggested that Barkis was willin'.
Exley had bet the company on a bold leap into the new technology. He calls it "the most exciting business opportunity I have seen in my 36 years in computing." Moreover, in the view of Rick J. Martin, an analyst with Prudential Securities and a former I.B.M. executive, "This was Exley's chance to say to the historians 20 years from now that Chuck Exley was more than a bean counter. He was a computer person." The first Series 3000 machines were rolled out last September.
With negotiations between NCR and A.T.&T. at an impasse, Robert Allen went public on Dec. 2, 1990, announcing a $90 all-stock offer that was clearly designed to increase the pressure on Exley and his board. The offer was good until Dec. 5, a day when many things happened. The NCR board met and strengthened the company's poison pill defenses. The directors also decided to ignore A.T.&T.'s request that NCR remove itself from the protection of the Business Combination Act of Maryland, where NCR had been incorporated since 1928; under that act, an acquiring company with less than 80 percent of a target company's stock could not take control for five years.
And on that same day, in the New York offices of Weill Gotshall and Manges, NCR's counsel, Exley met with Allen and informed him that NCR would agree to be bought -- at $125. In a "Dear Chuck" letter, Allen responded that he could not understand how a merger that would be a disaster at $90 would somehow succeed at $125. In fact, Exley had not wavered in his opposition to the sale of the company, but he and his board also had a legal obligation to their shareholders: the board had to sell the company if A.T.&T. offered, in the directors' judgment, a reasonable price. And on Dec. 5, the "reasonable" price was $125.
The following day, A.T.&T. publicly tendered for all of NCR's stock, offering $90 a share in cash, and Exley immediately took personal command of the public battle. "I basically cleared my calendar," he says, "and turned over the running of the company to Gil." Gilbert P. Williamson, NCR's president, had already been designated as Exley's successor. The lawyers, bankers and public relations counselors were kept in the background. Exley knew that the struggle, with its inevitable lawsuits and billingsgate, could distract his employees, destabilize his company and even drive away customers. "We moved immediately to isolate the company from the crippling effects of the battle."
One of Exley's principal tasks was to lobby the institutional investors, the pension funds and insurance companies that owned 75 percent of NCR's shares. He personally visited the 40 largest investors. "I guess I'd have to say our biggest problem was our institutional investors, who in some instances were very anxious for us to sell at a price that our board felt was far below the real value of the business."
And Exley's constant use of the stakeholder concept as a defensive weapon in interviews and advertisements proved to be a powerful irritant in some quarters. "NCR aggravated so many people with that stuff," says Louis Lowenstein, director of the Columbia University Center for Law and Economic Studies. If customers, suppliers and employees have significant rights, he adds, "you are no longer accountable to the owners of the business. It's like saying you can operate in the capitalist system without being accountable to the capitalists." Exley acknowledges that some of the institutional investors held similar views.
Nor was Exley's mission made easier by the fact that a number of the institutions had substantial holdings of both A.T.&T. and NCR. "These people were put in a rather strange position," he says. "One of them believed that the merger was inevitable and not a good thing. But if you had eight times the investment in A.T.&T. as in NCR, they explained, then you would vote your NCR shares in a manner that would provide the lowest possible price for NCR. The logic is inescapable, but how this all reads on shareholder rights, I'm at a loss to say."
Allen, too, made the rounds of the large institutional investors, where he emphasized that his company had said from the very beginning that NCR would remain in Dayton, would remain autonomous and would run A.T.&T.'s computer business. It would be a reverse takeover. Yet at the California Public Employees Retirement System, as elsewhere, he found himself on the defensive. According to DeWitt Bowman, the fund's chief investment manager, Allen spent considerable time countering Exley's vigorous arguments -- an unaccustomed role for the chairman of a utility that had for so long operated in a protected environment. In the end, the fund voted with A.T.&T.
In appearance, demeanor and background, they were an ill-matched pair. The patrician Exley, a first-generation American, was born in Detroit in 1929 to a Canadian mother and a Trinidadian father who was a sugar merchant of English descent. Exley majored in economics at Wesleyan University and took his M.B.A. at Columbia University. The youthful-looking Allen is Midwestern to his fingertips, a native Missourian who grew up in Indiana. His parents were in the retail clothing business. Allen graduated from Wabash College in 1957 with a major in political science.
During the takeover fight, Allen was far from pleased when his company was labeled a "predator" in the press. Like so many A.T.&T. lifers, he was devoted to what he called "the integrity of the brand name." Directly out of college, he had joined Indiana Bell and risen slowly through the ranks of the regional operating companies, finally becoming chairman of the Chesapeake and Potomac. In his next posting, to A.T.&T.'s New York headquarters in 1983, Allen's rise was meteoric. Within four years, he went from executive vice president to president -- in part because of his willingness, then rare at A.T.&T., to trim staff dramatically. He was thrust into the chairman's job in April 1988 upon the unexpected death of James E. Olson.
In the course of the merger battle, A.T.&T. was often called "aggressive." Allen did not mind. He believed the word accurately described the company he is reshaping. The company he inherited, on the other hand, was a beleaguered world leader in telecommunications, manufacturing and research whose over-staffed and cumbersome bureaucracy was a legacy from its days as a monopoly. On Jan. 1, 1984, acting on a Federal court order, A.T.&T. had divested itself of its regional telephone companies and begun the long struggle to adapt to a newly competitive marketplace. "I think what's happening in Eastern Europe is in the category of what A.T.&T. had to do," says Kavner.
Allen broke the company into 20 entrepreneurial units. He eliminated thousands of jobs. He transferred thousands of employees into the sales division, halting the erosion of the long-distance telephone business. Last year the company launched a new bank card, called the A.T.&T. Universal Card, that swiftly became the fifth most popular in the nation. "There's no question in my mind that A.T.&T. has turned the corner," Allen says. "We have learned from our environment and we have a deep respect for our competition."
But there was one environment that proved remarkably uninstructive. As a result of divestiture, A.T.&T. had finally been allowed to make its entry into the computer business. Ultimately, the company believed, it could create the long-awaited connection between computing and telecommunications that would make computers literally as easy to use as the telephone and would reward the company with a huge international business. A.T.&T. set out to challenge I.B.M. But A.T.&T. had almost no computers to sell, a problem it tried to solve by forging a series of alliances with four companies that did.
The new machines -- primarily PC's and minicomputers -- did nothing that I.B.M. machines could not do, and typically they were more expensive. Furthermore, A.T.&T. did not know how to sell them. Says Charles Ferguson, a computer authority at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, "Everything A.T.&T. has done to stay in the computer business has been kind of irrational."
Under Allen, important elements of the company's computer strategy changed. While A.T.&T. continued to pursue commercial and government contracts for its existing machines, it also began emphasizing open systems in its marketing efforts. The strategy, identical with NCR's, finally seemed to make possible the elusive linkage of computing and telecommunications. There was only one problem: A.T.&T. was not nearly as adept as NCR at marketing the new machines and software.
At the A.T.&T. annual meeting in April in Chicago, an employee stepped into one of the four phone booths from which stockholders could ask questions. "In buying NCR," he said, "you're saying the NCR people are better than A.T.&T. people." Allen did not answer directly, but many industry analysts believe that this was precisely the statement A.T.&T. was making with its relentless pursuit of NCR. After years of losses, the purchase of NCR represented A.T.&T.'s best hope of remaining in the computer business.
The analysts also identify a number of other motives:
* NCR, with 1990 revenues of $6.3 billion, was far smaller than A.T.&T., with revenues of more than $37.3 billion. But NCR's 1990 earnings of $369 million would have been more than enough to offset A.T.&T.'s losses in the computer business that year -- an estimated $200 million. Allen denied that this fact had any bearing on the merger. "Acquiring NCR," he said, "has nothing to do with getting us out of our computer losses. That's Chuck Exley rhetoric."
* Sixty-two percent of NCR's business was transacted abroad. Given the company's adept foreign sales force, NCR offered A.T.&T. a far greater global presence than it had been able build on its own -- and an opportunity to increase considerably the export of A.T.&T. products.
* A.T.&T.'s computer business had never been able to significantly exploit the discoveries of Bell Laboratories. It was possible, as Allen repeatedly suggested, that the much more tightly disciplined NCR computer operation would find many commercial opportunities in Bell Labs. Not everyone agreed. "Just because I might want to see what's inside Bell Labs," said Philip M. Neches, NCR's chief scientist, "doesn't mean I'd want to use any of it."
Allen saw the advantages of a merger. Exley saw disaster. When he appeared before Allen's board last November, he described 13 computer company mergers, all of them failures. NCR, Exley believed, could continue to introduce its new products or fix A.T.&T.'s computer business, but it could not do both. "I told Bob Allen," Exley says, "your outside advisers, the bankers and lawyers, aren't going to be around to pick up the pieces when it's all over. It's going to be you."
On Jan. 16, A.T.&T. announced that stockholders had tendered approximately 70 percent of NCR's shares. It was far more than enough to allow A.T.&T. to launch a proxy fight aimed at overthrowing NCR's board. The issue would be decided at a special NCR shareholder meeting called for March 28; even if A.T.&T. failed to win the 80 percent vote required to overthrow the 12-member board, it would have more than enough votes to replace the four directors, including Exley, who were standing for reelection. The NCR board countered by voting itself the power to expand by four seats, and, on Feb. 20, establishing an employee stock ownership plan that would give its presumably loyal work force 8 percent of the company. (Almost a month later the plan would be overturned by a Federal judge who proclaimed that it made a "mockery" of the shareholder voting process.)
For weeks on end, the companies exchanged the usual takeover lawsuits, yet apparently nothing else was happening. Then on March 7, at a meeting with securities analysts, Exley seemed to concede that he had lost hope of keeping his company independent. Early in the battle, he had told his employees that 90 percent of all companies under attack could not ride out the storm. He had hoped to be the exception, even though an A.T.&T. purchase of NCR was inevitable if A.T.&T. stayed the course and offered a reasonable price. A.T.&T. had stayed the course, although it had not yet offered NCR's board a price it considered reasonable. But there was a limit to NCR's endurance. "I began to be concerned that this battle was going to damage NCR," Exley recalls. "As soon as I got that in my mind, I felt we had to go for a transaction."
Allen, too, felt that it was time to close the transaction. On the afternoon of Sunday, March 10, he called Exley at his Dayton offices. The fact that the call was placed would later prove to be the only thing the two could agree on. Exley says Allen told him that A.T.&.T. had considered raising its offer, had decided not to and would soon issue a press release. When the press release reached him by fax later in the day, Exley says, he learned for the first time that A.T.&T. was prepared to offer $100. But Allen maintains that he had told Exley what the offer was and that Exley had turned it down. To this day, neither man can explain the discrepancies.
In the Dayton community, the predominant reaction to the proposed merger had been dismay. The Lieutenant Governor had suggested that A.T.&T. "reach out and touch someone else." Two local banks had taken out a full-page newspaper advertisement that included the telephone numbers of MCI Communications and U.S. Sprint.
"This is a community where all the action players communicate with each other very easily," says David H. Ponitz, the president of Sinclair Community College. "Put this in the context of A.T.&T. Say I need $5,000 and I go to a branch office. They recommend it to somebody somewhere else who doesn't give a damn about the community, has got 15 other requests on his desk, and has no idea how to prioritize them."
County Commissioner Charles J. Curran takes a similarly bleak view: "There'll be a lot of receptions and a lot of coffees and a lot of promises about how their commitment will never change, but the commitment will change."
Still, remarkably few people in Dayton wanted to antagonize the possible future owner of the city's crown jewel. Instead of a protest rally, the University of Dayton organized a "Salute to the People of NCR."
Elsewhere in the stakeholder constituency, some of NCR's customers saw no benefit for them in the merger. For example, David V. Evans, a vice president with J. C. Penney, headquartered in Plano, Tex., said his company, which has 25,000 NCR point-of-sale terminals and 17,000 more on order, saw no particular advantage in the merger. "We already use A.T.&T. and we also have a contract with MCI," he said. "It's a competitive environment. We find it attractive."
On March 25, Allen and Exley met in New York for five hours. But any chance of reaching an immediate agreement collapsed the next day when each side accused the other of refusing to negotiate. Allen had wanted to discuss the financial details, particularly the dangerous golden parachutes. To Exley, it was important to explain why NCR was worth far more than $100 a share. On March 27, when Exley announced that NCR would accept $110 a share, and nothing less, Allen says he felt it was nothing but an attempt to manipulate the vote at the NCR shareholder meetings the next day. In the event, A.T.&T. was able to replace four directors, but fell short of its larger goal to replace the entire board.
In the days following the meetings, talks resumed. "I thought we were going to move forward to a swift conclusion," says Exley, "which proved to be a mistake in judgment on my part." On April 4, Allen and Exley met again over coffee and cookies in Exley's New York hotel room. Exley said he could not take a price of less than $110 to his board.
When the meeting broke up, no agreement had been reached. "After April 4," Exley said, "things seemed to stop."
Finally, on April 21, the six-month drama approached its inevitable end. A.T.&T. came forward with a $110 all-stock offer. According to Allen, the new bid was made possible by a surge in the price of A.T.&T shares. Yet even then, there were details to be hammered out.
At 11:30 A.M., May 6, in A.T.&T.'s Chippendale skyscraper on Madison Avenue, the agreement was signed. All incompatibilities between A.T.&T. and NCR had miraculously vanished. NCR would administer its own charities, future computer products would bear the NCR name and NCR would decide what -- if any -- A.T.&T. products would be maintained. Or so A.T.&T. said. Exley had agreed to become chairman of the transition planning committee; then, as he had always insisted during the long struggle, he would retire.
Four days after the signing in New York, Exley found himself in a reflective mood. "Standing in the A.T.&T. boardroom where I had made my presentation in November," he said, "I felt that I had come full circle. There was a real sense of relief that at last the thing was over." He was delighted that his executive and scientific teams had remained intact. "We haven't lost a soul. And let me tell you, the headhunters have been calling our people."
Exley singled out his directors for special praise. "Our board had the courage of lions," he said, "and they were absolutely determined that the company was not going to be sold on the cheap. They received all sorts of letters from institutions urging them to sell at $90 a share. They never wavered."
Months before the agreement was reached, A.T.&T. had clearly been preparing to hand over its computer business to NCR. The computer division eliminated a tenth of its 10,000 positions. Senior managers were shifted to other positions in A.T.&T. while middle managers were offered generous bonuses to remain behind and hold the division together until the merger occurred. A.T.&T. also promised to set up "gatekeepers" to shield NCR from any surviving imperial impulses at A.T.&T., and to assign a senior executive to listen to NCR's complaints, if any, and report back to Basking Ridge.
As co-chairman of the transition committee, Exley pushed for an unusually rapid integration of the two companies. "We're trying to do something difficult here, and speed is very important," he says. "I believe it is the best method of preserving the values, particularly the values on the A.T.&T. side. They have important customer relationships, and we've got to give assurances to those customers. They've got valuable people, and we don't want those people to go drifting away."
No matter how carefully the companies are combined, serious doubts remain about A.T.&T.'s ability to achieve its ultimate strategy, the linking of telecommunications and computers. It has never worked before. "There is no model for success," says the analyst Judith Hurwitz. "I.B.M. tried it, Hewlett-Packard tried it, Trident tried it a couple of times. There is mistrust, there is cyberphobia, between the communications side of the house and the computing side. It has nothing to do with how well the technology works."
As an episode in the annals of high finance, A.T.T.'s successful attack says much about the changed merger environment. In dramatic contrast to the well-publicized feeding frenzies of the 1980's, the deal was not characterized by heroic investment banking and the posturings of M.&A. lawyers. Instead of the high-priced advisers, the companies themselves controlled the shape of the deal.
In some ways, it is as though the 1980's never happened. In the absence of the torrents of cash provided by ever-more-risky issues of junk bonds, the preferred method of taking over a reluctant target has become, once again, the tedious and far-from-certain proxy fight. There was much about the deal that was specific to the strategic needs of A.T.&T., but the few large takeovers that have occurred since the collapse of the junk bond market in 1989 have been similarly driven by strategic needs. Unlike mountains, these companies were no longer assaulted simply because they were there.
In the end, however, just as in the 1980's, it was the short-term interests of NCR's institutional shareholders that decided the company's fate. Exley tried to argue that many other factors should be taken into account when a company's value was being determined -- its prospects, its products and its relationships with stakeholders. But when NCR's investors saw a stock price they liked, they took the money and ran.
A.T.&T. -- through a spokesman -- asserts that the merger with NCR will produce a strong American competitor in the global market for open systems, the most rapidly growing segment of the computing business. But NCR was already a global competitor in open systems. Its Achilles' heel was that it was a publicly owned company.
And because NCR was publicly owned, Charles Exley is now $34 million richer, thanks to his large holdings in the company. Ironically, a significant portion of these holdings consisted of incentive stock options, awarded because of his success in creating a company that became an all-but-irresistible takeover target.

HEADLINE: Delinquencies in Co-ops and Condos Are on the Rise

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT

 BODY:
MANY co-ops and condominiums in the New York region are feeling the pinch of growing delinquencies in monthly payments from their residents, real estate experts say, a result of loss of income in the recession plus sharp rises in the cost of keeping an apartment.
"It's occurring everywhere,"said Mary Ann Rothman, executive director of the New York Council of Cooperatives, which represents 130,000 dwellings in the city and suburbs. "Someone who bought at the tippy-top of the market in the 1980's may not still have their same wonderful job, or may not get the big raise and bonus they anticipated." 
 Some owners have been laid off, some have lost income because of declining business, according to co-op and condominium officials. Compounding the problem are increases in monthly maintenance fees, generally 7 to 15 percent this year at most buildings. These are due mainly to rapidly rising property taxes, labor costs and New York City water and sewer bills.
The latest round of maintenance increases comes on top of a decade of rising operating expenses. A study by Ms. Rothman's council showed that a typical co-op maintenance charge on the East Side more than doubled from 1980 to 1989, while the overall cost of living rose only 56 percent in that period.
Increasingly, co-op and condoboards are imposing stricter penalties on late payers and building managers are intervening faster when payments lag, first with informal inquiries, then with legal action that can lead to eviction and foreclosure.
To avoid costly litigation and forced sales, managers say, they encourage financially troubled residents to come forward and arrange to repay their debts. Mortgage lenders sometimes agreeto such arrangements.
A "famous" artist in a West Side penthouse "fell six months behind because his fees were slow coming in," said Paul Brensilber, executive vice president of Streamline Management, which runs buildings with 6,000 apartments. The artist is now reducing his arrears by paying extra each month.
"We have many work-outs going," said Les Gurren, president of Excelsior Management, which operates 10,000 co-op and condo apartments in the city and Westchester. In one case, he said, a corporate treasurer who was laid off took seven or eight months to find a new job and paid "at a lower rate till he could start catching up."
Not all cases have happy endings. Robert T. Cicchillo, president of Alexander Brett, which manages 2,000 apartments, said one Riverdale owner lost his job and "didn't have any money" and the apartment was too much to handle.
"They really did try everything to sell," he said, "but eventually they couldn't, so the bank foreclosed."
Co-ops and condos have always had occasional overdue accounts arising from marital or financial troubles, illness or death, but in recent months delinquencies have grown noticeably, management officials say, although there are no centralized statistics.
Anita Sapirman, president of Saparn Reality, which manages 3,000 city co-op and condo apartments, said, "Normally, payments were in by the 10th of the month. Now we've noticed some people are slowing down or not paying at all. Some became unemployed and are sending partial payments or are calling us and telling us they're in trouble."
"These are times when some people just don't have money," said Mr. Gurren of Excelsior.
Delinquencies have become cause for serious concern, board members and managers say, especially since building finances are usually premised on 100 percent collection.
"Budgets are so tight that they can't afford to have people not paying on time," said Leslie Winkler, president of Belmarc Management. The impact is more pronounced on small co-op buildings because arrears on one apartment represent a significant share of the total budget.
But with overdue payments limited to a minority of residents so far, real estate experts say the problem has not reached the point of threatening to bankrupt buildings.
Some recently converted cooperatives have been pushed to the brink of insolvency, however, by the related problem of sponsors' defaulting on maintenance for unsold apartments. Such troubled buildings also tend to suffer from delinquencies among residents, Mr. Brensilber said, because their mortgages and maintenances are relatively high.
Owners who would like to get out of their obligations by selling are likely to find themselves in a bind. With sagging property values, he said, "they would get less now than what they paid for their apartments."
To help cover their costs, some strapped apartment owners move into cheaper rentals and sublet. Although boards often bar or limit subletting, many are easing restrictions in the face of economic realities.
The region's total number of co-op and condo dwellings probably exceeds 500,000, according to Vicki Chesler, editor of the Cooperator newsletter and an adviser to the Co-op and Condo Alliance, an owner group.
Some managers of luxury buildings say they have not seen much of a problem. Marilyn Corradini, senior vice president of property management for William B. May, said applicants for expensive apartments normally have to show substantial assets to win approval and thus are less likely to default. Donald C. Goodwin, director of management for Brown, Harris, Stevens, said: "I would say it's a minimal problem at the high end of the market."
Montly payments are legally due the first of the month, but most buildings have a 10-day grace period, said Michael R. Finder, a housing lawyer in Manhattan who has seen delinquencies rising at cooperatives he represents.
A board can move to evict a nonpaying resident and sell the apartment. If there is a mortgage on the apartment, the board can also force the lender to start paying the apartment's monthly charges to the building.
"Boards are getting much more stringent about paying on time," said Mr. Gurren. "We're also doing much more early intervention, even when someone goes over just a few days, so we can nip problems early."
"Some boards used to wait 60 days before starting legal action," he said, "but those days are long gone."
A high-rise co-op complex in Brooklyn this spring notified its residents: "In recent months maintenance arrears have increased sharply. If allowed to continue unchecked, the co-op has few alternatives available to make up the shortfall." To encourage timely payments, the board doubled its late fee to $50 and imposed interest of 1.33 percent a month on arrears.
"Some people are embarrassed at letting their friends and neighbors in the co-op know they're in trouble," said Ms. Rothman of the co-op council, "but it makes much more sense to write a note to the management agent or board and say 'I lost my job' or 'my mother is ill,' or whatever the problem is."
Similarly, banks often prefer to work out a schedule for settling back payments, rather than incur the legal cost of foreclosure and risk losing money in a forced sale.
"I have found banks to be surprisingly flexible, because they really don't want to go to enforcement," said Stuart Fish, counsel to Alexander Brett management. "If the borrower acts in good faith and says 'I lost my job,' 'I'm getting a divorce' or 'I'm going into for surgery,' they may be willing to suspend payments or accept interest-only for some period."
Although hardship cases are painful, said Charles Rappaport, president of the Federation of New York Housing Cooperatives, representing 175,000 apartments in the city and suburbs, "you have a responsibility to protect the co-op and the other residents, so there are tough decisions."

HEADLINE: Q and A

BYLINE: By SHAWN G. KENNEDY

 BODY:

Rent Status
 
Question: I am planning on bidding on a six-family apartment building in Brooklyn being auctioned by a bank. I need to find the status of the individual units and what the current legal rents are. Can I get this information from the city if the rents are regulated? . . . Anthony Cafaro, Brooklyn 

Answer: No. The State Division of Housing and Community Renewal, which has jurisdiction over rent-regulated housing, does not have authority to release to prospective buyers information about the status of tenants and the rents they pay.
However, this information is available to the owner of the building. Thomas R. Viola, a spokesman for the division, said that the bank, as owner, could authorize the agency to release the information on rents. Perhaps the best approach is to contact the bank officer responsible for the property to arrange to have the information sent to you.
 
Illegal Yard Sale
 
Question: I have a neighbor who has a yard sale practically every weekend. Sometimes he sells new merchandise. It not only causes traffic jams on the street, but presents an esthetic problem in what otherwise is a nice residential neighborhood. Is this situation legal? . . . Charleen Lang, Maspeth, Queens
 
Answer:No. The city's zoning code does not address yard sales. But Vahe Tiryakian, a spokesman for the Department of Buildings, said that his agency considers the type of sale you describe to be in violation of the prohibition against commercial enterprises in residential neighborhoods.
Some businesses are permitted in residential areas, he explained, but this certainly is not one of them.
Mr. Tiryakian said that the occasional sale of household belongings, like the yard sales or rummage drives that homeowners and tenants occasionally hold, would probably not violate the code.
"The distinction is that these types of neighborhood yard sales are infrequent," said Mr. Tiryakian, "and what is sold tends to be personal belongings that people just want to recycle. The sales are not commercial enterprises in the usual sense."
You may file a complaint against your neighbor by calling the Department of Buildings. The telephone number of the borough office in Queens is (718) 520-3402.
 
Inspection for a Co-op
 
Question: My husband and I recently rented a co-op town house in New Jersey. This unit is for sale and we are seriously thinking of purchasing it. However, we would like to know if the normal procedures for purchasing apply, like home inspection, radon test and termite inspection, since what we would be buying would be shares in a cooperative not the unit itself. . . . Kristine O'Connor, Little Falls, N.J.
 
Answer: Yes, a professional home inspection would be a good idea, said Richard R. Kahn, a Hackensack, N.J., lawyer who specializes in real estate matters.
"It may well be that the co-op corporation is responsible for many problems involving the structure, like termites," said Mr. Kahn, "but prudence would dictate that in this case rule of reason would apply. There is no point is buying into potential problems that a home inspection would reveal."
Mr. Kahn said that in addition to the inspection for termites and radon levels, a check of the air-conditioning and heating systems and other structural components would be wise.
You can probably find a professional who will perform all of these services.

HEADLINE: Legislators See Little Change in Spending Plan

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON

 BODY:
AS the state's lawmakers resume their special session this week, they are expected to analyze Connecticut's tax system in minute detail, as they claw their way toward an answer to the historic question of whether there should be a tax on wages. But they are not expected to dwell long on the question of where that money will go -- or not go. Legislators say that the preliminary $7.7 billion spending plan hammered out in the final weeks of the regular session will probably not be changed greatly, despite what some lawmakers have criticized as heartless cuts in spending for social programs and the ambivalent and uncertain affects of the plan's package of long-term spending controls.
The reasons for the anticipated spending gridlock are bound up in both the political dynamics of the General Assembly and the simple function of the clock. The spending plan was the centerpiece of a coalition budget that passed both the House and Senate before being vetoed by Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. last month, and leaders of the Republican minority have repeatedly said since then that they would immediately reject any replacement budget that does not resurrect the spending plan. 
 The majority Democrats, meanwhile, have been deeply divided over every tax idea floated so far, including an income tax. They badly need at least a few Republican votes to pass a budget in time for the start of the fiscal year on July 1. That means retaining the spending plan largely intact.
Mr. Weicker further sharpened the focus on taxes when he vetoed the legislative budget last month. The Governor, who proposed his sweeping budget overhaul and income tax plan in February, said he was rejecting the legislature's plan not because of disagreements about the spending package, but because the revenue measures were flawed. The coalition plan would have resolved the state's fiscal crisis through a huge expansion of sales and corporation taxes, a change that Mr. Weicker said would hurt the economy and be cruel to the poor. All that points to a spending package that combines open-handed generosity in some areas with deep spending cuts in others. The legislature restored about $80 million in education grants to wealthy towns that Mr. Weicker had wanted to cut, for example, but retained deep cuts in spending for the construction of low-income housing, a $78 million reduction in Medicaid reimbursement for nursing home operators and a reduction in cost-of-living adjustments for welfare recipients.
Advocates for the poor say that in some areas, the budget helps and hurts at the same time. The plan would cut $3 million from the rental-assistance program, which helps poor people pay housing costs, but would retain full spending for shelters for the homeless. Allocations for subsidized housing would be reduced to $50 million from $94 million, and direct grants to nonprofit housing developers to help defray their administration costs would be eliminated entirely.
"In trying to shortsightedly solve this immediate budget crisis this year, we are jeopardizing what we have carefully built," said Jeffrey Freiser, the executive director of the Connecticut Housing Coalition, a group that lobbys for low-cost housing.
"Our nonprofit developers are being left completely empty handed," Mr. Freiser said. "Those are small community-based operations that just can't survive that kind of funding drought."
The plan also contains a lengthy list of structural spending changes that could have far-reaching implications for future budgets. An amendment to the State Constitution limiting the growth of state spending in future years, for example, is considered almost certain to pass in the special session and be sent on to the voters for consideration, lawmakers say. The amendment would prohibit state spending from growing any faster than the rate of inflation or the growth in personal income.
What remains unanswered is what sort of spending would really be covered by a spending cap. State grants to municipalities and spending for the Medicaid program, two of the largest single items in the budget, are both driven by formulas or definitions of eligibility. If a cap on spending growth conflicts with those other regulations, which one holds sway?
Another long-term change would take the Department of Motor Vehicles off the state's general-fund budget entirely and place it instead in the separate transportation fund. The shift would save an estimated $51 million next year in general fund revenues, but critics say they fear a drain on the transportation fund's resources.
Among its functions, the fund sells state bonds to pay for things like highway repair, then collects gasoline taxes and license fees to pay the interest and principal. Its bond rating is crucial in determining the cost of state borrowing.
 
Depends on Who's Looking
 "It's an issue of financial soundness, of budgetary soundness," said Representative William R. Dyson, a Democrat from New Haven and co-chairman of the Appropriations Committee. Mr. Dyson said he questioned the wisdom of transferring the Department of Motor Vehicles, but he conceded that all such spending issues will take a back seat to taxes in the days to come.
"Is the issue regarding transportation fund solvency in 1998, or 1997, or 1996 of any importance?" Mr. Dyson asked. The answer, he said, is that it depends on who's looking. "For the bondholders, it is," he said. "For us here, it might not be as important."
But the spending and taxing sides of the budget are also bound to intersect during the special session, and several flash points have been identified that could spark changes on one side of the budget or the other. The proposal to reduce cost-of-living adjustments for welfare recipients, for example, was initially suggested by Mr. Weicker in his budget.
The proposal was part of the Governor's overall budget plan, which called, among other changes, for a lowering of the 8 percent sales tax -- the highest statewide rate in the nation -- to 4.25 percent. Because the sales tax was being cut so dramatically, the Governor's budget officials argued, slowing the growth in welfare benefits was not as draconian as it seemed.
The legislature's coalition spending plan also included the cost-of-living reduction, but in that plan, the sales tax was kept at 8 percent and expanded to a wide new realm of transactions. Weicker administration officials argued that the expansion of the sales tax would make the welfare reduction cruel and unfair.
 
Erosion of Sales Tax
 The circle was completed on the last day of the regular legislative session on Wednesday, when the Senate called up Mr. Weicker's budget for what leaders said was a symbolic vote of no confidence. They said they wanted to convey, in part, that the Governor's budget plan had become obsolete in the four months since his initial proposal.
They said that the continuing erosion of sales tax collections, in particular, had widened the revenue gap that the budget will have to make up. That has made a 4.25 percent sales tax impossible, the Senators said. Even if all else were kept intact in Mr. Weicker's proposal -- including the 6 percent wage tax on income over $25,000 for a couple filing jointly and $12,500 for an individual -- the sales tax would have to be at least 5.25 percent, they said.
The Senate defeated the Weicker plan by a vote of 28 to 8, then adjourned several hours later.
In his closing comments, Mr. Weicker said: "Why there is no budget is irrelevant as of this moment. When is the only question of importance."

HEADLINE: New Courthouse

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 The article on the new Federal office building and courthouse to be built downtown ["A Spur to Slow Construction," April 28] unfortunately missed some points. 
 First, the project was an initiative of Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan. To his credit, he aimed for quality architecture. Unfortunately, he also pushed for the friendly condemnation.
The new courthouse, for which there is a greater need than the office building, should be given the Broadway site. The Chinatown community's only park will be darkened by the new courthouse in its designated location behind the New York County Courthouse, which will require relocation of many utility lines.
The environmental-impact statements for the buildings noted serious concern about the sites' geological and hydrological problems. The danger posed to the integrity of 22 Reade Street, where the City Planning Commission has its headquarters, by the construction of the new 290 Broadway building on the same block is set forth in the reports.
Nineteenth-century cast-iron buildings have collapsed during construction and 22 Reade Street itself caved in during renovation. It remains without a certificate of occupancy.
The General Services Administration would have liked to acquire the full Broadway lot but the city's Department of General Services felt it had done a wonderful job with 22 Reade Street. The staff at the Department of City Planning feels otherwise.
The rear windows of 22 Reade -- assuming the building doesn't collapse, sink or slide into the construction pit during construction -- will face an air well.
The city should have ceded the entire block to the Federal Government and relocated the Department of City Planning.
 
BRUCE ROSEN
Forest Hills, Queens

HEADLINE: Sunday Dinner;
Where Casual Finally Meets Reasonable

 BODY:
If there are two words that characterize the New York City dining scene these days, they are casual and reasonable. After the showy excess of the 1980's, diners yearn to loosen their ties, lean back and relax, and economy is a major concern. The restaurant industry has been quick to heed the call with many establishments that combine both qualities. Here are three of them.
 
Claire
 156 Seventh Avenue, near 20th Street, (212) 255-1955 -- Modeled after a restaurant by the same name in Key West, Fla., this pleasing seafood house in Chelsea is a big, aqua-toned place with bare wood floors, paper-covered tables, skylights, wood latticework room dividers and palms. Appetizers on the Sunday menu include blackened tuna sashimi with a wasabi-soy sauce; roasted portobello mushrooms with pesto vinaigrette; Bahamian conch chowder; and roasted andouille with creole mustard sauce. Among entrees are sauteed softshell crab with tartar sauce; Bayou crayfish patties with cayenne-cilantro sauce; broiled Key West grouper Provencal; Norwegian salmon with a cucumber-dill sauce; and roast duckling with a sauce of fresh plums and hot peppers. For desserts, Key lime pie and mango crumb pie. Appetizers range from $3.95 to $8.95; main courses, $14.95 to $16.95; desserts, $3.50 to $4.95. Sunday dinner is from 5:30 P.M. to midnight. (Review, Sept. 23, 1988.) 

Rose Cafe
24 Fifth Avenue at Ninth Street, (212) 260-4118 -- Richard Krause, the chef and owner of this upbeat American restaurant comes from the California school of cooking and serves fine food at very reasonable prices. Three dining areas are done in soft eggshell-toned walls and simple cylinder-shaped sconces. A glass-enclosed sidewalk terrace affords an animated urban panorama. For starters on Sunday, there are crisp potato pancakes with creme fraiche and caviar; pork and shrimp dumplings with Cantonese lobster sauce and hot mustard; a salad of couscous, sweet peppers, eggplant, zucchini, red onions and mache; and pizza topped with sun-dried tomatoes, yellow tomatoes, homemade mozzarella and fresh basil.
Main courses include rare charred tuna with a mango-tomato-red onion vinaigrette; grilled summer vegetables with wild rice and five-bean salad; roast breast of duck with cassis and poached pears; and soft-shell crab served with a Chinese black bean sauce, steamed mussels and crisp spinach. Among the desserts are toasted angel food cake with coffee ice cream and chocolate sauce, and assorted fresh fruit gratin with a Champagne sabayon. Appetizers range from $4.25 to $7.50; entrees, $12.95 to $16.95; desserts, $4.50 to $6. Sunday dinner is from 5:30 P.M. to midnight; Rose Cafe also serves a brunch from 11:30 A.M. to 3:30 P.M. (Review, May 25, 1990.)

 
Phoenix Garden
 46 Bowery, inside the arcade just north of Elizabeth Street, (212) 233-6017 or (212) 962-8934 -- This is neither the most affable nor the most comfortable spot in Chinatown, but some of the best Cantonese fare in New York City can be had here. Among recommended starters are mustard greens and sliced pork soup with ginger; pepper and salty shrimp; stewed eggplant with ground ham casserole; and crispy roasted squab. Fine main courses include sea scallops in hot black pepper sauce; braised duck with mustard greens; stewed beef flank with sweet turnips, mustard greens, garlic and coriander; and lobster with satee sauce, a piquant blend of black pepper and curry, served over noodles. Appetizers range from $3.25 to $8.95; main courses, $5 to $25.50. Sunday hours are from 11:30 A.M. to 10:30 P.M. No credit cards are accepted. (Review, May 10, 1991.)

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: A Party Fleet Tries Not to Founder

BYLINE: By RICHARD D. LYONS

 BODY:
Chris Coronesi stood at the stern rail of the Pastime II amid a half-dozen cronies fishing for flounder three miles off the Rockaway jetty near the Brooklyn-Queens border. He had one hand on a fishing rod and the other on a cellular telephone with an extension cord that snaked into a portable battery pack as his feet. Mr. Coronesi, the president of Aspen Associates, a Manhattan construction management and contracting company, was talking to a client.
"Hold it a minute," he said into the phone after feeling a tug on his rod. "I've got some business on the other line." 
 Mr. Coronesi's friends howled with laughter, and Mr. Coronesi displayed the self-satisfied smirk that bespeaks the man who has beaten the system. But the scene was possible only because of the recession.
"There's no construction business in New York right now, so why should I sit in my office being depressed when I can come out here on George's boat and enjoy myself?" he said.
 
The Skipper Hates Fish
 Mr. Coronesi and most of the 25 fishermen aboard the 65-foot fishing boat are regular customers of Capt. George Richford. Mr. Richford, the 50-year-old owner and skipper of the Pastime II, has been operating out of Sheepshead Bay for 35 years. A grizzled salt who can't stand the taste of fish, he runs the boat with his son, Phil Richford, 25, and two crewmen.
The very names of the craft in Sheepshead Bay -- Amberjack V, Sea Wolf, Ranger, Helen II, Sunshine, Romance, Grace -- are meant to entice the kind of people who regard fishing as more entertaining than watching television or playing cards.
But the recession that sent Mr. Coronesi out fishing has, at the same time, helped to cut into the number of party boats based in Sheepshead Bay. Where there were 33 party boats three years ago, there are now 18. And Mr. Richford's boat, which is licensed to carry 70 people, was on this day carrying only 25.
Mr. Richford is well aware that, for Sheepshead Bay, an evolution is under way. While the party-boat business is going downhill, condominium developers -- hoping to cash in on the long and colorful history of the area -- are putting up apartments hardly a clamshell's throw away from Pier 3, where the Pastime II docks.
 
Birthplace of Surf and Turf
 Sheepshead Bay hit its prime a century ago, when Lillie Langtry, Lillian Russell and their entourages would traipse out to the Brooklyn waterfront. Those were the days before air-conditioning and food refrigeration, when cooling onshore breezes were a luxury and so was fresh seafood.
Diamond Jim Brady coined the term "surf and turf" for the gargantuan lobster-and-steak dinner he favored at the 2,800-seat Lundy Brothers restaurant on Emmons Avenue. But Lundy's, a New York landmark that anchored the Sheepshead Bay community for decades, closed more than a dozen years ago. Mr. Richford and the remaining party-boat operators have fought a long and losing battle to have the city help the fishermen and restaurateurs by, for example, providing off-street parking for customers. The boat owners seem to have little political influence, and most of their customers are now on the far side of 60.
Perhaps 15 of the 25 fishermen aboard the Pastime II that morning were retirees, paying a discounted rate of $13 for a half-day of fishing. (The full fare is $16; children can fish for $9.) But not all those on Mr. Richford's boat were retired.
Ruthie Ashkenazi, 17, who had just graduated from high school in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn, was on her first fishing trip. She was with her boyfriend, Kevin Rosenfeld, 16, of the Borough Park section, a clerk in a camera store.
 
It Might Be the High Seas
 "Kevin phoned me at 3 A.M. and said we were going fishing," she said. Kevin had started going out on party boats a couple of months ago. "I caught 42 mackerel the first time I went," he said, "and now I fish at least once a week."
Looking out over the water, which was occasionally blanketed by fog, he added: "I like to think that I'm fishing in the middle of the Atlantic Ocean. I'm not, of course, but it makes me feel good."
He might well have been speaking for the others, because eventually it became clear that for many of them, going fishing was more important than catching a monster fish. Indeed, only three fish of any size were hauled in that morning.
Charlie Schuster, 79, of Glendale, Queens, caught one of them. Mr. Schuster, who used to run a textiles mill in Brooklyn, goes out on the Pastime II several times a week. "Thank God for Social Security," he said shortly before he hooked the three-pound flounder that won him the "largest fish" pool of $38.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Chris Coronesi, a Manhattan contractor, can fish aboard the Pastime II only because his business is bad. Pastime II is one of 18 party boats left in the Sheepshead Bay fleet. (Photographs by Dith Pran/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Laura Cook Weds John P. Booth Jr.

 BODY:
Laura Fellows Cook, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederic William Cook of Peekskill, N.Y., was married yesterday at St. Mary's Episcopal Church in Scarborough, N.Y., to John Patrick Booth Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Booth of Farmingdale, L.I. The Rev. William R. Harper officiated.
 The couple, both 26 years old, graduated from Williams College, the bride cum laude. The bridegroom was a Herbert Lehman scholar. 
 Mrs. Booth is a compensation analyst at the Towers Perrin management consulting concern in New York. Her father heads Frederic W. Cook & Company, management consultants in New York. Her mother, Sara Jasper Cook, is a movie critic for The North County News, a weekly newspaper in Yorktown Heights, N.Y.
 The bridegroom has been a history and economics teacher at Cheshire (Conn.) Academy. He is to join the faculty of the Brunswick School in Greenwich, Conn., in September. His mother, Julia Booth, is employed in packaging at Estee Lauder in Melville, L.I. His father is a plumber.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIARY/June 2-7

BYLINE: By Joel Kurtzman

 BODY:

COMPANIES
 
Where's That Time Warner Synergy? 

To the poor Time Warner Inc. shareholder, it must seem like arm-twisting time. Just before the merger last year they were treated to tales of synergy. Just after the merger, reality -- in the form of $11 billion in debt -- appeared like a skunk at a garden party. To bring down that debt, rumor had it Time Warner would sell off a minority interest. No such luck. Last week the company released its debt-reduction plan. It will try to raise about $3 billion through an offering of 34.5 million new shares for a price between $63 and $105, depending on how many shares are sold. But the plan requires investors to buy new shares to maintain their percentage ownership. An investor with 100 shares might have to kick in more than $5,000. "It's an unbelievable deal for shareholders, if someone does the math," said Steven J. Ross, the company's chairman. Maybe so, but Time Warner stock fell $11.25 to $99.50 on the news and closed the week at $94.675.

Baby Bells' Chance to Grow
 
When the courts created the seven regional phone companies from the old Bell system in 1984, there was a lot the "Baby Bells" were not permitted to do. Manufacturing their own equipment, for instance, was taboo. So was offering long-distance service. But last week the Senate voted 71 to 24 to allow the Baby Bells to make their own equipment -- although only if they do it domestically with minimal foreign content. The Senate figures letting the Baby Bells manufacture here will help trim the $792 million trade deficit in telecommunications equipment. The Senate also thinks that with $77 billion in revenues, the Baby Bells have the cash to become master manufacturers -- even exporters of their handiwork. But opponents of the measure fear the Baby Bells will have to raise phone rates to subsidize their entry into manufacturing. The measure now has to clear the House, where it faces a tough battle.
 
One More Ailing Airline
 
Another airline is in trouble. But this time the winds are favorable. Last week America West Airlines Inc. suspended payments to holders of leases on its planes to conserve cash. A drastic step. The airline -- the nation's ninth largest -- lost $49.9 million in the first quarter and $2.6 million the previous quarter. But for the first time since the Persian Gulf crisis, traffic was up sharply across the industry and fuel prices were down. That, analysts say, could keep the airline out of Chapter 11.
 
Bidding for the General
 
Before Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf became a media star, all he had to contend with were Saddam Hussein and the Republican Guards. Now agents, editors and publishers have been added to the list. Five publishers -- Bantam, HarperCollins, Alfred A. Knopf, William Morrow and Random House -- are all bidding for General Schwarzkopf's life story. The bids range from $2.5 million to $5 million (the rights they want to buy differ). But the general had better move with dispatch. With so many articles about him -- and with other concerns pushing the war into the background -- "he is in danger of being overexposed," said Jib Fowles, a professor of communications at the University of Houston.
 
The Truth About Fat
 
Food labeling has always been a battleground between the sizzle and the steak. Packagers want products to seem good for you even if they are not. They see labels as a chance to advertise. Health advocates want packages that tell the whole truth -- which requires space. Last week the Federal Drug Administration said it was clamping down on false claims about fat, its second crackdown in little more than a month. "A product that says it is 97 percent fat free but has 50 percent of its calories from fat is misleading," said David A. Kessler, head of the F.D.A. In April the F.D.A. restricted use of the word "fresh." "We have got to get false and misleading statements off the label," Dr. Kessler said.
 
Advertising's Letdown
 
The advertising industry has already suffered two years of sluggish growth. Last week it learned it will have to suffer a third. Robert J. Coen, senior vice president at McCann-Ericson U.S.A., lowered his estimates for how much American companies will spend on advertising this year. Revenue will grow just 3.1 percent, not 4.6 percent as he had originally hoped. Mr. Coen, who has been forecasting the ad business since 1948, said revenues will be $128.6 billion this year. But 1992 will be rosier, he said. He sees revenues growing by 8.5 percent -- to $144 billion -- due to the Olympics and the Presidential elections, events sure to glue consumers to newspapers, radio and the tube. After that, it's anybody's guess.
 
Chrysler in the 'Junk' Heap
 
Detroit's woes show no sign of abating. Sales of domestically built cars and light trucks dropped 10 percent in May from a year earlier. Chrysler's sales fell the most, down 23 percent. Just after the figures were released Standard & Poors downgraded Chrysler's bonds to "BB-" -- which makes them "junk." "With the exception of April and January, last month was still one of the lowest sales months in memory," said Irwin L. Kellner, chief economist for Manufactures Hanover Trust in New York. "We may have hit bottom, but we're a long way from recovery."
 
 
 
THE ECONOMY

 
Credit Markets Act Up
 
The economy is bottoming out, said Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, at a news conference in Japan. But that piece of good news sent the credit markets into conniptions. The price of Treasury bonds fell sharply, driving up interest rates by almost 50 basis points. Quite a hefty jump for a single day. Why all the fuss? "The markets see an upward trajectory and they think inflation," said Samuel D. Kahan, chief economist at Fuji Securities in Chicago. But this time the markets may be getting it wrong. Recessions are typically followed by periods of perky growth between 5 and 6 percent. That's inflationary. But this is not a typical recession. It is shorter and shallower than most and the recovery is likely to be weaker. "Growth will only be about 1.8 percent over the next three quarters. That's non-inflationary," said Mr. Kahan. Even so, the markets are acting scared.
 
A Recovery Without Muscle
 
More evidence that the economy's soft landing into a recession will be followed by a 98-pound weakling of a recovery: Unemployment increased by three-tenths of a percent to 6.9 percent in April, according to the Labor Department. Increased unemployment often precedes a recovery since companies want to make sure their order books are full before they start hiring again. Still, the numbers show that while certain sectors of the economy are beginning to hum the growth tune, it will take time before the ranks of the unemployed are thinned.
 
Setting a Date for Recovery
 
Picking the date when the economy noses its way back into growth is a tricky business. But last week an important indicator, the National Association of Purchasing Management's monthly index, showed growth may be near. The index, based on a survey of the buying plans of the nation's top purchasing managers, edged its way up to 45.4 percent in May from 42.1 percent in April, the first increase in seven months. "This is another confirmation that the bottoming-out process is ending and signs of a recovery are beginning to emerge," said Jerry J. Jasinowski, president of the National Association of Manufacturers.
 
A Reconstructed Industry
 
The building industry has been languishing at activity levels not seen since 1982. That is finally beginning to change. Spending on construction projects jumped by 0.8 percent in April, the Commerce Department said last week. That is the largest gain in 14 months.
 
 
 
INTERNATIONAL

Hesitant Help for the Soviets
 
President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's speech last week in Oslo was a real spellbinder, they said. He spoke about perestroika and how the West needs to help it succeed as he slipped into town to pick up his Nobel Peace Prize. But his words did not play in Paris where finance ministers of the world's 24 richest nations were meeting. This hard-nosed group needs to see an economic reform plan that has a chance of turning the Soviet Union around. So far it has not. "Until they see a plan," said Benjamin Weiner of Probe International, a consulting firm in Stamford, Conn., "the only credits Gorbachev will get will be the ones that benefit the lending country most."
 
A Target, Translated
 
"Target" must mean different things in English and Japanese. In 1986, American and Japanese trade negotiators set 20 percent as a target for how much of the Japanese computer-chip market American companies would get. American chip makers never came close. The Reagan Administration retaliated with a 100 percent duty on some exports. Even that did not work. Last week the Bush Administration negotiated another chip pact. The target was the same, but critics were concerned that it has no timetable. "The Japanese only move on these things when someone pushes them," said Laura D. Tyson, a professor of economics at the University of California, Berkeley.
 
Same Old Arms Sales
 
To a cynic listening to Defense Secretary Dick Cheney last week, the new world order might have sounded surprisingly like the old one. Mr. Cheney, returning from a 10-day trip to Europe and the Middle East, announced arm sales worth $2.1 billion. Twenty Apache Helicopters, made by by McDonnell Douglas Inc., would go to the United Arab Emirates. The Administration was also considering selling them 337 of General Dynamics' M1-A1 tanks. The new world order seems to favor exports.

HEADLINE: Tarnish on the Golden Arch?

 BODY:
To the Editor:
As a 16-year -- now former -- McDonald's franchisee I can readily attest to the veracity of "An American Icon Wrestles with a Troubled Future" (May 12). 
 The prime cause of McDonald's problems is corporate and executive arrogance. This attitude permeates the entire structure. It has resulted in a reactive and defensive management style instead of a pro-active and progressive one that sees future social changes and is prepared to capitalize on them as they materialize.
In the late 1970's, at a convention in Orlando, Fla., I publicly advocated to a McDonald's executive the need for salads as an alternative to our sandwich menu, which consisted of red meat and fried food. His answer: "Salads are for flower children." Salads were finally introduced in 1987. The McLean Deluxe was only very recently introduced and the excellent grilled chicken breast sandwich is still being tested.
Environmentally, because of its ubiquity, McDonald's is erroneously thought to be a major polluter. It isn't. But management should have understood this fact and taken action late in the 70's by implementing a program that would resolve this problem. The current customer-oriented program accomplishes little environmentally and much less in public relations than was desired.
Reducing prices does not help the economically impacted franchisee. Without significant reductions in site and building costs, this action only reduces profits and creates dissatisfaction in the operator community.
The long waiting list of franchise hopefuls is mostly made up of people who are looking at the past profits made by existing franchisees and who don't understand the enormous amount of hard work it takes to achieve an ever-decreasing bottom line.
McDonald's is one of the finest organizations in the world. Will management have the wisdom and clairvoyance to adopt a pro-active style to solve its current and future problems?
 
MIRICK FRIEND
Newton, Mass., May 23

HEADLINE: A Cavil or Two on Raising Oil Prices

 BODY:
To the Editor:
I offer your reader David Marder (Letters, May 26) several cavils on raising oil prices: 
 It is not in the national interest to promote petroleum use in either agriculture or petrochemical manufacturing.
Long before benefits from any general "petrotax" increase can be felt great hardship will have been imposed on lower-income Americans.
Bursts of inflation have been associated with increases in oil price throughout modern times.
 
ROBERT C. SOMMER
New York, May 26

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Letter

HEADLINE: World Markets;
New Highs for South African Stocks

BYLINE: By Jonathan Fuerbringer

 BODY:
Inflation in South Africa is around 14 percent. Last year the economy declined about 1 percent, and this year the forecast is for little or no growth. Gold prices are weak, which is no help for the world's leading gold producer. And the violence between the followers of the African National Congress and the Zulu-dominated Inkatha Freedom Party has complicated the negotiations over movement toward a new Government.
But despite these factors, the South African stock market, the 10th largest in the world, has managed to climb this year. In fact, the market's industrial index, which includes manufacturers, retailers and consumer goods companies, has consistently hit record highs in the last several months. On Friday, it closed at 3,682, another new high, which is up 22 percent for the year. The overall local index, which includes gold stocks, is up 18 percent since the end of 1990. 
 Despite the psychological boost that the market has had from the rally in the stock markets in the United States and elsewhere, much of the explanation is in South Africa's special circumstances.
Chief among these is the "hothouse" effect of South Africa's economy. To stop capital outflow, South African mutual and pension funds and individuals cannot legally invest overseas, and exchange controls make it prohibitively expensive for companies to do so. This means the cash stays home, and, simply put, there are a lot of rands in South Africa chasing a small number of stocks.
According to John Taylor of James Capel Inc. in London, the Government may soon raise limits on the portion of mutual funds that may be invested in stocks to 75 percent. The limit is 65 percent now.
In addition, consumer spending is thriving, especially among blacks, despite the recession. "It has been a funny sort of recession here," said Niall Brown of Simpson McKie, a brokerage house in Johannesburg. "It has been a fixed-investment and a capital-goods recession but not a consumer recession." This phenomenon is also reflected in the decline in the country's savings rate.
"As strange as it may seem to the outsider, there has been a redistribution of wealth," added Emmanuel Pohl, director of the research department at the firm of Davis Borkum Hare, referring to the growth of the underground economy. "And that spending power has been driving this sector."
The stock in Edgar's, the dominant retailer of clothing, footwear, textiles and accessories, is up 42.5 percent this year. South African Breweries has risen 30.4 percent.
There are some signs that this rally may hold, although it could face some corrections. Gold stocks have rallied now that the price of gold, which was up again on Friday, seems to have bottomed out. Economic projections for next year show the economy beginning to recover and earnings, especially in the industrial sector, rising to about 18 percent, according to Mr. Taylor.
At the same time, negotiations toward a new Government, while difficult, are moving ahead. And President F. W. de Klerk has pledged to dismantle the last of the apartheid laws this year. The United States could lift its economic sanctions soon because the South African Government is close to meeting the preconditons. The European Community has already removed its toughest sanctions. Still, many analysts argue that in the beginning this will have an impact that is more psychological than financial.
But the outlook is also still very risky, in part because of the concern over economic development, which will require a return of capital and investment from abroad and help from international financial agencies, like the International Monetary Fund.
Mr. Taylor of James Capel said, "The social situation remains extremely fragile, and unless the issues of housing, education and law and order are urgently addressed, unrest could threaten to dislocate the promising advances made in the political-economic arena."
 The governor of South Africa's central bank, Chris Stals, said recently that the country could be ungovernable by 1995 if economic and social problems are not dealt with. "We must not overlook the influence of the low growth rate on the prevailing violence," he said.

HEADLINE: Currency;
Dollar Still Gains On Mark, Franc

 BODY:
The dollar rose sharply on Friday, bringing it to a new level in its four-month rally, in which it has risen 22 percent against the mark. The dollar passed 140 yen and 1.77 marks, key levels in its march back from post-World War II lows against the mark and levels not far above the record low against the yen.
The stimulus on Friday was the surprising employment report. Rather than showing a decline in nonfarm payroll jobs -- which had been the consensus expectation -- the Labor Department said nonfarm jobs increased by 59,000. This means the recession may be ending and there is little chance the Fed will lower interest rates further. The Japanese are also less likely to lower their interest rates.
