HEADLINE: Who in the End Pays for Free Trade? The American Worker

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In "Who Champions the Working Class?" (Op-Ed, May 26), Robert B. Reich presents the stunning statistic that two-thirds of American wage earners have lost 12 percent in real wages (hence in purchasing power) in the last 15 years -- and then proceeds to deplore protectionism. But global free trade is the very phenomenon that produced that statistic. No other explanation is convincing. 
 Corporations always pay workers as little as they can. But labor unions forced wages up to higher levels. No more. Stiff international economic competition, often the direct product of free trade involving cheap foreign labor using first-rate machines, has gravely weakened unions and forced them to forgo wage gains to promote job security. And when union wage levels stagnate or fall, wages in the nonunionized service industries suffer also. That is the pattern. The upshot: two-thirds of American wage earners are mired in comparatively low wages -- or in increasing unemployment. They are the clear victims of free trade in the modern world.
Free trade provides more jobs for desperatedly poor foreign workers. If we believe that the welfare of everyone everywhere matters, that should be a source of satisfaction.
But while free trade is also a bonanza for consumers, improves industrial efficiency and is good for many skilled workers and professional employees, it is bad for tens of millions of American workers. And while the slippage in American wage levels hasn't caused this recession, it will prolong it and weaken the eventual recovery. The lack of enough worker purchasing power to fuel a vigorous economy is an ominous development with long-range consequences that proponents of free trade don't like to confront or even acknowledge.
We are told that the answer to this problem is to upgrade American education and hence United States technical and creative skills. But that is a long, arduous and uncertain project. Given the negative factors at work, no one knows how it will turn out. So Professor Reich provides a glib answer, but not a reassuring one.
American workers are paying and will continue to pay a very high price for this nation's commitment to free trade.
 
REO M. CHRISTENSON
Oxford, Ohio, May 28, 1991
 
The writer is an adjunct professor of political science at Miami University.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: British Health Service, Much Beloved But Inadequate, Is Facing Changes

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, June 8

 BODY:
Ever since the inception of the National Health Service just after World War II, Conservative Party politicians have found that meddling too much with a system that provides health care for all Britons was political suicide.
Prime Minister John Major's Government says it is trying to put the system on a more businesslike basis and improve its services to customers, and it is paying for it this year. 
 Underfinanced, inefficient and universally beloved, the "National Health" will consume about $56 billion of taxpayers' money in 1991, almost three times what it took a decade ago, but about the same percentage of British gross domestic product -- a little less than 6 percent.
Yet it cannot satisfy many of the country's needs.
 
700,000 Wait for Surgery
 More than 700,000 people are on waiting lists for operations, the Government acknowledges, and about 200,000 of them have been waiting for more than a year. Nearly half them are waiting for one of these common operations: hernia repair, varicose veins, hip replacements, examinations of joints, tonsils and adenoids, sterilizations and cataract removals, the Department of Health says.
But because hospitals do not have enough beds, or lack money to pay enough surgeons to perform all these operations, the waiting lists grow.
The Government increased spending on health this year by $5.25 billion, but besides more money, it thought more competition for customers among hospitals and doctors might help.
Under a law that was passed last year, the Government began last month to allow some hospitals and group general practitioners with at least 9,000 patients to administer their own budgets and enter into service contracts with one another, instead of being told what to do by the Health Service bureaucracy.
Soon after the plan went into effect in April, Guy's Hospital, one of the best known and respected London teaching hospitals in the system, announced that it would eliminate 600 of its 3,000 staff jobs, mainly by attrition, over the next year. Its sister hospital, Lewisham, would lose 300 more. Guy's later reduced the number of jobs to be lost to 295.
The chief executive of the Guy's-Lewisham trust, Peter Griffiths, told the staff that the first year would be difficult, because they needed to clear debts of $11.9 million from previous years. "There is no point in trying to support a service that is not the best for patients, simply because it has always been provided," he added.
Because it was one of the flagships of the Government's new program, the hospital instantly became the center of a political storm. In the tumult, few asked whether Guy's might be doing some things best left to others, or whether it was overstaffed, as critics say the whole health service is.
Instead, the debate centered on whether the Government's plans would lead to a deterioration in the quality of care for all patients, or give preferential treatment to those whose doctors went along with the new plan.
"It's very difficult to see how losing 10 percent staff over a year is going to improve the quality of care," said Prof. Harry Keen, an opponent of the Government's plans who formally retired from Guy's last year but continues to maintain an office in the 266-year-old hospital.
All this was happening, furthermore, as Mr. Major was coming under pressure to decide when to call the national election that must be held by July of next year. The opposition Labor Party also sounded alarms nationwide about what would happen to the 56 British hospitals that have been given self-governing status, with 120 more expected to get it next year.
A special parliamentary election to fill a vacancy in the Conservative-held Monmouth constituency in Wales became a referendum on the Health Service changes, and the Labor Party won comfortably. Opinion polls showed that the Health Service was far and away the voters' biggest concern.
In an interview on the grounds of Guy's the other day, Professor Keen said, "The doctor's job is not to make money, but to spend money wisely and well."
Ian McColl, head of the department of surgery at Guy's, said that was precisely what the staff reduction would do. "This will release money that can be used to treat more patients," said Lord McColl, who supported the Government's plans for changes and was given a life peerage in 1989.
 
Many Are Alarmed
 Instead of reassuring people, the changes have scared many into thinking that the Government's real object was to dismantle the Health Service, privatize it, and leave them to pay their hospital bills through health insurance they can buy on their own.
Some free-market economists wish the Government had done just that when it passed the new law.
"The structural flaw in the Government's proposals was that they didn't take into account the true nature of health care, which is that it's partly discretionary," said David G. Green, head of the health unit at the Institute of Economic Affairs, which tried and failed to convert Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher to its position in 1988.
"Except for emergency cases," he said, "whether people choose to have many different kinds of operations depends partly on income, partly on fashion, personal belief or skepticism in medical science, pain threshholds and so on."
 
Monopoly Criticized
 In his view, as long as the Health Service remains a virtual monopoly, economic inefficiencies like waiting lists for operations will be inevitable. Only an estimated 6.8 million of Britain's 57.5 million people carry private health insurance, and private hospitals have 78,500 beds, compared with the Health Service's 282,900.
"It's still a rationing system, with producer domination and consumer weakness," he said of the Health Service.
And despite the system, many Britons do end up with worries about paying for health care. A retired British journalist on a small pension, for instance, wrote to his American employer at the end of last year saying he needed a triple bypass heart operation and a heart valve replacement. "The National Health Service said April was the earliest it could take me," he wrote. "So the alternative seemed death or a private hospital immediately."
He went to a private hospital and had the operations last fall, at a cost of $26,250 from his own pocket.
"He shouldn't have done that," Lord McColl said, when told about the case. "He should have gone back to his National Health Service hospital and told them that another hospital could get him in earlier, and they probably would have let him jump the queue."
 
Preferential Treatment Charged
 Some Health Service doctors have charged that large general practitioners with their own budgets were being promised such preferential treatment, in exchange for bringing in patients, and income, to some of the new self-managing hospital trusts. But the hospitals and Mr. Major deny this.
"There is no question of a two-tier health service," he told the House of Commons the day of the voting in Monmouth.
The Labor Party leader, Neil Kinnock, said that if his party won the next election, it would spend $35 billion more on public services, including health, over the following four to five years.
Labor also says that as a percentage of gross domestic product, the United Kingdom spends less on health -- 6.1 percent, most of it on the National Health Service -- than most other European Community countries. The United States spent 11.2 percent in 1987, according to the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development in Paris.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Ian McColl, left, head of the department of surgery at Guy's Hospital in London, who said that a planned 20 percent reduction in staff "will release money that can be used to treat more patients." (Jonathan Player for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: De Klerk Visits Kenya's Chief, Urging Normal Ties

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER S. WREN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JOHANNESBURG, June 8

 BODY:
South Africa's long closed door to the rest of Africa swung open wider today when President F. W. de Klerk flew to Kenya for a brief but significant visit with President Daniel arap Moi.
Kenya became the 10th African country to receive Mr. de Klerk in the two years since he replaced P. W. Botha as National Party leader and then President and promised to dismantle apartheid. 
 His domestic revisions have led to a growing acceptance of South Africa among black African countries that were offended by its racist ideology. South Africa's isolation was also eroded by its disengagement from the war in Angola and the granting of independence to Namibia, which was administered by Pretoria for 76 years.
At a news conference after his arrival in Nairobi, President de Klerk expressed the hope that South Africa would be admitted sooner rather than later into the Organization of African Unity, which held a summit meeting in Nigeria this week.
"We are part of Africa and I think most African countries would welcome us into the O.A.U.," Mr. de Klerk said, according to the South African Press Association.
South African officials see President de Klerk's visit to Kenya, which dominates East Africa, as a breakthrough because it is one of three African countries that, through their regional stature, could influence a normalization of relations across the continent.
The other two countries are Egypt in northern Africa and Nigeria in West Africa. Mr. de Klerk met with President Hosni Mubarek of Egypt during Namibia's independence celebrations in March 1990. On Tuesday, President Ibrahim Babangida of Nigeria told reporters that he was not opposed to meeting Mr. de Klerk if it would help bring equal voting rights for South Africa's black majority.
At a meeting this week in Abuja, Nigeria, the Organization of African Unity agreed to reconsider economic sanctions against Pretoria "with a view toward readmitting South Africa into the international community" once it adopted "measures which lead to positive, profound and irreversible change."
Some South African officials say they hope that will happen after Parliament scraps the last apartheid legislation this month.
President arap Moi of Kenya was among the leaders at the African summit meeting who argued for a more flexible approach to South Africa as a result of its transition toward non-racial democracy.
The dropping of sanctions by the 51nation organization would constitute a prestigous acknowledgement of political change in South Africa that could encourage the United States and other European countries to follow suit. It would also open new markets in Africa for South African exports, which cost less than goods imported from Europe.
A report released at the O.A.U. meeting estimated that South Africa's commerce with the rest of the continent had reached $4 billion a year. South African officials say their country is already trading with every other African country but one. One official said he believed the exception was Libya. According to another official, two tiny African countries, Equatorial Guinea and Djibouti, failed to trade with South Africa last year.
Since August 1989, Mr. de Klerk has visited Mozambique, Zaire, Zambia, Ivory Coast, Namibia, Cape Verde, Madagascar, Morocco and Senegal. He is scheduled to visit Swaziland on Monday.
President de Klerk's trip to Kenya today has been described in the South African press as the biggest top-level visit undertaken to another African country since 1948, when the National Party came to power and proceeded to introduce apartheid.
President de Klerk, who was met on his arrival in Nairobi by President arap Moi, was accompanied by Foreign Minister Roelof F. Botha and three other Cabinet ministers responsible for trade and tourism, energy and agriculture.
The visit has more modest goals of establishing President de Klerk's credibility and defining areas for bilateral cooperation.

HEADLINE: New York City Pursues Early-Retirement Plan for Principals

BYLINE: By JOSEPH BERGER

 BODY:
New York City school officials are holding delicate negotiations on a plan to entice as many as one in five principals to retire within a year. The plan is intended to save on salaries and open slots for more black and Hispanic administrators.
Even proponents of the early-retirement plan, which would provide generous pension incentives, worry that it could churn up more turmoil in a system already bracing for hundreds of teacher layoffs and steep cuts in maintenance and supplies. 
 Replacing a principal is a drawn-out and intensely political process, often pitting parents and community school boards against each other. Once an appointment is finalized, it may take months for everyone to grow comfortable with the change.
But the plan's champions also see in the ripples of this upheaval an opportunity to allow more black and Hispanic assistant principals to become principals and more minority teachers to become assistant principals.
 
Worried About an Exodus
 In a system where more than 80 percent of the students are black, Hispanic or Asian, almost 70 percent of the principals and 75.8 percent of the assistant principals are white. That disparity is partly because administrators are drawn from the overwhelmingly white ranks of teachers and partly because there is a disproportionately low number of black and Hispanic candidates who have taken the required graduate courses and job tests.
Facing budget cuts of $505 million, the seven-member board began discussing early-retirement incentives for principals because such opportunities are already being offered to senior teachers to reduce salary costs and protect younger teachers from layoffs. Michael J. Petrides, the Staten Island representative to the Board of Education, said members were concerned about the patent unfairness of offering pension bonuses only to teachers.
Still, board members and Schools Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez were worried that an unlimited retirement offer would lead to an exodus of experienced school leaders. They talked about capping the number of those who would be allowed to leave at 15 percent for principals and 10 percent for assistant principals.
But Mr. Petrides and Donald Singer, the president of the Council of Supervisors and Adminstrators, which represents the principals, proposed a "controlled attrition" plan that would allow everyone who wished to retire to do so, but in stages that might minimize disruption. One group of principals would leave in September, another in February and another in September 1992.
 
200 Might Retire
 Mr. Singer said he believes as many as 200 of the 330 eligible principals would take advantage of the pension incentives, or one-fifth of the city's 988 principals. Other officials in his union estimated the number at closer to 130. Usually, 50 principals retire in a year, union officials said.
"The Chancellor hasn't said yes or no," Mr. Singer said. "He sees a lot of merit in the plan. He wants to see the fiscal implications."
Mr. Petrides said Mr. Fernandez, who would make the ultimate decision on the plan, liked it. But city officials, he said, worry that it would inflate the pensions of people who were planning to leave anyway.
The pension incentive would give professionals who are older than 55 or have 30 years of experience three extra years of work credit in computing their pensions. Principals earn from $61,452 to $74,139, and their pensions can reach 80 percent of their final year's salary.
 
'Can You Justify It at All?'
 The plan is already drawing fire from some of the city's public interest groups. Jeanne Frankl, executive director of the Public Education Association, an educational advocacy group, said that the plan's savings would be small, because the difference between starting and senior principals' salaries is not as great as that between a starting and senior teacher's.
"Since you cannot justify it on economic grounds, the question is, can you justify it at all?" she asked. "The real problem is that who goes and who stays is not decided on the basis of the system's needs."
James S. Vlasto, a spokesman for Mr. Fernandez, would confirm only that discussions were taking place with the principals' union, and said Mr. Fernandez has not stated what kind of plan he favors.
"The bottom line is we're not going to agree to anything that would be disruptive to the school system," he said.
 
Possible Savings in Millions
 A pension consultants' study, he said, calculated that the savings from an early-retirement plan for all supervisors could range from $1.7 million to $7.6 million.
Mr. Singer is clearly eager to see his plan enacted because it would make all his members happy: Retiring principals and assistant principals would get richer benefits, and other assistant principals would have opportunities for promotion.
 
Once Burned, Twice Cautious
 Responding to those who worry about turmoil because of a vacuum in leadership, he said, "I don't accept the premise that our assistant principals are not quite well trained to take on the responsibility of being principals."
"It's got to be good for the system or we're not going to do it," the union leader said. "We feel it would be a big plus for women and minorities."
That argument was similar to one made by Ninfa Segarra, the board's Bronx representative.
"The great risk is not to take advanatge of an opportunity for savings and for improving the demographics of the work force," she said. She said ways could be found to hold disruption to schools in check.
Despite his support for early retirement for principals, Mr. Petrides, a former dean at the College of Staten Island, said that his experience at the City University of New York led him to be cautious. The university, which used a retirement incentive plan in 1986, lost professors who were hard to replace and did not achieve the savings it sought or its affirmative action goals.
"It can in the long term be very positive," he said. "It can also be an absolute disaster."

HEADLINE: North Korea Agrees to Nuclear Plant Inspections

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, June 8

 BODY:
North Korea has told the International Atomic Energy Agency that it would sign an agreement allowing international inspection of all of its nuclear installations, including those that the United States said were part of a project to build nuclear weapons, the agency said today.
The announcement, which came after a meeting on Friday in Vienna between the agency's director, Hans Blix, and a group of senior North Korean diplomats, is potentially the first break in the standoff over the mysterious plant at Yongbyon, just north of the North Korean capital, Pyongyang. In the past North Korea has said it would allow international inspection only if the United States removed all of its nuclear weapons and its troops from South Korea. 
 A spokesman for the agency, Hans Friedrich Meyer, said by telephone from Vienna that the North appeared to drop that demand at the meeting. "Yesterday they said that they will sign the agreement after negotiations that they would limit to purely technical matters," Mr. Meyer said. He defined those matters as questions of inspection scheduling and procedures.
North Korea, however, has made no public statement about changes in its demands about the American weapons and military presence in the South. In Seoul, South Korea's Foreign Ministry said today that "reports from the International Atomic Energy Agency appear to be true." It added that "we will closely watch the process until North Korea finally signs the accords."
 
Sign of Growing Anxiety
 The apparent change in tone in Vienna is the latest sign that the Government of Kim Il Sung, North Korea's aging President, is growing increasingly worried about its diplomatic isolation.
 Less than two weeks ago, Pyongyang said it would "reluctantly" agree to apply for separate membership in the United Nations. Previously it had insisted that the North and South enter as one country, under the North's communist leadership, but the Soviet Union made it clear that it would no longer block South Korea from entering the United Nations independently. China's Prime Minister, Li Peng, is believed to have conveyed a similar message when he visited Pyongyang recently.
Mr. Meyer said he did not know what prompted the new statements by the North Koreans, who were represented by a special envoy, Chon Chung-kuk. But, he said, "There is obviously a lot of pressure on them."
In fact, in recent weeks the nuclear installation in Yongbyon has received considerable attention, much of it orchestrated in Washington and Tokyo, and it has increasingly become a diplomatic liability for the North.
 
Pressure to Permit Inspection
 Even Moscow, the North's traditional ally, has joined the United States in publicly warning the Government of Kim Il Sung that it had no choice but to yield to international inspection. Japan told North Korea again three weeks ago during talks in Beijing that it would refuse to begin diplomatic relations, or to provide any of the economic aid that would come with diplomatic recognition, until inspections were allowed.
North Korea in 1985 signed the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty, nu<--and that treaty obliges it to sign another accord,-->endnu allowing international inspection of all of its nuclear installations. But negotiations over that accord sputtered along for years with no resolution, ending last summer when North Korea insisted on the withdrawal of American nuclear weapons from the Korean peninsula.
In the past few months, American officials have circulated satellite photographs of the nuclear complex to government officials in several nations in Asia, to press the point that the plant could be capable of producing crude nuclear weapons within five years.
The Yongbyon complex includes several reactors and appears to be able to reprocess spent fuel into weapons-grade material.
The North has denied that the installation was designed to produce weaponry and says that it is solely for peaceful purposes. But there are no power lines emerging from the plant, meaning that it would have no use for electricity generation.

HEADLINE: Businesses Recoil at Energy Tax Increases in Albany Budget

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, June 8

 BODY:
State legislators referred to last year's $1.8 billion tax package as "The Big Ugly." But after passing new energy taxes this week that threaten to close factories and weaken businesses, they now may be facing something even uglier.
Much of the 65-day delay in passing this year's state budget was spent in a search for a tax compromise that would satisfy the state's need for revenues without unsettling its recession-racked economy. Unable to agree on raising the personal income tax or the gasoline tax, the Legislature by default settled on raising the tax paid by producers and importers of petroleum, and it created a similar tax on natural gas. The taxes would raise $600 million of the $1.2 billion in new taxes and fees included in the budget. 
Since January, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo has steadfastly rejected raising personal income-tax rates, arguing that an increase would harm the state's competitiveness, pushing businesses across its borders. But business leaders have found the energy taxes that were passed instead so abhorrent that Daniel B. Walsh, the president of the Business Council of New York State, made the startling statement this week that in his view "anything would be better" -- including an increase in the personal income tax.
Mr. Walsh and other business leaders agree that an income-tax increase would send negative signals about the business climate in a state already suffering from a reputation for high taxes. But they predict that the energy taxes will have an immediate effect on competitiveness and employment.
 
Companies Warn of Layoffs
 Officials at International Paper Company said this week that the new taxes may force them to padlock a turn-of-the-century mill in Corinth that employs 600 people. Alcoa raised the possibility of laying off 800 of the 1,500 workers at its aluminum fabricating plant in Massena. A spokesman for the Grumman Corporation, based in Long Island, which has laid off 11,000 workers in the last five years, said the company could face further reductions because of an increase estimated at $1.5 million in their tax bill.
The state's largest utilities warned that the taxes would force them to pass along significant cost increases -- more than 3 percent for purchasers of electricity and 9 percent for purchasers of natural gas -- to nonresidential customers. Oil companies, meanwhile, predict that motorists will see an increase of up to 6 cents a gallon at the gasoline pump.
And because the new taxes cover natural gas but not coal, environmentalists say they believe that the measures will encourage the use of the dirtiest fuel while discouraging use of the cleanest, contradicting the state's own energy policy.
"It's directly contrary to any air quality considerations," said Peter A. Bradford, chairman of the Public Service Commission. "It's not a forward-looking piece of legislation."
 
Cuomo Calls Taxes 'Lemon'
 Immediately after the tax package was passed last Monday night, legislative leaders announced they were willing to reconsider the energy taxes. And Mr. Cuomo made it clear he did not like the package, calling it "the political lemon of the year."
Mr. Walsh said he thought the taxes could be renegotiated if Mr. Cuomo follows through on his pledge to veto a significant amount of spending in the Legislature's $51.9 billion budget. Mr. Cuomo is expected to announce his vetoes -- possibly worth as much as $1 billion -- on Sunday or Monday.
The lawmakers raised the petroleum business tax, which was first imposed in 1984, by 5.2 cents per gallon, to 12.8 cents from 7.6 cents. They also created a new natural-gas tax of 51.2 cents per thousand cubic feet.
Those amounts include a 15 percent surcharge on corporate taxes imposed by the state last year. Residential users of petroleum and natural gas are exempt from the tax.
 
Approved Under Time Pressure
 The Democratic leaders of the Assembly and the Republican leaders of the Senate agree that the taxes will hurt businesses badly. But with political obstacles blocking other revenue-raising avenues, and with lawmakers under pressure to pass a budget after a record delay, the Legislature approved the taxes anyway.
And although the state's leaders have agreed to take a second look at the energy taxes, there has yet to be any softening of the obdurate positions that led to their adoption.
Mr. Cuomo continues to insist, as he has since late January, that a 10-cent-a-gallon increase in the gasoline tax would be the best way to raise needed revenues in a recession.
Assembly Speaker Mel Miller rejected the gasoline tax as regressive, while promoting a modest and temporary increase in the income tax.
The Senate majority leader, Ralph J. Marino, preferred a menu of nonrecurring revenue measures that were shot down by Mr. Cuomo and Mr. Miller as fiscally irresponsible. He has not proposed alternative taxes.
 
Politically Less Risky
 The effects of the energy taxes will eventually be felt by most customers through the costs passed along by the businesses and utilities that pay the tax, but the measures still pose less political risk than other taxes.
"It's a desired tax politically because people can't tell it's hitting them," said Donald J. Reeb, an economics professor and expert on tax policy from the State University of New York at Albany. "It's easier to disguise."
The impact of the taxes on manufacturing will be worsened by the fact that New York already ranks near the top of the country in the price of electricity and in taxes on energy. Industry officials said it would be difficult to pass new costs along without damaging their competitiveness.
"I don't know if the marketplace will bear it," said Michael L. Cooper, state public relations manager of Alcoa. "I think this tax will only serve to help our competitors, here and abroad."

HEADLINE: Without Fanfare, Blacks March to Greater High School Success

BYLINE: By JASON DePARLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PITTSBURGH, June 5

 BODY:
This week Kevin Wilson will slip into a cap and gown and count himself a part of one of black America's most encouraging trends: its ever-improving high school completion rate.
While the percentage of white or Hispanic students who finish high school or pass an equivalency exam has shown little improvement for two decades, the percentage of blacks who do so has been on a constant rise. The black completion rate has improved so much faster than that of whites and Hispanics that the experts are at a bit of a loss to explain it all.
 
Midnight Encouragement
 They cite the general broadening of the black middle class and blacks' historic emphasis on education. They note the contributions of early childhood programs like Head Start and the expanded availability of equivalency-exam programs for dropouts. They discuss changes in the economy that make a high school degree more of a necessity than ever.
Then they confess a bit of pure puzzlement. 
 "I'm not sure that if we added all these up, we'd account for the large improvements we've seen," said Aaron Pallas, an education professor at Michigan State University and a leading researcher on high school completion. "I don't think we've got a good explanation for it."
Mr. Wilson, an 18-year-old senior at Oliver High School in Pittsburgh, thinks of his father when trying to explain his success in school. A railroad laborer who never finished high school, the elder Mr. Wilson would sometimes wake his son at midnight and tell him to repeat out loud, "I am somebody."
"He'd say to get farther, to compete with all the white people and all, you've got to get an education," said Mr. Wilson, a quiet, intense youth who sports a whisper of a mustache and a class rank of 6 out of 182.
As good as the high school news may seem, it comes with caveats. Though graduation rates are up, test scores have not risen as fast, meaning many blacks may still be entering the job market without the skills they need. The percentage of black high school graduates who go on to college has declined. And some experts argue that the general progress for blacks may disguise the existence of an inner-city group that has been left behind.
More discouraging still are changes in the economy. With businesses demanding increasingly complex skills, some high school graduates may fare worse than dropouts did in the days when well-paying factories offered a brand of working-class salvation.
Still, when most headlines seem focused on the failures of teen-age blacks, cap-and-gown time at schools like Oliver High is a season of satisfaction. Last week the seniors there proudly presented themselves as scrape-by-class kids with middle-class dreams.
At 18, Charmaine Benson has all the demographic makings of a high school dropout: a mother who left school when pregnant at age 14 and has rarely worked; a father who was killed on the Pittsburgh streets when she was 2; a childhood in a housing project that leads Ms. Benson to make casual comments like, "Friend of mine, he got killed."
But for four years, she has been getting up at 5 A.M. to catch two city buses to go to a school across town, simply to escape the neighborhood influences.
 
Deceptive Statistics
 As for parental influence, Ms. Benson says bitterly that when she brings home good grades, her mother accuses her of thinkng she is better than everyone else. "When you work hard and stuff, you like somebody to tell you, 'That's nice -- keep it up,' " she said. "She's not the type."
Mr. Wilson, whose father was stabbed to death in an argument three years ago, will enroll at Washington and Jefferson College in Washington, Pa. He hopes to become a doctor.
The good news about declining drop-out rates seems to fly in the face of a nationally perceived crisis, as some districts have reported drop-out rates as high as 40 and 50 percent. Part of the explanation has to do with what experts call the notorious unreliability of local statistics.
Individual districts often count as dropouts students who transfer to other school systems without letting them know. And they have no way of gauging the percentage of students who pass a high school equivalency test after leaving school. At the same time, some districts are under pressure to report artificially low figures, for political reasons.
 
Closing the White-Black Gap
 A more reliable gauge of educational achievement comes from the Census Bureau's annual Current Population Survey, which interviews about 55,000 households about education and other things.
In 1970, 27.9 percent of the blacks surveyed said they had not finished high school or passed an equivalency test, compared with 13.2 percent for whites. By 1989, the black rate for non-completion had been cut by more than half, to 13.8 percent -- not far from the 12.4 percent for whites.
But the numbers for whites include responses of Hispanics, driving the drop-out rates up. The Hispanic dropout rate in 1989 was 33 percent; the figure for non-Hispanic whites, to be published later this year, is expected to be below 10 percent. Researchers say the high numbers of Hispanics who do not complete high school include many immigrants, some of whom come as teens and never enroll.
In the past decade, the gap between black and white performance on achievement tests has also been narrowed.
 
Hiding the Good News
 In the 1974-75 school year, 8 percent of 17-year-old black students were reading at an "adept" level, the third-highest of the four categories used by the National Assessment of Educational Progress, a nationwide test. By the 1987-88 school year, that percentage had more than tripled, to 26 percent. The white rate, while little improved, was still significantly higher, at 46 percent.
Oddly enough, the good news about the black progress is one that some educators resist advertising, for fear that it would undermine efforts to bring increased attention and money to the schools.
When the National Center for Education Statistics first published a report on dropout rates in 1989, researchers drafted a news release that highlighted the black progress. But aides to Education Secretary Lauro F. Cavazos asked that it be reworked, to stress instead the continuing problems of Hispanic Americans, said a department source familiar with both drafts.
"They still thought dropouts were a big problem, and they didn't want people to think that we had solved the problem," the source said.
 
Despite Diploma, Low Earnings
 The figures on black college enrollment are less encouraging. The percentage of black high school graduates who go on to college dropped to 28 percent in 1988 from 30 percent in 1978, a dip that may simply reflect the fact that more and more blacks are finishing high school. The percentage of white high school graduates enrolled in college rose to 39 percent in 1988 from 31 percent in 1978, according to the National Center for Education Statistics.
While black men and women finish high school at approximately the same rate, many more women go on to college. In 1988, 443,000 black men were college students, while 687,000 black women were.
And studies show that a high school degree alone is an increasingly poor guarantor of a good living, since businesses are requiring ever more skills.
Sheldon Danziger and Gregory Acs, researchers at the University of Michigan, found that the percentage of black high school graduates with low earnings more than doubled between 1973 and 1987, rising from 16 percent to 38 percent. The researchers defined as low earners anyone making less than $12,000 a year, in figures adjusted to 1987 value.
In Pittsburgh, at the same time the closing of the steel mills means there is less to lure students out of school, the development of a dizzying array of special programs means there is more to keep them in.
This is particularly true at Oliver, where 30 percent of the students are poor enough to get free lunches and about half have been identified as having problems with family, the law, or drugs and alcohol that put them at risk of dropping out.
There is a day care center where student moms can leave their infants. There are small, after-school classes to entice students who have dropped out. For those who want to learn a trade, there is a cosmetology lab, a printing shop, a professional-style kitchen and an engine-repair shop.
"If you really want to get a high school education, you can get one," said Andy King, the school principal.
But even the school's special programs cannot account for the mysterious determination of students like Ms. Benson, who hustles past the boarded windows of a public housing project each morning to catch the 6:18 bus.
 
Passing On Her Lessons
 Three days a week, she again crosses Pittsburgh in order to get to a job at Roy Rogers. She bags hamburgers and hustles to make the 9:18 bus home. Last summer, she worked a second job doing clerical work in a program put together by local businesses to guarantee jobs for high school students.
Later this month, one of Ms. Benson's teachers will drive her outside the city for only the second time in her life, taking her to the summer session at Lock Haven University in Lock Haven, Pa., where in four years she hopes to emerge as a elementary school teacher.
Asked how much she would like to someday earn, she pauses, and then settles on the too-good-to-be-true figure of $24,000. "That'd be about $2,000 a month, wouldn't it?" she said, slightly in awe.
Asked where her drive comes from, this surprising woman offers a surprising answer.
"I think TV had a lot to do with it," she said. "They say it's bad for you, but I think it can help.
"Like if you watch, 'Lifestyles of the Rich and Famous,' then you want to be rich, too."

HEADLINE: GULF WAR AFFECTS FATE OF HOSTAGES

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 7

 BODY:
The invasion of Kuwait and war that followed created opportunities and obstacles for the release of Western hostages still held in Lebanon, Administration officials and independent experts on international terrorism say.
But despite the positive signals, unfulfilled demands of the captors continue to block any release of the 12 Western hostages, including six Americans, held by the Shiite Muslim Party of God, an Iranian-backed organization believed to be the umbrella group for the kidnappers. 
 On one level, the Persian Gulf crisis has removed some of the obstacles in the way of a hostage release.
First, in the confusion of Iraq's invasion of Kuwait in August, a group of prisoners whose fate was tied to that of the hostages was freed. In 1983, 17 men were imprisoned in Kuwait for conducting a terrorist campaign against the American and French embassies and public buildings and oil installations.
The primary condition for the release of some of the Western hostages was freedom for the 15 of those men who were still in prison at the time of the invasion. Most if not all of them have since returned to Lebanon.
 
Guarantee Against Retaliation
 Second, a recent Syrian-Lebanese treaty of cooperation gives Syria greater control over Lebanese affairs, and, therefore, over the captors. Despite the promises by the Lebanese leadership to disarm all militia forces in the country, Syria has allowed the Party of God to keep its arms.
One of the main concerns of the hostage-holders has been that they be given some sort of guarantee that there will be no retaliation against them if they lose the protective cover of the hostages. The fact that they can remain armed is seen as an indication that the kidnappers retain considerable influence in the country and might be allowed to operate even if they did not hold the hostages.
An expert on terrorism, Brian M. Jenkins, said: "The captors still have powerful incentives in keeping the hostages. They provide the groups with prestige, give them an identity and leverage with their Iranian sponsors. Otherwise, they're just another armed faction in Lebanon."
The Bush Administration has said that Iran has enough influence over the captors to force a release if it wants to, and has linked an improvement in relations with Teheran to a hostage release. In recent months, a number of senior Iranian officials, including President Hashemi Rafsanjani, and Foreign Minister Ali Akbar Velayati, have said in public statements and private meetings that the hostages are a liability and should be released.
 
End of Diplomatic Isolation
 But Iran is driven by two different impulses regarding the hostages. President Rafsanjani's effort to reach out to the West and other countries in the region at an oil conference last week in Isfahan shows that he feels confident of his strong position at home and could absorb criticism from radical elements within Iran's leadership if he were to take action on the hostages.
On the other hand, Iran has already broken out of its diplomatic and economic isolation by successfully improving relations with Europe, Japan and its Arab neighbors, and does not need a relationship with the United States.
"The war made it easier for Iran to release hostages if it wants to, but Iran does not have any particular incentive to move on the hostage front," said an Administration official who closely follows this issue. "They are moving out of their isolation without us."
Complicating matters is the fact that Iran's influence over the captors may be waning.
 
Israeli Release of Prisoners
 "The Iranians still have influence but it has probably dissipated as Rafsanjani has grown stronger," the official continued. "The Hezbollah don't trust him, because they know that in his eyes they're expendable."
With the freedom of the prisoners in Kuwait, the key condition for a hostage release has become Israel's release of Palestinian prisoners and about 300 pro-Iranian Lebanese prisoners, including Sheik Abdul-Karim Obeid, a fundamentalist Shiite cleric who was abducted by Israeli paratroopers in 1989.
Last month, there was a fluury of statements by Israeli officials and members of the Party of God about a possible swap that could pave the way for the release of the Western hostages. Israel said that it would free the Lebanese prisoners and 40 Palestinians captured in Lebanon in return for the repatriation of seven missing servicemen, at least two of whom are still believed to be alive.
The Party of God replied that it was willing to trade two Israelis it is holding in exchange for Arabs held in Israel. But Abbas Musawi, a Shiite cleric who is the group's newly elected leader, said Israel's reluctance to include other Palestinian prisoners in the proposed exchange was hampering a deal.
In recent weeks, some Iranian officials have linked the hostage release to the settlement of financial claims against the United States. But Administration officials do not believe that the claims issue is crucial. They say that the resolution of claims by both sides in the wake of the 1979 seizure of hostages at the American Embassy in Teheran is advancing smoothly at a special tribunal at the Hague.

HEADLINE: Under Harassment, Many Palestinians in Kuwait See No Choice but to Leave

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: KUWAIT CITY, June 8

 BODY:
Facing ruthless police harassment, enforced unemployment and the withdrawal of social services, many of the Palestinians who stayed here after the Iraqi invasion say they now have no choice but to leave Kuwait.
Although the Government has not gone so far as to openly declare that it wants most of the Palestinians to go, at almost every opportunity this country squeezes them harder. In conversations with Government officials, foreign diplomats, Kuwaiti citizens and the Palestinians themselves, nobody disputes that the goal is to drive them out. 
 "Things are bad here every day," said a youth named Jihad, pressing ice-cold oranges into juice for a visitor at a hamburger joint in the Palestinian district known as Hawali.
Jihad said he expected before long to move to Jordan, where he hopes he can enlist in the army. He said that he was detained and roughed up by the police a few days ago, that his brother was wasting away in prison, and that two hours earlier a Kuwaiti soldier had come in and struck one of the waiters. His father, he said, is unemployed.
 
Recurring Themes
 In almost every conversation with Palestinians the same themes recur. Only occasionally does one meet a Palestinian who plans to stay.
One of them is Saleh Ali Odhman, a gap-toothed 65-year-old dirtied by a day of labor as a mechanic for hire. His workshop was destroyed in the invasion, but he says he can still get work, perhaps because he carries a passport from Syria, which opposed Iraq in the war to expel the Iraqis from Kuwait.
"I am come here to work, to eat, to live, happy," he said in English. "Why I make trouble? If you haven't any problem, you don't break law. If you are quality gentleman in your life, nobody ask you anything."
But other Palestinians, especially those with passports from Jordan and Iraq, say they and their friends are continuously bullied by the authorities or by ordinary Kuwaitis.
 
Brutality Investigated
 The Government's chief prosecutor said today that his office was actively investigating several cases of police brutality and civil rights abuses, and has some police officers in jail awaiting charges and trials.
"We are investigating not just one person but many, including soldiers and policemen," the official, Hamed al-Othman, said in an interview with three Western reporters. He did not provide details of the investigations or say when he expects trials.
Mr. Othman defended the police, saying, "There are a lot of police who do their jobs correctly." He said that he expected the successful prosecution of police brutality cases to serve as a powerful deterrent to further abuses, and that for this reason "we are doing our best to get these cases to the court as fast as possible."
 
Some Turn to U.S. Embassy
 He promised to protect anybody who comes forward with evidence of crimes by the military, the police or Kuwaiti vigilantes. But the Palestinians interviewed said they were too afraid to take their complaints to the Government.
Instead, some of them go to the United States Embassy, and journalists and human rights workers have found evidence that at least some of their accounts of horrible beatings are true.
In a speech in Kuwait today, the American Ambassador, Edward W. Gnehm Jr., pointedly urged the nation not to tolerate "hatred and prejudice" against the Palestinians.
"No matter how emotionally difficult it is," he said, "Kuwaitis must now champion justice and fairness for all people in Kuwait in the same way the entire world stood for those principles for Kuwaitis. To do otherwise will give Saddam Hussein a victory of evil proportions."
Of nearly 400,000 Palestinians who lived here when Iraq invaded, more than half left during the occupation, and they are not being allowed back. The Kuwaitis, who say the Palestinians sympathized or actively collaborated with the Iraqis, are so angry about this that they scarcely care that vital jobs held by Palestinians in the oil, banking and other industries are not being done now. They seem to believe that Egyptians, Indians, Syrians, Filipinos and other expatriates can be recruited to do most of those jobs.
 
Fears of an Uprising
 But the Kuwaitis also recognize that the expulsions must be handled carefully. Many people worry out loud that if the pressure is too severe or too violent, another uprising could erupt in Kuwait like the one that has shaken the occupied territories in Israel.
Although most people, even Palestinians, think a revolt is unlikely, they do not consider it impossible. People say the occasional gunfire heard at night in Hawali shows that the Palestinians and the Kuwaitis alike have armed themselves from the hurriedly abandoned Iraqi arsenals.
Mr. Othman's comments today were clearly intended to reduce tensions. So was the Government's move this week to call on all senior police officers -- about 80 people with the rank of colonel or higher -- to submit resignations. The purpose of the move was not explained, but the most common theory is that the Interior Ministry wanted to exert more discipline over an unruly police force that has been accused time and again of torturing Palestinians.
The Government also announced this week that expatriates, including Palestinians, would be allowed to withdraw retirement savings accounts. The money has not yet been paid, but it would make it easier to leave the country.
On the half-deserted streets of Hawali, far more people plan to go than say they will stay. The consensus here is that only about 80,000 of the 170,000 Palestinians remaining will end up staying permanently.
 
Leaving Can Be Difficult
 Even those who are ready to flee cannot easily do so. The cost of air travel is prohibitive for many, and they are refused transit visas from the Saudis, who control the overland route to Jordan. Many hold travel documents from places like Egypt where they are not welcome. And Kuwait itself refuses to issue exit papers quickly to many who want to leave right away. Some say Kuwait wants to arrest and prosecute more Palestinians. Others say they will be allowed out only after they spend all their savings or sell their property and businesses at distress prices.
Many Palestinians are living on their savings or scraping by with odd jobs, but the screws are being tightened.
A week ago, as more and more Kuwaiti landlords returned from exile, Palestinians began hearing demands for rent. Even those who can afford to pay are sometimes told that their leases will not be honored.
Palestinians who took car license plates from the Iraqis are unable to obtain new Kuwaiti plates, so they cannot leave Hawali to shop in the well-stocked stores elsewhere in the city. And the Government is canceling their free medical care and schooling.

HEADLINE: Parade Unfurls Symbols of Patriotism in the Capital

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 8

 BODY:
This bastion of worsted summer wools and diplomatic demeanor tossed off its suit jacket and let out a yell today, glorying at length and en masse in a celebration of the nation's lopsided triumph over the army of Iraq.
Thousands of people jammed a route studded with patriotic symbols -- from the Capitol past the Washington Monument and Lincoln Memorial, then across the Potomac River to the Pentagon -- to witness a huge parade of American armed might. 
 The National Park Service estimated the crowd at about 200,000. That was far below the organizers' prediction of 1.4 million, but still a large crowd for Washington, said William Spruill, a Park Service spokesman.
 
A $12 Million Festival
 It was the largest military exhibition in the capital since the Supreme Allied Commander of World War II, Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, led a parade down Pennsylvania Avenue after the war ended, and it was the most impressive display of war technology in recent history.
Once pegged at $8 million, the cost of the celebration, including the parade and display, rose sharply in recent days, to more than $12 million. The Defense Department is picking up $7 million of the bill, with the rest to be paid by a group of 20 veterans' organizations that sponsored the parade.
It began quietly early this morning when President Bush laid a wreath at the Tomb of the Unknowns in Arlington National Cemetery, then eulogized the 147 American servicemen and women who died in the Persian Gulf war.
Moved close to tears for the second time in days, Mr. Bush said in a quavering voice that Kuwait is free today because "we dared risk our most precious asset -- our sons and daughters, our brothers and sisters, our husbands and wives -- the finest troops any country has ever had."
Later, at 11:39 A.M., a single F-117 Stealth fighter streaked overhead the length of the Mall, kicking off a procession of troops, tanks, missiles, helicopters, jets, boats, artillery, armored trucks and even an unmanned reconnaissance aircraft. For two hours, they rode, marched, flew, clanked and were towed down broad Constitution Avenue past a reviewing stand where Mr. Bush, Vice President Dan Quayle, Defense Secretary Dick Cheney and 250 others watched.
The celebration also featured a display of military equipment along the Mall, a picnic for troops and their families, and a U.S.O. show and fireworks display in the evening.
 
Washington Meets Mainstream
 Amid a crush of spectators clad in shorts and tank-tops that bristled with portable video cameras and cold drinks, Mr. Bush and his entourage sported the only conservative ties and designer dresses to be seen. For the briefest of moments, powerful and self-important Washington seemed not all that different from mainstream Wichita and Walla Walla.
"That's why I came here, because I'm a patriot," said William Spence, who traveled from Los Angeles to see the parade. "We're patriots paying tribute to other patriots."
John Redding, a 47-year-old computer scientist from Rockville, Md., said: "People want to see the hardware -- the Tomahawks, the Patriot missiles, the tanks. These were exciting heroes of the war."
There were dissenters. In Lafayette Square across from the White House, perhaps 150 demonstrators railed over loudspeakers against the war and what they called American militarism.
"We do not want the media to portray the picture that there was universal consent about this genocidal war or this fascist military spectacle taking place out here," said one speaker, Sahu Barron of the National Coalition to Stop U.S. Intervention in the Middle East. "This is farce beyond imagination."
A sprinkling of other protesters, some carrying flags plastered with anti-war slogans, filtered into the parade throng. But they were quickly lost in a sea of American flags waved by the thousands of spectators and emblazoned on thousands more T-shirts and posters.
More than 8,000 troops, many newly returned from the gulf region and given a hasty refresher course in marching, made the walk of more than two miles from Capitol Hill to the Pentagon. They were led by Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf, the head of the Pentagon's Central Command, who was outfitted in the blotchy sand-colored camouflage fatigues that he wore when he headed the war effort in Saudi Arabia.
General Schwarzkopf stopped at the reviewing stand and saluted Mr. Bush. The President later leaned down and asked him, "Why don't these guys carry their rifles?" The General's answer could not be heard.
Several blocks south of where Mr. Bush reviewed the parade, a bold little girl ran out into the middle of the street. She handed a small flag to Vice Adm. Stanley R. Arthur, who commanded American naval forces in the war zone and led Navy personnel in the parade. Similarly emboldened, another child ran up and handed him a yellow flower.
Before the parade had advanced another hundred feet, enough children had run up that Admiral Arthur's left fist clutched a brace of flags and flowers. Behind him, his four staff officers tried hard to look serious and not break stride as they accepted flowers and flags from still more children.
Although the cost of the celebration ballooned in recent weeks, few in the crowd seemed bothered by the expense. "I think people deserve this," said Robert Nash, 30, a military engineer. "They deserve to celebrate."
One who differed was Ada Carter, a real estate agent from Washington.
"I think it's extreme, with the economy like it is," she said. "This is very extravagant when half of the country is unemployed. There are better ways of showing our appreciation."

H. Norman Schwarzkopf, commander of Operation Desert Storm, on the reviewing stand yesterday. (Photographs by Paul Hosefros/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Sanctions on Iraq Exact a High Price From Poor

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BAGHDAD, June 8

 BODY:
After 10 months of economic blockade, Iraq has been transformed from a land where oil bought guns and food and status to an outcast country where no airlines fly, no grain is bought, no spare parts fill the storerooms.
With apparently limited seepage, the international sanctions imposed after its occupation of Kuwait have sealed Iraq from the outside world. 
 In doing so, they have brought strong pressure on the Baghdad Government to offer some political concessions to its Kurdish minority, promise a kind of democracy to its people and show a readiness to comply with international demands for the destruction of its chemical, nuclear and biological warfare potential.
But the sanctions have not fulfilled another underlying objective: President Saddam Hussein is still in power, his elite is entrenched around him, and he shows no sign of relinquishing the powerful grip whose sinews -- the secret police, the army and the Baath Party -- have sustained his 12-year dictatorship.
 
Looking to the Elite
 The debate that seizes many Iraqis and foreign specialists, thus, is this: will the blockade ultimately force action by the Iraqi elite, who are seen in the United States as the only group strong enough to force Mr. Hussein out? Or will the sanctions continue to do what they have done so far -- bring yet more hardship to the poor while causing only modest inconvenience to the rich and powerful?
The argument advanced in the West is that sanctions and isolation will bring such deprivation and discontent that the loyalists surrounding the President will conclude that their only means of survival is to be rid of him.
But that theory is challenged by the fact that the senior figures viewed in the West as potential agents of change are inextricably linked to the Iraqi leader by kinship and political debt.
"The sanctions don't affect the regime," said a middle-ranking civil servant who let it be known to a reporter that he opposed the President's rule. "They have money, cars. They can buy their way out. The poor cannot."
"The big shots in the army and the party still have their Mercedes and villas," said a foreign specialist here. "That's why they prefer to be close to Saddam. If he goes, they do not know what the internal situation would be."
In practical terms, the sanctions have divided Iraqis into two groups: those who depend on limited and often inadequate rations fdistributed at low prices by the authorities, and those who can afford to augment the rations with purchases on the open market.
Within the ration system, said the Trade Minister, Mohammed Mehdi Saleh, "rice is scarce and cooking oil is one quarter of what was available before."
"The commodities available on the market have high prices," he said. A kilogram of open-market rice now costs the equivalent of $15 at the official exchange rate. Before the conflict, the price was equivalent to 72 cents.
Meat prices have doubled, Baghdad residents say. A liter bottle of mineral water costs the equivalent of $3.
The private market is supplied largely by truck from Jordan along the broad highway between the two countries that represents its only lifeline save for the smugglers' trails from Iran, Turkey and Syria. But all those routes seem to supply principally Iraqis able to satisfy expensive tastes. Over the past two weeks, a reporter traveling in the country saw cola from Syria and beer from Lebanon and Jordan in private stores, while lines formed outside the Government's ration stores for staples like flour, rice and cooking oil.
Sanctions have been lifted on food and medicines. But according to United Nations Security Council resolutions, Iraq must meet two principal demands to qualify for the full lifting of sanctions: dismantling of chemical, biological, nuclear and ballistic missile capability and agreeing to pay a large percentage of its oil revenues to Kuwait in war reparations.
But since the United Nations sanctions monitoring committee has denied an Iraqi request to export $1 billion worth of oil to purchase food and medicines, and since Western governments, including those of the United States, Britain and Switzerland, have thus far refused to unfreeze Iraqi assets worth another $1 billion, Iraqi officials say, Baghdad cannot afford to make the purchases that it is technically allowed.
"Iraq is by and large cooperating in the military demands," said a senior United Nations official here, but has balked at a United Nations suggestion that it pay 30 per cent of oil revenues in reparations.
In any event, said the Information Minister, Hamed Youssef Hammadi, "how can you get Iraq to pay war reparations while it is prevented from exporting oil?"
Possibly the most critical impact of the sanctions has been on Iraq's annual wheat purchases of 2.3 million tons, accounting for around two-thirds of the needs of a country used to importing three-quarters of its overall food requirements.
 
Meager Harvest Predicted
 These days, as combines reap the wheat crop of the plains north of Baghdad, agricultural specialists say Iraq's own harvest will be lower than usual, making the imports more important than ever at a time when Iraq is least equipped to pay for them. Baghdad has struck deals for a total of 1.7 million tons of wheat from Australia, Canada and Thailand, but all three deals are conditional on Baghdad's securing access to frozen assets in the U.S. and elsewhere to finance them.
That seems to mean a crisis is approaching. The local harvest is estimated at between 800,000 and 850,000 tons, possibly three months' supply under the ration system.
But Iraqi officials refuse to say what their overall food stocks are, considering that a strategic secret in a war of nerves with the West, pitting Baghdad's appeals to Western consciences against the Western urge to force President Hussein's ouster.
"Where is the humanity in all this? Where are the American human rights?" asked Mustafa Fayek, reconstruction manager of a power-plant here, echoing themes heard frequently among those close to the authorities. "The war is over. We are meeting the allies' demands. So why make our children starve and die in hospitals with no medicine?"
For some, possibly with some wishful thinking, the sanctions have built a hope that the blockade will deepen Iraqis' resolve to resist Western demands.
"I think this is going to stiffen the Iraqis," said Information Minister Hammadi. That suggested a protracted confronation with those who imposed the sanctions.
"In South Africa and Rhodesia, sanctions ultimately had an effect," said a senior United Nations official, "but it took time."

HEADLINE: Woman Slain Walking Her Dogs Near Central Park

BYLINE: By DENNIS HEVESI

 BODY:
A woman walking her dogs near Central Park at dawn yesterday was stabbed to death by a deranged ex-convict wielding a carving knife, the police said.
The screams of the woman, Alexis Welsh, brought many of her neighbors on the Upper West Side running. As one neighbor sat by the 30-year-old woman's side, two others stalked a suspect into Central Park, where they pointed out the tall, bedraggled man to officers in a patrol car. 
 At least 20 neighbors poured out of their homes in the minutes after the 5:30 A.M. attack to offer help.
The stabbing occurred in front of 31 West 69th Street, on the north side of a tree-lined street of stately brownstones between Columbus Avenue and Central Park West.
Mrs. Welsh, of 143 West 69th Street, a former Rockette who worked for the Ogilvy & Mather advertising agency and attended Fordham University, had been on her way to join a group of acquaintances who walked dogs together in the park's early-morning calm, some neighbors said, although the police said it was not clear if she was going to or from the park.
"She was stabbed in the neck and back with a carving knife with an 11-inch blade," a police spokesman, Sgt. Edward J. Burns, said. "The knife was recovered from the victim's back."
The suspect was identified as Kevin McKiever, 34, an unemployed man who used to live at 6 West 103d Street. Residents of that building said Mr. McKiever had been evicted two years ago. They recalled him as an erratic, sometimes violent man. One neighbor displayed a court order of protection bearing Mr. McKiever's name, and said he had stabbed her two years ago and set her apartment door on fire.
 
'Did Jail Time'
 During a news conference yesterday afternoon at the 20th Precinct station house on West 82d Street, the Police Department's Chief of Patrol, David W. Scott, said Mr. McKiever "did jail time" starting last September in a case that "concerned burglary, arson and assault." Chief Scott did not say whether those charges were in connection with the attack on Mr. McKiever's former neighbor two years ago.
"He is involved in some sort of program that seems to us to be an out-patient program," Chief Scott said, but he said he did not know if it involved psychogical counseling.
The chief said Mr. McKiever has been charged with murder, assault, attempted robbery, criminal possession of a weapon and resisting arrest in the killing of Mrs. Welsh.
Chief Scott said Mr. McKiever had been charged with robbery based on the accounts of Mrs. Welsh's neighbors who said she told them, "he has my bag." As of yesterday afternoon, no pocketbook had been found.
Mr. McKiever put up a struggle as he was arrested by Sgt. Frank Ziede and Police Officer Richard Kenney, the chief said.
 
'Windows Pop Up' at a Scream
 "There was blood on his hands," Officer Kenney said.
The chief praised the community, saying seven callers to 911 described the suspect and two neighbors followed Mr. McKiever into the park.
A woman who has lived across the street from the crime scene for 30 years said: "This block has a reputation for helping. When a scream is heard, the windows pop up."
The woman, who asked not to be identified, said she was sitting on her terrace, as she does often, listening to the birds, when the peace was pierced by the screams of the victim: "Help me, Help me, I don't want to die." Soon after, she said, "There were people running all over the street from every direction."
Maddy Tarnofsky, a lawyer who lives on 69th Street, said, "The people on the block behaved valiantly." Ms. Tarnofsky said she knew Mrs. Welsh because they both were part of an "informal community" of dog owners who frequently meet in the park. "We don't necessarily know each other's names," she said, "but we know each other's dogs."
She said Mrs. Welsh was walking her cocker spaniels, Pizza and Pepperoni. It is not unusual for the dog walkers to be out so early, Ms. Tarnofsky said. Usually, people walk alone to the park and meet there, she said.
 
Man Walking 'Very Nonchalantly'
 Bob Pellettieri, a stockbroker who lives at 31 West 69th Street said he was awakened by a woman's screams.
"Those screams were blood-curdling," he said. "I could tell someone was in real trouble."
Clad only in his shorts and a tank top, he ran outside. "I was the first to get to her," he said.
Mrs. Welsh was lying in a pool of blood beside the wrought-iron railing in front of his brownstone. "She was very conscious," he said. "She was moaning, crying out."
At that point, Mr. Pellettieri said, he looked up and, 50 feet away, saw a tall man, wearing a greasy red down jacket, slowly walking away. He was walking "very nonchalantly," Mr. Pellettieri said. "That's what made me notice him."
"I was going to take after him but I didn't want to tackle some innocent bystander," Mr. Pellettieri said.
Just then, Alex Ross, an advertising art director who also lives at 31 West 69th Street, ran out of the building. Mr. Pellettieri said he turned to Mr. Ross and said, "Follow that guy," and Mr. Ross did. Another unidentified neighbor joined the pursuit.
Later, Mr. Pellettieri said, Mr. Ross returned and told him that he had followed the man into the park, maintaining a distance of about 20 feet.
 
Died of Blood Loss
 Several blocks away, inside the park, Mr. Ross flagged down the patrol car, then led the officers to the man in the red jacket. Mr. McKiever was arrested beside the bocce courts near the Sheeps Meadow.
Among the 20 or so neighbors who came out to the street was a doctor, who stayed by Mrs. Welsh until the ambulance came. "There was really nothing that could be done," Mr. Pellettieri said.
Mrs. Welsh died at 11:10 A.M. at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center at Amsterdam Avenue and 114th Street. She had stab wounds in the neck, back, head and buttocks, a St. Luke's spokeswoman, Phyllis Goodman, said. "She went right into surgery," Ms. Goodman said, "but she just bled to death."
A police spokesman, Lieut. Robert Nardoza, said Mrs. Welsh's husband, Christopher, was an employee of a Wall Street brokerage.
 
Married Three Years
 A neighbor in Mrs. Welsh's building, who asked not to be identified, said the victim was a former Rockette at Radio City Music Hall. The neighbor said the Welshes were married about three years ago.
"She's a lovely person, very friendly," the woman said. "She was a good neighbor. Anything that went on in the building, she helped out. At Christmas time, she'd help decorate the lobby." The neighbor said Mrs. Welsh had gotten the two small dogs only recently.
Residents of the building where Mr. McKiever had lived on West 103d Street said they had seen him using crack and stalking angrily around the neighborhood after he was evicted.
The neighbor who showed the protective order, Sarah Kearney, said Mr. McKiever "was a crazy, a real fruitcake."
"He kicked in my door," she said. "He broke into my window and stabbed me with an ice pick. He poured gasoline and tried to light up my door."

HEADLINE: The World;
Iran Gingerly Tries a Bit of Pragmatism

BYLINE: By YOUSSEF M. IBRAHIM

DATELINE: TEHERAN, Iran

 BODY:
AFTER 12 years of turmoil and war, Iran appears relaxed. Mayors are busy cleaning up their cities. Merchants are doing a sometimes thriving business, and the Teheran airport has a new green "nothing to declare" door, through which people can enter the country less intimidated than they once were made to feel.
In such respects, the heirs to the militant Islamic revolutionary regime of the late Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini appear confident enough to ease some of the rigor of their revolution. Yet for Iranians, life remains a struggle. Personal freedoms are severely curtailed. Through systematic segregation at work and in public places, women remain the second-class citizens that they became in Ayatollah Khomeini's years. And with an average income of $100 a month, the Iranian middle class is straining in the face of 40 percent inflation rates. 
 During a week-long visit to this country, so many contradictory signals of liberalization and militancy were apparent that the only judgment that appeared safe was that of a West European ambassador who said the regime has reached "the limits of its contradictions." Iran is at a point, this diplomat said, where pragmatists will have to face down militants in order to carry out further reforms and retain those already introduced.
The changes from the dour, abstemious and xenophobic days of Ayatollah Khomeini are, indeed, often dramatic. This month the Mayor of Isfahan is throwing a big party to celebrate the city's 400th anniversary, an occasion for which the city's captivating ancient architecture has been transformed into a majestic sight with specially illuminated bridges and flowing fountains.
Foreign visitors can exchange their currency at what used to be the black market rate -- a rate that makes Iran one of the cheapest countries for a foreigner to pass some time in. At night, in the mountains framing Teheran, tiny restaurants glitter in niches perched over waterfalls, serving grilled meats with rice and yogurt for less than $5.
 
Next Elections: 1992
 Fereidun Fesharaki, a program director for the East-West Center, a Federally financed institution devoted to Asian and Pacific affairs that is located at the University of Hawaii, visits his native Iran every year and believes that the signs point to progress toward moderation. "What is done is actually less important than what is said," he remarked recently in Isfahan.
The next parliamentary elections are scheduled for April 1992; among diplomats, there is a consensus that if supporters of the current President, Hojatolislam Hashemi Rafsanjani, carry those elections, the process of liberalization will go forward. But many Iranians from the heavily watched and burdened middle class warn that when it comes to personal freedoms, particularly for women, Mr. Rafsanjani is not much more liberal than his fellow clergymen. Generally, the issues of women and human rights are not high on the agenda in plans for changing Iran's political and social systems.
Indeed, the radical fringe of the regime can still make a difference. A few weeks ago, the Government invited all exiles with skill or money to return to Iran to freely invest, but a few days after a meeting in Washington between Government officials and exiled Iranian businessmen, the Ayatollah's son, Ahmad, spoke up. In an interview in Teheran, he opposed the return of the exiles, who he described as having been thieves and exploiters under the fallen Shah.
Summing it up, a middle-class Iranian woman said over tea at her apartment, "One of the greatest gifts God gave the Iranians is the ability to adapt to almost anything." Speaking of present conditions, she added that "a few things are better."
Streets, for one thing, are cleaner, now that the Government has been selecting mayors who will address local problems. The other day Teheran's mayor told shopkeepers to paint their stores and do it in different colors -- or have the city do it and charge them. It prompted residents to joke about "Technicolor Teheran.".
To find the money for such programs, the authorities are bending some columns of orthodoxy erected by the Islamic regime that came to power in 1979. In Persian, one method is called "khodyari," which roughly translates as "voluntary sacrifices." This refers, for example, to the extraction of money from parents to improve schools that are supposed to offer a free education to every child. In addition to paying their taxes, merchants "donate" money to the municipality to beautify their environment.
Still, businessmen say they have had a good year and expect things to get better next year. One manager who owns an import-export business and a travel agency said both ventures did well in the fiscal year that ended in March, even though exchange rates were chaotic.
In the area of personal freedoms, however, reform has not manifested itself at all. Iran is still a police state and the advocates of liberalization appear to have left this important field to the militants.
