HEADLINE: The World;
In the Trade Wars, China Has Learned Guerilla Tactics

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN

DATELINE: BEIJING

 BODY:
WHEN a truck from China pulled into the neighboring Portuguese enclave of Macao late last year, American officials happened to be on hand to take a peek at the cargo. They were surprised to find Chinese-manufactured ski jackets bearing labels reading "Made in Macao."
Business executives in both China and Macao were clearly trying to evade the limits imposed by China's quota of garment exports to the United States. American officials say that it was one incident in a pattern of unfair trading by China, and that in 1990, such practices brought China $2.5 billion in extra sales to the United States that were not counted in the bilateral trade statistics. "They got away with this for years and no one did anything about it," said an American official. "They thought they could continue getting away with it." 
 While all nations cheat on free trade to some degree, China is a socialist country that has put up barriers to imports so brazenly that it hardly makes a pretense at advocating free trade. One theory has it that China may be displaying a passion for building up net exports to accumulate foreign exchange -- what economists call a mercantilist streak. From missiles to textiles, exports have become a top priority. The pressure has led many companies to evade international rules, and the result is likely to be a protracted struggle between Washington and Beijing over China's trade behavior.
Last year, the United States's trade deficit with China was $10.4 billion -- the third largest, behind only Japan, with which the United States had a $41.1 billion deficit, and Taiwan, with which the deficit was $11.3 billion. China, whose exports have more than tripled in the last decade, is the only non-market economy that has become a major exporter to the United States.
And while most Western countries say they would like China to abandon more of its Government control of the economy, they are finding that China is maintaining socialism while also learning some of the ways that exporters like Japan and Taiwan cause headaches for foreign industrial countries.
In many ways, China is a picture-perfect unfair trader. Just ask anyone who wants to sell cars here. Not only must a foreign auto company pay stiff duties; it must also give two cars of each model to the Government, pay $40,000 for "testing" and finance a Chinese delegation's trip to "inspect" the factories overseas.
While the United States has had disputes with Japan over rice and with Taiwan over turkeys, the barriers in China are in many respects more comprehensive and fundamental. The exchange rate here is fixed, most big companies are state-owned, Government permission is needed for most imports, and in many cases tariffs have been raised and barriers added in the last few years.
 
Export Promotion
 A big export promotion effort, coupled with curbs on imports, has pushed China's overall trade balance from a deficit of $6.6 billion in 1989 to a surplus of $8.7 billion last year. And trade is likely to continue to do well -- unless Congress cuts off most-favored-nation trade status for China, against President Bush's wishes -- partly because China is gradually devaluing its currency.
While they admit that Chinese enterprises often engage in illicit practices, some Chinese economists disagree that China's trade machine is basically unfair. They say the central Government has tried hard to curb some unfair practices, but that decentralization and the boom in capitalist enterprises in southern China -- just the kind of things Westerners want to see -- are thwarting the effort. "China is a developing country, and there is a cost to free trade," said a Chinese economist. "It must protect some of its industries. Is that unfair?"
American businessmen are much less sympathetic. To many, China's economy is a giant maze, with dead ends at every corner and booby traps that lead to dense tangles of bureaucracy and high costs. For instance, beyond extensive tariffs, quotas and other restrictions, China has a set of secret regulations that foreigners cannot even see. Often companies learn about them only through trial and error: sometimes a shipment is allowed into the country, sometimes it is not.
Nicholas Lardy, a specialist on the Chinese economy at the University of Washington, said that while China has curbed imports and boosted exports in the last two years, it is not clear that it will sustain its apparent passion for accumulating foreign exchange through the unbridled sale of exports. He noted that for most of the 1980's, China imported more than it exported, and he suggested that last year's trade surplus was an anomaly -- explainable partly because China faced economic uncertainties and restricted access to foreign capital and loans.
Prudence and caution, some Western economists say, thus may be enough to explain China's recent trade surplus. China is getting rid of export subsidies, and allowing imports to rise again. Its domestic economy is also rebounding and this may increase demand for imports. Still, in the first four months of this year, its overall trade surplus rose to $2.34 billion, up from $1.31 billion for the same period last year. Similarly, the United States deficit with China expanded to $2.19 billion in the first quarter, compared to $1.88 billion in the same period last year.
"I think it comes from a very deep-rooted ambivalence toward opening to the West and distrust of foreigners and capitalism," said another American economist who specializes in China. "Maybe some of those dirty tactics are engaged in because everyone is under so much pressure to generate revenues."

HEADLINE: Doing Business;
In Washington, Moscow's Moment Has Arrived

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
A SEIZE-THE-MOMENT psychology has suddenly taken hold in Washington, a feeling that the moment has arrived to finish a lot of unfinished business with Moscow, before electoral politics or some crisis somewhere distracts everyone's attention. "Washington is a one-issue town, as we've all known for a very long time" says Robert Legvold, a leading Soviet scholar at Columbia University, "and this month, once again, it's the Soviet Union. Moscow has gotten desperate, thrown a lot of fishing lines in the water, and that has Washington all astir."
Already, the United States has settled a potentially disruptive dispute with the Soviets over the interpretation of the new treaty setting limits on troop levels in Europe. That opened the way for a major new effort, launched in Geneva last week by Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d and his Soviet opposite number, Aleksandr A. Bessmertnykh, to wrap up at last an agreement on long-range missiles. If that works, President Bush and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev plan a summit meeting in Moscow this month or next. 
 Already, Mr. Bush has announced that in return for the relatively liberal new emigration law adopted by the Soviets, a change that has long been a key goal of American policy, he has eased limitations on trade with Moscow for another year, and his aides say he will soon grant Moscow the preferential trade status that it has long sought. The Administration is also weighing the possibility of extending sizeable new credits to the Soviet Union for use in agriculture.
 
An Invitation to London
 Already, the Bush Administration has reversed itself and agreed that Mr. Gorbachev should be invited, as he asked, to the meeting of the leaders of the seven big Western nations in London in mid-July, where he will state his case for more aid.
And already, Mr. Bush has sent a vivid signal to his embattled friend in the Kremlin that the United States wants to do business. By choosing as the new ambassador to Moscow not a career officer but his Texas chum Robert S. Strauss, Democrat and deal-maker extraordinaire, the President has shown that he considers this a special moment in the evolving superpower relationship.
Other questions loom just ahead, notably the timing, the nature and the scope of American assistance to the Soviet economy, at a time when it is not entirely clear what the shape of that economy will be six months or six years from now -- or, for that matter, what the components of the Soviet Union will be.
 
Ambiguity in Moscow
 Much has changed in Moscow, but not the old gift for ambiguity and double-talk. The name of the country may soon be changed from the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics to the Union of Soviet Sovereign Republics, but Mr. Gorbachev and others insist that this does not mean that the country is any less socialist, not at all; it certainly does not mean that Lithuania, for example, is sovereign in any sense of the word understood in the West.
As the dimensions of the Soviet-American relationship in the 1990's are debated, there is a sense that the world may be at or near a threshold. Surely, one was crossed with the coming of perestroika, and another with the dismantling of the Soviet empire in Eastern Europe. The next could mean the achievement of a stable, business-like, normal relationship -- if not yet the intimacy of deep friendship -- between the Soviet Union and the West, and that could mean an era when most people could sleep a great deal easier.
Yet taking the step into that new world is not going to be easy.
 Senator Richard G. Lugar, the Indiana Republican, said the other day that the key question for American policy-makers and the American people is whether or not a real change in the relationship is coming. Despite what he termed "this full-court press on all fronts," he said the answer was not yet clear to him and other influential foreign-policy specialists in Congress.
Many in Washington, especially but not exclusively conservatives, still want more evidence of change before they commit themselves too fully to sending billions of American dollars to the Soviet Union; old suspicions die hard here, as well as among Moscow's bureaucrats and generals. What is sought is evidence, for example, that the Soviets are scaling back their spending on strategic weapons and on sustaining Cuba. And evidence that Mr. Gorbachev has made a complete commitment to a market economy.
"So far, it seems pretty half-baked to me," said Mr. Lugar. "There's a lot of come-hither, but there is also a suggestion, among the Russians I've talked to, that if you folks don't come up with the money then we'll forget about reform."
 Europeans, fearful of chaos in the biggest country on their continent, are somewhat more eager than the United States to help the Soviets out. Hence their pressure on Washington to agree to ask Mr. Gorbachev to London.
But the grandest vision is the so-called Grand Bargain, under which vast Western aid would be supplied in return for sweeping Soviet reform. It is the project of prominent Soviet economists, led by Grigory Yavlinsky, who have been meeting for weeks at Harvard University with a group of American academics who have no official standing but include in their number Robert D. Blackwill, who used to be a key member of the staff in the Bush White House.
That approach has a legion of critics, inside the Government and outside. "It's a grand illusion, not a grand bargain," says Marshall Goldman, a Harvard professor who is not involved in the project. "It has diverted our attention from the task at hand, which is sorting out what is feasible and when. Meanwhile, the country is falling apart, the G.N.P. is collapsing, Gorbachev is in danger of losing control. You can't do business with an elephant when its trunk is going one way and its tail the other."
A major problem, in the view of Stephen Cohen of Princeton University, as well as Professor Goldman, is that during the cold war the West lost the habit of thinking about the Soviet Union in political terms, framing the issues exclusively in military or global strategic terms. The result, Professor Cohen said, is that Washington "lacks any real sense of Gorbachev as a man who has to satisfy many constituencies, who's going to zig and zag like any leader, who can't simply impose his will whenever he wishes to."
 
A New Hybrid?
 Several unresolved questions stem in part from this difficulty, notably the question of what kind of Soviet Union the West wants or can hope to see, as a practical matter, at the end of a reform process. A country like the United States? Not likely. Like Poland? Also not likely, given the size of the Soviet Union, its heterogeneous character and its history. Most experts believe that a mixture of Western ideas with Russian tradition is the best that can be hoped for, particularly if the change is to be evolutionary and relatively controlled, rather than sudden and destabilizing.
Too much Western pressure for Soviet reform could worsen a political backlash against Mr. Gorbachev that has already begun, fueled by the ancient Russian suspicion of things foreign against which Peter the Great struggled so hard. Russian officials tell American friends, "We're not a beggar nation, you know, we're still powerful," precisely because they fear that that is how they may be seen by others.
And dangerous as over-dependence on Mr. Gorbachev may be, at a time when power clearly is devolving into more and more hands, Washington worries that "what lurks is despotism," in Professor Cohen's phrase, if he is deposed.
And if the country falls to pieces? Independence for the Baltic states is one thing, a key Administration planner says, "but it's hardly in our national interest to have Armenia and Georgia and the Central Asian republics peeling off, and this vast continental country in turmoil."
Mr. Bush must weigh how much to put into the scale to try to keep those things from happening. He must try to avoid, in the cliche of the hour, pouring American taxpayers' money down a rathole, at a time when pressure from the electorate is mounting for the commitment of scarce funds to help the United States catch up in such areas as education, housing and health care. He must try to balance the need to help Mr. Gorbachev and the Soviet Union in their hour of greatest need against the necessity to provide incentives for them to continue to change.
Getting it right must seem impossible at times, with so many variables and so many complexities. Clearly, there can be no quick fix. Professor Legvold, among others, warns that "the Soviet problem will require very considerable Western attention for a very considerable length of time."
And yet, said Mr. Lugar after assessing the problems for more than an hour, "I have this feeling, this hunch, that just a few yards down the road we may have the opportunity to act decisively in our national interest by helping the Soviets, if only we can see exactly how and when to do it."

HEADLINE: Headliners;
The Fissioning of the Nuclear Family

BYLINE: By FELICITY BARRINGER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
IT was the kind of demographic news calculated to bring joy to the makers of single-portion soups and the managers of singles bars. More Americans are home alone. More than one in every nine adults over age 18 lived alone in 1990, a total that exceeds 27 million people.
That news, coming from an annual survey by the Census Bureau, was one more indicator of the atomization of the American household. Like a cubist painting of a human figure, households have been continually rearranged over the last 30 years by personal preferences and economic imperatives. 
 Now some sociologists are beginning to wonder if some trends that have left the nuclear family with a decreasing share of the American life-style market are on the wane. In particular, the tendency of young people to marry later may be ready to reverse itself, said Thomas Espenshade, a population expert at the Office of Population Research at Princeton University. "You may be seeing a high-water mark on this," he said, referring to new figures that show American men marry for the first time at an average age of 26.1, and women at an average age of 23.9. The figures are about three years above the low marks of 1956.
"Divorce probability and age at first marriage may be near a peak," Mr. Espenshade said, adding that "a trend back to earlier ages of marriage and childbearing" would result in ages for first marriages somewhere between the 1956 lows and the 1990 highs. "Women in their 20's have had enough opportunity to observe both the pros and cons of delayed marriage and delayed childbearing," he said.
In the meantime, many people are still finding rest or restlessness in solitude or informal unions. Among women between the ages of 30 and 34, 16.4 percent have never married, up from 6.2 percent two decades ago. Unmarried couples number about 2.9 million.
That trend and others show no sign of slowing. Particularly ingrained is the trend toward single parenthood, fueled by the upward surge in the divorce rate in the 1970's, and more recently by the acceptability and increased prevalence of unwed motherhood. In 1990, 73 percent of children under 18 lived with both parents, down from 85 percent two decades before.

HEADLINE: Ideas & Trends;
For Consumers, Bank Reform Offers Not So Much as a Toaster

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
DRIVEN by the fear that lightning could strike twice, the Bush Administration is pressing for deregulation that could change the nature of the banking system and, it maintains, eliminate the chance of another financial cave-in and a multibillion-dollar taxpayer bailout. The measure's name even has a somewhat comforting ring: the Financial Institutions Safety and Consumer Choice Act.
But consumer advocates say the legislation, which has the support of Democrats and Republicans alike, is anything but their choice. 
 The architect of the plan, Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady, envisions the banking company of the future offering a wider variety of services -- like insurance, stock brokerage and mutual funds -- that generally have been off limits for banks. He says that breaking Depression-era barriers and enabling banks to expand into new businesses and across state lines will insure that a healthy banking industry will survive.
Consumer groups are unenthusiastic; encouraging the consolidation of the banking industry, they say, guarantees less bank competition. Banks will become even more impersonal than they are now, the critics say, charging their ordinary customers larger fees and higher interest rates while cutting back on their traditional services of loans and deposits.
 "Unquestionably, this is anti-consumer legislation," said Peggy Miller, a lobbyist for the Consumer Federation of America, an umbrella group representing 240 national and local consumer organizations. "There is nothing positive in this for the ordinary person."
"We just sent out an alert to our membership and many of them feel deeply outraged," Ms. Miller added. "The clear lack of concern in Congress for their interests is going to mean that their fees will be higher, interest rates are going to go up for them and credit is going to become even harder to obtain."
Opponents of the legislation say Congress is buckling under the pressure of a two-prong offensive: on one side, the banking lobby led by the strapped, big money-center banks, and on the other, the White House. Both maintain that the alternative to the measure would be the catastrophic collapse of the nation's most prominent institutions and another multibillion-dollar bailout, like that of the savings and loan failures. It is a weighty argument. The savings and loan bailout may ultimately cost taxpayers $500 billion over 40 years.
Adding to the bailout scenario is the state of the fund that insures bank deposits, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation. While the F.D.I.C. estimates that more than 200 of the nation's 12,300 banks may fail this year, the General Accounting Office has said the fund is virtually insolvent.
In moving toward deregulation, a House banking subcommittee recently added an amendment that basically eviscerates the Community Reinvestment Act of 1977. It would exempt most banks -- those with less than $100 million in assets -- from the act, which, among other things, prohibits redlining, the practice under which banks decide not to issue loans in middle- and lower-income neighborhoods. The amendment rolls back 14 years of progress that consumers have made in forcing banks to serve their local neighborhoods.
 
Eliminating an Unpopular Tool
 The chairman of the banking committee, Henry B. Gonzalez, a populist from Texas, says he will fight to restore the the reinvestment act. But he also acknowledges that he may not command a majority of votes on the committee.
The Community Reinvestment Act compels banks to make loans to those areas that are in most need of economic development and it requires regulators to rate banks by their willingness to lend to their communities. Regulators can then use the ratings as a basis for denying banks permission to expand or merge. The subcommittee's amendment would virtually eliminate the evaluation process for most banks.
Banks have complained that the act has little effect on their behavior and only adds tens of thousands of dollars to their regulatory costs.
The Community Reinvestment Act "is probably the most unpopular legislation for bankers," said Kenneth H. Thomas, a bank analyst and consultant in Miami. "They feel it serves primarily as a tool for credit allocation, which they oppose because lending is primarily what they are in business for. On the other hand, community groups believe bank redlining has contributed to decay of the inner cities. The truth is somewhere in between these views."
While a banking subcommittee left most of the measure intact, it faces a critical test this month when the Banking Committee decides what provisions to send to the floor. And the package awaits further scrutiny from two other House committees. Last Thursday, Representative John D. Dingell, the powerful chairman of the Energy and Commerce Committee, expressed serious concerns about most of the major elements of the legislation in a letter to House Speaker Thomas S. Foley.
What is likely to come out of the process is a plan for financing the insurance fund, greater powers for the regulators to step in earlier to seize troubled institutions and the elimination of barriers to interstate banking. In the end, the protection of larger banks may be a loss for the consumer but a gain for the taxpayer.
But the trend in Congress has marked a strong break from past moves on Capitol Hill that have altered the financial services industry. In recent years, virtually every major piece of legislation in the area had attached some goodies for consumers. Not this time. Consumer advocates have had a hard time making even a dent in the legislation.
One change, proposed by Representative Joseph P. Kennedy 2d, Democrat of Massachusetts, would have required banks to cash all Government checks up to $3,000, with the modest aim of sparing lower income people, veterans and the elderly high check-cashing costs. The amendment, which had been approved by the subcommittee in 1988, was soundly defeated this time, by a vote of 27 to 9.

LENGTH: 917 words

HEADLINE: Ideas & Trends;
A Long, Slow March Out of Storybook Land

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN

 BODY:
WHEN he became a literary agent in 1972, Morton Janklow was invited to lunch by Simon Michael Bessie, then a senior editor at Harper & Row. Mr. Bessie's summation of the principles of publishing was straightforward: "Just remember, there are never too many books about Hitler, Lincoln, Napoleon and the Civil War." For a seat-of-the-pants business, such homespun wisdom seemed to be enough. Green jackets, it was said, do not sell, nor do short stories or books on the American Revolution or the Arctic. Dogs and doctors, however, were reported to be subjects of inexhaustible appeal.
 In an industry in which it is sometimes said that market research consists of the first printing, anecdotal evidence and even superstition still flourish. But publishing, now a $17 billion business, is growing up, and many of its myths are crumbling. Stiffer competition, mergers, escalating advances and declining book sales are all making publishers look more closely at reality. 
 At the Association of American Booksellers annual convention in New York last week, there was abundant evidence of an industry now far too diverse and sophisticated for old nostrums to suffice.
More than 1,600 publishing companies and more than 7,000 booksellers were present. So too were hordes of foreign publishers and agents. In all, over 35,000 people attended, a record. Drawing them was an astonishing variety of books: first novels, reissues of the classics, stories of film stars and reformed criminals, tales of Waldo and Wall Street, reference works and revamped Bibles, coffee table books and new novels by Norman Mailer, Anne Tyler and Amy Tan.
It was apparent that in trying to sell all these wares, publishers have come a long way from the time when myth had it that books either sold themselves or they failed. Take Doubleday's "The Firm," a thriller by John Grisham, which was prominently displayed. Written by a little-known author, it was cleverly built into a best seller, partly by marketing directly to law firms through advertisements in legal journals and by seeding the market with mailings of sample books. Or there was Donna Tartt, a diminutive figure being escorted through parties as a hot new property, her mystique the object of careful cultivation by editors at Alfred A. Knopf. Her first novel, "The God of Illusions," was bought by Knopf for a sum reported to exceed $400,000.
As Ms. Tan said, "We have to perform." Forget myth, substitute marketing.
The convention came at the end of a year that has seen the collapse of one of the biggest myths of the book trade, that fiercely loyal book addicts make the industry recession-proof. With Waldenbooks and B. Dalton stores proliferating, bookselling has become more tightly intertwined with other retail businesses. When mall traffic declines, as it has by as much as 20 percent over the last year, so inevitably do book sales. Moreover, the very fact that the reading public has grown larger and more disparate means that it is more fickle. A book lover will buy even in hard times but an idle browser of commercial blockbusters will hesitate.
 Other myths are also dying hard. Instead of sticking to the old wisdom, which held that the biggest books should be published in either May or October -- to attract buyers looking for a good read for their summer vacations, or to lure purchasers of Christmas gifts -- publishers are experimenting. Increasingly, any month except December (too much competition) is regarded as a viable month to publish. Even mid-summer, once considered a dead period, is now believed to be a time when reviewers are less besieged. "The rules are less clearcut than in the past," said Roger Straus, the publisher of Farrar Straus & Giroux. "The only surviving myth is when publishers tell you the check is in the mail."
Pricing, long a myth-ridden area, is also becoming more flexible. Cork Smith, the editor in chief of Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, recalls working at J. B. Lippincott in the early 1950's and having "a long and extremely serious debate over whether it was possible to price a long hardcover novel called 'Angelique,' by Serganne Golan, over $5."
Until last year it was widely assumed that no one would buy a nonfiction book that cost more than $29.95. But "The Civil War" by Geoffrey C. Ward, with Ric Burns and Ken Burns, priced at $50 by Knopf, and a biography, "Captain Sir Richard Francis Burton" by Edward Rice, priced at $35 by Macmillan, both became best sellers. Meanwhile, Random House has decided to price books at round dollar figures, abandoning the myth that $19.95 is a lot more attractive than $20.
 Still, some old adages have not been abandoned: A book that has not worked in hardback will generally not sell in paperback either even though it is much cheaper. The Vietnam war works, the Korean war does not. Fiction from Latin America is fine, but non-fiction books about Latin America don't sell so well. Forget the Philippines: the country does not sell. Aborigines are tricky: books entirely about them are not easy to sell, but works partly about them do better. And it may still be a good idea to call a book "Lincoln's Doctor's Dog."
 "It all makes about as much sense as the book business makes," said Mr. Smith of Harcourt, Brace. "But you tell me why the American Revolution is uninteresting and the Civil War nearly always sells."
 Another publisher, who insisted on anonymity, said, "The biggest myth of all survives: that we know what we are doing."

HEADLINE: Headliners;
The Bucks Stopped

 BODY:
When Marion C. Moran was sworn in as the first female Mayor of Bridgeport, Conn., she was a self-described housewife and real-estate broker who had won as a Republican in a Democratic stronghold. Her fief, a once-bustling urban center of 142,000 and the largest city in Connecticut, had long ago fallen on hard times, and her austerity platform promised to reduce city services -- except for police and fire -- and raise taxes only in an emergency like bankruptcy. Last week, after city officials failed to close a $12 million gap in the $304 million budget for fiscal 1991-1992, the Mayor filed for bankruptcy, saying she couldn't balance the budget without dismissing up to 100 officers from the 340-member police force. Mrs. Moran was seeking to circumvent the grip of the state's financial review board and place Bridgeport in the control of a Federal judge. But the board promptly vowed to block the Mayor's plan and imposed a budget balanced by an 18 percent increase in property taxes.

SECTION: Section 4; Page 16; Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 643 words

HEADLINE: How to Crush Communism

 BODY:
The Soviet Union stands at the turning point of the century; careful injections of Western assistance could lead it decisively toward the free market and a free society. Yet a harsh chorus in the West now proclaims "No aid before reform."
Since no one seriously proposes unconditional giveaways, what the slogan really means is no promise of aid until after reform. That would mean no aid at all. And that would be a mistake as monumental as is the moment. 
 The time for the West to exercise leverage is now -- when it can sway the battle within the Soviet Union between forces pushing market reforms and the old Communists clinging to centralized control.
The Soviet path to markets will be painful and frightening -- especially in the early stages when citizens face raging inflation and unemployment for the first time in their lives. The promise of aid could mitigate the fear and persuade the Soviets to take the plunge.
The alternative is to sit back and watch the Soviet economy implode, threatening the disintegration of a country with, among other things, nuclear weapons. That's reason enough to engage the Soviets before their economy collapses.
 American and Soviet analysts, some working together, propose a so-called Grand Bargain. Aid would flow as the Soviets undertook specific economic reforms en route to free markets. Aid would cease the moment they balked. The plan is modeled on the program under way in Poland, where the World Bank and International Monetary Fund play their traditional oversight role. Indeed, the Grand Bargain is grand only in scale; its plan for economic development is routine.
The plan would provide about $25 billion of aid a year for several years. The money would come from Western governments and international institutions. America's share would be $3 billion or $4 billion a year, hardly onerous. The Soviets don't need and wouldn't tolerate a detailed blueprint. But they would have to agree to price reform, budget balance, massive privatization and legal protections for property and contracts.
The first step would be price decontrol and elimination of most subsidies to inefficient businesses. Because prices and layoffs would soar, temporary aid could cushion the early shock. The sequence would proceed along these lines:
Currency Stabilization: A $10 billion fund would support the value of the ruble, thereby facilitating trade. In Poland, the stabilization fund was never touched. If the Soviets, as required, set a realistic value for the ruble and cease printing new rubles, their fund won't be needed either.
Balance-of-Payments Relief: This would involve cash to import food and other supplies during the early phase of price decontrol. Aid might be $15 billion or $20 billion the first year, then taper off to zero within four years.
Infrastructure: Soviet transportation facilities, food distribution networks, banks and nearly everything else are crumbling. As the need for balance-of-payment relief wanes, $8 billion a year or more would be diverted to long-term investments.
Technical Advice and Privatization: International institutions will chip in several billion a year to provide advice about accounting, conversion of military facilities, management training and much else. And the new European Bank for Reconstruction and Development would direct money into start-up companies and other private initiatives.
This program is realistic; it has been used in other underdeveloped countries. And it is financially feasible. Institutions like the World Bank are already geared to supervise the effort.
What's missing are commitments on both sides. The Soviets have repeatedly promised radical reform, only to shrink back at every decisive moment. Perhaps this time, the West can push them to take the plunge -- all the way to markets.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: Public & Private;
Instant Replay, Confettied

BYLINE: By ANNA QUINDLEN

 BODY:
One of the weirdest technological wonders of our modern age, along with the fact that you can now bake a potato in the time it takes to blow your nose, is the strange case of the video camera. We have a generation of children who think life works like this: You do things, and then as soon as you are finished doing them, you watch yourself doing them on television. The result is that reality sometimes seems even more synthetic than it is.
This is the image that comes to me when I consider the Persian Gulf war parade to be held tomorrow in lower Manhattan. The parade will be an instant replay of many of the elements that made the conflict in the gulf so popular in some quarters, and so troubling in others: 
 * The parade will divert attention from domestic disasters, in this case the city of New York, which will put its best face forward and keep all the homeless people with shopping carts off the parade route. Mayor Dinkins has called this the Mother of All Parades, and he should know; he's dealing with the Great-Granddaddy of All Fiscal Crises in a city that has long seemed like America's Stepchild. Tomorrow, for a few brief hours, this will look like an intact family.
* The parade will cost lots of money. And, like the war, no one knows exactly how much. The money is coming from private sources, since even amid parade fever it was agreed that spending millions of city dollars when we can't afford to keep our libraries open or our playgrounds in decent shape was not going to fly. But private money could be spent on more enduring things than confetti and balloons. Job programs for unemployed veterans might be one nice way for the private sector to show its support.
* The parade will make things seem simple. We won, we're glad, we're great. This is what parades always do. When the Yankees win the Series and all seems right with the world, it is fitting that we throw trash at them and yell our fool heads off. But the St. Patrick's Day parade has always made me a little queasy because it suggests that Ireland is God's darlin' little patch of perfect green when Belfast is still lousy with bullets and blood. "Triumph in the Desert," its publisher has called a glossy picture book about the gulf war. Triumph isn't the word I would have chosen.
Parades are often one-word answers to complicated questions.
Perhaps there has never been a sentiment so potent in this country as the one that demanded we expiate the sins of Vietnam by embracing the veterans of the gulf war. Except for the national sentiment that said this was going to be quick and clean and done with. Parades provide a sense of closure, and of celebration.
But both are illusory. Most of the American men and women in the gulf came home safely, and that is a great blessing. But Saddam Hussein remains in power, Kuwait is a feudal nation aflame, and America has sunk back into the recession doldrums that war fever gilded for a time.
Tomorrow the usual suspects will hold counterdemonstrations, that small indefatigable coterie who protested Grenada and Panama and Vietnam, who have had a lifetime of picketing government buildings. There were others of us who thought that this war was wrong and have watched with horror its aftermath, the carnage and suffering in Iraq and the subsequent closing of the American mind to anything but our own supremacy. But we only mumbled our objections, then and now, because we feared being caught by the patriotically correct. Like the war, the parade is designed to bury dissent beneath an overdose of hardware and warm fuzzies, to say again: support the troops or else.
I think the best way to support the troops is to provide decent conditions on their bases while they serve, and to promote an economy that can provide jobs when they are discharged.
And the best way to consider the lessons of war is not a multimillion-dollar paper storm. I like the group of Catholics from Queens who will gather in a church to read the verse from Isaiah about turning swords into plowshares and the Gospel according to Matthew in which Jesus exhorts us to love our enemies. This will not be as photogenic as either the parade or the war. But at least it is not synthetic reality, not an instant replay reinforcing again the crazy conclusion that the Persian Gulf war was nothing more than Norman Schwarzkopf's grin and Roman candles.

HEADLINE: Topics of The Times;
At Home in New York City

 BODY:
Badly buffeted by the recession, New York City's economy isn't exactly thriving these days. But nearly lost amid the gloom last week were two announcements confirming that the city remains a dynamic financial and management center.
After considering a move to Baltimore, St. Louis, Atlanta or Cleveland, the Girl Scouts of the U.S.A. will keep their national headquarters in Manhattan, along with 400 jobs. The Wall Street investment firm of Bear, Stearns & Company, meanwhile, has decided to transfer 1,500 employees early next year from three locations in Manhattan to downtown Brooklyn's new Metrotech Center. The firm had considered relocating these workers to New Jersey. City officials say losing these jobs would have cost the city about $200 million, justifying the tax breaks and other incentives offered Bear, Stearns to stay. 
 Short-term anxiety about the financial pinch need not obscure long-term opportunities.

HEADLINE: Mutual Funds;
Catching Up With Peter Lynch

BYLINE: By Carole Gould

 BODY:
About this time last year, Peter Lynch, the legendary stock picker who led Fidelity's Magellan Fund, retired at the age of 46 as head of the nation's largest and most successful stock fund.
These days, Mr. Lynch still keeps an office at Fidelity, and he works there anywhere from two to five days a week. He leaves home at 8 A.M. instead of 6:45, after making breakfast and lunch for his daughters. He leaves the office at 5 P.M., not 7, and does not work weekends. But he still eats lunch at his desk, he says, and "I go like crazy" during the work day. 
 Mr. Lynch resigned as a director of Fidelity when he left Magellan because "it was too time consuming," he said, and he wanted "a new challenge." Instead, he was elected by other trustees as one of 12 trustees for the Fidelity Funds.
In this role, he acts as "scorekeeper, judge and cheerleader," he said. "My job is to make sure that Fidelity shareholders are treated fairly."
Each month, Mr. Lynch and the rest of the equity committee listen to presentations by two stock-fund managers. While they look at whether a fund's investments are in line with its objectives, the big question, Mr. Lynch says, is: Can you tell me the 25 biggest positions in the fund, and why you own them?
In fact, the trustees met last week to review Magellan's performance under his successor, Morris Smith. How is Mr. Smith doing? "Great," Mr. Lynch said.
Besides his responsibilities for Fidelity, Mr. Lynch continues as a director of the Morrison Knudsen Corporation and of W. R. Grace & Company, which he joined in the 80's because he was friendly with William J. Agee and J. Peter Grace, the companies' chief executives. When he retired, he was besieged with requests to join other boards, all of which he declined.
Overall, Mr. Lynch estimates, the Fidelity work takes only one or two working days each month; the corporate board work takes another day or two. The rest of his working time is spent with charities.
The biggest beneficiary is the Archdiocese of Boston. Mr. Lynch says his best accomplishment this past year is a scholarship program for inner-city students sponsored by the archdiocese. For last February's black-tie fund-raising dinner, Mr. Lynch persuaded companies to buy tables "to get Boston business to hear the story of the inner-city schools," he said. Next year he will serve as chairman of the affair.
He is also chairman of the investment committee for the Museum of Fine Arts in Boston, and he spent a small amount of time teaching at Boston College.
Most of his activities require Mr. Lynch to keep up with the financial markets. As for his current thinking on the United States, Mr. Lynch said the economy began to run out of steam a little more than a year ago. The 1990 slowdown would have been a small one, he said, except for the added pressures created by the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait last summer. Now, "it looks definitely like a good-size recession," he said.
Is a recovery imminent? Mr. Lynch notes that housing is more affordable that it has been in 15 years and consumer confidence is much improved from its low levels of last fall. He concluded: "All the ingredients are there for a recovery, but there are no signs of it yet. Things will probably look a lot better in 12 months."
As for stocks to buy, Mr. Lynch demurred. "I'm out of the business of predicting stocks for public consumption," he said.
When he was picking stocks out in the open, Mr. Lynch was on the top of the heap. As he took over Magellan on June 1, 1977, the fund had $22 million in assets. By the time he left, assets totaled $14 billion.
In that time, Magellan earned an average annual return of 29.3 percent, according to Lipper Analytical Services, which tracks mutual funds. That is nearly double the 15.2 percent return for the Lipper Growth Fund Index. And while the stock market suffered several setbacks of 10 percent or more during Mr. Lynch's tenure, Magellan never lost money for a full year.
What does he have to say to fund investors who are looking for guidance?
First, he recommends long-term horizons. Do not invest money that might be needed in the next year or two, because market behavior for such short periods can be random, he said, adding that "people who try to get into the market for a quick 10 percent usually end up losing 10 percent." It is only over 5 or 10 years that the stock market becomes fairly predictable, he says.
Investors should also gauge their "tolerance for pain," Mr. Lynch said, because the stock market has dropped at least 10 percent 40 times in the last 70 years, or roughly every two years. Ask yourself, "what will I do when the market drops?" he suggests. If the likely response is to sell, do not invest.
For long-term investors, he is a strong proponent of "dollar cost averaging." Investing small amounts regularly reduces the average cost of fund shares because more shares are purchased when prices are lower.
Finally, do not overpay for mutual funds. While many financial advisers generate huge commissions by selling funds that carry hefty sales charges, Mr. Lynch said, "In most cases, there's no correlation between what you pay and what you get."

HEADLINE: The New Intellectuals at the Fed

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR

 BODY:
Last July, when the Federal Reserve Board's powerful Federal Open Market Committee met to decide the central bank's next move in managing the nation's money supply, a new member, Fed governor David W. Mullins Jr., did not hesitate to speak up.
On the eve of the meeting, which is always conducted in strict secrecy and in as formal a manner as a Japanese Kabuki play, there were signs that the nation's banks were becoming unusually reluctant to make loans to business. The worry was that credit-starved companies would be forced to slash spending, weakening the already-sluggish economy. The F.O.M.C. had to decide whether to nudge interest rates down, a move that would loosen credit and might keep the economy from slowing more. The risk was that easier credit might fan inflation fears and push up long-term interest rates. 
 Mr. Mullins, by his own account, waded right in. He argued that lowering the Federal funds rate, the rate that banks pay for overnight loans, would not amount to a shift toward easier money. The banks' credit squeeze was having the same effect on the economy as if the Fed were tightening the money supply. To keep money supply growth on its intended course, he maintained, the Fed needed to loosen up a bit. His argument helped persuade the committee. The funds rate was lowered by a quarter of a point.
The ways of the Fed often appear arcane. But to the economists, bankers and stock and bond traders who track the secretive board's every twist and turn, last July's deliberations provided a glimpse of the ideas and attitudes that are shaping a broad new intellectual consensus about the Fed's goals: making inflation-fighting the top priority.
To be sure, Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, is the dominant figure at the institution. But the Fed is far from the monolith it sometimes appears and Mr. Greenspan, more than most chairmen in the past, encourages other F.O.M.C. members to air their views. Those inside and outside the Fed frequently mention three people on the 19-member committee whose intellectual arguments and pursuasive skills have become key to forging the central bank's philosophical underpinnings -- and broad policy.
Besides Mr. Mullins, a Harvard Business School finance whiz and former Treasury official who has been nominated by the Bush Administration to become the Fed's vice chairman, they are: W. Lee Hoskins, a Milton Friedman disciple who heads the Cleveland Federal Reserve Bank and frequently dissents from majority decisions, and Wayne D. Angell, a Fed governor and contrarian who has taken stands that have earned him first the label of a dove, later that of a hawk.
Mr. Mullins, who is 45, and Mr. Hoskins, who is 50, were children in the prosperous, low-inflation Eisenhower era and came of age in the restless 1960's. Mr. Angell, who is 61, was raised in the Depression and Dust Bowl years on a Kansas farm and was a wheat farmer and state legislator. He taught economics at a Baptist college before becoming a central banker.
At the Fed, the new consensus generally favors the kind of steady-as-she-goes, hard-money policies that central bankers pursued back in the Eisenhower and Kennedy years, when inflation rarely crept over 2 percent and home mortgage rates stayed south of 6 percent.
"I don't think there are broad philosophical differences at the Fed," Mr. Mullins said. Debates mostly concern assessments of the economy and how best to implement monetary policy, not goals or the long-run course that has been set.
The new consensus, heavily influenced by recent academic research and modern theories of finance and rational expectations, is a far cry from the one that dominated the 1970's, when the Fed was supposed to smooth out the ups and downs of the American economy, and began to crumble in the 80's. In practical terms, that policy meant slamming on the brakes by raising interest rates when the economy boomed and inflation took off and hitting the monetary accelerator by lowering interest rates when the economy started to slump and unemployment rose.
In the new consensus, inflation is Enemy No. 1. "There is widespread agreement that stable prices are at all times the goal of monetary policy," said H. Erich Heinemann, chief economist at Ladenburg, Thalmann, a brokerage. Some credit the outspokenness of Mr. Hoskins and Mr. Angell on price stability for the fact that most F.O.M.C. members, including Mr. Mullins, now support legislation mandating that Fed policy pursue near-zero inflation.
The consensus also embraces the idea that "monetary policy should focus on maximizing long-term economic growth," as Mr. Angell puts it. It holds that economic growth comes from an anti-inflation policy.
The Fed's change in thinking is being crafted within the purview of the F.O.M.C., which consists of Mr. Greenspan and the six other Fed governors, plus the presidents of the 12 regional Federal Reserve banks, who share four votes.
Influential members, notably Mr. Mullins, Mr. Angell and Mr. Hoskins, shape the consensus through presentations at the meetings. They give speeches, have their staffs conduct research and write scholarly papers, write papers of their own and circulate comments on colleagues' work. The three are also considered adept at interacting with their colleagues both in the office and socially.
The idea that the Fed could let inflation creep up a little in order to bring down unemployment was a policy staple of the 1960's. The tandem rise of inflation and unemployment in the 1970's killed that thought. "Not only do I think there is no long-term trade-off between inflation and growth, but I think there is no short-term trade-off either," said Mr. Mullins. "If we drove down short-term interest rates aggressively now, we would drive up long-term rates, making the recession longer."
That inflation is ultimately fueled by excessive money growth is a monetarist notion that is now all but gospel within the Fed. Mr. Mullins, Mr. Hoskins and Mr. Angell -- as well as Mr. Greenspan -- all agree that the Fed should gradually lower the growth of M2, the broad measure of the money supply, to roughly the same rate as the growth of the economy's productive capacity.
Matching deeds to words, the Fed has nudged down its targets for money supply growth since the mid-1980's. Actual growth in the past four years has averaged half the pace of the prior four and month-to-month zigs and zags have shrunk sharply. "The focus on M2 targets is indicative of more systematic policies and less fine-tuning than in the past," said John B. Taylor of the President's Council of Economic Advisors.
The big test, of course, is whether inflation and long-term interest rates come down as the recession ends. Fed officials hope that will be the payoff of the past four years' policies. At the moment, long-term interest rates still reflect investors' worries that inflation will stay stuck at around the 4 percent rate of the past few years.
If in the past Fed policy debates could be framed in terms of monetary doves pitting themselves against monetary hawks, in the Greenspan Fed the doves are gone. Now, it's various breeds of anti-inflation hawk.
In one debate, monetarists like Mr. Hoskins argue that monetary policy should not be geared to the dollar's foreign-exchange value. Others, like Gary Stern, president of the Minneapolis Fed, favor fixed exchange rates, which means coordination of monetary policy with other countries.
A more basic issue concerns how much the Fed should give up its discretion over setting its goals and strategies. Reflecting a consensus in academia, a growing minority within the Fed, including Mr. Hoskins, believes that monetary policy should be conducted as much as possible according to rules. "Rules let the public judge whether the Fed is doing what it says it is. That increases credibility," said Art Rolnick, research director at the Minneapolis Fed.
But there is dissent. Mr. Mullins, for example, does not believe that any simple rule can work for long. Gerald Corrigan, president of the New York Fed and as such the most powerful of the regional bank presidents, believes that future crises are unpredictable and that the Fed cannot afford to limit its options.

HEADLINE: For Oregon's Health Care System, Triage by a Lawmaker With an M.D.

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY EGAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SALEM, Ore., June 5

 BODY:
As an emergency room physician, Dr. John Kitzhaber has spent much of his professional life in the fast-motion treatment of bleeding patients.
Now, as the author of a plan that could make Oregon the first state to insure that health care is provided for all its citizens, Dr. Kitzhaber is trying to use triage on a system that he considers shamefully ill. 
 Wearing his two hats, as President of the Oregon Senate and as a small-town physician, Dr. Kitzhaber has helped his state fashion a medical plan that is the talk of professional journals. The plan is also being widely discussed in political circles and in countries, including Canada and Britain, that are looking for ways to keep their national health care systems solvent.
 
Working With Congress
 His next target is Congress, whose approval is needed within the next year if Oregon is to begin carrying out its groundbreaking plan that ranks and limits care. Dr. Kitzhaber says that the Federal Government has refused to offer anything to the 32 million Americans without health care and that now that the states are trying to solve the problem Congress must show some leadership or get out of the way.
Oregon's plan, part of a package of legislation passed two years ago, would extend Medicaid benefits to all people with incomes below the poverty level and would set a minimum standard of care for those with private insurance. It would do this by rationing treatments, based on a list of what would be covered and what would not. The current system, Dr. Kitzhaber says, rations people.
The Oregon plan represents a major shift in the delivery of health care from the issue of who is covered, to what is covered.
If the plan is to proceed, Congress must authorize a waiver of the current rules for Medicaid, the health care system for the poor that is jointly financed by the Federal and state governments. Medicaid, created to provide health care for the poor, last year covered less than half the people living below the official poverty level because of inadequate financing by the states and Federal Government.
"If we can force the debate to one between the current system and what Oregon is offering, I'm convinced we will win, because the current system is indefensible," Dr. Kitzhaber said.
Wearing jeans and a floral tie, Dr. Kitzhaber was working the Oregon Legislature in the last days of the session, which is expected to end in mid-June. It has been another year of triumph for his health bill, which was born amid headlines and controversy and has now moved to center stage as one of the most talked-about ideas in health care.
The man behind the experiment is a 44-year-old native of the Northwest who practices politics and medicine with equal fervor. A graduate of Dartmouth College, he received his M.D. from the University of Oregon Medical School and has practiced medicine for 17 years in Roseburg, in the timber country of southwestern Oregon. A liberal Democrat, he was first elected to the Oregon Legislature in 1978, and is in his fourth term as President of the Senate.
 
The Plan's Birth
 Dr. Kitzhaber says his idea was born of frustration at seeing "people we were lopping off on one end of the system ending up in the emergency room." His plan was to have a system that emphasized preventive care, he said, and this was codified in the rationing list.
"Believe me, I'd prefer a Federal solution," Dr. Kitzhaber said, "but we can't wait for Congress to get its act together while 40,000 children in the United States die, every year, before their first birthday."
After much uproar in the early stages of the Oregon plan, criticism in this state has been muted. The priority list, ranking 808 disorders and their treatments based on a formula that is equal parts mathematics and public opinion, has received international attention as a pioneering experiment.
As it is, 204,000 Oregonians who qualify for Medicaid receive a relatively rich package of medical benefits, while those who are not poor enough -- mostly people in low-paying jobs -- receive nothing. Medicaid would be extended to an additional 77,000 people here, that is, everybody below the Federal poverty level, and the benefits would be trimmed, based on the list.
The cutoff, the line below which public financing would not be provided, is to be drawn in the next few weeks as the state Legislature finishes its budget deliberations. Officials say that if $30 million is added, as expected, to Oregon's current annual share of Medicaid of $257 million, then the line on the list will be drawn somewhere around 600. The 200 or so disorders and treatments that would not be covered include lung transplants, acne, Parkinson's disease, reconstructive breast surgery and terminal AIDS with less than 10 percent chance of survival. Those who are terminally ill can get hospice care, counseling and medication for pain relief through the plan.
Some early critics, among them businesses and groups representing the poor, have largely become allies of Dr. Kitzhaber.
 
Covering Everybody
 "The reason we're winning converts is because everybody in Oregon is going to be covered, one way or the other," he said, "and we're doing it with a concise model for how to contain costs."
Dr. Kitzhaber said the two basic models for national health care -- one financed primarily by employers and the other by government -- were doomed to failure until they addressed the question of keeping costs down.
"Congress has not had the guts to look at the fundamental question, which is: What medical services are really appropriate and what are not?" he said.
By assuring everyone a minimum level of care -- even if that means one system for the rich and one for the poor -- the most glaring leaks in the system are covered, he said. As an example, he noted that a family of three with an income of $5,500 a year is considered too wealthy to qualify for Medicaid in most states. But that family would be covered in Oregon.
"That is rationing of health care, and legislative bodies do it every budget cycle," he said.
The Oregon plan is not without critics. In Congress, Representative Henry A. Waxman, Democrat of California, and a leading voice on health care issues, said he was concerned that Oregon set a bad example by taking an already small pie and cutting it into more pieces, taking benefits away from the poorest of society.
A similar complaint was made by members of the Children's Defense Fund, which follows medical and social issues affecting children. "It's not that we object to rationing, per se, it's just that we don't like singling out children, who make up half the Medicaid population, for rationing," said Molly McNulty, a health specialist with the group. "We are not defending the status quo, but we don't see the answer as scaling things back."
 
Answering the Critics
 Dr. Kitzhaber says he is perplexed at criticism from those with whom he has always felt a political kinship. "They are measuring the Oregon plan against an ideal world, and, of course, it's got problems when you put it that way," he said.
The states, Oregon among them, continue to be the innovators in universal health care, but with mixed results. Hawaii's system requires that employers provide insurance for their workers, but it does not address the poor who are working part time and do not qualify for Medicaid. Massachusetts has a similar plan, but it is threatened by the recession.
Oregon's plan, even the part that requires employers to provide insurance, would use the priority list to keep costs down and still assure a minimum level of care.
In an editorial in last month's Journal of the American Medical Association, the Oregon plan was described as "a bold attempt to maximize health care benefits" and "an ambitious experiment that should be encouraged."
Dr. Kitzhaber says that trying something as innovative as a universal health system is much easier in a state like Oregon, with its population of less than 3 million and its growing economy. "Of course, it helps to be a doctor and President of the State Senate," he said.

LENGTH: 1385 words

HEADLINE: The Nation;
When the Subject Is Civil Rights, There Are Two George Bushes

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES

 BODY:
George Bush, the man whose Presidential campaign benefited from the now notorious Willie Horton commercials, also has the distinction of having appointed the first black Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, Gen. Colin Powell. He will be remembered as a President who vetoed a civil rights bill in 1990 and, if he carries through with his threat, again in 1991, while making a point of donating half the proceeds from his autobiography, "Looking Forward," to the United Negro College Fund.
Images of Mr. Bush's relations with blacks collide at odd angles, revealing no coherent pattern other than contradiction. It is a Janus-like approach that allows his enemies or supporters to choose the lens through which they view him -- as an enlightened healer or a cynical opportunist. And combined with his flip-flops on issues like abortion, "voodoo economics" and "no new taxes," his approach to race raises a broader question: Is there no coherent pattern, or no coherent value system? 
 The President says he would veto the job discrimination bill approved last week in the House by a vote of 273 to 158, contending that it would force employers to adopt hiring and promotion quotas. Recently his top aides helped undermine efforts by civil rights groups and corporate executives to hammer out a compromise bill they hoped would satisfy the President's objections. Critics said that Mr. Bush was more interested in using quotas as a political issue than in having the bill enacted.
Mr. Bush clearly believes, with some justification, that he has fought for equality, and he and his associates display flashes of outrage when faced with accusations of insensitivity to the rights of any American. "He would be so offended by any kind of prejudice and racism that it must be terribly painful to have those kinds of charges hurled at him, particularly in light of his record," said Sheila Tate, Mr. Bush's press secretary during his Presidential campaign. Associates of Mr. Bush also cite polls showing he has a high approval rating among blacks.
Mr. Bush's history reveals a man whose public and private life has included both episodes of moral courage and incidents that his opponents say demonstrate either racial insensitivity or a willingness to use the racial card for political gain.
In 1948, as a student at Yale, he led a fund-raising drive for the United Negro College Fund, following the lead of his father, former Senator Prescott Bush, who had been chairman of the group's fund-raising appeals in Connecticut.
But as a candidate for the Senate from Texas in 1964, Mr. Bush came out against the Civil Rights Act of 1964, the landmark law that ended segregated lunch counters, restrooms, movie theaters and other public accommodations, and made employment discrimination illegal. In the campaign, Mr. Bush said the law was "politically inspired and is bad legislation in that it transcends the Constitution." He was essentially following the lead of his party's Presidential candidate, Barry Goldwater, who had denounced the bill.
 
Hopes and Regrets
 Three years ago, writing in his autobiography about his successful 1966 race for the House, Mr. Bush lamented that it was "both puzzling and disappointing" that he attracted so few black votes. "My hope had been that a Republican candidate might be able to break the Democratic Party's grip on black voters in the area," he wrote. "As county G.O.P. chairman, I'd placed our party funds in a black-owned bank and opened a party office with a full-time staff near Texas Southern, one of the state's major black colleges." In the book, Mr. Bush didn't mention his opposition to the 1964 civil rights bill.
In 1968, when the cause of civil rights was more politically popular, following the murder of Martin Luther King Jr., Mr. Bush voted for the Fair Housing Act, legislation that banned discrimination in housing. The vote touched off a firestorm of criticism within his conservative Congressional district. As Mr. Bush describes the situation in his autobiography, he faced down conservative critics of the vote at a meeting in his district, saying, "Somehow it seems fundamental that a man should not have a door slammed in his face because he is a Negro."
Mr. Bush seemed to be carrying on the theme of racial justice in 1988 when as Vice President he brokered a deal between Congressional backers and critics in the Reagan Administration of a bill that significantly strengthened the Fair Housing Act.
But that same year, Mr. Bush left himself open to charges of racial insensitivity when his Presidential campaign benefited from advertisements depicting the case of Willie Horton, the black inmate who raped a white Maryland woman while on a furlough program from a Massachusetts prison.
 
The Horton Case
 Mr. Bush said the Horton case simply highlighted his Democratic opponent Michael S. Dukakis's approach to crime. But many blacks were offended by the racial overtones and Lee Atwater, Mr. Bush's campaign manager, apologized for the commercials before he died last year from a brain tumor.
And so the contradictions continue. In addition to yearly donations of about $1,000 to the United Negro College Fund, Mr. Bush contributes on average $750 annually to Morehouse College, the black school in Atlanta on whose board of trustees his wife has served since 1983. Yet he has also at times displayed a startling myopia to conduct many blacks might find offensive.
Ten days ago he denounced the civil rights bill now before Congress in a speech at the F.B.I. Academy in Quantico, Va. In choosing this forum, Mr. Bush seems to have ignored the sensitivities of many blacks to the F.B.I.'s history of trying to discredit Martin Luther King Jr. Last August, without admitting any wrongdoing, the agency agreed to a $1 million out of court settlement with a black agent who charged that he had been harassed because of his race.
 
High in the Polls
 Still, the President remains popular among black voters, at times achieving an approval rating of 70 per cent in the New York Times/CBS News Polls. Even with his threatened veto of the civil rights bill, he racked up a 58 percent approval rating among non-whites in a Gallup poll released on June 2. In comparison, Ronald Reagan averaged an approval rating of 23 per cent among non-whites in the eight years of his Presidency and was never able to top a 50 per cent approval rating.
"Bush enjoyed one major advantage -- not being Reagan," said Eleanor Holmes Norton, the Congressional delegate from the District of Columbia. "He has done cosmetic things in office, but it is difficult to cite evidence of policy improvement in favor of minorities and poor people over his predecessor."
Two memos written by The Nathan Group Inc., a black political consulting company hired by the Republican National Committee, lay out a strategy to attract more black voters "without compromising a single plank in the Republican platform." Whether by design or coincidence, Mr. Bush appears to have followed the company's recommendations almost to the letter.
In March 1989 the Nathan Group recommended that the President meet with the Congressional Black Caucus "for the sole purpose of listening, and showing his sensitivity to black issues and a rapport." Two months later Mr. Bush met with 20 members of the caucus, the first time the group had been to the White House in eight years.
Among the recommendations made in a second memo, written in February, was that Mr. Bush look for opportunities to attend "significant black events such as speaking at major black institutions like Hampton University." Four weeks ago, Mr. Bush gave the commencement address at Hampton.
"In politics, perceptions are the only reality," The Nathan Group wrote. "The only thing that's going to count when black Americans consider the merits of the Republican Party is how their perceptions have been molded, negatively or positively."
But political consultants, like television programmers and advertising executives, have a way of underestimating the public. In a country still so divided, 27 years after the passage of the Civil Rights Act, voters both black and white may be less impressed by grand gestures than by concrete plans to lead them out of a dangerous racial impasse.

HEADLINE: NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Texas City, Tex.;
7-Year Hiatus On Malls Ends

BYLINE: By LETTICE STUART

 BODY:
THE Mall of the Mainlands, the first shopping mall built in the Houston area in seven years, has leased 60 percent of its 768,000 square feet and lured stores away from Galveston and Texas City.
The mall, which opened in March in this small town 35 miles southeast of Houston, is a joint venture of the Edward J. DeBartolo Corporation of Youngstown, Ohio, and the MGHerring Group of Dallas. 
 Plans had been on the drawing board since the MGHerring Group optioned the 122-acre site in 1978. M.G. Herring, the company's chief executive officer, said he bought the property expecting to build a mall within a few years, but had to shelve those plans when Houston's bubble burst in the mid-80's.
A flurry of overbuilding during the boom times, compounded by a sluggish economy that put many retailers out of business, left Houston with a glut of retail space. The last malls built in the Houston area were the 1.2 million-square-foot Deerbrook Mall and the 822,000-square-foot West Oaks Mall; both opened in 1984.
Another factor, the unavailability of financing, is a problem that has dramatically affected the shopping center industry nationwide, said Don Pendley, a spokesman for the International Council of Shopping Centers in New York City. Only 1,019 new centers were built in 1990, a 50 percent drop from the high of 2,036 built in 1986.
Texas City, with a population of 45,000, is the nation's 17th busiest port, specializing in imported crude oil, bulk minerals and dry chemicals. It is 15 miles from the growing tourist beach resort of Galveston on the Gulf of Mexico and is surrounded by small towns with few stores.
Normally, the geographic area that a retail development draws from -- called the trade area -- has five to six square feet of department and discount store space per person, but the Galveston County area has fewer than three, Mr. Herring said. Many shoppers have been going to the nearest regional malls, 13 and 22 miles away, he said.
In 1989, with Houston rebounding and DeBartolo as a partner, construction of Mall of the Mainland began. When it opened, 52 percent of its space was leased. Two anchors were Sears, which closed its store in Galveston's Galvez Mall, and J. C. Penney, which closed its downtown Texas City store.
The mall is DeBartolo's first shopping center in the Houston area. The Ohio firm, which began with a 48,000-square-foot shopping plaza in 1949, now owns or manages more than 86 million square feet of retail space in the country.
