SECTION: Section 6; Part 2; Page 27; Column 1; Business World Magazine

LENGTH: 3571 words

HEADLINE: HEALTH CARE;
MISSION + MARGIN: The Nun as C.E.O.

BYLINE: BY JOHN PAUL NEWPORT; John Paul Newport, who is based in New York, writes about business and ethics.

 BODY:
In the walnut-paneled mansfield room of the Capitol building in Washington, some 90 guests had eaten their fill of chicken with lemon sauce and a troop of white-coated waiters had begun clearing the dishes. As the decibel level rose, a woman slipped away from her table and, thick white hair peeking from the coiffe of her navy-blue habit, started to make her rounds.
Pausing at a nearby table, Sister Irene Kraus said a few words that set off peals of laughter. Then, linking arms with a diner, she led him briskly across the room to greet another guest. A moment later, chatting with two nuns, she broke into an impromptu dance. Sister Irene, 66, is the chief executive of the Daughters of Charity National Health System, the largest private, nonprofit hospital chain in the country. In fact, with its 36 acute-care hospitals, 19 other health-care facilities and net revenues last year of $3.1 billion, the Daughters are right behind such for-profit giants as Hospital Corporation of America and Humana. 
 The dinner in the Mansfield Room last summer was a gathering of the top executives from the system's eastern region, and Sister Irene was clearly in her element. "Work the crowd, work the crowd," she said with a resigned grin as she returned to her table for dessert. "We don't like to admit it, but there's a little bit of the political animal in all of us."
Sister Irene has had ample opportunity to exercise her political talents over the years -- as the chief executive of six successive Daughters' hospitals, as past chairman of the American Hospital Association (the only woman to hold that position) and as the guiding force behind the merger that created the hospital chain in 1986. Now she confronts two major tasks, which she sums up as "margin and mission."
Even before establishing the first Catholic hospital in the United States in 1828, the Daughters were dedicated to treating the poor. Each hospital in the chain, for example, is required to devote at least 25 percent of its operating income to that mission. At the same time, the Daughters are, financially speaking, on their own; today, more than ever, their survival depends on their ability to make tough, cost-effective decisions.
Expenses in the $221 billion hospital industry have risen at nearly twice the rate of inflation since 1984, while reimbursements from Medicaid, Medicare and private insurers have been drastically scaled back. Yet, at a time when most hospitals, profit and nonprofit alike, are losing money, the Daughters of Charity have managed to stay in the black -- and to win a top-of-the-industry Aa bond rating from Moody's Investors Service.
That performance flies in the face of the conventional wisdom, which holds that nonprofits are not serious businesses: They put mission ahead of margin, and thus lack the kind of efficiency achieved when the total focus is on earning a profit for shareholders. Of late, however, such informed observers as Peter F. Drucker have challenged that perception, noting a dramatic increase in the ranks of disciplined, innovative managers in the nonprofit sector. Sister Irene is one of the new breed.
Traditionally, the task of determining the right balance between margin and mission has been in the hands of the sisters themselves. That is rapidly changing as their ranks thin, in line with the dramatic decline in the number of American nuns. Lay people are already in charge of close to half of the Daughters' facilities. The final verdict on Sister Irene's stewardship may well depend on her success in inculcating the order's values in the laymen who will be running the system in the years ahead.
Go as slow as you want to on this matter, Jerry." Sister Irene was seated in her modest office in the Daughters' three-story, brick-and-glass headquarters in Maryland Heights, Mo., a suburb of St. Louis; her words were addressed to her chief financial officer. "People aren't quite ready for this one yet, so we might as well drag our feet. Don't you think?" Jerry P. Widman nodded and jotted down a few words on a pad.
The matter at hand was a proposal to require all hospitals in the chain to observe a common fiscal year-end. That would make accounting easier on the national level but raise some hackles among individual units. Sister Irene was concerned that the national office -- a staff of 108 people with a $12 million-a-year budget -- might be imposing too many new rules on its members. According to Sister Theresa Peck, the chief operating officer, Sister Irene's "instinctive sense of timing -- when to go ahead and when to pull back" is among the most indispensable of her managerial skills.
At meetings with her aides and in private conversation, the C.E.O. is typically forthright and amiable, often finishing her pronouncements with a small chuckle. Sometimes, though, the stern schoolmarm surfaces. On the agenda of her session with Widman was a real estate project that the Daughters had invested in at the behest of his money managers. Widman warned that the project was in some trouble. "We need to keep an eye on it," he said. Sister Irene responded curtly, "That's your job, sir."
But a moment later, the sun broke through again as she praised him for masterminding a Boston hospital's debt refinancing -- a maneuver that will save the facility $800,000 a year.
The Daughters' system is big business. Its hospitals, nursing homes, psychiatric centers and other medical facilities are scattered across the nation, primarily in urban settings; with 12,270 beds in service (out of 14,949 licensed beds) it is bigger than the next two largest Catholic systems combined. (About 10 percent of the country's hospitals are nonprofits operated by Catholic groups. In 1989, the latest year for which numbers are available, nonprofits as a whole accounted for 3,220 of America's 5,455 community hospitals. A mere 769 of the community hospitals were for-profit, and the remainder were facilities supported, in whole or part, by local and state governments.)
The order of the Daughters of Charity was founded in France in 1633 by St. Vincent de Paul and St. Louise de Marillac to care for "the sick, aged, infirm and necessitous persons," and the Daughters in the United States to this day look to the French motherhouse for guidance. Each of the hospitals reports to one of four regional headquarters. The regions were originally autonomous; five years ago, the single Daughters of Charity system was created.
The potential advantages of the move were clear: economies of scale, a wider sample from which to draw promising lay executives and a chance to develop what Sister Irene calls strong core values. Money management represented another opportunity. Now, at the end of each business day, cash from all the hospitals flows into a central national account and is invested at preferred rates. The financial bulk of the chain is such that its facilities can be self-insured, at minimal cost, with each member hospital paying an annual "premium" to the national office. Similarly, the 26 largest hospitals cross-guarantee each others' financial obligations.
"The genius behind a system like this one," says Charles J. Nellans, a research analyst at John Nuveen & Company in Chicago, "is that they reach a balance. Some hospitals have a bad year, another in another state will have a good year."
Yet the decision to merge was not easily made, and the restructuring of responsibilities has been an agonizing, years-long process. The basic problem was right out of a business school case study: How much authority would the individual regions and hospitals be willing to cede to the new national system? The person chosen to lead the national office would have to be a paragon: respected, patient, tough-minded, experienced in the ways of hospitals and the Daughters.
All of which led to Sister Irene, then chief executive of the 540-bed St. Vincent's Medical Center in Jacksonville, Fla.
Sister Irene's approach to the merger was clear from the start. "We wanted to keep as much function down at the local level as possible," she says, "without losing our ability to perform as a national system." The old fragmented reporting structure remains -- the local hospitals, the regions and the national system all maintain their own boards of directors. The regions retain much of their control over individual hospitals, including the authority to appoint chief executives, and the managers of the local hospitals take care of day-to-day operations and do their own fund raising.
Yet, bit by bit, the national office has taken on new responsibilities, including strategic planning, government affairs and auditing. Regions contemplating capital outlays of more than $10 million must now clear them with national. These changes have not always been greeted with enthusiasm. Some hospitals resented being forced to hire an internal auditor who reports directly to national headquarters. Others complain that headquarters does not sufficiently consult them before issuing new policies.
Sister Irene strongly disputes that charge; she points out that hospitals have 60 days to respond to any proposed system-wide policy before it is submitted to the national board for approval. What really keeps the system running smoothly, though, is an informal communications network. Proposals are hashed over endlessly in casual conversations in the halls or on the telephone. By the time any issue arrives formally at the national level, chances are a consensus has been reached.
At the center of this network is Sister Irene. She spends 60 percent of her time on the road, visiting virtually every hospital at least once a year. She knows them all intimately. On arrival at a facility, she walks about, meeting old friends, listening to problems, offering advice. The topics range from financial tactics to personal career choices to religion. Back at the office, the same process is transferred to the telephone.
Meanwhile, she supervises the national office. "It's amazing how accessible she is," says David H. LeMoine, senior vice president in charge of audit services. "It's hard for me to do anything wrong because I run practically everything by her first."
St. Vincent started the order to care for the poor," says Sister Irene, "but where did he spend most of his time? In the courts of France, that's where, sashaying around with all the ladies and the kings and the princes. And what for?" She rubs thumb and fingers together. " 'Give me your money,' he said." But times have changed; charitable gifts, royal or otherwise, no longer suffice. "In the United States in this day and age," says Sister Irene, "the way to do it is to run institutions that are financially solid."
Her own institution fits the description. "It's a very, very strong system," says Nellans of John Nuveen, which holds a sizable quantity of the Daughters' bonds. The privately placed bonds are issued by the Daughters to fund their capital investments. The system's approach is a model of conservative finance. "Our goal," says Jerry Widman, "is to have funds on hand equal to the amount of our debt." That sounds like a pipe dream in modern America, yet, as of 1990, the chain's indebtedness was $1.1 billion and its cash and short-term holdings totaled over $900 million.
The typical American company today, having made a $30 million investment in capital goods, will amortize it at the rate of $1 million a year but not actually set aside the cash needed to replace those goods when they wear out. The Daughters will.
The Daughters' vital signs are impressive. Their hospitals' occupancy rate for 1989 was 73 percent, some 7 percent above the industry at large. Currently, only five of the system's hospitals are operating at a loss. In fiscal 1990 the Daughters realized a surplus of about $190 million.
"Hospitals used to operate under the Robin Hood philosophy," says David J. Sauer, a vice president of the St. Louis-based Catholic Health Association. "Paying patients and third-party providers would, in effect, subsidize charity care."
But in 1984 Medicare and Medicaid, overwhelmed by health-care cost inflation, began limiting how much they would reimburse hospitals and doctors for specific procedures. Many private insurers, similarly strapped, followed suit. "The cost-shifting of yesterday is no more," says F. Dale Whitten, the Daughters' vice president for strategic planning.
In fiscal 1990, 50 percent of gross revenues from patients came from such ancillary sources as X-rays and hospital pharmacy operations; inpatient care brought in some 28 percent, and outpatient services, such as minor surgery, accounted for 23 percent. About 41 percent of the revenues from these three categories was provided by Medicare, 7 percent by Medicaid and 22 percent from other third-party payers such as health maintenance organizations.
To maintain their profitability in this increasingly pinched health-care environment, the Daughters have had to be hard-nosed and competitive. Their Florida hospitals were among the first to advertise on billboards ("When your Mom's chicken soup isn't enough," was one tag line). To lure physicians with large practices to sign on with system hospitals, the Daughters employ the same stratagems used by their rivals, from wining and dining the doctors to building high-technology-care units for such specialties as cancer and open-heart surgery.
But the Daughters also know when to bail out. After years of steadily losing business to a big new suburban hospital in Montgomery, Ala., the Daughters sold St. Margaret's hospital to Humana in 1989. In El Paso, Texas, the system decided to close its aging Hotel Dieu Medical Center rather than rebuild it because El Paso's other hospitals were already operating at less than 50 percent occupancy. Instead, the Daughters built a walk-in, primary-care clinic in one of the city's poorest neighborhoods.
During the last decade, the system's outpatient services have grown from about 5 percent of revenues to 23 percent. The move reflects the increasing unwillingness of insurers, especially Medicare, to reimburse hospitals for inpatient services that can now be done on an outpatient basis.
The shift means that the Daughters' big central hospitals now focus more on intensive care -- and that many rooms in these hospitals are no longer needed. National headquarters is helping in the conversion of such space into doctors' offices and other uses.
Sister Irene grew up in Baltimore in a home bursting with children -- five sisters, a brother and an all-but-permanent contingent of their friends. Her father, Frank B. Kraus, was an executive with the Pennsylvania railroad. As a schoolgirl at Seton High School -- named for Elizabeth Ann Seton, America's first canonized saint and the founder of the Daughters of Charity in this country -- she excelled at sports, dramatics and music and served as editor of the school newspaper and as a class officer. Along with a half dozen or so of her classmates, she joined the Daughters of Charity right after high school, in 1941. She was 17.
"I came from a home life that was as solid as it could be -- you wouldn't think of sassing your mother or your father -- and that's the same environment I found with the sisters," she says.
The order guided her into nursing. While working her way up the ladder from scrub nurse to operating-room supervisor to chief executive, she earned a bachelor's degree and eventually an M.B.A. at Florida Atlantic University.
As a C.E.O., Sister Irene frequently demonstrated her self-confidence and willpower. While head of St. Vincent's in Jacksonville, for example, she called for the construction of 15 affiliated health-care clinics across the city. The move made strategic sense, since Jacksonville's population was growing away from the hospital's east-side location, but it threatened the private practices of physicians near the new clinics. "The doctors in this city could have lynched her," says William C. Mason, chief executive of the Baptist Medical Center. "But when the dust settled, everyone saw the wisdom of what she had done."
Today, Sister Irene still lives the austere life that is an essential part of her vows as a Daughter of Charity. Her $200,000-plus salary goes directly to her original provincial house in Maryland, which in turn provides her with room and board, life-long health care and a stipend of about $300 a year to spend as she chooses.
Most mornings, Sister Irene rises at 4:30 for an hour of prayer and meditation in her provincial house in St. Louis. Then she and Sister Theresa attend mass, arriving at the office by 7 o'clock. At day's end, Sister Irene returns home for dinner, more prayer and a brisk walk or swim.
To some, Sister Irene's life might seem uncomfortably stretched by irreconcilable forces -- the contemplative demands of the religious community, her rambunctious personality, the edgy dickerings of the business world. But she seems to have reached an accommodation: "People sometimes ask me how I could go from hands-on nursing to a desk job. Didn't I join a religious community to save souls? So I came up with the term, 'the apostolate of administration.' Where are most major decisions made? Here." She thumps her desk for emphasis. "Justice, charity to employees, to patients, to doctors, advocating for the poor -- you can make great decisions and great policies from here that impact more lives than I could ever touch at bedside, one-on-one."
As nonprofit facilities, the hospitals of the Daughters of Charity enjoy certain advantages over for-profit competitors. For one thing, the Daughters are more likely to receive private gifts, though they amount to only some $7 million a year for the whole system, a tiny fraction of its revenues. A more significant advantage is the Daughters' tax-exempt status. Not only does the system pay no taxes, but its tax-free bonds can offer much lower interest rates than the bonds of its for-profit rivals.
In recent years, a controversy has flared over the tax exemptions granted non-profit hospitals. A bill has been introduced in Congress that would require them to return more to their communities in the form of charity care than the hospitals are saving in taxes. The Daughters of Charity are not among the critics' targets, having saved $65 million in taxes and provided some $76 million last year in direct charity care plus absorbing $947 million in Medicaid and Medicare underpayments and an additional $176 million in bad debts.
There is no commonly accepted method for measuring hospitals' delivery of charity care, which makes comparisons notoriously tricky. But according to the formula used in an American Hospital Association survey for 1989, the latest year for which figures are available, nonprofit hospitals on average devoted an amount equal to 6 percent of their gross patient revenues to uncompensated care, and the Daughters came in at 5.7 percent. The figure for for-profit institutions was 5.4 percent.
David LeMoine had been a partner at a major accounting firm before he joined the Daughters' national office, attracted by the degree to which religious values and a sense of mission would be a part of his new work life. Meetings always begin with prayer. Five core values -- including "simplicity" and "respect" -- serve as the basis for lectures and discussions. "Most of us executives," says LeMoine, who is not Catholic, "could make more money somewhere else. This mission stuff, as corny as it sounds, is really our motivation. At the place I came from, I was basically just working to fulfill the goals of the guy right above me, and I hated it."
The Daughters are in good corporate company in their effort to teach employees what the institution stands for. The Walt Disney Company and I.B.M. do the same. In the case of the hospital chain, though, the need is particularly urgent as the ranks of the Daughters of Charity get ever thinner. Sister Theresa Peck, who is 56, estimates that among the 350 sisters who work in the health ministry, there are only 12 to 15 younger than she who might one day be capable of administering a hospital.
At the training sessions for lay managers, Sister Irene says, "We want to talk about what you, as a leader in a Christian environment, would need to know from an ethical and moral point of view that would allow you to make good and just decisions when you consider a joint venture, or a new marketing campaign, or competition."
In fact, executives cite any number of examples of such decisions -- a malpractice suit that was settled generously even though attorneys felt the Daughters could have won in court; extra attention paid to on-the-job safety and hazardous waste disposal. And when religious principles collide with financial objectives, there is no question where loyalties lie. Abortions are never performed in Daughters of Charity hospitals, which also place a high priority on keeping obstetric facilities open.
Sister Irene is philosophical about the degree to which lay managers are replacing the religious in operating the hospitals. "Why shouldn't the laity be involved?" she asks. "We have no corner on being the only people who can help the poor. Because everything is cyclical. If and when God has a need for more of us, then I think we'll see it. We'll be back."

HEADLINE: Rapt by Roses, Maddened by Catalogues

BYLINE: By Maxine Kumin; Maxine Kumin's most recent books are "Nurture," a collection of poems, and "In Deep: Country Essays."

 BODY:

SECOND NATURE
A Gardener's Education.
By Michael Pollan.
258 pp. New York:
Atlantic Monthly Press. $21.95.  
 A pleasurable shiver of recognition gripped me midway through Michael Pollan's brief and disarming introduction to "Second Nature: A Gardener's Education." It seems that he and I have confronted the same woodchuck, relived Thoreau's problem when he made "the earth say beans instead of grass," and undergone the same physical and moral struggles to redeem our craggy hillside dairy farms in New England.
The author's maternal grandfather, a Russian emigre who started out in the New World selling produce from the back of a horse-drawn wagon, was a rigorous vegetable gardener who extirpated every weed that dared erupt in his orderly rows. His father, on the other hand, mowed his initials into the weedy front lawn rather than conform to his suburban neighbors' standards for an undivided grassy sward. Where, between two such polarized stances, might we reasonably expect to find this third-generation American?
Wittily, aphoristically and with great natural charm, Mr. Pollan, who is the executive editor of Harper's Magazine, discloses his considered position as gardener and humanist, sociologist, ironist and historian. He is at ease with topics ranging from the importation of Old World weeds into the New, to the proper dimensions and method of preparation of a large hole for a new tree.
On the latter subject, when opening the earth to receive the root ball of a tree in New England, expect "boulders the size of office safes." For starters, dig as deep as the root ball you are planting, dig twice as wide as deep, and fill the hole with water.
On the matter of weeds, we learn that virtually every so-called marauder we have come to pursue with vengeful hoe was brought here either accidentally or on purpose: Saint Johnswort in 1696 by Rosicrucians, who believed it had the power to ward off evil spirits if gathered on St. John's Eve; tumbleweed in the 1870's by Russians who planned to raise flax in South Dakota and carried the weed seeds with them unintentionally.
A disquisition on roses from the Middle Ages to the present opens the section titled "Summer." I found it an absolute tour de force; it enlarged my world view. As Mr. Pollan examines the social hierarchy of the old rose we traverse the Roman Empire, the Middle Ages, the Renaissance and the period of the Enlightenment with five major species, known across Europe. Compared with such modern cultivars as the hybrid ever-blooming tea rose, the old roses, he reports, are frankly sensual, overpoweringly perfumed and they bloom all at once, unreservedly, holding nothing back.
Mr. Pollan examines the petals of an alba -- one of the five royal families -- called Maiden's Blush. In France, "as Vita Sackville-West tells us, blooms that blush a particularly deep pink are given the 'highly expressive name' of Cuisse de Nymphe Emue . . . the thigh of an aroused nymph." Our author is carried away by the carnality of the flower. Compared to Maiden's Blush, he finds the new hybrids are "no more alluring or sexually aware" than Girl Scouts.
In another free-standing essay, "The Idea of a Garden," the impact of a 1989 tornado on the Cathedral Pines, a carefully preserved stand of old white pines in Cornwall, Conn., provides Mr. Pollan with an opportunity to discuss the community's divergent responses to this broad-scale destruction.
The Nature Conservancy wanted not to interfere with the natural forces that had been unleashed. Outraged citizens wanted the felled trees removed for esthetic, pragmatic and economic reasons. A classic environmental battle shaped up; its compromise solution gives Mr. Pollan a jumping-off place from which to examine the ethics of state-of-nature theories versus ecological restoration.
While this topic is indeed worthy of examination, the succeeding essay, "Made Wild by Pompous Catalogs," is the liveliest in the book. Here Mr. Pollan conducts a hilarious and trenchant analysis of the annual garden deluge that pours out of the mail pouch immediately after New Year's Day. For while all may be tranquil on the glossy surface of these catalogues brimming with luscious photographs, controversy lurks within. It seems that social and political differences infest each gaudy page that presages spring.
Mr. Pollan catapults us from the top of the hierarchy -- White Flower Farm and Wayside Gardens -- into the vast middle-class mainstream pamphlets from Burpee, Park, Harris, Stokes and Gurney's, and on to such counterculture houses as Johnny's Selected Seeds, the Vermont Bean Seed Company and Pinetree Garden Seeds, which exude "perhaps just a whisper of right eousness." For the break point between midcult and that faint whisper is perhaps clearest in the various catalogues' approach to pest control. From Johnny's on, the emphasis is on organic rather than chemical controls, sabadilla dust in place of Sevin, sexual lures to ensnare Japanese beetles rather than downright death-to-all powders.
The tour continues through Cook's and Shepherd's, which specialize in European and Oriental vegetables and aim to restore flavor and grace to the vegetable kingdom. While commerce has focused on the thick-skinned tomato that ships well and iceberg lettuce that travels unflappably for a week in a boxcar, these seed houses offer instead almost a dozen varieties of basil and even more subtle shades and variegated shapes of edible greens.
Mr. Pollan concludes with a discussion of "the fiery radicals of the garden world," Seeds Blum and J. L. Hudson, who, having declared war on the homogeneity of hybrid crops, are at work disseminating open-pollinated heirloom seeds. They seek to sustain a broad gene pool for the future, taking into consideration local crop conditions, disease resistance and above all, flavor.
Now these small demurrers. While I was happy to find Mr. Pollan firmly allied with those of us who oppose the wanton broadcast of pesticides and inorganic fertilizers on lawn and garden, I wish he had lingered a little longer over this vital subject. He writes about his earnest search for a vein of ancient cow manure he knows underlies some corner of his property, and we come upon him often sifting rich compost into his planting rows. But I miss an essay on mulch, a topic that gets only scant attention. Grandfather, with his straight lines of vegetables requiring continual and relentless weeding, might have benefited from opened-out pages of this newspaper topped with spoiled hay between his rows.
"Second Nature" is a treasure house of information for the serious gardener, a delightful read for any armchair strategist who has yet to pick up a hoe and as delicious a meditation on one man's relationship with the earth as any you are likely to come upon this year.

HEADLINE: The Executive Life;
Competitive Croquet? You Better Believe It

BYLINE: By Nancy Marx Better

 BODY:
Twilight settled over the manicured greensward in Central Park that serves as headquarters for the New York Croquet Club. Dressed in fresh-pressed whites -- polo shirt, Bermuda shorts, socks and sneakers -- Mike Gibbons concentrated hard on his last shot. "Yellow's dead on red and blue's dead on black," explained Mr. Gibbons, who is an executive vice president of Estee Lauder, the New York-based cosmetics giant. "I'm going for a rush."
Click. A tap of his mallet sent the red ball rolling. Click. It hit the blue ball, sending blue through the final wicket. He raised his mallet in victory. "This game is all about summing up a situation and making a quick decision," said Mr. Gibbons, a nationally ranked croquet player. "That's why executives are good at it. We're always strategizing." 
 Competitive croquet is a darling of the business set. The United States Croquet Association says there are 350 croquet clubs in 48 states today, up from just five in 1977. In a recent survey, it found that 88 percent of its 5,000 or so members identified themselves as businesspeople. "Croquet has been likened to warfare on the corporate battlefield," said Jack Osborn, founder and president of the Palm Beach-based U.S.C.A. "That's why it attracts so many executive types."
 Warfare? In a Great Gatsby-style game that's played while sipping champagne and nibbling caviar? Where sweat is caused solely by the sun? "In golf, you play against the course," said Mr. Osborn. "In croquet, you try to destroy your opponent." Hence, for executives, the game's charm: a sadistic streak belies its genteel veneer. "Croquet mimics office politics," said Tim Quinlan, an executive at Tesco, a Long Island-based direct marketing company. "You can really screw someone over if you want to."
Serious enthusiasts are quick to contrast competitive croquet and backyard croquet. It's like comparing the Yankees to a Little League team. Competitive croquet, either a singles or doubles match, is properly played on one-quarter-inch bentgrass with a time clock allowing 45 seconds per shot. The object seems simple: to get two different-colored balls through the six-wicket course before the other side does. But the rules -- and tactics -- are highly complex, requiring the concentration of chess and the coordination of billiards. "It helps if you're good at problem-solving," said Mr. Quinlan. "Then you can learn pretty fast."
For example, Will Hiltz, an executive vice president in Smith Barney's corporate finance department, learned to play in 1980. The next year, he made it to the United States championships -- where he came close to beating the defending champion. "I don't think there are many other sports where I could be nationally ranked after playing for a year," he said. "I could play golf my whole life and I'd never make it to Augusta."
Having a national ranking makes ribbing easier to take. "I get a lot of grief from my friends about playing croquet," said Bill Duncan, chairman of the First American Bank of New York. "But there's definitely a bit of agressiveness to it. You have to know when to advance and when to retreat. You have to map out a plan."
Since mental agility is valued over muscular prowess, gender makes little difference. "I beat men all the time," said Jean Arrington, secretary of the U.S.C.A. In fact, croquet was the first game that allowed women in Victorian England to compete directly with men. It's the quintessential "level playing field" -- which helps account for its growing popularity among convention planners.
When Levi Strauss and Transamerica, both based in San Francisco, held management meetings last fall at the Meadowood Resort in St. Helena, Calif., croquet was on the agenda. The Breakers hotel in Palm Beach conducts clinics for beginners on business trips. "It's not like golf, where it takes up the whole afternoon," says Gretchen Deweese, publicity director for the Breakers. "You can play a game in an hour or two, and get back to work."
 Like golf, however, croquet can be addictive. Robert Clayton, retired chief executive officer of the New York securities firm of Laidlaw Adams & Peck, became so enthralled that he installed a state-of-the-art court at his Long Island beach house. Several of his cronies -- including Charles Lazarus, C.E.O. of New Jersey-based Toys 'R' Us -- followed suit. "Maintaining a court is a big commitment," said Mr. Clayton. "You have to water it every day and mow it several times a week." The U.S.C.A. estimates that it costs about $4,000 a year to care for a standard 105-by-84-foot court. A set of top-quality equipment can run $3,500.
While croquet has long been associated with the rich and powerful, advertisers like Rolex and BMW have only lately discovered its allure. One selling point: a 1987 U.S.C.A. study that found members had an average income of $125,000 and that 25 percent were millionaires. "The demographics of the sport are extremely upscale," said Mr. Gibbons.
But even croquet can't escape the lingering recession. Two major sponsors -- menswear manufacturer Gieves & Hawkes and retailer Abercrombie & Fitch -- have abandoned plans to host upcoming U.S.C.A. tournaments. "They've suspended promotions for this summer due to the downturn in their industry," said Mr. Osborn. "When the economy picks up, they'll be back."
By then, with more public courts available and popularity on the rise, the game may have a more egalitarian following. "I think it's losing the elitist image," said Ms. Arrington of the U.S.C.A. "Some of our younger players are construction workers and machinists. They don't all drive around in Jaguars."

HEADLINE: FORUM;
How Business Can Help in Schools

BYLINE: By ROBERT B. REICH; Robert B. Reich is author of a new book, "The Work of Nations: Preparing Ourselves for 20th Century Capitalism."

 BODY:
With great hoopla, American corporations are entering into all sorts of partnerships with their local public schools -- such things as awarding cash grants to excellent teachers, donating computers to classrooms, encouraging corporate employees to tutor slow learners. But these represent scatter-shot approaches to America's core educational problem: the nation's growing number of young, unskilled workers.
The earnings of workers with only high school diplomas dropped 9 percent during the 1980's and the earnings of dropouts fell 12 percent. Before it is too late, American business must launch a coordinated national strategy to rescue youth who are not bound for college. Specifically: 
 1. Shift educational giving from prestigious colleges to public elementary and secondary schools. Of the $2.6 billion contributed by American corporations to education in 1989, only $248 million went to support public primary and secondary schools. The rest went to colleges and universities and to private secondary schools, whose students are already well-positioned to thrive in the global economy. Less likely to succeed are many of the children in public primary and secondary schools.
2. In devoting resources to the public schools, look beyond the schools where the company is headquartered. Schools near corporate headquarters may not be the ones whose students are in the greatest danger of dropping out or of failing to gain basic skills. For example, some of the nation's most impressive corporate-school partnerships are in Fairfield, Conn. -- where, not incidentally, several major American companies are based and where some of America's best-endowed public schools already offer a first-class education. But much more in need of corporate partners are schools in poor rural townships or working-class metropolitan areas.
3. Don't starve the public schools in industrial areas by demanding tax breaks from the community as a condition for coming or staying there. In 1957, corporations accounted for about 45 percent of local tax revenues; in 1989, around 16 percent. It's easy for a corporation to get an inviting tax deal simply by suggesting to municipal officials that without tax incentives the company won't locate there, or will leave. But because individual taxpayers in many of these industrial communities can't afford to make up the difference, the quality of public education suffers. Yet these are the very schools in which the proportion of young people not going to college typically is high.
4. Give summer jobs to high schoolers. Summer jobs provide one of the best means for teenagers to become acquainted with the world of work and the discipline it requires.
5. Collaborate with the public schools to design and provide apprenticeships for jobs that will await high school graduates upon completion. All too often, high school students not headed for college are dumped into vocational-education classes that are little more than holding bins. What students most need is technical training under the tutelage of skilled workers, within apprenticeship programs carefully designed to supplement classroom work -- and with guaranteed jobs awaiting successful completion, as in Germany.
6. Hire students for full-time jobs directly out of high school. American corporations often require that employees possess some college or postsecondary vocational training before they are hired -- even for nontechnical jobs. Typically, the requirement is meant to insure that new employees have achieved a minimum standard of literacy and numeracy. A better way is for the corporation to rely on standardized tests, which high school seniors can take voluntarily.
7. Base hiring decisions on overall school performance. Students who are not going to college often fail to apply themselves in high school because they don't see any connection between their performance in school and their prospects for a good job when they graduate. That is because companies rarely inquire about high school performance during the hiring process.
8. Train noncollege employees. American corporations claim to spend almost $30 billion a year on employee training, but most of the training goes to college graduates, who are twice as likely to have access to corporate training as employees without college degrees. As a result, people without college degrees are often consigned to dead-end jobs, with no hope for promotion and little job security.
Following these eight principles may be less dramatic than donating computers to classrooms. But taken together, they offer the means by which corporate America can have an even more profound effect on the lives of America's children who are most at risk of failing in the new economy.

HEADLINE: Metro Matters;
Tick, Tick, Tick: Cuomo Can Afford To Wait on 1992

BYLINE: By SAM ROBERTS

 BODY:
If "they also serve who only stand and wait" becomes the axiom of the 1992 Presidential campaign, no Democrat can stand to wait longer than Gov. Mario M. Cuomo.
Mr. Cuomo says he has no plans to run, no plans to make plans and no plans not to make plans. But the thirst for leadership in the Democratic Party and the vacuum that it is in the nature of political reporters to abhor even more than politicians (witness an earlier New York Governor's rush to fill the vacuum created by Hoover) prompt many to continue to discount Mr. Cuomo's repeated, if marginally less unequivocal, disavowals of candidacy. 
 In 1990, Mr. Cuomo declined to declare that his decision to seek another four-year term as Governor would signal his refusal to run for President two years later. He has not declared flatly, as he did four years ago during a radio interview program, that he would not be a candidate.
"Everybody ignored it and, in effect, they called me a liar for six months," Mr. Cuomo recalled. "I'm not going to do it again. I wouldn't insult myself or lose my dignity by playing the media's game."
 The more he insists that he is not engaging in any game at all, the more he tries to trans form the political liability of his home state's tribulations. And the more he talks about leaving it.
 "I will tell the New York story everywhere they want to hear it," he says, because, he maintains, that story represents the best ex ample of a state that is coping with economic and social change and the consequences of national economic policies. "New York State is as close to a miniature for the nation as you can get," he says, pointing out that it is mostly rural, dependent on agriculture and is being invigorated by immigrants: "This is the future of the country."
Mr. Cuomo acknowledges that he is likely to bear the brunt of public blame for the state's embarrassing budget delay. "How can I convince anyone in Utica it's Mel Miller's fault? They never heard of Mel Miller," he said, referring, for others who never heard of him either, to the Assembly Speaker from Brooklyn. "Just as President Bush will have to pay for the failed national economy," the Governor added, "no matter how many Persian Gulf wars we win."
One unintended consequence of the record delay in getting a budget approved has been to buy him more time. Moreover, if Mr. Cuomo indeed became a front-runner for the nomination, then another political axiom could prevail: The less time spent as a front-runner, the better. In 1992, more convention delegates are likely to be selected sooner, which means that more money will have to be raised and spent sooner -- particularly by candidates without national stature, like former Senator Paul E. Tsongas of Massachusetts and Senators Tom Harkin of Iowa and John D. Rockefeller 4th of West Virginia.
"The clock is very cruel to them," said Paul Tully, political director of the Democratic National Committee.
A candidate who procrastinates risks missing some technical deadlines for organizing, elevating minor mistakes into egregious errors in the glare of publicity and falling short of fund-raising goals. But if a vacuum persists, more familiar candidates could benefit from an explosion in campaign coverage and an apparent diminution in the attention paid to early caucuses and even primaries in unrepresentative states like Iowa and New Hampshire.
If Mr. Cuomo has not decided already, he and other prominent potential candidates may not have to until well beyond the summer. "He can wait longer than anybody in the field," said Thomas E. Donilon, a Democratic strategist.
"I'm suggesting you can wait pretty late in the year," said John A. Marino, whom Mr. Cuomo installed as chairman of the Democratic State Committee.
"I don't think he has to make a final decision until December," said David Garth, a Cuomo friend and political consultant.
As Governor of New York, Mr. Cuomo has visibility. Some of his campaign money could be applied to a Presidential race. He has consistently articulated a case against President Bush, whose popularity could erode because of the economy, his health or his running mate.
Doubts predominate, though, particularly about whether Mr. Cuomo would feel comfortable about running and whether he could govern and conduct a grueling campaign simultaneously. Yet even if a challenge looks like a lost cause, Mr. Cuomo once remarked that "there can be a nobility in facing an uphill struggle, even one that seems nearly impossible, but only if you feel good about yourself and what you're doing."
The Governor was feeling good the other day. "I am very good with ideas," he was saying. "There's no important domestic issue I haven't dealt with. I can also talk about foreign affairs -- free trade, China, most-favored-nation status. Do you know where Matilda and I just celebrated our anniversary? In Columbia County, at a Japanese restaurant."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: PRESS NOTES;
Maxwell Fights Murdoch On a New Front: Coupons

BYLINE: By Alex S. Jones

 BODY:
WHILE The Daily News battles for survival on many fronts, the fight over coupons for such things as a 75-cent discount on a Jell-O cheesecake has become a major engagement that the New York paper has been losing.
The coupon fight is another front in the war between Robert Maxwell, the British publisher who owns The Daily News, and Rupert Murdoch. The two have competing newspapers in London, and Mr. Maxwell has started a new horse-racing paper, The Racing Times, to compete with The Daily Racing Form, which was until recently controlled by Mr. Murdoch.
Mr. Murdoch's News Corporation also owns Quad Marketing Inc. and Product Movers Inc., two of the three companies that produce the coupon booklets in many Sunday newspapers.
 Coupons are an important source of revenue for papers and attract readers. But all three coupon companies stopped placing coupons in The Daily News when its Sunday circulation fell sharply from 1.1 million in the five-month strike that ended in March, when Mr. Maxwell bought the paper.
The Daily News immediately started trying to woo advertisers back by guaranteeing that its audited Sunday circulation would average at least a million for the six months ending in September. A News spokesman said the paper was "on target," but declined to give numbers.
Thus far, however, none of the coupon booklets have returned to The Daily News, although they do appear Newsday and The New York Times.
Les Goodstein, vice president of advertising at The News, said the non-Murdoch coupon company, Valassis Inserts Inc., would begin placing its coupons in The News by mid-July. David A. Brandon, president of Valas sis, said a deal with The News was close, but not yet complete.
 Should Valassis coupons return toThe Daily News, the other two coupon companies may be under greater pressure from package-goods companies to go back as well.
 But Ken Bortner, president of Mr. Murdoch's News America Publishing, said its coupon booklets would not return to The News unless the rates came down drastically.
"If our coupons are to be used to build circulation, we should have an incentive to go back," he said. "If we just help Mr. Maxwell and not Mr. Murdoch, what's the point?"
At The Daily News, there is suspicion that the absence of the coupon books is not based on economics.
"Murdoch just does not want to do business with Maxwell; that's the end of the story," said a News executive who spoke on condition of anonymity.
But Mr. Goodstein said he remained "confident that at some point we'll get the business back."
And Mr. Bortner said, "Given the right structure and right terms, something could be worked out."
 
Editorial Feud Continues
For 15 years, readers of the editorial pages in Shreveport, La., have been able to choose between the conservative voice of The Times of Shreveport and the outspoken liberalism of The Shreveport Journal.
The Journal ceased publication in April, but its prickly editorial page has survived and appears Monday through Friday side-by-side with The Times's editorial page. On Saturday, The Times's op-ed page separates the feuding views, and Sunday belongs to The Times exclusively because The Journal did not publish on Sunday.
"As far as I know, this is unique," said Charles T. Beaird, the 68-year-old Shreveport native who has the right to express his liberal views in The Times until 2000.
Starting in 1953, The Times, owned by the Gannett Company, and The Journal were published in a joint operating arrangement in which they merged production, business and delivery operations and split the profits.
The Journal, the afternoon paper, lost money, so the much-larger Times said the arrangement would not be renewed when it expired in 1994. But The Journal owned the rights to the paper's press, a complication.
The compromise was to close The Shreveport Journal but continue the editorial page. And Mr. Beaird's family will also receive The Journal's roughly 20 percent share of The Times's profits until 1994.
 
Latest Bout for Trump
When it comes to negative press coverage, Donald J. Trump usually attacks. So the New York developer recently declared war on a Wall Street Journal reporter.
Norman Pearlstine, the executive editor, acknowledges that his reporter might have used better judgment -- and has second thoughts about a time when he accepted Mr. Trump's expensive hospitality.
But he expressed full confidence in Neil Barsky, who has been covering Mr. Trump for The Wall Street Journal since 1989, and said Mr. Barsky would continue on the Trump beat and would not be reprimanded.
On May 31, The Journal published an article by Mr. Barsky that said Mr. Trump's finances were was so strained that the developer might have to borrow money from his father.
 Mr. Trump denounced the article as untrue and charged that Mr. Barsky had asked for free tickets to the Holyfield-Foreman fight, staged by Mr. Trump in Atlantic City on April 19.
 Mr. Pearlstine said Mr. Trump told him that Mr. Barsky had been given three $1,000 tickets and then asked for two more tickets and a hotel suite, which were refused. Mr. Trump charged that Mr. Barsky was retaliating with his article.
Mr. Pearlstine said what happened was quite different. He said a Trump official offered a ticket to Mr. Barsky. The Journal's policy generally prohibits accepting gifts. Mr. Barsky asked Fred R. Bleakley, the news editor, whether he should accept.
Mr. Barsky wanted to go to the fight to gain access to top Trump executives. Mr. Bleakley did not express strong opposition, which he now regards as his mistake.
Mr. Barsky accepted the ticket, was invited to take two and agreed, so his brother could go. He paid $100 for a third ticket for his father, but when he went to pick up the two free tickets, he was offered a third $1,000 ticket for his father. He accepted.
But The Journal says there were no requests for two additional tickets or a free hotel suite.
Mr. Barsky said he probably should have refused the tickets. "I made a mistake, and it's a beaut," he said.
And Mr. Pearlstine said, "The fact that Donald chose to call and complain a month after the event rather than at the time suggests that he was seeking favorable coverage and is upset he didn't get it."
Mr. Pearlstine said he might have erred when he accepted Mr. Trump's invitation in 1988 to a helicopter ride to Atlantic City and free tickets for the Tyson-Holmes fight. He said he reasoned that the trip would enable him to meet valuable news sources. "If he offered the tickets today, I would not accept them," he said.
Mr. Trump said he was "strongly considering major legal action" against The Journal and Mr. Barsky.
But Mr. Pearlstine was skeptical that such a suit would ever be filed. He said The Journal had sent $3,000 to Mr. Trump for the tickets.

HEADLINE: Angola's New War;
As Battle Lines Form for Elections, Ruling Party Secures Grip on Power

BYLINE: By KENNETH B. NOBLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LUANDA, Angola, June 9

 BODY:
It will long be debated who won and who lost Angola's 16-year civil war, but most diplomats and political experts here believe that as the nation prepares to hold its first free elections, the leftist Government has an edge in the coming campaign.
 The peace accord signed in Lisbon on May 31, culminating a year of talks involving Washington and Moscow as well as the warring factions, provides for elections in the second half of 1992. But the pact gives the Luanda Government sweeping powers in the interim, at least for the moment, say analysts examining the document's fine print. 
 For one thing, the accord says nothing about the legal framework for elections. Those details are to be worked out by a political and military commission made up of the Angolan Government, rebel representatives and representatives from the three mediating governments, the United States, the Soviet Union and Portugal, who are scheduled to hold their first meeting on June 17.
 
Ruling Party Holds On
 Jardo Mulekalia, the Washington representative of the Angolan rebel organization, the National Union for the Total Independence of Angola, or Unita, said in a telephone interview that Unita would insure that the Government would not hold sway over the voting arrangements.
"We will have our say about how the election will be run," the official said. "The Government's laws are not going to be the final word."
But until new electoral rules are hammered out -- a process that could take months -- the Luanda Government can make whatever rules it likes. And so far, the narrowly based, rigidly centralized ruling party has shown little inclination to loosen its grip.
Last week, during the seemingly endless round of parades and rallies staged by the Government to mark the end of the civil war, the ruling party, the People's Movement for the Liberation of Angola, made sure its posters and slogans blanketed the city. Other groups were strongly discouraged from doing the same.
In fact, until the Government issues new press and political association rules -- and it seems in no rush to do so -- other groups are barred from even trying to canvass new members without its permission. "The Government's got a monopoly on power, and they're not going to give it up easily," said one observer.
 
Counting on Ethnic Loyalty
 Despite the restrictions, new centrist parties hoping to profit from popular disenchantment with the warring factions are sprouting almost daily. So far, at least 25 groups have sought recognition from the Government to participate in next year's elections. But for the moment they appear to be little known and without strong leadership.
"With a little time, these new groups could pose a challenge to the M.P.L.A and Unita, because there's a real yearning for an alternative," said one Western diplomat. "But right now, they're too green."
The most potent element in the contest, however, could be the enduring power of regional and ethnic loyalities. And in this realm, too, the ruling power appears to have an edge.
The presumed political base of the Unita leader, Jonas Savimbi, is the mostly rural and agrarian central highlands, the region dominated by his ethnic group, the Ovimbundu.
The ruling party, by contrast, draws its support mostly from Kimbundu people of Luanda, Angola's capital, and the nearby Cuanza Valley.
 
A Possible Swing Party
 If voting occurred along regional and ethnic lines, which is often the case in Africa, Mr. Savimbi and his supporters could get about 40 percent of the vote, mainly from the Ovimbundu. The People's Movement, analysts say, would probably win support from the Kimbundu and the Luanda-Chowde people in the northeast, who together form about 35 percent of the population.
Under such circumstances, choices made by a third major ethnic group, the Bakongo, concentrated in the northeast but also living in pockets along the Congo and Zaire borders, could prove decisive. The Bakongo group, significantly, was the ethnic base of the National Front for the Liberation of Angola, which fought against both the People's Movement and Unita during the bloody years following Angola's independence from Portugal in 1975.
For Angola's nearly nine million people, the voting process is the first peaceful struggle for power many have known. Before the civil war that claimed more than 300,000 lives erupted in November 1975, the country had experienced years of guerrilla warfare as nationalists demanded freedom from Portugal.
Last year Portugal, acting as a mediator, brought the United States-backed Unita and Soviet-backed People's Movement together for the first of what would be seven negotiating sessions ending in the cease-fire accord signed last month.
Holden Roberto, the former leader of the National Front, who now lives in Paris, recently signaled that he would return to Angola soon, but it was not certain what he intended to do.
Many of his followers have recently joined the ruling People's Movement. While Mr. Roberto is said to be still opposed to the other factions, political observers here believe the Bakongo are likely to vote in large numbers in favor of the People's Movement.
 
Skepticism Abounds
 An issue that could still hurt the ruling party, however, is its two decades of rigid adherence to Marxist-Leninist policies. Only last fall, in the wake of democratic changes sweeping Africa, did the party abandon Marxism and declare itself a social democratic force.
Since then, almost nothing once sacrosanct to the party leaders has been left untouched. Mention of Marxism is virtually taboo, and mention of the topic is met with insistent disavowals of the doctrine. Advocacy of free markets and of economic competition are now standard.
Although the Government's political offensive has had some success, judging by the crowds at its rallies last week, the overall effort seems to be mired in popular skepticism. Many Angolans seem unwilling to forgive the Government for the suffering brought on by years of repressive rule.
"The M.P.L.A. has still got a huge image problem here," said a teacher who spoke on condition of anonymity. "People don't trust overnight conversions."

HEADLINE: U.S. Gap In World Investing

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 9

 BODY:
Foreign investment in the United States exceeds American investment overseas by much more than most economists had previously believed, according to two new measurements released today by the Commerce Department.
The department's previous calculations of the nation's net investment position, which showed an even greater United States deficit than the new measures, had been widely discounted by many economists as outdated and badly understating the value of American investments overseas and of the Federal Government's holdings in gold. 
 While the earlier calculations, for example, indicated a deficit of more than $660 billion in American investment overseas in 1989, private economists were predicting that, if correctly calculated, the deficit would be less than $200 billion, and some suggested it might be non-existent.
 
At Least $281 Billion
 The Commerce Department took the criticisms into account in the new measures of international investment released today. Nonetheless, the figures showed that foreign investments in the United States still exceeded American investments overseas by at least $281 billion and possibly $464 billion in 1989, the latest year for which data were available.
Allan H. Young, the director of the department's Bureau of Economic Analysis, said his statisticians had spent a year reviewing much more detailed information than the outside economists had been able to use.
The significance of the figures is hotly debated. Some economists contend that they simply show that the United States is a good place to invest and that international capital markets are functioning properly in sending money here.
But other economists and many politicians have warned that the nation's investment position shows that the United States is no longer competitive in world markets and has mortgaged its future to foreigners.
The department has traditionally used three different techniques for adding up United States investments abroad and foreign investments in the United States. Bonds, small stakes in companies and Federal Government holdings of foreign currencies were valued at current market prices. So-called direct investments -- which include land, factories, corporate subsidiaries and large stakes in companies -- were valued at their original purchase prices, even if they were bought many years ago. And year after year, the Federal Government's large holdings of gold were valued at just $42 an ounce.
Under the original-purchase-price measure, America's net investment position turned negative in 1984, when the value of foreign holdings in the United States based on their purchase price exceeded the similar value of United States holdings overseas by $2.2 billion. By 1989, the deficit by this measure had swelled to $663.7 billion.
 
No Appreciation Factor
 Economists outside the Commerce Department have long criticized these figures as erroneous and misleading. American companies made huge investments overseas in the 1960's and 70's that must have appreciated in value since then, they said, adding that large foreign direct investment in the United States is a comparatively recent phenomenon.
Yet the department's statistics would have counted a $10 million American purchase of a company in Tokyo 40 years ago, for example, the same as a $10 million Japanese purchase of a company in New York 4 years ago.
The Commerce Department addressed this problem in the revised measurements released today by valuing gold at the price prevailing at the end of each year and by following two different methods proposed by private economists for calculating direct investments.
One approach, known as a market-value calculation, multiplies American investments in foreign companies and subsidiaries by the appreciation in each foreign country's stock market since the investment was made. An international index of stock markets is used for small countries without their own well-developed stock markets.
This calculation produced a deficit of $281.4 billion in 1989, the most recent year available. Figures for 1990, using any system of calculations, will not be available until next month.
The Commerce Department's other new approach, known as a current-cost calculation, values investments in land, factories and other tangible assets at current prices. The department assumed that land appreciated at the same rate as overall prices in each economy, a technique that the department's statisticians acknowledged might underestimate the actual appreciation.
Taking this depreciation into account and factoring in exchange-rate fluctuations, the net United States investment deficit was $463.9 billion.
 
A 'Trivial' Gap
 Robert Eisner, the William R. Kenan Professor of Economics at Northwestern University and a former president of the American Economic Association, said that this deficit was too small to be meaningful.
"Whether it's $800 billion, $600 billion or $400 billion is trivial compared to a national wealth of $20, $30 or $40 trillion, depending on how you measure it," he said.
Even if the deficit is large and widening, Professor Eisner said, it may not be important. The extra annual interest and earnings payments leaving the United States will tend to exceed incoming interest and earnings payments by only a few billion dollars, a tiny amount in a nearly $6 trillion economy, he said.
It is also not entirely accurate to refer to the United States as a net debtor nation, Professor Eisner said, because little of the foreign investment in the United States has taken the form of outright loans, as opposed to investments in United States stock, land and factories.
If foreigners wanted to sell these assets quickly, Professor Eisner said, the value of the dollar would fall and the value of American investments overseas, valued in other currencies, would rise. Thus, he added, the nation's net investment position would come back into balance.
Some politicians have expressed concern that the United States may have mortgaged its future by becoming a net debtor nation.
"The figures confirm that the U.S. has become a major international debtor," Senator Max S. Baucus, Democrat of Montana, chairman of the Senate Subcommittee on International Trade, said today in a statement. "There is no denying that the net creditor/debtor position of the U.S. has slipped dramatically in the last 10 years."

HEADLINE: For Young Theatrical Experiment, Two Down and How Many to Go?

BYLINE: By MERVYN ROTHSTEIN

 BODY:
When "Our Country's Good" closed on Saturday night at the Nederlander Theater, a little more than a month after the play about 18th-century Australian convicts opened, it marked the second flop in two tries for the Broadway Alliance, the plan set up last year to encourage the production of more serious plays and the growth of new audiences by reducing both costs and ticket prices.
And while many theater people say it is much too soon to pass final judgment on the alliance, most of them add that changes must be made to improve its chances of success. 
 Those changes, they say, include increasing the strict limits on budgets for production and advertising and raising ticket prices to the level of Off Broadway. In addition, they say, producers of an alliance play that becomes a hit should be allowed to switch it to a potentially more lucrative full Broadway contract, raise ticket prices to standard Broadway levels and move it to a more glamorous Broadway house.
"It's basically a wonderful idea to produce shows on Broadway and make them available to the public under Off Broadway conditions at theaters that would otherwise be unoccupied," said Bernard B. Jacobs, president of the Shubert Organization, Broadway's largest theater owner, describing the alliance's policy up to now. "But the conditions have to be altered and made more realistic."
 
$400,000 Top Cost
 Under terms of the alliance plan agreed to last year by a coalition of Broadway producers, theater owners, craft guilds and unions, the plays must be produced for no more than $400,000 instead of the $800,000 to $1 million the average serious play costs these days.
Royalties, many salaries and other costs for alliance plays are cut by an average of at least 25 percent. Ticket prices range from $10 or $12 to a maximum of $24, compared with the present nonmusical top on Broadway of about $40 to $45 and the Off Broadway ticket price of about $30. The producer is not allowed to change to a full Broadway contract, increase prices or take the play to a bigger theater.
Frank and Woji Gero, co-producers of "Our Country's Good," said that a realistic budget figure would be $500,000 and that a realistic ticket price would be about $30.
"We were longing to use a slogan like 'Broadway at Off Broadway prices," Ms. Gero said, "but we couldn't because our prices were cheaper than Off Broadway. We think they should match Off Broadway."
Increasing the budget and raising the ticket prices would also provide more money for advertising and marketing. "I think you have to allow a little more room to advertise and promote the show," said Rocco Landesman, president of Jujamcyn Theaters, who is a major supporter of the alliance. "Right now it's on a bit of a starvation diet."
 
Need for Advertising
 Mr. Jacobs said that "if a show gets rave reviews, there's no way to tell the public, because you don't have the advertising budget for it." He added that the producer should also have the incentive of being able to make more money from a hit by making it a regular Broadway attraction.
Under the alliance, each of the three major Broadway theater owners -- Shubert, Jujamcyn and the Nederlander Organization -- designates one of its theaters for alliance plays. Mr. Jacobs said he thought the plan should be expanded to include more of the theaters that are frequently dark.
Mr. Landesman said he hoped that "the unions, particularly Actors' Equity, which has had the most rigid attitude toward the alliance, will be open and accommodating and figure out what adjustments to make in the structure to make it work better."
But Alan Eisenberg, executive secretary of Actors' Equity and chairman of the alliance committee, which is to meet later this month, said he thought talk about change was "premature."
"The whole point of this was to do small plays, with small casts and one set," Mr. Eisenberg said. "Let's not lose sight of what this is about. 'Our Country's Good' should not have been done under the alliance. It was too big. It had too many actors." The play has a cast of 10.
 
Economics of Reality
 Some theater people say privately that the alliance plan, which is to expire in February, has never made sense, that it doesn't take into account the reality of Broadway economics. The only plays that will be done under the alliance, they say, are ones for which producers would have trouble raising money under any circumstances, plays with very limited chances of success.
They say it is doubtful whether the public will pay to see a serious drama on Broadway at any price if it has no big-name star. And if the play has a major star, or a star playwright like Neil Simon, the producer would have no interest in the alliance, they add. So if a typical Broadway play has about a 60 percent chance of success, they conclude, an alliance play's hopes are 20 percent, and the spending limitations make things even worse.
In addition, some theater people have questioned whether the reduced prices make potential theatergoers think they are being sold damaged goods.
But the alliance's supporters disagree. All they need, they say, is a hit.
"Having two failures doesn't help," Mr. Gero said. "But there's nothing wrong with the alliance that a hit won't solve."
Mr. Landesman said that both the first alliance play -- "The Speed of Darkness" by Steve Tesich, which closed in March after only 36 performances -- and "Our Country's Good," by the little-known playwright Timberlake Wertenbaker, would have had "problematic runs" even if they had been done Off Broadway.
"All the Broadway Alliance needs is plays that people want to see," he said. "I think the biggest mistake would be to write the alliance off because it started with a couple of plays that didn't work."
Mr. Eisenberg noted that both plays received only middling reviews. "A play that's received well by the critics will be the test of whether this works or not," he said.
Now the alliance awaits the fall season and its next play, hoping it will fare better. Jane Slotin, plan manager for the alliance, said that the producers of one play would soon announce their intentions to open it in the fall.
And the Geros say they, too, are planning to bring in a new American play under the alliance in October or November. Yes, they acknowledge, "Our Country's Good" was a financial failure. "But we got six Tony nominations," Ms. Gero said. "So maybe we've helped the alliance take a few baby steps forward."

HEADLINE: Report Critical of Drop in Savings

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, June 9

 BODY:
Criticizing the United States in particular, the coordinating bank for the world's central banks said today that long-term economic growth in the industrial world was slipping because of a sharp drop in savings as well as a decline in public investment by many governments.
In a report issued today, the Bank for International Settlements said the drop in savings -- which provides the money for investment for future growth -- could also hurt Eastern Europe and the third world because they need to attract investment money to spur their economies. 
 The bank, which is often called the central bankers' central bank, said the budget deficits in the United States and many other countries are the main reason for the decline in savings. The bank said the imbalance between the supply of savings and the demand for investment money has created a capital shortage that has pushed real interest rates to near-record levels.
"The high level of real long-term interest rates in virtually all countries is widely seen as a reflection of such a shortage," said the bank, which is based in Basel, Switzerland.
The bank's annual report added that many governments, but most notably the United States Government, are also undermining economic growth by curtailing investment in core public infrastructure, like roads and public transportation. The report said empirical evidence showed a link between such investment and the rate of economic growth.
"A deterioration in infrastructure over the past decade is clearly evident in the United States, where the problem is concentrated in major cities," said the bank, which is known more for conservative views than Keynesian ones. "Decisions on government spending priorities must take account of the growth-enhancing aspects of appropriate public investment."
 
Drop in Public Investment
 The report stated that net public investment in the United States, for projects like roads, bridges and airports, has dropped to one-quarter of 1 percent of total economic output, by far the lowest of all major industrial nations. In Japan, net public investment is 5.7 percent of output, and in Germany, 3.7 percent.
"Regions investing more in infrastructure," the bank stated, "tend to have higher output, productivity and employment growth. Public investment often stimulates output growth by providing a base on which private investment can build."
The report said an increase in national saving was important not just to spur growth but to help relieve pressures expected to arise from a projected long-term increase in the proportion of the elderly in the indusrial world.
 
Low U.S. Savings Rate
 "The decline in national saving may be an important factor in the slower improvement in living standards in a number of industrial countries," the bank said.
The bank noted that net national saving in the United States dropped from 10.8 percent of gross national product in the 1960's to 4 percent in the 1980's. That compares with a 20.9 percent rate in Japan in the 80's, and an 11.6 percent rate in what had been West Germany.
Some economists have argued that the drop in national saving is a result, not a cause, of slower economic growth. But the bank, backing the argument that low savings rates cause low growth, noted that in the 1980's Japan had the highest savings rate and highest real wage growth rate of the major industrial countries. In contrast, the United States had the lowest savings rate and lowest growth in real wages.
 
Constraints on Growth
 The bank noted that the industrial world's recent economic slowdown has helped raise the savings rate. But it added that "the longer-term decline in national saving in many countries remains a constraint on capital investment and, ultimately, growth in the world economy."
The report said that in the short term, Eastern Europe and the developing world will not make significant demands on Western capital because Western corporations and banks will not find them an attractive place to invest. But if the reform process is successful in Eastern Europe, the report said, a much greater strain on the West's savings could result.
The bank noted that net saving among the major industrial countries dropped to 10 percent of gross national product in the 1980's, from 13.5 percent in the 60's. Almost all the drop was caused by a decline in government saving, rather than in private saving. The bank's report noted that the United States, France, Britain, Italy and Canada all went from budget surpluses in the 1960's to deficits in the 80's.
The bank did not call for immediate moves to slash budget deficits, recognizing that this could worsen the current economic slowdown. Instead, it said deficit-cutting efforts "in the industrial countries should be reinforced, particularly once an upturn in economic activity allows greater flexibility in the design of fiscal policy."
