HEADLINE: As Candidates Wait to Run, Cash Waits to Follow

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 9

 BODY:
No prospective Presidential candidate has yet come calling on E. William Crotty, a leading Democratic fund-raiser, and that says a lot about the changed role of money as the 1992 Presidential campaign draws near.
By this time four years ago, five Presidential contenders had made separate visits to Mr. Crotty's home in Daytona Beach, Fla., soliciting his help. 
 But unlike the 1988 campaign, when the major Democratic candidates had already established fund-raising organizations that had collected at least $15 million altogether, the money race this year has not even been joined.
"I don't know any of my friends who have been asked to make a particular commitment," said Mr. Crotty, who eventually went with Senator Al Gore of Tennessee in 1988. "And it's getting late."
 
On the Sidelines
 With potential candidates unusually hesitant to dive into a race against a popular incumbent and with many longtime donors sapped by the sluggish economy, Democrats who raise money are on the sidelines. The lack of activity is certain to significantly alter the dynamics of the primary season as compared with the last two Presidential campaigns, and will undoubtedly affect who captures the Democratic nomination.
Four years ago, Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts catapulted into the top tier of candidates in large part because he had established credibility by amassing huge sums of money very early. But since there is no comparable situation this year, candidates may be left hoping that lightning strikes them politically so the donations start pouring in. By the end of 1987, Mr. Dukakis had collected $10.6 million; Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri $4.4 million and Mr. Gore and Senator Paul Simon of Illinois $3.8 million apiece.
"Politics will drive the money," said Duane B. Garrett, a San Francisco fund-raiser, "rather than a Dukakis example, where money helped drive politics."
It is generally assumed that candidates will need to raise at least $6 million by the end of this year to prepare for the early contests -- the Iowa caucuses and New Hampshire primary are in February -- and qualify for Federal matching funds. Many analysts argue that this compressed political season benefits the best-known entrants with highly developed fund-raising networks who can enter the race late and draw contributions quickly. On the other hand, lesser-known candidates, struggling to raise dollar after dollar, may find themselves shut out.
As evidence of the dearth of fund-raising, Impac, a group of major Democratic fund-raisers in 1988, is holding its first meeting of the year on Tuesday, a session that will be attended by several possible candidates. In an invitation to members, Nathan Landow, the head of Impac, conceded there is so little interest in the Presidential field that the group may disband.
"This may be our only meeting during the '92 election cycle," Mr. Landow wrote. "If for no other reason, let's do it for old time's sake. Who knows, maybe we'll learn something about our party's future of which we are presently unaware."
 
A Retreat in Virginia
 In another effort to get fund-raisers more involved, the Democratic Party is holding a retreat next week in Leesburg, Va., with several top fund-raisers, potential candidates and other party leaders to devise strategy for the 1992 general election campaign.
"The whole conventional wisdom about the system forcing candidates to gear up fund-raising early can now be disputed," said Herbert E. Alexander, an authority on Presidential campaign finance at the University of Southern California. "The race may be competitive on the basis of crash fund-raising at the end of the season."
Republicans have no such worries because President Bush can easily tap his network of supporters and raise as much as he needs for the primary season. But without a serious challenger expected for the nominations, Mr. Bush has no great need for money. Candidates who make it to the general election can count on public subsidies to finance their races.
The Democrat whom most fund-raisers cite as being best-positioned to raise large sums of money quickly is Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York, who insists he has no plans to run. Mr. Cuomo is in an enviable position because he is well known nationally and is the leading officeholder in a large state filled with potential donors.
 
When Experience Counts
 Others who could be well-positioned financially should they decide to run are those who have sought national office before and thus are well known and already have fund-raising networks: Senator Gore, Representative Gephardt, Senator Lloyd Bentsen of Texas and the Rev. Jesse Jackson. Mr. Gephardt and Mr. Gore have quietly taken some fund-raising trips, but they deny that the money is for Presidential drives.
These other possible candidates are not as well poised because they have not previously sought national office: Gov. L. Douglas Wilder of Virginia could tap sizable contributions in state as a sitting Governor. Senator John D. Rockefeller 4th of West Virginia is well known nationally but his fund-raising ability is largely unproven, though he could forgo Federal matching funds and use his personal wealth to finance a race.
Senator Tom Harkin of Iowa has built up a list of liberal donors across the county. Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas benefits from sitting in office and has begun to develop a core of possible donors nationwide as chairman of the centrist Democratic Leadership Council.
The one candidate who has been most aggressively holding fund-raising events in several states is the only one who has officially announced: former Senator Paul E. Tsongas of Massachusetts.
 
'The Only Game in Town'
 The Tsongas campaign's chief fund-raiser, Nicholas A. Rizzo, said he hopes to have raised $400,000 to $500,000 by the end of June to keep the organization running and out of debt. But he said the task was difficult because Mr. Tsongas has been out of office for seven years, and because the lack of competition has led to little interest in the race.
"We're the only game in town, and that's nice," Mr. Rizzo said. "But it's a double-edged sword. Without competition, there's nothing to compare Tsongas to, and that fact does not stimulate interest. When others enter the race, it will hopefully raise the level of fund-raising because people will have a reason to give."
Mr. Garrett, the San Francisco fund-raiser, agrees that the second-tier candidates are put "in the traditional niche of having to score well early to get the funds to continue on. The last person who was really successful with that formula was George McGovern in 1972." He added, "All of the less-known candidates are vulnerable to the sudden entry of a Gore, Cuomo or Gephardt -- a nationally known candidate with a major fund-raising base."
One who takes issue with the idea that less-known candidates will be at a disadvantage is Robert A. Farmer, the treasurer of the Democratic National Committee who was the chief fund-raiser for the Dukakis campaign, which had raised about $4 million by this time four years ago.
"A lot of people think that a late start helps the guys who can raise a lot of money," he said. "I think it hurts the guys who can raise a lot of money. It means money will be less of a factor than it was before. A lot of people have the ability to raise $3 million."

HEADLINE: Flooding Turns Farmland Into Pools of Trouble

BYLINE: By DON TERRY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CLARION, Iowa, June 8

 BODY:
In his 58 years of farming here, Henry Delger has never seen so much storm water covering the fields and drenching the spirits and hopes of so many of his neighbors. With a sad, slow shake of his head, he said the heavy rains that have hit the Midwest in recent weeks had made "grown men cry."
"I can believe it," Mr. Delger's friend, Robert Robb, said as the two men sat and talked the other day at a grain elevator in this farm town of 3,000 in north-central Iowa. 
 "There are acres and acres of ponds out there where corn should be," Mr. Delger said. "People can't even get into their fields to plant. A lot of them are going to go broke."
This has been one of Iowa's wettest springs ever, flooding basements and streets, overflowing riverbanks and soaking millions of acres of rich farmland.
 
350 Percent Wetter Than Usual
 In Hamilton County, north of Des Moines, rainfall was reported to be 350 percent of normal levels.
"In May our field turned into a lake," said Ruth E. Book, an administrator at Iowa State University and a farmer's wife. "We put a boat on it and went boating. We tried to decide whether to stock it with fish or wait and see if we could plant."
The rains have greatly delayed planting in 44 of Iowa's 99 counties, largely in the north-central part of the state, where some farmers are up to a month or more behind their normal corn planting schedule.
The delay could cut the harvest in some of those counties by 30 percent and push farmers who barely survived the hard times that swept rural America in the 1980's off the land.
Last week, Gov. Terry E. Branstad asked the Federal Government to designate the 44 counties as disaster areas and to ease and extend farm and price protection programs.
 
Many Unscathed
 Like a tornado that demolishes one house and leaves its neighbor standing, the rains have caused few problems for most of the state's farmers. Over all, nearly 90 percent of the corn crop and most of soybeans have been planted, and Iowa is expecting a good fall harvest. But it is not yet clear what effect this spring's weather will have on the prices that farmers get for the crops or that consumers pay for their food.
This has been an unusually wet spring throughout the Midwestern farm belt, but except for north-central Iowa and south-central Minnesota, the flooding has not been severe enough to have a major impact on farming.
"Somehow when the hurt is spread around it's different," said Garren O. Benson, an agronomist at Iowa State University in Ames. "But this time the hurt is concentrated. And there's no question that some farmers in the hardest-hit areas will go out of business."
The rains have also delayed spring planting in several counties in southern Minnesota, and Gov. Arne Carlson is seeking Federal help for farmers in at least eight counties there.
A spokesman for Governor Carlson, Tim Droogsma, said, "There have been a lot of sleepless nights for some of these guys."
He added: "Farming is a tricky business. You're at the mercy of so many things. The weather. Financial markets. International events."
Corn should be planted by early May. According to crop experts at Iowa State University, yields decline by 16 percent if planting is delayed until June 1, by 29 percent if the planting is not finished by June 10 and by 45 percent if the planting drags on until June 20.
 
Paying for Idle Tractor
 "It's disastrous for the individual farmer if all of a sudden you lose 30, 40 percent of your crop," Mr. Droogsma said. "Your income is slashed but your overhead isn't. You still have debt payments. You still have to pay for that tractor sitting out there in the rain."
A few recent days of sunshine have helped the farmers in both states, but the fields are still so wet around Clarion, in Wright County, that tractors and other equipment are at risk of getting stuck in the mud.
"The people who pull them out, that's been a good business to be in," Mr. Benson said. "Ironically, much of the same area was dry in 1988 and '89 when we had a problem with drought."
With the break in the weather, farmers have been working well into the night, trying to dry their fields by plowing before planting. Often, they have been forced to plow in uneven rows as they steer around "wet holes" and large patches of mud scattered in low spots.
At the Clarion Farmers Elevator Cooperative, Al Struthers, the manager, walked in and brushed the feed dust off his jeans. He said he did not usually work outside his office but business has been so slow because of the rain that he had been busying himself with chores around the elevator. He figures the cooperative will lose several hundred thousand dollars.
Mr. Struthers said the average rainfall for the area is 34 inches for a full year, but so far this spring 24 inches have fallen.
"There's a lot of stress," he said. "We're all tied to the farm economy around here. If the farmers don't make money, the hardware store suffers and the feed store and on and on. We were coming back from the depression of the 80's quite well and then this hit."
Twenty miles north, Harold Trask was reluctant to leave his fields "because I don't want to waste a minute drying them out."
Mr. Trask has been farming for 21 of his 44 years. One night, about 10 days ago, when the rains were heavy, he sat at his window and watched the water pour from the sky.
"I wasn't crying," he said. "But tears were running down my face."
Still, Mr. Trask is one of the lucky ones in Wright County. He also raises hogs, so does not depend entirely on corn and soybeans as do about 75 percent of his neighbors.
His windswept face shows his worry. "We're a month late around here," he said. "It means no profit. It means being barely able to hold the farm together for another year."
He drove down a gravel road, pointing out dozens of wet holes and weed-choked patches of mud. He walked across a field, water oozing from the black soil after each step.
"We shouldn't be trying to work these fields when they're so wet," he said. "But we're desperate. Honest to God, we just don't know what to do. But we might be O.K. if this weather holds."
The forecast for Monday calls for rain.

HEADLINE: Homeownership At Record Level For New Yorkers

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK

 BODY:
While New York City is still primarily a tenant's town, the surge of co-op conversions and housing construction in the 1980's brought the level of homeownership above 25 percent for the first time, according to figures in the 1990 census.
It is a truism of American life that people who own their homes think and act differently from renters, and a variety of political leaders and others expect the increase -- from 23.4 percent of households in 1980 to 28.4 percent in 1990 -- to be reflected in areas from career mobility to political affiliation. 
 Most expect the rise in homeownership to be a bulwark against the flight of middle-class and affluent residents from the city, and to lead to pressure to hold down municipal taxes and spending. Even though homeowners remain vastly outnumbered, the recent purchasers are beginning to organize on the grass-roots level and think of themselves as a group.
"It has taken a while to realize that the landlord is us," said Mary Ann Rothman, executive director of the Council of New York Cooperatives, the largest among a growing number of homeowner groups, with 1,550 member co-op and condominium buildings.
"We spent the 80's consciousness-raising, not getting organized as a voting bloc," she added. "Now that needs to be done."
For other new homeowners, the change from renting has meant a broader change in perspective. "You see yourself and the city in longer terms," said Gail Wiese, who purchased her Brooklyn Heights apartment when her building was converted into a co-op in 1986. Since then, she has been elected to her co-op board and has begun to attend Community Board meetings. "As an owner, I have more responsibility," she said.
The potential impact of such activism has not escaped the notice of politicians, including Ruth Messinger, the Borough President of Manhattan, which gained 73,993 homeowners in the 1980's, more than any other borough. "We still have very legitimate concerns about the status of renters, but a growing number of people who own their homes will have somewhat different interests," she said.
The census report, release last month, shows that the number of homeowners in the city rose from 652,000 in 1980 to 807,000 in 1990.
The report confirms other studies by the city and state showing that the biggest surge came in ownership of apartments, both co-ops and condominiums, in new buildings as well as those converted from rentals. Construction and conversion reached a peak between 1984 and 1988, then ground to a virtual standstill as the city's economy slumped in the wake of the 1987 stock market collapse.
The ranks of new homeowners include many who now feel trapped in their homes. Though the wave of conversions helped thousands of New Yorkers move from tenancy to ownership at low insider prices, thousands more who bought apartments late in the decade paid more than the homes would now fetch in a slumping market.
 
A Stake in the City
 But what is bad for homeowners may be good for the city: those who cannot sell their homes without taking a loss are not inclined to move. The result, some economists maintain, is a larger, more stable middle class with a greater stake in New York's future.
"The simple fact of homeownership does not mean people will put up with severe deprivation in their quality of life, but it does have a stabilizing influence," said Kathy Wylde, vice president of the New York City Housing Partnership. "It means people are committed to the city."
Social scientists who have studied the behavior of homeowners elsewhere in the country say they are more likely to vote, join civic groups and volunteer for community projects than renters. Homeowners also tend to vote their pocketbooks, studies have shown, favoring low property taxes and zoning and development policies that preserve property values.
That pattern may not be as clear-cut in New York. One reason is that many of the city's renters -- particularly those with rent-regulated apartments -- are politically engaged and consider themselves just as committed to New York as owners. And because of the hectic schedules of many of the city's professionals, those who can afford to own apartments often have little time to become more involved in politics or community projects.
"Manhattan co-op and condo owners are busy people -- they tend to keep to themselves," said George Levitt, a bank executive who purchased a condominium on East 80th Street with his wife, Susan, in 1989, and has been attempting to organize other owners to lobby for property-tax relief.
 
Poorer Areas Affected
 Still, many New Yorkers who purchased apartments in the 1980's say they are more interested in neighborhood affairs, keep themselves better informed about city politics, and feel that they have a longer-term stake in the city than they did as renters.
While most of the increase in homeownership came in middle- and upper-income neighborhoods, it also occurred in poor areas that had been in rapid decline in the 1960's and 1970's.
Using government subsidies -- and in some cases city-owned land and buildings acquired almost for nothing -- housing groups have sold more than 10,000 homes since the mid-1980's in Harlem, the South Bronx, the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn, and elsewhere. They have been purchased mainly by families in the city's swelling minority middle class.
"These are the very people who could leave the neighborhood if they want to, and we want them to stay," said Joseph E. Holley, director of the Northeast Brooklyn Housing Development Corporation.
The Census Bureau said the surge in homeownership came after 30 years when the balance of New York City renters and homeowners showed little change. It said the level of homeownership declined slightly during the 1970's, from 23.6 percent in 1970 to 23.4 percent in 1980, after rising gradually from 21.8 percent in 1960, 19.1 percent in 1950 and 14.3 percent in 1940.
According to the city's Finance Department, there are now 503,647 apartments in co-ops and condominiums in the city. The city's data, however, do not distinquish between apartments that are owner-occupied and those occupied by renters.
The surge of co-op and condominium construction and conversion is best reflected in records kept by the Real Estate Finance Bureau of the New York State Attorney General, which reviews plans from developers and sponsors.
The bureau said the peak growth year was 1986, when it accepted plans for 765 new buildings and conversions, with 52,800 apartments. By last year, it said, the pace had slowed drastically, with plans accepted for 288 new buildings and conversions, with 21,261 units.
This year, conversions and construction have all but ceased. Frederick K. Mehlman, an assistant attorney general, said only one plan for a co-op or condominium building had been submitted in each of the last two months.
Still, he said, when the city's economy strengthens, "there are a lot of landlords out there that still would like to convert their buildings."
 
Problems for Many Co-ops
 The surge of co-op conversions followed by an economic slump has left big problems for shareholders in hundreds of converted buildings where sponsors are in default on maintenance charges, taxes and other obligations.
Co-op owners have formed a number of groups in an effort to deal with the default problems, and some of those organizations are also broadening their focus to include issues like taxation. Apartment owners are forming alliances with landlords to fight the Dinkins administration's proposed sharp increase in real-estate taxes.
 
Concern Over Taxes
 Landlords and apartment owners share a concern over property taxes because they are taxed as a single, separate class of property owners, receiving less favorable treatment than owners of one- to three-family homes.
"The City Council has got to be very aware of the concerns of this constituency," said Debra Beck, vice president of the Real Estate Board of New York, which represents builders, landlords and others in the real-estate industry.
Some say the interests of co-op and condominium owners can be expected eventually to conflict with those of renters. Real-estate executives and some co-op owners assert that rent-regulation laws protecting tenants have have contributed to the problems of co-op defaults.

HEADLINE: Arms Talks: A Warm-Up

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 9

 BODY:
Although the Soviet and American Foreign Ministers have been meeting almost weekly to try to tie up long-delayed arms control agreements, the real focus of relations between Moscow and Washington has radically shifted to economics and the question of how the West can help transform Soviet society.
Don't be fooled by the recent attention that Washington and Moscow have been paying to arms control, both Soviet and American officials say. They are the wave of the past. The reason for the recent burst of arms control activity is that the Soviets are eager to get the conventional and nuclear agreements out of the way -- because Washington has made this a condition for a summit meeting that would focus primarily on economic help -- and Washington is eager to exploit Moscow's vulnerability. 
 Indeed, the joke making the rounds as Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d and the Soviet Foreign Minister, Aleksandr A. Bessmertnykh, were meeting in Geneva last week was that Washington should simply offer to buy all of the Soviet Union's nuclear missiles, and thereby simultaneously bring the nuclear arms reduction talks to a conclusion and help Moscow solve its economic problems.
"The whole focus of the relationship is shifting," an Administration Soviet expert said. "Even though Baker is dashing off to Geneva to deal with arms control, issues like that, which dominated the agenda in the '70's and '80's, are taking a back seat to economics. The real discussions will be about what is going on inside the Soviet Union."
In the last two weeks alone the State Department's Soviet desk has played host to representatives of the Soviet Democratic Russian Party, members of the Azari Popular Front, Armenian politicians and businessmen, the foreign minister of the Republic of Georgia, Baltic leaders, and members of the Supreme Soviet. None of them came to talk about arms control. They want to establish their own direct contacts with Washington, they want economic and political advice, and they want money.
But while the focus of the relationship is shifting, it is not doing so overnight, and that explains in part why it took months to tie up the conventional arms treaty and why it could take several more to finish the strategic arms reduction treaty, even though both sides seem to want it out of the way.
 
Gorbachev's Juggling Act
 The transformation of the relationship, American and Soviet experts explain, is being driven first and foremost by the revolution inside the Soviet Union, in which Mr. Gorbachev is required to juggle various coalitions, prompting radical policy zigs and zags. Last fall, when Mr. Gorbachev was cracking down in the Baltics and leaning on conservatives, the army and the K.G.B. for support, the relationship with the West noticeably cooled. The whole subject of Western economic help for Mr. Gorbachev was put on a back burner.
Now that Mr. Gorbachev is more desperate for help, and has apparently concluded that the hard-liners have little to offer and that the reformers are an increasingly potent political force, he has lurched in the other direction, asking the seven major industrialized democracies for an invitation to their July summit meeting in London, sending Soviet economic experts to appeal to President Bush and squeezing his own military to drop its objections to the conventional arms treaty.
But the Soviet leader cannot just snap his fingers and get his military to give in to all the American demands in the strategic arms talks, even though it might speed up a summit meeting. He still has to juggle, because he may need to lean on the military again soon if there is economic chaos.
"I think if you were alive in 1917 things would have looked just as confusing," said one Baker aide. "In retrospect all of the changes look clear and in one direction. But this is what it looks like when you are in the middle of a revolution."
The zigs and zags on the Soviet side are both matched by, and reinforce, similarly ambiguous behavior from the Bush Administration. The Administration is justifiably uncertain and dubious about how far Mr. Gorbachev is really ready to go, but in the past it has also demonstrated a certain inability to fully grasp the extent of the transformation taking place in the Soviet Union and how it can be influenced by the West.
The Bush Administration, after nearly three years, has established a consistent pattern in responding to changes in the Eastern bloc: it rarely catches the first train, but it rarely misses the last one.
Until recently, Mr. Bush was very passive about pressing his own bureaucracy to break the deadlock in the strategic arms negotiations, because of reservations from conservatives about aspects of the treaty. Six months ago, leading American Sovietologists were predicting that Mr. Gorbachev might not last until spring. Today, the emphasis has changed to how to support him and his programs. One day Mr. Bush signals he doesn't want Mr. Gorbachev at the London economic summit, then he reluctantly accepts, after pressure from the Germans, British and French. Up to now the Administration has been much more clear about what it won't do -- give the Soviets piles of money -- than what it will do if they institute free-market changes.
"Such passivity is curious, if not dangerous, on a matter that has such profound implications for the future security of the United States," Robert D. Blackwill and Graham Allison, two experts on American-Soviet relations, write in the latest issue of Foreign Affairs. "Having spent some $5 trillion to meet the military challenge of the Soviet Union around the globe, is the United States to opt out now when the Soviet future is being formed?"
The mindset within the Bush Administration on this issue, though, is evolving month by month, as clearly indicated by the appointment of a lawyer, businessman and arch-capitalist, Robert S. Strauss, as the next ambassador to Moscow, replacing Jack F. Matlock Jr., a career Sovietologist.
American officials say that if a summit is to be held this summer between Mr. Bush and Mr. Gorbachev, it will serve as a fulcrum to force the Administration to address exactly how it intends to approach the question of helping to transform the Soviet Union.
 
'Step-by-Step Process'
 At the Copenhagen NATO summit meeting, Mr. Baker alluded to this when he told the Western allies: "We are developing a package of supportive measures, which we hope to coordinate with you and others. But I honestly don't think we can catalyze Soviet reform through a big bang approach. Our effort is more likely to be a step-by-step process."
American officials won't say what exactly will be in this package -- in part because they don't know themselves. But officials talk about programs to help the Soviets tap their oil reserves, to coordinate all the worldwide grants and credits already going to the Soviet Union and to provide advice on economic distribution.
But many of these ideas were first floated around the time of the Malta summit almost two years ago. There is still no consensus within the Administration for a program that would go much further. It does not necessarily have to involve piles of money, but it will probably have to be something more far-reaching than "technical advice," so that reformers within the Soviet Union can use it to help convince conservatives that the free market is both the right way to go and can be achieved without the mammoth social explosion that Mr. Gorbachev has begun to warn about.

HEADLINE: A Tourist and a Dispatcher Are Killed by Stray Gunfire

BYLINE: By GEORGE JAMES

 BODY:
A woman from London who was visiting New York and a car dispatcher from Brooklyn were struck by stray gunfire in separate shootings Saturday night. They died hours apart in the same hospital.
The London woman, Yvonne Williams, a 30-year-old mother of five, was walking about 10:45 P.M. in the vicinity of 101st Street and Northern Boulevard in Corona, Queens, on her way to visit friends when she was hit in the lower back by a bullet fired by someone in a street dispute, the police said. 
 The dispatcher, Nelda Caraballo, 37, of 71 Nostrand Avenue in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn, a mother of three, was working at the Borinquen Car Service, 826 Flushing Avenue in the Bushwick section of Brooklyn, when she heard gunfire at 11:37 P.M., the police said. She stood up to see what was happening and a bullet struck her in the chest. An unidentified 9-year-old boy and a 22-year-old man sitting in a private car nearby were seriously wounded. The motive in the shooting is under investigation.
Both victims died at the City Hospital Center at Elmhurst.
 
Seven Shot in Brooklyn
 In a third shooting Saturday night, seven people were shot, five of them by stray gunfire, in a street dispute in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn. The five bystanders ranged in age from 8 to 57 and were treated at Kings County Hospital and released. The police did not release the names of the victims.
Mrs. Williams was on "her very first trip to the United States," said her sister-in-law, Carmel Smith of the Wakefield section of the Bronx. She said Mrs. Williams, who had come to visit relatives, arrived on Thursday night and had planned to return on Wednesday. On Saturday, Mrs. Williams went with a niece to see friends in Corona, where she was hit by the stray gunfire during "a dispute on the street between some people," a police spokesman, Officer Andrew McInnis, said.
Mrs. Williams was born in St. Catherine in Jamaica, and as a child moved to England with her family, relatives said. She married and had five children, now aged 3, 6, 12, 14 and 16, Mrs. Smith said. The children remained in London during their mother's trip to America. Mrs. Williams, who was separated from her husband, worked part time in an office.
Ms. Caraballo, who had been unemployed for three years, had been working as a dispatcher at the Borinquen Car Service for only two weeks, the owner, Fabio Mata, 37, said yesterday.
A friend, Anna Gonzalez, 32, said Ms. Caraballo lived with her daughter, Lucy Jimenez, and had two sons, Hector Jimenez, who is an auxiliary police officer in the 79th Precinct, and Tony Jimenez.
Details of the shooting were still being investigated yesterday and it was not clear if any of the five people in a car parked at 849 Flushing Avenue near the car service were the gunman's targets.
Two of the passengers, Orlando Villanueva, address unknown, and the unidentified boy were wounded, the police said. Yesterday evening, Mr. Villanueva was in serious but stable condition at Bellevue Hospital Center and the boy was in stable condition with wounds to the neck and shoulder.
The police were investigating whether a dispute at the car service earlier on Saturday prompted the shooting.
The Flatbush shooting began at 9:22 P.M. when a man chased two other men and fired at them, missing them but striking the five bystanders in front of 324 Nostrand Avenue, the police said.
A short time later, at 9:48 P.M., a man believed to be one of those who was chased in the earlier shooting shot two men in front of 261 Lenox Road in the Flatbush section. Both men were treated at Kings County Hospital and released. The police did not release their names.
The police arrested Lawrence Simmons, 30, of 1225 New York Avenue in the Gravesend section of Brooklyn, in the shooting as he rode on his bicycle, with a 9-millimeter pistol in his hand, past the scene of the earlier shooting, a police spokesman, Sgt. Nicholas Vreeland, said. Mr. Simmons was charged with two counts of attempted murder, reckless endangerment and criminal possession of a weapon.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Nelda Caraballo, 37 years old, was hit in the chest by a stray bullet on Saturday night in theBushwick section of Brooklyn.

HEADLINE: In Bridgeport, Higher Property Taxes Just Add Injury to Accumulated Insult

BYLINE: By GEORGE JUDSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., June 9

 BODY:
Insult is not hard to come by here. Suburbanites boast that they never visit Bridgeport, the state's largest city and the banking and legal center of Fairfield County. A county atlas shows Stamford, not Bridgeport, on its cover. Amid Fairfield's sometimes stunning affluence, the city's flagship hotel advertises rooms for $49.
Pawnshops seem as common as convenience stores. The University of Bridgeport, a private institution, has half as many students as 10 years ago. Citytrust Bancorp, a major bank, has a negative net worth. When the city's high schools were admitted -- on a trial basis -- into the Fairfield County Interscholastic Athletic Conference this spring, the decision carried the weight of history, as though Bridgeport itself had been admitted into the county.
 
'A Leper Colony'
 The feeling of accumulated insult has much to do with Bridgeport becoming the first city in the nation to enter bankruptcy court. The alternative was a big property-tax increase, on top of what was already the state's highest local tax rate, only to balance a budget that would leave streets dirty, parks unmowed, beaches without lifeguards, libraries and centers for the elderly closed. 
 This is a city that feels it has paid enough, and that now it is time for others to help.
"Bridgeport right now is a leper colony," Alderman Thomas J. White said on Thursday, unaware, like most of his colleagues, that Mayor Mary C. Moran was preparing to file for bankruptcy protection that afternoon.
"The attitude in the suburbs is, 'You made your problems, now live with them,' " he said.
Bridgeport offers constant reminders of past glory and precarious future, of glaring contrasts between wealth and poverty that divide the city and cut it off from its suburban neighbors.
Along Main Street, one end of downtown is anchored by the sparkling headquarters of People's Bank, an almost playful office tower by the architect Richard Meier. At the other end, a half-dozen blocks north, a landmark hotel's windows are boarded up, its roof half collapsed by fire.
Along Long Island Sound, masts from a marina stand in the near distance behind the P. T. Barnum Houses, a project so grim it looks like a work camp. A mile west, the comfortable Black Rock neighborhood rises to hilltop estates above St. Mary's by the Sea, a waterfront promenade.
What is increasingly missing between the extremes of Barnum and Black Rock is the middle class, which in Bridgeport is largely white. The 1990 census found only a slight decline in population, counting 141,686 people. But non-Hispanic whites declined by 20,000, to 45.6 percent, from 59.4 percent in 1980. Blacks grew to 25.2 percent, from 20.2 percent. Hispanic groups, mainly Puerto Rican, grew even faster, to 26.5 percent, from 18.7 percent.
Among the departing whites were many younger families. Left behind were an aging white population in the North End and a young and growing minority population concentrated around housing projects in the poor neighborhoods of the East Side, South End, and increasingly, the West End.
Among Bridgeport's whites, according to the census, only 20.1 percent are under 18 years old; 33.5 percent of blacks are under 18, as are 37.6 percent of the Hispanic residents.
 
'What Do You Get?'
 Laurayne Farrar-James, an Alderman who represents an East Side district that is 90 percent black and Hispanic, said the divisions within the city intensify a common conviction that Bridgeport does not provide enough services to justify higher taxes, much less the 18 percent increase required by the budget imposed by a state financial review board on Friday.
In her neighborhood, she said, garbage is often not picked up, streets are dirty and crime is a constant problem. Some people have told her they would support higher taxes if that would greatly improve services, but instead, the new budget on July 1 will eliminate all street cleaning, half of the city's centers for the elderly and all of its youth-recreation programs.
"What do you get for your money?" asked Susan Powley, who lives on the Trumbull border. "Garbage and snowplow and the right to use Seaside Park."
With annual taxes on modest colonials and ranches commonly $3,000 to $4,000, and car taxes and a sewage tax adding hundreds more, the North End is acutely aware that taxes in neighboring Trumbull and Fairfield can be nearly half that, that their schools are excellent and that many of their residents commute in and out of Bridgeport without contributing anything to the cost of the city's social services.
"It's not a grass-roots thing, it's legislative," Mr. White, who represents the North End, said of the Common Council's resolve to avoid a large tax increase. "The aldermen are absolutely opposed, because we are overtaxed and our suburban neighbors are artificially undertaxed."
Both the well-off and the poor feel trapped, in part by the same recessionary pressures that are pushing Bridgeport's strained finances to the limit.
Many homeowners who stay do so because they cannot afford to move, and they fear that the city's bankruptcy action will further depress house prices.
"You can't move out because nobody's buying," said Israel Velazquez, a General Electric worker who owns a house on the East Side.
In the last few years the city has lost 14,180 jobs and three of its largest remaining factories, Remington Arms, Bryant Electric and Carpenter Steel.
"People say the city should be run like a business," Alderman White said. "Well, let me tell you, if it was a business it would have moved out. It would have gone south."
 
Paying Now for Spending Then
 Many people blame mismanagement for the current crisis, in which Bridgeport faces an 18 percent increase in property taxes to close a $12 million gap in its $308.2 million budget. But the state officials who oversee the city's finances, and who oppose its efforts to seek bankruptcy protection, say there is little room to maneuver.
Donald A. Kirshbaum, executive director of the Bridgeport Financial Review Board, said residents have reason to believe they do not get much for their taxes. Twenty-five percent of their payments, or $30 million, is spent on the past: police and fire pensions, full health insurance for retirees and the $60 million in bonds sold in 1989 to bail the city out of a crisis then.
Now the economy is sliding, Mr. Kirshbaum said, and "the bigger problem is that the state budget is under tremendous pressure."

HEADLINE: Dreams Fade in the Wine Country

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE M. FISHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SONOMA, Calif.

 BODY:
During the wine boom of the 1970's, doctors, lawyers and others with money to invest started wineries. Many were seeking a gracious way of life, with their names on their own wine labels and enough profits to pay for new French oak barrels. Now, rising costs, lower consumption and increased regulation and taxation are weighing them down. Many want to sell, and some already have.
Peter Haywood was a successful 37-year-old building contractor who tired of battling planning commissions. In 1974, he planted a vineyard so he could work outdoors. Six years later, after selling grapes and making wine at home, he built the Haywood Winery in Sonoma County. It soon earned a good reputation, particularly for its zinfandel. But as a business, it languished. 
 "I could make the wine, but I couldn't sell the requisite amount to make it pay," he said. "I don't think any of us who began in the late 70's had an inkling that the market would level off and competition would increase several-fold."
In April, Mr. Haywood sold his brand and most of his inventory to Racke International, a German company that already owned the Buena Vista Winery in Sonoma.
For wine drinkers, a change of ownership often means a change in the bottle, for better or worse. Most wine critics agree that Buena Vista's wine has improved considerably since Racke acquired the brand, the state's oldest, founded in 1857. But Chateau St. Jean lost both its wine maker and its reputation after being bought by Suntory Ltd. The Wine Spectator magazine asked in a feature article about the label, "Where has the magic gone?"
Many other small wineries with strong followings are being acquired, often by foreign corporations, while weaker labels might vanish. In its fifth year of declining sales, the American wine industry is consolidating.
"There are many brands for sale," said Jean-Michel Valette, a principal in Hambrecht & Quist, a San Francisco-based investment banking firm that specializes in wine deals. There have been 14 purchases in the last two years, and at least that many are likely in the next 12 months, he said, adding, "There is a pent-up number of deals ready to happen."
Many wineries stay on the market for years as their owners hold out for glamour premiums. But buyers want only respected brands at prices low enough to promise healthy returns.
 
West Coast Phenomenon
 Weaker wineries, or strong ones at high prices, do not sell. The Spring Mountain Vineyards in St. Helena, Calif., the winery where "Falcon Crest," the evening soap opera, was filmed, has been for sale for nearly 10 years, with an asking price of about $20 million. Parducci Wine Cellars in Ukiah, Calif., has been on the market for two years.
"Most of the wineries don't provide any reasonable rate of return at their asking price," said Jon Fredrikson, a San Francisco-based consultant. A Napa Valley ordinance limiting growth has scuttled some deals there, he said, adding, "Unless there's the possibility of expansion, it scares away the big corporate buyers."
The pace of consolidation is picking up, particularly in California and Oregon, wine people say. In New York State, none of the roughly 100 wineries is known to be for sale, although some vineyards and some wine-making operations are. Some industry executives say several New York wine makers are shopping for wineries in California.
In a time of declining sales, strong wineries are growing largely at the expense of weaker ones. Wine makers shopping for small wineries say some sellers are urgently seeking buyers.
As wine consumption declined nationally, small premium wineries at first consoled themselves that people were drinking less but better. Most of the decline was in low-priced "jug" wines. But now sales growth of premium wines -- the industry category for those that sell for more than $5 a bottle -- has also slowed, and many analysts see a glut in wines costing $12 and up. Those wineries that continue to grow in the 90's emphasize high quality at a moderate price.
Some small wine makers who are trying to sell say they want to continue making wine while the new owner takes over sales and administration.
Besides selling his brand name to Racke, Mr. Haywood sold his wine-making operation to Ravenswood, another small producer. But he kept his vineyard. Mr. Haywood and his wine maker now work for Racke, which has shifted production of Haywood wine to the Buena Vista winery and added a medium-price chardonnay to the Haywood brand, increasing shipments to 50,000 cases from 10,000.
Wine makers who buy other wineries provide their sales forces with additional products and allow growth beyond the original brand. Haywood "had a small but tremendously loyal group of customers we thought we could build upon," said Stephen Cousins, president of Racke U.S.A. He said Racke expected to continue to grow by acquisition and by building its brands.
Even experienced wine makers find it hard to grow these days without a large partner. Charles Ortman had served as wine maker or consultant to more than 20 wineries before starting Meridian Vineyards, but his new winery languished.
 
Deal With a Unit of Nestle
 "Meridian needed a home," Mr. Ortman said. "It needed a building and much more capital than our limited partnership could raise."
Housed in a temporary structure, Meridian was dependent on the grape-crushing operations of other wineries. So he sold Meridian to Wine World Estates, a unit of Nestle S. A. that also owns Beringer Vineyards in the Napa Valley. Wine World moved Meridian from Napa to Paso Robles, on the central California coast, where Wine World had acquired vineyards, and has built it from under 10,000 cases to 50,000.
"Having marketing taken care of, I can focus all of my energy on making the best product," Mr. Ortman said. He had experience with Paso Robles grapes and liked the wine they made.
But not every small wine maker dreams of being acquired. Scharffenberger Cellars, which makes sparkling wine in Mendocino County, first had a marketing agreement with Fetzer Vineyards. Then Scharffenberger was acquired by the French Champagne houses of Lanson and Pommery, which in turn were acquired by the LVMH Moet Hennessy-Louis Vuitton conglomerate. Lanson and Pommery have since been sold again, to Allied-Lyons P.L.C., but Scharffenberger remains part of Moet.
 
'Swallowed Up by 3 Whales'
 "I've been the little guy swallowed up by three whales now, and I'm not too impressed," John Scharffenberger, the vineyard's founder, said. "The synergies just weren't there."
Mr. Scharffenberger said his small brand became lost in the large portfolios of his acquirers, so the increased sales force was no benefit, though he acknowledges that his large partner's capital is helpful. He prefers to do his own marketing, but for many small wine makers the sales and marketing power of a large organization are a major attraction.
One reason is that distributors -- the middle of the three-tiered system of alcoholic-beverage sales in the United States -- have undergone their own consolidation. In most major markets, the number of distributors has shrunk to two or three from a dozen or more in the 60's.
 
Advantage of a Big Company
 "To get that buyer's attention, you've got to have some people and some volume," said Terrence Clancy, president of the Wine Alliance, based in Santa Rosa, Calif. Wine Alliance, a unit of the British conglomerate Allied-Lyons P.L.C., has acquired Clos du Bois, Callaway and Atlas Peak and has an option on the William Hill Winery.
Consolidators like Wine Alliance and Racke can approach a distributor with a broad portfolio of wines, covering a range of price categories and styles.
The wines of small premium producers typically command higher prices, which translate into higher gross profit margins. But since sales and administration take a proportionately greater bite from a small business than from a large one, the small wineries are ultimately less profitable. If a consolidator can maintain the pricing of a premium wine, the economies of scale in the larger organization bring greater net profits.
"Larger wineries can pick up strong brands, bring them into the portfolio very efficiently and continue to get the high margins associated with these strong brands," said Gary N. Brayton, a principal with Deloitte & Touche in San Francisco who specializes in wineries.
If the people leaving the wine business now outnumber those entering, there are still plenty who dream of owning a winery and putting their names on the labels.
"It's similar to the restaurant business," Mr. Ortman of Meridian Vineyards said. "There are some looking to get out, and it is hard to make money, but there is money to be made if you go at it right. It can be done."

HEADLINE: The Last Dinosaur

BYLINE: By Andrew Stein; Andrew Stein is president of the New York City Council.

 BODY:
Many American cities, swimming upstream against the rough currents of economic recession and the loss of Federal aid, have adopted innovative ways of delivering services based on competition and consumer choice. But in New York City, it is business as usual.
Phoenix uses competitive bidding for some sanitation services and for street repairs and custodian services. (The city's public agencies are allowed to bid for the right to deliver the service.) 
 In Newark, N.J., two-thirds of all sanitation services have been privatized at a considerable savings to the taxpayer.
Some California cities -- for example, Visalia and Sunnyvale -- are moving away from traditional line-item budgets that allocate a fixed sum for specific agency functions but provide no incentives for saving money. Under the new arrangements, if managers save money they can keep some of it for new programs.
At City Hall, we have no trouble turning off street lights, closing libraries and museums and ruining the education system. But we have been reluctant even to debate solutions that would threaten the special interests strangling many agencies.
In the city's 1,000 school buildings, the custodians' powerful union still rules: The cafeterias of even our most overcrowded schools are mopped only once a week. Principals cannot tell janitors what to do.
In the sanitation department, antiquated union work rules mean many crews finish their routes in four or five hours and then spend the day at private pursuits.
An absurd six-month statute of limitations -- the only one of its kind in the state -- protects incompetent elementary and junior high school teachers from effective discipline.
All this is not entirely the fault of this administration. For too many years, the city assumed that the only way to solve problems was to create bigger and ever more unaccountable bureaucracies. From 1950 until 1990, the city workforce increased by 50 percent, although our population decreased by 7 percent.
To be sure, with New York's economy mired in recession and no longer producing sufficient revenues to sustain the bloated agencies, some officials pay lip service to "downsized government." What these words mean in practice is devastating across-the-board cuts in services.
The conventional wisdom seems to be that the way out of the fiscal crisis is to raise taxes, gut programs and wait for the economy to rebound. Presumably, when revenues start coming in again, city agencies can be restaffed and programs restored.
But this approach ignores economic reality. We can no longer ask businesses and the middle class to pay ever-higher taxes to sustain a huge mismanaged workforce -- certainly not when other cities and regions offer more efficient government, better services and lower taxes.
By applying a cleaver to essential services, the administration can produce a chimerical "balanced" budget by the July 1 deadline. But New York will keep hemorrhaging.
Only the discipline imposed by market forces can make the people running agencies constantly streamline their operations.
We can start by rewriting the work rules. Under state law, it is almost impossible to transfer a worker from one agency to another and layoffs must be based strictly on seniority. Thus, at times of fiscal crisis, City Hall cannot move workers around or get rid of the least efficient people.
When government has to compete with the private sector, it has to lower its costs and deliver services more effectively.
So let's think about allowing competitive bidding between private companies and city agencies for garbage collection, custodial services, street repair and building security, among other functions. And let's encourage greater productivity by providing managers with incentives for running their agencies more cheaply.
Municipal unions have long considered such approaches political taboos. But governing methods across America are changing, and if New York does not change, our city will go down in history as the last bureaucratic dinosaur.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: TENNIS;
Courier More Than Power Player

BYLINE: By ROBIN FINN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, June 9

 BODY:
James Spencer Courier, a terrier of a tennis player who counts himself among Dade City, Fla.'s top three exports, along with orange juice and country music, established his credentials on a global scale this stormy afternoon when he turned Andre Agassi aside, 3-6, 6-4, 2-6, 6-1, 6-4, in the final of the French Open. It was the first trip to a Grand Slam final for Courier, who has a 4-0 finals record in his career.
Jubilant after a victory that improved his ranking to No. 4 in the world and earned him $451,660, Courier, the former Little Leaguer who likens his tennis stratagems to those of a pitcher, ripped his clay-stained white baseball cap from his head and threw it into the stands. 
 "It's each to his own as far as caps go," said Courier, who put his favorite topper, a Cincinnati Reds cap, into the closet after deciding it was "too trendy."
"This hat was special to me all through the tournament, but this tournament is over," he said.
 
Gaining Confidence
 Asked about his plans for Wimbledon, the next Grand Slam on the calendar, Courier, whose pedigree on clay is far more impressive than his performances on grass, only smiled and said: "Don't spoil my day. But I think I'll take a little bit of confidence in with me." Previously, Courier's best Grand Slam finishes came in the fourth rounds here, in 1989 and 1990, and at the 1991 Australian Open.
Courier, a 20-year-old product of the same United States Tennis Association development program that enhanced the careers of Michael Chang, the 1989 French Open champion, and Pete Sampras, the defending United States Open champion, spent his teen-age years alongside Agassi at the Nick Bollettieri Tennis Academy in Bradenton, Fla. Courier graduated from high school in that period but turned down a tennis scholarship from Southern Methodist University in order to follow Chang, Agassi and Sampras onto the professional tour.
Last November, Courier began working with Jose Higueras, the same U.S.T.A. coach who guided Chang to this title two years ago. The union was not specifically intended to create another command coaching performance for Higueras in Paris, but that's what happened.
"Now he's two for two," said Courier, who has won two other major titles this year, at Key Biscayne, Fla., and Indian Wells, Calif., under the aegis of Higueras.
 The 38-year-old Higueras, a former Davis Cup player for Spain, first dedicated himself to transforming the redhead into less of a hothead, and then got to work on the rest of his problem areas. It was intelligent shot selection, not the shots themselves, that was lacking in the Courier repertory.
"The serve, the forehand, the slice backhand, we've been working on everything," said Higueras, who today provided Courier with the one piece of strategic advice that turned the tables on Agassi. Noticing that Courier was over-eager while awaiting Agassi's serve in the first set and a half, Higueras took advantage of a 20-minute rain delay to remind Courier to step back and give himself more time to prepare the sort of return that might damage Agassi's momentum rather than fuel it.
"When I saw that first set and a half, I saw that Andre was playing great and part of the reason for that was that Jim was playing right into his hands," said Higueras. Courier backed up, Agassi backed off, and the Floridian reversed a 1-3 deficit in the second set to even the match, a recovery that baffled Agassi.
Courier, who believes Higueras is responsible for injecting the proper degree of thoughtfulness into a talent that formerly traded too much on power and not enough on patience, took care to thank Higueras from the winner's podium and also invited the coach to a celebratory dinner.

HEADLINE: Dow Off 1.34, to 2,975.40; Trading Is Light

BYLINE: By H. J. MAIDENBERG

 BODY:
Stock prices moved in a narrow range on light volume yesterday as many traders stayed on the sidelines amid deepening concerns over the recent surge in long-term interest rates.
The Dow Jones industrial average crept down by 1.34 points, to 2,975.40, while the Standard & Poor's index of 500 mostly blue-chip stocks slipped 0.86, to 378.57, and the New York Stock Exchange's composite index eased 0.45, to 207.74. 
 Big Board volume plunged to 127.7 million shares, from 168.1 million on Friday, and 654 stocks rose while 904 issues declined.
 
Nasdaq Index Down 2.69
 Not only were the blue chips ignored, but so were many secondary issues, as witnessed by the drop of 2.69, to 495.85, in the Nasdaq composite index.
"The market's biggest concern is the recent sharp rise in long-term interest rates," said Robert B. Ritter, chief market analyst at Ladenburg, Thalmann & Company. "The fact that the Treasury securities market is also in the doldrums provided small comfort to the equities market."
Mr. Ritter added that while a lengthy parade through much of New York City's financial district drew many brokers and their staffs to their windows, it was not the principal cause of the low volume in the stock market. But low volume does inhibit many traders and others who prefer the relative safety of a more liquid market.
As it was, Occidental Petroleum was the Big Board's most active issue, rising 1 3/8, to 22 5/8, on a turnover of two million shares. News reports said Occidental had sold its stake in coal-mining operations in China and was involved in an oil exploration deal in Algeria.
Pepsico was a close second on no specific news, slipping by 3/8, to 30 1/4, on a volume of 1.96 million shares. Philip Morris edged down 1/4, to 66 1/8, and placed fourth after RJR Nabisco, which was unchanged. Philip Morris said it had no comment on a suit by the Securities and Exchange Commission charging a company executive with insider trading.
Time Warner, which was badly battered last week because of a negative reaction to a proposed rights offering, slipped a further 50 cents, to 94 1/8. Among some other issues in the news, Hilton Hotels dropped 2 3/4, to 43 5/8, after Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company lowered earnings estimates. Pfizer rose a dollar, to 57, after Cowen & Company reiterated its buy recommendation.
 
Gold Shares Rise
 An upward spike in gold that sent prices to their highst levels since last January was attributed to favorable technical factors. But the move helped some gold-mining shares. Homestake rose 7/8, to 16 5/8, and American Barrick was up 3/8, to 22 1/8.
At the American Stock Exchange, Echo Bay Mines, a Canadian gold producer, topped the most active list, rising 1/4, to 9 3/4, on a turnover of more than 496,400 shares. In all, Amex volume fell to 9.7 million shares, from 12.9 million last Friday, while its market value index slipped 0.21, to 369.77.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Prices of U.S. Issues Little Changed

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities were little changed in light trading yesterday, momentarily stemming last week's steep slide.
To some traders, the lack of activity came as something of a surprise, given the sea change in market perceptions wrought by economic data that strongly suggest the recession is about over. 
 "I thought people would make up their minds to do something after the weekend, because we had very significant news last week," one trader in government bonds said. "The numbers put a lot of grist in the mill for the argument that the bottom is here. But there hasn't been any follow-through."
 
Hints of Rebound
 Over the last month, declines in weekly initial unemployment claims and an improvement in auto sales have offered hints that the economy might be turning up.
But the galvanizing event for many traders and economists was the May employment figures released on Friday. Those figures showed that for the first time in 11 months employers added workers to their payrolls.
"There is no question that the data are signaling a recovery, and not some ephemeral upturn," said Anthony J. Vignola, chief economist at Kidder, Peabody & Company.
On Friday Mr. Vignola revised his growth estimates for the economy, and now expects a more vigorous performance for the balance of the year. The employment numbers were not the "driving force" behind the change in the firm's forecast, he said.
 
3.8 Percent Growth Forecast
 "The big question is not what is going on in the second quarter, but what will happen in the third," he added. "If the auto industry performs as expected, our forecast of 3.8 percent third-quarter growth is probably conservative."
Until last Friday, Mr. Vignola had projected second-quarter growth at 1 percent, to be followed by 2.9 percent in the third quarter. He now expects growth in the second quarter to be 1.7 percent.
"The fact that most people think that the turn has come has made people negative" on the bond market, another trader said, "but barring some bad inflation numbers later this week I think we will be stable until new supply hits the market later this month."
 
Unchanged From Friday
 By late yesterday, the Treasury's 8 1/8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021 were offered at a price of 96 7/32, down 2/32, to yield 8.47 percent, unchanged from late Friday.
Among Treasury note issues, the 8 percent 10-year notes were offered at 98 1/8, down 2/32, to yield 8.27 percent. And the 6 3/4 percent two-year notes were offered at 99 5/8, up 1/32, to yield 6.95 percent.
At the weekly auction of three-month and six-month Treasury bills, the three-month bills were sold at an average discount rate of 5.60 percent, up from an average rate of 5.59 percent at last week's sale.
Bids on the new six-month bills produced an average discount rate of 5.78 percent, up from an average rate of 5.71 percent a week ago.
 
Activity Extremely Slow
 Activity in the secondary market for investment-grade corporate bonds was extremely slow, traders said. Prices of most issues were unchanged on the day.
"Once people get comfortable about where the Treasury market is going, then they will focus on the corporate market," one corporate bond trader said. "Until that happens we aren't likely to go anywhere."
In the secondary market for tax-exempt municipal bonds, the $675 million worth of New York City securities that were sold last week were freed to trade.
Market participants said that continued demand for 30-year New York City securities pushed up prices yesterday. The new city bonds, which offered a maximum yield of 8.55 percent when they were sold, were offered at a price to yield 8.50 percent late yesterday. "Demand is there because people tend to realize there are not a lot of bonds with those sorts of yields out there," one municipal bond trader said.
 
Prices Mostly Unchanged
 The flurry in the New York City securities was the only activity in an otherwise dull session. Prices of most widely quoted securities were unchanged on the day, municipal bond traders said.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar in a Broad Retreat, But Gains Against the Yen

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar slipped against major foreign currencies yesterday but rose against the Japanese yen as traders expressed uncertainty over the future of Japan's economy.
At least 10 European central banks and the Bank of Japan sold dollars in European trading in an attempt to control the dollar's rise, traders said. 
 The dollar closed at 141.55 yen in New York, up from 140.35 yen on Friday. In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 141.17 yen, up 1.78 yen from Friday's close of 139.39 yen. In London, the dollar was quoted at 141.90 yen.
The United States currency continues to show strength as signs emerge that the United States recession has bottomed and the economy is resuming growth, currency analysts said.
"This dollar will continue to be bid because basically our economic woes are behind us," said Jesse Torres, senior trader for the Bank of Boston, commenting on the rise in the dollar.
Dealers said the Bank of Japan started the intervention in Tokyo dealings, a move they said had been expected after Friday's rally in the dollar on news of better-than-expected United States jobless figures for April.
The European selling was led by the German central bank, which was joined by the central banks from Switzerland, Spain, Italy, Denmark, Belgium, Britain, France, Austria and the Netherlands, dealers said.
 
Decline in British Pound
 The British pound fell to $1.6685, from $1.6710 late Friday in London. In New York, it cost $1.6705 to buy one pound, less expensive than $1.6710 late Friday.
Other late rates for the dollar in New York, compared with late Friday's prices, included: 1.76785 German marks, down from 1.7720; 1.5105 Swiss francs, down from 1.5190; 5.9875 French francs, down from 5.9985; 1,312.00 Italian lire, down from 1,312.75, and 1.14705 Canadian dollars, down from 1.14775.

HEADLINE: Poll Finds Strong War Support, but Some Erosion

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL

 BODY:
Despite the political unrest and lingering refugee problems that have mired American soldiers in Iraq, public support remains high for President Bush personally and for his actions in the Middle East, the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll shows.
But behind the patriotism and pride of the parades through New York and Washington lies a growing concern among some Americans. They say the Persian Gulf war was not worth its price in lives and other costs and was not likely to produce the opening for a lasting peace in the Middle East that Mr. Bush has predicted. 
 A large majority of Americans, 72 percent, still said the United States did not make a mistake when it went to war to drive Iraq's occupation forces from Kuwait. And 80 percent, including a large majority of every social, regional, racial, educational, generational and income group, said they took pride in the action.
But with American troops still in Iraq and President Bush unable to show progress in his Middle East peace initiative, the poll indicated a slow but steady erosion of the post-war euphoria. The erosion was reflected in an equally consistent decline in approval for Mr. Bush's handling of foreign policy and for his performance in general.
 
Foreign Policy Score Falls
 The number of Americans who said they approved of the way Mr. Bush was handling his job over all dropped from the extraordinary high of 88 percent in March, soon after the war ended, to 75 percent in the new survey. This is the first time Mr. Bush's approval score has dipped below 80 percent in Times/ CBS News polls since the war.
This may result from a drop in the number of people who said they approved of the President's handling of foreign policy, from 83 percent in March to 68 percent in the latest nationwide telephone poll, which was conducted among 1,424 adults last Monday through Thursday, before the huge victory parades in Washington and New York.
Americans' approval of Mr. Bush's handling of the economy, now much lower than for his foreign policy, has not changed measurably. In the survey, which had a margin of sampling error of plus or minus three percentage points, 48 percent said they disapproved of how Mr. Bush was dealing with economic problems and 41 percent said they approved.
The historic peaks that Mr. Bush achieved immediately after the war could hardly have been sustained for long. And since researchers have to go back to Dwight D. Eisenhower to find a President nearly as popular as Mr. Bush at this point in his first term, the new declines probably do not pose a serious threat to the President's chances of winning a second term in 1992.
Rather, Mr. Bush seems to be headed back toward a measure of popularity and approval that, while still unusually high, might be more sustainable in the long term.
The new survey also seemed to reflect less a decision by Americans that they now regret the war than an awareness that what seemed to be a clear-cut victory has frayed into a more confused peace.
 
Views on Broader Peace
 Indeed, Mr. Bush and his advisers have long acknowledged that the longer American involvement in Iraq dragged on, the more difficult it would be to hold onto the strong support they enjoyed at the height of the battlefield successes.
While Mr. Bush has said the war created a "window of opportunity" to pursue a larger peace in the Middle East, only 38 percent of those surveyed said they thought "a lasting peace in the Middle East" was more likely. Thirteen percent said the war made it less likely and 46 percent said the war would not make much difference.
In addition to the 80 percent who said they felt proud about what the United States had done in the Persian Gulf, 6 percent volunteered that they were proud of American troops, if not of the Government. Only 10 percent said they were not proud at all.
These figures were essentially unchanged from those of a survey immediately after the fighting stopped on Feb. 28. But there was a significant shift on another question: the number of people who said the war was not a mistake, 72 percent, was down from 80 percent in late February, and the 22 percent who said it was a mistake was up from 13 percent at the end of the war.
And while 66 percent of Americans, when reminded of the loss of life and others costs of war, said the war was worth it, the number who disagreed nearly doubled, to 30 percent now from 17 percent in the February poll.
As Mr. Bush is keenly aware, the continued power of President Saddam Hussein of Iraq still troubles many Americans. Sixty-nine percent of those surveyed said the United States should have continued fighting until Mr. Hussein was removed from power, up from 63 percent in May and 55 percent in late February.
The survey provided few other clues about the decline in approval of Mr. Bush's handling of foreign policy.
A substantial plurality of 47 percent said the United States should give China the same trading privileges that it gives to other friendly nations, which Mr. Bush has done. Thirty-nine percent said China should not have those privileges.
When it came to the Soviet Union, 62 percent said the United States should extend trading privileges and 27 percent said it should not. Mr. Bush is poised to give this "most favored nation" status to the Soviet Union.
But just as Mr. Bush faces opposition in Congress to extending financial aid to the Soviets, 59 percent of those surveyed said they would oppose giving money to help reform the Soviet economy. Thirty-four percent said they would favor such aid.
There was a large increase in those who said that, over all, trade restrictions were necessary to protect American industries: to 63 percent now from 51 percent in June 1990. Twenty-seven percent said free trade must be allowed even if domestic industries were hurt by foreign competition.
 
Most See Economy as Bad
 On domestic issues, 57 percent of Americans said the economy was fairly bad or very bad; 41 percent said it was fairly good, while only one percent said it was very good.
There was a small shift, to 23 percent from 18 percent in April, in those who said they thought the economy was getting better. But 47 percent said it was the same and 29 percent said it was getting worse.
As is often the case, bread-and-butter issues like the economy or unemployment were most frequently listed as the biggest problems facing America, and there were signs that health care, an issue that political strategists are seizing for the 1992 campaign, is indeed important to Americans.
Sixty-four percent said the Government should require employers to make health insurance available to all their workers, up from 56 percent the last time this question was asked, in April 1990, while 29 percent said health insurance should be left up to the individual employer.
Sixty percent said they favored national health insurance financed with tax money to pay for most forms of health care, while 30 percent said they opposed such a plan.
 
 
 
How the Survey Was Conducted
 The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted June 3 to 6 with 1,424 adults around the United States, excluding Alaska and Hawaii.
The sample of telephone exchanges called was selected by a computer from a complete list of exchanges in the country. The exchanges were chosen so as to assure that each region of the country was represented in proportion to its population. For each exchange, the telephone numbers were formed by random digits, thus permitting access to both listed and unlisted numbers. The numbers were then screened so that calls would be placed only to residences. Within each household one adult was designated by a random procedure to be the respondent for the poll. The results have been weighted to take account of household size and number of telephone lines into the residence and to adjust for variations in the sample relating to region, race, sex, age and education.
In theory, in 19 cases out of 20 the results based on such samples will differ by no more than three percentage points in either direction from what would have been obtained by seeking out all American adults.
The potential sampling error for smaller subgroups is larger. For example, for blacks it is plus or minus about 10 percentage points.
In addition to sampling error, the practical difficulties of conducting any survey of public opinion may introduce other sources of error into the poll.

HEADLINE: Stadium and Home on List of 'Endangered' Places

BYLINE: By MARTIN TOLCHIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 10

 BODY:
Independence Hall is falling down, and so are Tiger Stadium in Detroit and Montpelier, the Virginia home of James Madison.
They are on the fourth annual list of "America's 11 most endangered historic places," to be published Tuesday by the National Trust for Historic Preservation, a Congressionally chartered nonprofit group dedicated to restoring America's crumbling monuments. 
 Although the plight of these sites has long been known, the group hopes its listing will focus attention on the disintegration in a new appeal for aid from both government and private sources. Several of these sites, including Independence Hall and Montpelier, have benefited from restoration efforts, but much more needs to be done to preserve them, the report says.
 
Lessons From the Past
 The places on the list evoke memories and teach the lessons of history. Some, like the 65-year-old Franklin Post Office in Franklin, Tenn., continue to perform their original functions.
"Every one of these places has a very special utilitarian value," Jack Walter, president of the group, said in an interview. "You go to Independence Hall to learn how to be a better citizen tomorrow. You go to Tiger Stadium to keep alive a tradition that goes back to 1901."
First constructed that year as Bennett Park, the stadium was rebuilt in 1912, the same year Fenway Park opened in Boston.
Tiger Stadium, where legends like Ty Cobb, Hank Greenberg and Al Kaline set records, needs renovation and expansion. "This landmark is a symbol of stability for a city that has suffered major social, political and economic upheavals of 20th-century life," the report said.
Walden Pond and Woods in Concord and Lincoln, Mass., where the writer and philosopher Henry David Thoreau lived and wrote, is also on the list. "It is somewhere you go to think about the environmental movement that Thoreau founded," Mr. Walter said.
Independence National Historical Park, which includes Independence Hall, the Liberty Bell and the Founding Fathers' meeting places, "lacks adequate resources to repair leaky roofs, replace archaic fire-sprinkler, plumbing, heating and air-conditioning systems or remove such potential hazards as asbestos and PCB's," the report said.
The Madison mansion "needs to be stabilized and its enormous copper roof replaced," the report said. In addition, 135 of Montpelier's adjacent buildings need maintenance or rehabilitation.
Montpelier, Tiger Stadium, the Franklin post office, Independence Park, Walden Pond and Woods and the Southeast Light on Block Island, R.I., now menaced by the Atlantic, are making their first appearance on the National Trust's annual listing.
This year's list also includes some holdovers:
Antietam National Battlefield Park in Maryland, site of a bloody Civil War battle, because of encroaching development.
Fort Frederica, on St. Simon's Island, Ga., "in danger of being overwhelmed by a modern commercial complex."
Kennecott Mines in Kennecott, Alaska, afflicted by "harsh winter snowfalls, spring floods and vandalism."
The Penn School in Frogmore, S.C., one of the earliest schools for freed slaves, which is suffering from the "severe coastal climate, termite infestation and lack of funding for maintenance."
South Pasadena, Calif., where historic neighborhoods are endangered by a planned freeway.
