HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Unisys in $207 Million Deal To Sell Timeplex Subsidiary

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA, June 10

 BODY:
The Unisys Corporation said today that it would sell Timeplex Inc., a computer networking subsidiary, for $207 million to a joint venture led by Ascom Holding A.G., a Swiss telecommunications and automation concern.
Unisys, a military contractor and the nation's third-largest computer maker, said the sale, which should close before September, would help trim its debt, which stood at $3.43 billion at the end of March. Unisys lost $551 million last year on revenues of $10.1 billion, largely because of big interest payments. 
 The deal for Timeplex, based in Woodcliff Lake, N.J., and other real estate transactions this quarter would put the company's total asset sales at more than $500 million since early 1990.
The company's debt-reduction goal for this year is at least $600 million, Peter Hynes, a Unisys spokesman, said from the company's headquarters in Blue Bell, Pa.
In the last month, Unisys also announced the sale of its Detroit office building and 31 surrounding acres and said it would sell 2.2 million shares of its Japanese subsidiary, Nihon Unisys Ltd. Last week, the company said a subsidiary, the Unisys Credit Corporation, had sold $131 million in lease-receivable backed certificates. Industry analysts said Unisys also appeared to be trying to sell its military business.
"Despite an extremely difficult economic environment since our asset sale program began in early 1990, we have realized $170 million in cash, primarily from real estate sales, through March 31, 1991," said James A. Unruh, the Unisys chairman and chief executive.
Tom Willmott, an analyst at the Aberdeen Group in Boston, called Timeplex one of Unisys's "rubies," and said the company might have to sell more of its better assets to protect its "milk and butter" subsidiaries.
But he cautioned that the sale might not be as helpful as it appeared. "When you divide it up and sell it off, you still end up in debt," Mr. Willmott said.
Unisys bought Timeplex in January 1988 with $330 million in Unisys stock. The company employs 2,300 workers in more than 40 countries.
Unisys stock fell 37.5 cents today, closing at $3.75 on the Big Board.

HEADLINE: U.S. Rebuffed On Rates Cut

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: BASEL, June 10

 BODY:
The world's top central banking body today dismissed calls from the Bush Administration for lower world interest rates, saying it was more important to tame inflation than to act hastily to overcome recession.
The Bank for International Settlements implicitly rebuked the Treasury Department for calling on other leading economies to use rate cuts to spur growth. 
The bank said inflation, not cyclical economic swings, should be central banks' No. 1 enemy.
"The upswing will start from a relatively high level of inflation and that is my concern," the organization's president, Bengt Dennis, said. "We should try to avoid a situation where we have to brake the upswing and tighten our monetary policy again."
Mr. Dennis was speaking at the end of the Basel-based bank's annual meeting. The meeting brought together top officials from more than 80 central banks.
The United States Federal Reserve Board was represented at the meeting by Wayne Angell, a Federal Reserve Board governor, who said he supported Mr. Dennis. "There are no inconsistencies between me and Bengt Dennis," he said.
Mr. Dennis's warning on inflation mirrored recent shudders among American investors, who feared the nation's first recession in eight years might soon give way to rising inflation.

HEADLINE: Citicorp Plans to Spur Loans for Companies

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
Citicorp said yesterday that it would begin a financing program this week that would help corporate customers borrow up to $1 billion in the commercial paper market.
Under the arrangement, which several other banks are studying, Citicorp's Citibank subsidiary will refer corporate customers with strong ratings from Moody's Investors Service and the Standard & Poor's Corporation to Premium Funding Inc., which was created by Citicorp and Merrill Lynch & Company. 
 Using proceeds from commercial paper it will sell through Merrill Lynch, Premium Funding will make loans for up to 120 days and repay the commercial paper as the loans are paid. The arrangement enables the companies to pay lower interest rates than if they directly sold their commercial paper.
 
Burden of Low-Profit Loans
 The new program, as well as changes Citibank is making in its other commercial paper programs for large corporations, will help it satisfy the loan needs of customers without burdening the bank with low-profit loans that require large amounts of capital.
Although Citicorp has recently raised more capital to comply with tougher standards that begin next year, it is trying to limit its need for still more capital by selling loans, or arranging financing programs like the Premium Funding one that help it avoid making new loans.
Good-quality corporations eligible to participate in the Premium Funding program would normally borrow at interest rates below the 8.5 percent prime rate, according to one banker who asked not to be identified.
 
Cost of About 6.20 Percent
 Through the Premium Funding program, he estimated, such companies might borrow currently at a cost of about 6.20 percent, or less than they would have to pay if they tried to sell commercial paper under their own name, and not much different than the cost of a bank loan.
"Premium Funding is not meant to be a cheaper source of financing than a bank loan," said Ken M. Wormser, a Citibank vice president. "It is intended to help corporations diversify their sources of funds." Bankers said the program might be especially attractive to corporations whose ratings were high enough to qualify them for low-cost bank loans, but which did not qualify for the top ratings needed for ready acceptance in the commercial paper market.
Merrill Lynch, which will sell Premium Funding's commercial paper to investors, has plans to include other regional banking companies, thereby expanding Premium Funding's lending ability to $3 billion.
In a similar plan, the Mellon Bank Corporation of Pittsburgh has created Allomon Funding to issue commercial paper and make corporate loans to Mellon's customers. Allomon's name was created from the names of the Allegheny and Monongahela Rivers, which converge in Pittsburgh to form the Ohio River.
 
Cut in Need for Capital
 To protect commercial paper investors from losses, Citibank has agreed to buy a minimum of 20 percent of the outstanding loans, or a larger amount depending on the size and quality of the loans issued by Premium Funding. By agreeing to purchase, if needed, only a small part of the loans, bankers will greatly reduce the capital they require to satisfy the needs of their corporate customers.
With an ordinary loan, for example, a bank would have to keep $8 of capital for every $100 lent. But with the Premium Funding program, Citibank will need to have only $8 of capital per $100 of purchase commitment.
The introduction of the Premium Funding program comes at a time when Citicorp is revamping other commercial paper programs used to finance corporate trade receivables.

HEADLINE: Indians Balance Changes and Tradition

BYLINE: By DAVID GONZALEZ

 BODY:
When New York City's first Hindu temple opened in Flushing, Queens, 14 years ago, volunteer priests had to be culled from the handful of devotees who worshiped before silver-sheathed sculptures of ancient deities.
Now, seven full-time priests minister to a congregation of thousands of Indian immigrants. On some feast days a line of barefoot worshipers snakes down the ornate temple's steps waiting to chant prayers and make offerings of fruits and flowers. 
 "The demand has far outstripped what we have," said Dr. Alagappa Alagappan, chairman of the temple, the Hindu Temple Society of North America.
 
Growing Population
 In the latest sign of the growth and vitality of the Indian community in New York, the temple broke ground last month on a $4.5 million addition that will house a wedding hall, auditorium and banquet room.
The city's Indian population has skyrocketed from about 6,000 in 1970 to more than 94,000 in 1990, according to the Department of City Planning. Many of those immigrants came as part of a stream of professionals who began arriving from India's teeming urban centers after American immigration rules were liberalized in 1965.
Their familiarity with city life and English has helped many to blend prosperously into the city's economic mainstream and eventually to send for relatives in India. Now many Indians here find themselves grappling with a common struggle among immigrants: the battle between parents and children over maintaining traditional values or adopting American customs.
"The tension is increasing between maintaining Indian traditions and adapting to American society," said Dr. Madhulika Khandelwal, a historian at Queens College who has studied the post-1965 influx. "This is a society very much at the crossroads."
Indians have lived in New York City since the early decades of this century, when a handful of professionals and students settled here in search of opportunity. Many of them later played major roles in the nationalist movement for Indian independence.
In the 1950's, India endured a brain drain in which many unemployed college graduates left the country. But with strict limits on the number of Indian immigrants allowed into the United States, many settled in the United Kingdom and some African nations.
American immigration policy eased in the mid-60's, increasing the annual flow from 100 to 20,000 Indians. Thousands of doctors, engineers, scientists and academics, most of them young men, joined the small nucleus of students, diplomats and professionals who had preceded them here, and quickly landed jobs.
"The professional community has done exceedingly well," said Dr. Anand Mohan, a professor of philosophy and political science at Queens College who immigrated 35 years ago. "Most of them are pretty bi-cultural."
 
Greater Diversity
 As the first wave achieved economic success in the 1970's and applied for citizenship, they were joined by relatives, many of whom were not professionals. With those arrivals, Dr. Mohan said, the community's profile changed, making it more diverse and reflective of Indian society. Many of the new immigrants opened clothing stores, newsstands, electronics shops and insurance and travel agencies that catered to the growing community. Unskilled laborers who spoke limited English worked at gas stations, drove cabs or hawked newspapers.
Economics was the driving force that brought many of the immigrants here. For others, the motivations were even stronger.
Harbans Singh, who works for a courier service, said he and his parents left their farm five years ago to escape the turmoil in the Punjab, long plagued with feuding between Hindus and Sikhs, a separate religious group concentrated in the region.
In New York, such problems seem nonexistent. The various elements of the city's Indian community have coexisted with little factional strife, respecting one another's traditions. Perhaps it is appropriate that the bulk of the Indian community is in Flushing, an area first settled in the 1600's by Quakers fleeing religious persecution.
"There is no enmity or anything of that sort," said Sewa Singh, secretary of the Sikh Center on Parsons Boulevard. "We go to see our Hindu friends and they come to see us."
 
Traditional Prayers
 At last month's celebration at the Hindu Temple Society, devotees chanted ancient Sanskrit prayers while priests made offerings of incense, apples and split coconuts. The temple, with its conical, tiered towers embellished with figures of monkeys, peacocks and eagles, may look out of place to some, rising above a row of boxy Archie Bunker-style houses along a tree-lined stretch of Bowne Street -- but not to Mr. Alagappan. "John Bowne was a great religious freedom fighter," he said of one of founders of the Quaker community in Flushing. "Somehow all these things come together here."
Sikhs and Hindus work side by side at Wholesale Liquidators in SoHo, where turbaned security guards stand watch as young Indian women work the cash registers.
Suman Chand, a 19-year-old student at Queens College who works at the store, said Americans tended to see all Indians as a single group, a tendency that had carried over into her community.
"Here, Sikhs, Hindus and Muslims, we don't care, we stick together," she said. "We just think, 'Oh, they're Indian.' We share that."
They also share an abiding interest in news from the homeland, eagerly snapping up copies of Indian newspapers, most recently to read about the assassination of Rajiv Gandhi, the former Prime Minister. While some Indian political groups have chapters in the United States, many Indians said political activism was not a priority.
"You can't influence Indian politics by remote control," said Dr. Mohan, who added, "There is nothing to do but feel utterly helpless."
 
Preserving a Heritage
 Instead, some professionals have focused on charitable work, raising money to refurbish temples in their hometowns or to establish health clinics in rural villages.
"It is a drop in the ocean considering the needs of India," said Dr. Mohan, who has donated money to rebuild a 1,200-year-old temple in his ancestral village in southern India.
At the same time, some Indians are keeping a wary eye on the future of their community in the United States. "Our endeavor is to look forward," Dr. Alagappan said during the groundbreaking ceremonies at the Hindu temple. "We have to go forward in the 21st century and have the children preserve the Hindu heritage."
In a house adjoining the temple, barefoot children sat cross-legged on the floor repeating the prayers chanted by a temple priest. Across the street, a handful of young girls practiced the sleek, angular movements of traditional Indian dance. To entice more children to come to the temple, the adults have tried to leaven spiritual and cultural lessons with sports and academic activities.
The clash between traditional and contemporary values most often erupts when children become teen-agers. While they want to please their parents by excelling in school, they bristle at traditional strictures involving dating and dress. Some young women have even begun rebelling against arranged marriages.
Shriki Jhaveri, 35, who owns an ice-cream-making business, said assimilation is tugging at his children.
At home, Indian records play on the stereo while traditional food is served for dinner in a household where both parents speak their native language of Gujarati. But Mr. Jhaveri's two daughters -- aged 5 and 9 -- prefer Western dress and music and wonder why their friends can eat meat while their family is vegetarian. Mr. Jhaveri frowns when he thinks of the effect the openness of American society could have on them.
"They see too much openness of women, like on the beach when they are half naked," he said. "It's hard, because our children are picking up Western values, but I still want them to look to me for Indian guidance."
Jayakrishna Ambati, a 20-year-old medical student, said traditional values need not be rejected by the young. "There are youngsters who feel pulled by two cultures," he said. "It is important to glean the best of both worlds. You can do it."
 
Few Return to India
 Dr. Khandelwal said that while many immigrants have integrated into the economy and their professions here, they have tried to prevent the Americanization of their families and social lives. "Not all are going through tensions, but there are clear signs of a generation gap, which is there in India, too," she said. "The pressure to keep traditions is strong."
Despite the emphasis on cultural traditions and interest in news from their homeland, few Indians move back to India once they have migrated. For many, professional ties and the responsibilities of raising a family make them reluctant to pull up stakes. "Sometimes I think I would like to go back and set up a knitting factory, and the Government would help me, but we can't get financing for homes," said Mr. Jhaveri. "It just gets too expensive to go back."
Others have no desire to return. "I would never think of going back to India," said Harbans Singh. "Americans help each other, but it's the opposite in India. Everybody gives you a hard time."

HEADLINE: New Finance Woes: F.D.I.C. Loss Worse; S.& L. Crisis Deeper

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 10

 BODY:
Despite forecasts of a turnaround, new figures show that the banking industry is still deep in crisis. And the financial woes do not end there: The disclosure came as the nation's senior auditor prepared to tell Congress that the savings and loan bailout is in such disarray that its costs cannot be estimated.
On the banking front, the nation's senior regulator doubled his estimates for losses to the fund that insures deposits in commercial banks. The report that the fund could lose as much as $23.1 billion in 1991 and 1992 was tucked away in the last paragraph of a news release from L. William Seidman on the condition of the savings and loan rescue. Mr. Seidman is the senior official for both the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation and the Resolution Trust Corporation, which oversees the savings and loan bailout. 
 To be sure, most regulators say the condition of the banking industry is not so grave as to require the kind of taxpayer bailout now under way to rescue the nation's savings and loans.
On Tuesday, Charles A. Bowsher, the Comptroller General, will tell Congress that Resolution Trust is in such disarray that it cannot be audited by the General Accounting Office and that the ultimate cost of the rescue thus cannot be calculated.
Mr. Bowsher heads the G.A.O., which is required by law to provide Congress with an audit of the trust corporation by the end of June every year. Its first audit was delivered last year.
Worried about the political impact of Mr. Bowsher's assessment on requests for more money for the bailout, the Administration announced today that it had appointed the deputy secretaries of the Treasury and the Department of Housing and Urban Development to "investigate and coordinate" audits of the trust corporation. Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady is expected to go to Congress in two weeks with such a request.
For the F.D.I.C. fund that insures bank deposits, Mr. Brady has not sought new capital, but instead has asked Congress to increase to $70 billion the fund's ability to borrow from the Government. Mr. Brady has assured Congress that taxpayers will not be counted on to repay the borrowed funds, but that they will be repaid from industry contributions and sales of assets seized from failed banks.
Earlier this year, Mr. Seidman estimated that the bank insurance fund would post losses of about $14.9 billion in 1991 and 1992 from the collapse of 340 banks.
The actual value of the insurance fund is in dispute. Mr. Seidman said that his agency's preliminary audit showed that the fund was worth $8.4 billion at the end of last year. Mr. Bowsher has said the fund is already "virtually insolvent" because it must also account for those banks that are likely to fail.
 
More Spending Forecast
 Mr. Bowsher is expected to tell the Senate Banking Committee that Resolution Trust is likely to spend significantly more than the $130 billion the Bush Administration projected last year.
Mr. Brady has repeatedly predicted that the savings and loan bailout will not exceed $130 billion, counted in 1990 dollars. The G.A.O. has put the cost as high as $500 billion over the 40 years that the Government is expected to borrow money to pay for the bailout.
In testimony prepared for delivery before the Senate Banking Committee on Tuesday, Mr. Bowsher says: "The best cost estimates for resolving failed thrifts today could be significantly understated and unexpected losses on asset sales could dramatically increase R.T.C.'s funding needs sometime in the future. R.T.C. headquarters is still unable to track all its assets in receivership or to provide information related to the book value, estimated recovery value, date of sale, sales price, and sale gain/loss on an individual asset basis."
A copy of the prepared testimony was obtained from an individual outside the General Accounting Office.
 
A Scathing Portrayal
 Earlier today, the G.A.O. made public a letter to Mr. Brady, sent in response to his request that the auditors identify specific problems at the Resolution Trust Corporation.
In a scathing portrayal of the trust corporation, the accounting office, an investigative arm of Congress, concluded that the agency had been unable to keep track of its growing inventory of billions of dollars in assets from seized institutions. In one instance, the G.A.O. found that Resolution Trust had awarded a contract to a company to manage $7.4 million in real estate that the agency had already sold.
The trust corporation has also apparently violated its own rules and awarded contracts to companies that have not met requirements to register with the Government.
But the problem that appears to present the greatest eventual cost to the taxpayer is the Resolution Trust Corporation's inability to accurately measure how much it should be receiving for the assets that it is selling. Mr. Bowsher concludes that this will probably mean that much of the so-called working capital that the Resolution Trust is borrowing and expects to recoup through sales may wind up becoming losses for the agency.
 
Asset Valuation Difficult
 Administration officials conceded today that valuing the assets in order to sell them and recoup top dollar would be difficult.
"Asset valuation is extremely tricky even in a good market," said Alfred A. DelliBovi, Under Secretary for Housing and Urban Development. "These are troubled assets to start with. Almost by definition, what's being wound down is junk."
But Mr. Bowsher said the trust corporation's "policy of aggressive discounting" could wind up meaning that the bailout would cost more.
"While everyone would like to see as many assets sold as quickly as possible for as much as possible, that dual expectation may be very difficult to realize," Mr. Bowsher said in his prepared testimony.

HEADLINE: U.S., in Shift, Will Back Aid to World Bank Unit

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 10

 BODY:
The Treasury has agreed to support a capital increase of up to $1 billion for the World Bank's private-sector lending division in exchange for organizational changes at the bank, Treasury and World Bank officials said today.
The Bush Administration had threatened to block the capital increase if the bank did not agree to devote 50 percent of its loans to the private sector in developing countries. 
 Under a compromise reached in the last several days, the World Bank will change its organizational structure to put more attention on supporting the development of the private sector in developing countries. The changes are modeled on moves the bank has already made to pay more attention to the environment and the role of women in development.
 
20 Countries Under Study
 The World Bank will study the private sectors in 20 countries over the next two years in connection with decisions on whether to finance economic restructuring programs in those countries. In addition, the president of the World Bank will head a new committee that will meet quarterly to review the bank's progress. And at least 20 mid-level officials will be hired soon to oversee the new emphasis on the private sector.
"They're not armchair economists, they're nuts and bolts executives," said a Treasury official who insisted on anonymity. "These should be people who have run companies, people who have run banks, and come from the developing world."
The World Bank's private-sector lending arm, known as the International Finance Corporation, had proposed a $1.3 billion increase in capital several months ago. A few World Bank board members, including the United States, favor an increase of $1 billion or less, while a slightly larger group of members favors a larger increase, said a World Bank official who insisted on anonymity.
The 22 members of the World Bank board are scheduled to decide the exact amount of the capital increase at a meeting on June 20.
The United States provides a quarter of the World Bank's capital and holds a quarter of the votes on major decisions at the bank. So, even though 155 countries are members of the bank, approval of capital increases virtually requires cooperation from the United States.
Some Democrats in Congress supported the bank in its opposition to the Administration's pressure. Representative David R. Obey, Democrat of Wisconsin, the chairman of the House Appropriations Committee's Subcommittee on Foreign Operations, Export Financing and Related Programs, took the initial legislative steps to appropriate money for the bank unit even though the Administration had not included such spending in its budget.
The Administration had contended that the World Bank was too fond of providing money for big government programs and was too reluctant to lend to entrepreneurs.
The bank's private-sector arm has been obliged to slow its pace of new lending in the last two years for lack of capital, said the World Bank official who insisted on anonymity. New-loan commitments grew 20 percent a year in the late 1980's, he said, but only increased 16 percent in the 12-month period ending on June 30, 1990.
In the 12-month period ending this month, new-loan commitments are expected to have grown just 4 percent, to $1.5 billion.
Without a capital increase, loan commitments would grow by 6 or 7 percent a year in the 1990's, the official said, adding that with the increase, the commitments should grow twice as fast.

HEADLINE: NEW YORK SALUTES;
In a Ticker-Tape Blizzard, New York Honors the Troops

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. McFADDEN

 BODY:
Three months after the last angry rocket of the Persian Gulf war, New York City lionized the victorious troops yesterday with a magnificent blizzard of ticker tape, patriotism and affection in a homecoming parade up lower Broadway's Canyon of Heroes.
With painted yellow bows underfoot and a glimmer of blue between the skyscrapers overhead, brass bands exploded, flags and confetti whirled in the wind and what might have been another Monday in Manhattan's gray financial district suddenly boomed into a dazzling holiday of music, marching, balloons and deliriously roaring crowds. 
 And last night, capping the day's celebration, a giant fireworks display lighted the velvet skies over the East River with chrysanthemums of red, white and blue, thundering pirouettes of silver and gold and, for its finale, the simulated destruction of an Iraqi Scud by an American Patriot missile.
 
Misgivings for Some
 In the footsteps of Lindbergh, MacArthur, the Apollo astronauts and American legions home from World Wars I and II, some 24,000 marchers -- troops from 17 allied nations that fought in the gulf, plus veterans of other wars and civilian groups -- crossed the Rubicon into history under a deafening tumult of cheering and cascades of confetti and ticker tape.
But the day was not a one-sided blast of patriotism. For many, the euphoria that had followed the swift victory over Iraq with relatively few American casualties in January and February had given way in the intervening months to new concerns over recession, crime, sagging municipal finances, civil rights and other matters, and some felt that the time for orchestrated celebrations had passed.
Moreover, many Americans could not find triumph in the conquest of a nation with the gross national product of Kentucky, certainly did not regard the Persian Gulf war as a great victory, and were uneasy about a celebration that would surpass those for the far more devastating world wars or the profoundly bitter conflicts in Korea and Vietnam.
And in the rush of yesterday's tumult, some said, it was easy to forget that 150,000 had died on the other side, that Iraq's economy and infrastructure had been bombed back into the 19th century, that Kuwait was still little more than a family-run enterprise, that Saddam Hussein remained in power in Baghdad and that American troops were still in his country protecting Kurdish citizens.
Even so, the day meant a great deal to New York. It was a chance for the city to strut its stuff, despite fiscal crisis and recession, to express gratitude to those who sacrificed and died for the country, and to reaffirm some old-fashioned ideals in an age that seems preoccupied with money, political correctness and marketable sentiments.
"U.S.A.! U.S.A.! U.S.A.!" the crowds chanted again and again as the troops in desert battle fatigues and sharp dress uniforms, the bands, the floats, the missiles and other military hardware, the international color guards and the celebrities moved up the skyscraper-walled canyon.
 
'Great Day to Be Back'
 "It's a great day to be back home in New York," exulted Gen. Colin L. Powell, the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, who was born in Harlem and raised in the Bronx.
The police estimated that 4.7 million people lined the one-mile route from Battery Park to Worth Street, and they called it the largest crowd for any single event in city history. The count, for all its seeming precision, appeared to be extravagant.
It implied that 235,000 people lined each of the 20 blocks on the route. The police conceded that it was based on a formula using square feet of street space and was a bit like numbering the blades of grass on a hillside. But it was in keeping with the hyperbole of the day.
"This was the mother of all parades," beamed Mayor David N. Dinkins, who had been using the phrase for weeks.
There was no disputing that the throng was enormous. People filled the broad sidewalks to capacity, gawked down from windows and rooftops at dizzying heights, spilled out of the plazas and side streets and choked four blocks of reviewing stands lining City Hall Park. And millions more watched on television.
It was an artist's conception of a spring day in New York: people in summery pinks and oranges for temperatures in the high 80's, an azure sky brushed with horsetails, the harbor shimmering in the sun like silver coins, and all along the parade route a palette of red, white and blue flags, yellow ribbons and desert-tinted uniforms. A brisk wind up from the Hudson swayed the trees in City Hall Park and blew the leaves in great masses like a woman's hair.
In the enormous fall of confetti and ticker tape, the sky at times grew dim, and the city and the parade seemed to recede in the storm as if into a framed picture. And for a while the familiar music of the streets, the bass rumble of traffic, the brassy horns were gone and all you could hear were the faint strains of "Hail, Hail, the Gang's All Here" or "The Halls of Montezuma," and above it all the madrigal song of a million cheering voices.
The four-hour extravaganza -- a $4.7 million private production that did not cost the hard-pressed city a cent -- was billed as the nation's biggest gulf war homecoming and the largest ticker-tape parade in New York history, and it was a day to remember.
 
The Negative View
 But, like any big event in a nation of diversity, there were those who disagreed with its substance and tenor, or whose enthusiams were at least tempered by the knowledge that this was just one of many parades and celebrations held across the country recently to mark the return of American forces, and that the conflict from which they had come home was perhaps the nation's least perilous war in this century.
Antiwar protesters dotted the route, but were concentrated at Vesey, Fulton and Ann Streets. "Operation Desert Massacre," proclaimed one sign mocking the march. "Jobs, health care and schools -- Not war!" said another. "This parade and the millions of dollars spent on it to celebrate the evil destruction of Iraq is obscene."
At least 25 protesters were arrested and 11 officers were injured in two clashes, one at Fulton, where a dummy was thrown into the path of the paraders, and another at Ann, where Christmas tree balls filled with red paint were hurled.
Many knew of the parade, but did not attend. "It's a bittersweet kind of celebration," said Carol Levine, a psychotherapist who had her bike out in Riverside Park. "It's not that I don't give a damn. I appreciate that we made an effort to do something, but it's a peculiar thing to celebrate, because Saddam Hussein is still in power and Kuwait is such a mess. I am left with a feeling that it is not resolved."
 
Festivities Start Early
 But for most of the people in lower Manhattan, it was a banner day of tribute to 12,000 troops from all 50 states and 17 nations, who marched with 6,000 veterans from other wars and 6,000 civilian groups ranging from bands and drill teams to dance troupes and fife-and-drum corps.
Even before the parade, the town was alive with activity. Mayor Dinkins, at a breakfast, gave the keys to the city to the three grand marshals -- Secretary of Defense Dick Cheney, the gulf commander Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf and General Powell.
By 10 A.M. all motor-vehicle traffic was cut off to lower Manhattan below Canal Street, and extra subway trains ferried in the swelling flow of paradegoers joining the ranks of those who had staked out the best viewing spots before dawn. Within an hour, the sense of excitement along Broadway was almost palpable.
Vendors hawked T-shirts, buttons, hats, flags and other souvenirs; 3,000 police officers formed phalanxes on both sides of Broadway; workers in hundreds of government and corporate office buildings filed out, and the crowds grew so dense that some spectators were squeezed 15 or 20 deep on the sidewalks.
"You couldn't even move," said Samantha Simone, a 14-year-old from Garden City, L.I., who fainted in the late morning heat.
 
148 Treated for Heat
 The Emergency Medical Service said 148 people were treated for heat exhaustion in temperatures that reached a high of 89 at 2 P.M., and for a variety of other minor injuries. A spokesman said 103 were treated at the scene, and 45 were taken to nearby hospitals. Most had fallen from barricades or trucks, and two were hit by objects thrown from windows.
 
Generals Lead the March
 A trio of vintage convertibles carried the grand marshals and their wives at the head of the line of march. Mr. Cheney, in a business suit, General Powell, in his dress greens, and General Schwarzkopf, in his familiar battle fatigues, waved constantly through the barrage.
Behind them came thousands of soldiers, sailors and marines, most of them in battle fatigues with helmets or barracks caps and desert boots, with rifles at shoulder arms or assault weapons slung tightly on the right.
They moved in lock-step mostly, shoulders back, chests out, heads up, battle flags in the vanguard of each unit, representing infantry, armored, cavalry, airborne, intelligence, mountain, support, engineers, maintenance, medical, supply, communications and reserve detachments.
A 15-foot Patriot missile, orange with a white tip, rolled by on a truck, followed by its launch system on a flatbed 12-wheel trailer. A few howitzers and battle tanks, ambulances and an armored car were in the parade, but it was not a show of weaponry or technology, which had been amply demonstrated during the war and seen in other parades.
Behind the United Nations flag came Jeeps bearing the flags of 40 countries that had sent observers, but not marchers, to the parade, and then marching units from 17 nations that had been allied in the Persian Gulf.
 
Awash in Debris
 When it was over, shortly before 5 P.M., Broadway was awash in debris: 12,000 pounds of confetti, one million yellow ribbons, 200 miles of ticker tape, enormous reams of computer paper and envelops and thousands of unidentified, multicolored bits and pieces.
The half-hour of fireworks that ended the celebration began at 9:45 P.M. as rockets climbed above the East River, filling the night sky over lower Manhattan and Brooklyn with a dazzling display of exploding colors. Every pier and vantage point on both sides of the river was jammed with spectators who numbered "in excess of a million," the police said. One of the most popular viewing spots in Manhattan was the South Street Seaport, which was closed at 8 P.M. when it was filled. to capacity.
Just to the south on Pier 11, overlooking the river and the Brooklyn Bridge, two marines who had marched in the parade gazed at the fireworks and reflected on their day in New York. "I've never experienced anything like this," said Pvt. Richard Douglas, 22, who was in the Persian Gulf for eight and a half months. "I've signed over 150 autographs today on T-shirts, flags, arms and even legs."
Pvt. Nicholas Collins, 22, said: "The City of New York has spoiled us. The parade was incredible. This makes us feel like celebrities."

HEADLINE: Stimulating Billions

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"States and Cities With Deficit Woes May Slow Rebound" (front page, May 31) is so misleading as to be hysterical. To say "the Federal Government is not stimulating the economy" is sheer nonsense. The Federal deficit for this fiscal year will be about $300 billion; last year it was $220 billion. That's $80 billion of stimulation! Most "cuts" in state spending are not cuts, but rather "no increases," which is a totally different subject.
 
PIERRE A. RINFRET
New York, May 31, 1991

HEADLINE: At Polaroid, More Than Snapshots

BYLINE: By GLENN RIFKIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.

 BODY:
At the Polaroid Corporation these days, talking about old-fashioned "instant photography" is out. The new chairman, I. MacAllister (Mac) Booth, talks instead of "rapid access, high-quality hard copy" -- terms more evocative of computer electronics than snapshots from family vacations. Mr. Booth would like doctors, researchers and business people wanting to take and transmit pictures to think first of Polaroid.
At the annual meeting last month, Polaroid executives displayed a spate of new products -- more, they say, than at any time in their history. These include a computerized system for producing medical images in seconds without traditional film; a digital scanner to enter pictures into computers, and a printer that makes instant snapshots from a computer screen. 
 The areas Polaroid seeks to enter are already crowded with much more experienced rivals, but Polaroid executives expect the great demand for computer-generated pictures to yield profits. "For us, even a small segment can be very lucrative," said Peter Kliem, a vice president.
Polaroid is trying to leap ahead in a year already marked by the death of the company's founder, Edwin H. Land; the retirement of his successor as chairman, William J. McCune Jr.; the expiration of key patents for the SX-70 instant cameras and film, and a sharp decline in profits.
Instant cameras are mired in a declining market. Video cameras, easy-to-use 35-millimeter Japanese cameras and one-hour developers have all eroded the demand for Polaroid's products. Instant-camera sales fell from a peak of 13 million units in 1978 to 4.5 million in 1990. Earnings grew in absolute terms, but at a rate that fell well behind inflation. If its new offerings fail, Polaroid may never regain the luster it had as an instant-photography innovator and the darling of Wall Street in the 1960's and early 1970's.
What Polaroid now calls family imaging, or instant photography for consumers, made up 70 percent of the revenues in 1978 but just a third today. Mr. Booth says that such figures actually illustrate the company's progress. "We don't mind being associated with instant photography, but we're not that narrow," he said. "There are plenty of applications for imaging outside of the barbecue."
Analysts are generally pleased with Polaroid's latest products, but doubt that the new technologies will deliver rapid payoffs. Some question whether Polaroid can crack these unfamiliar markets. "They have a limited capability to distribute through a direct sales force," said B. Alex Henderson, an analyst at Prudential Securities. Polaroid might have to rely on a major supplier of office equipment to sell its new products, he said. Mr. Booth himself warned that the cost of introducing new products and the prospect of lower earnings abroad portend a potentially dismal second half of 1991.
Mr. Henderson called the new products clearly important," but added, "They are a 1993 story." With nearly half of its revenues generated overseas, Polaroid may be rocked by a strengthening dollar, Mr. Henderson said, adding, "They've got a serious exposure to currency translations in the second half of this year."
This at a company whose earnings are already being hit hard. First-quarter earnings fell to $16.4 million, from $31.8 million a year ago, with earnings per share down to 13 cents from 43 cents. "The short-term prognosis is negative," said Eugene Glazer, senior vice president of Dean Witter Reynolds. "There's no momentum there and the recession is having a strong negative impact." Mr. Henderson expects Polaroid to earn $1.35 a share this year, down from $2.20 last year.
Then there have been some distractions: An interminable court battle with Kodak over patent infringement, in which Polaroid was awarded $900 million in damages, remains unsettled because of appeals by both companies. Fighting off a takeover bid by Shamrock Holdings Inc., an investment firm, preoccupied management two years ago.
Marketing has gone flat. The company that attracted Sir Laurence Olivier to make his only television commercial for its new SX-70 instant camera in 1972 has lost much of its pizazz.
 
Reorganized in '89
 In an effort to marry its instant-photography skills to computer technology, Mr. McCune brought Polaroid through a reorganization in late 1989 and declared the result an imaging company. The family- business- and technical-imaging divisions now each provide about a third of Polaroid's revenues.
Polaroid's fastest-growing, and healthiest, segment is its business division, which emerged when the company's executives noticed that they were selling more and more cameras to insurance companies, which use them to record damage, and realtors.
Mr. Henderson credits Carl Yankowski, the business-imaging group's vice president, with bringing needed marketing prowess to the company. Mr. Yankowski, 41 years old, went to Polaroid from Cadbury Schweppes three years ago -- the sort of executive from outside that the company once rarely hired.
In several other markets, company sales have been slower than Polaroid expected, Mr. Henderson said. The company is still searching for the right marketing campaign for the technical and industrial group, which includes professional photography, passport and identification photos and dozens of other niche markets.
Polaroid has tried to enter a host of other competitive new markets, like conventional 35-millimeter film, videotapes and even floppy disks. Mr. Booth acknowledges that those businesses have not been profitable; Polaroid has already quit selling floppy disks.
To stimulate camera sales and thus film sales, the company introduced its Onestep Flash instant camera earlier this year for less than $30. Mr. Henderson said that profit margins on the camera, now their least expensive model, were low, and that he expected the company's consumer sales to remain flat.
Polaroid's prosperity now depends on finding innovative products. "Their future is in their labs," said Brenda Landry, an analyst with Morgan Stanley.
Polaroid promises to begin selling a compact instant camera next year. Mr. Booth expects the camera's modest size and price -- the details are stil secret -- to attract buyers who have not bought a Polaroid before.
Analysts like Mr. Henderson are skeptical about the prospects for the new camera. He expects it to produce compact pictures the size of baseball cards. "Personally, I don't know why anyone would want it," he said.
Later this year, Polaroid will start shipping several other new products: the high-quality Hybrid 4 instant film; a digital scanner, to enter pictures into computers, and a computer printer that can produce snapshots.
 
New Imaging System
 The most distinctive new product is the Helios Laser Imaging System. Under development for more than seven years, Helios can produce medical images from ultrasound systems and sophisticated diagnostic scanners in 90 seconds; conventional photographic methods can take several more minutes to yield pictures that are usually not as sharp. The Helios system relies on a laser camera and digital computerized pictures. It will sell for $35,000, with its film costing about $1 a sheet.
Sheldon A. Buckler, vice chairman at Polaroid, predicts that Helios will bring in hundreds of millions of dollars. Mr. Henderson, the analyst, predicts sales of at least $200 million by 1994. and Polaroid has already demonstrated a color version of its Helios film. But Helios systems will not be widely available until well into 1992, while Polaroid will be paying off the development costs for several more years.
With the payoff from the Kodak suit possibly still years away, Polaroid needs many more developments like the Helios. The last of its key SX-70 camera patents are expiring this year. Ironically, as Polaroid awaits payment from Kodak on infringement of those patents, analysts doubt that Kodak or anyone else will jump into this decaying market now.
 
Need for Change Seen
 These days, Polaroid executives have little nostalgia anyway. Top executives openly speak of the need to reform a company where Mr. Land's spirit still lingers.
Mr. Land "did all the thinking; he was the only anointed generalist in the company," said Mr. Buckler, a veteran of 27 years at Polaroid. "He was a genius, a classic founder who had no great interest in organizational design," Mr. Buckler added. "He saw no reason to change."
In the last few years, Polaroid has recruited younger executives like Mr. Yankowski and James Ionson, a 40-year old astrophysicist who did research for the Defense Department's Strategic Defense Initiative, or "Star Wars." Mr Ionson will become Polaroid's head of research and development in August.
Still, the company remains dominated by quarter-century veterans like Mr. Booth, Mr. Buckler and Mr. Kliem. "We are searching for the right balance of the old and new," Mr. Buckler said. "There is a constant need for a 54-year-old company to unlock the mysteries of revitalization and rebirth."

CORRECTION-DATE: June 12, 1991, Wednesday

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day yesterday about product expansion at the Polaroid Corporation misstated the company's involvement in the floppy disk business. Though Polaroid has scaled back its investment in the disks, it still sells them.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Ends a Bit Higher; Gold and Silver Prices Drop

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar ended narrowly higher against most major currencies yesterday in quiet trading motivated largely by technical factors.
Gold prices declined after rising in Hong Kong. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $370.90 a troy ounce, down $2.80 from late Monday. The Republic National Bank in New York quoted a late bid for gold at $370 an ounce, off $2.70. 
 Silver prices also declined. On the Comex, silver bullion for current delivery settled at $4.48 a troy ounce, down from $4.52 Monday. Silver fell in London to $4.51 an ounce from $4.52.
 
Quieter Than on Monday
 The dollar started out higher in Tokyo, then continued upward in Europe and the United States.
Currency dealers said trading was quieter than on Monday, when at least 10 European central banks and the Bank of Japan sold dollars for yen in Europe to control the American currency's rise. Concerns about the Japanese economy were largely responsible for the yen's selloff, analysts said.
On Tuesday, the Bank of Japan released its quarterly survey of business sentiment taken in May and said there was little fear of a sharp decline in economic growth.
The British pound, meanwhile, was under pressure amid widening concern of a possible split in Britain's ruling Conservative Party over embracing the European monetary union.
In Tokyo, where global trading begins, the dollar rose 0.18 yen to close at 141.35 yen. It stood at 141.05 yen in London, and 141.25 yen in New York, down from 141.55 yen Monday.
The dollar was stronger against the British pound compared with Monday. Sterling fetched $1.6625 in London, down from $1.6685, and $1.6570 in New York, down from $1.6705.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late quotes Monday, included: 1.7735 German marks, up from 1.76785; 1.5160 Swiss francs, up from 1.5105; 6.0135 French francs, up from 5.9875; 1,319.00 Italian lire, up from 1,312.00, and 1.14435 Canadian dollars, down from 1.14705.
Late dollar rates in Europe, compared with Monday, were: 1.7717 German marks, up from 1.7705; 1.5125 Swiss francs, up from 1.5120; 6.0090 French francs, up from 5.9940; 1.9963 Dutch guilders, up from 1.9940; 1,316.09 Italian lire, up from 1,313.25, and 1.1454 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1473.
Gold fell in London to a late bid of $370.75 an ounce, from $372.75 late Monday. In Zurich, gold fell to $370.90 an ounce from $373.00. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold rose $5.25 an ounce to close at $371.96.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Volvo Searching Hard for Relief

BYLINE: By STEVEN PROKESCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, June 11

 BODY:
Although he professes to be optimistic, Christer Zetterberg, president and chief executive of Volvo A. B., has plenty of reasons to be gloomy.
The Swedish car company's most important markets -- the United States, Britain and Sweden -- remain severely depressed as the company tries to sell its most important new lines of luxury cars in nine years. The latest is the 850 GLT, a sporty sedan with a five-cylinder engine and front-wheel drive introduced today in Sweden. Volvo hopes the new car will attract younger buyers, many of whom now consider Volvo's offerings cumbersome and boring. 
 The 850 will go on sale in Sweden and northern Europe this year, and in the United States in October 1992.
 
High Absenteeism and Turnover
 Volvo is also struggling to lower its production costs. That is no small challenge in Sweden, where the worker absenteeism and turnover rates are the highest among industrialized nations.
Then, there is the task of making something out of an ambitious alliance with France's state-controlled Renault to develop and supply car, truck and bus components.
As if that were not enough, Volvo is forming a joint venture with the Mitsubishi Motor Corporation of Japan. In that deal, scheduled to be completed in September, Mitsubishi has agreed to buy a one-third stake in a Volvo plant in the Netherlands, leaving Volvo and the Dutch Government each with a third. Volvo and Mitsubishi plan to jointly develop new mid-size cars that would share major components and to raise the plant's annual capacity by some 50 percent, to about 200,000 cars. Mitsubishi is eager to grow in Western Europe: it is talking with Daimler-Benz of Germany about jointly developing and producing a four-wheel-drive sport-utility vehicle.
In a recent interview at Volvo's headquarters in Goteborg, Sweden, Mr. Zetterberg said a broader alliance of Renault, Mitsubishi and Volvo might develop. The three could supply each other with components like engines, he said.
That would be remarkable given how the French have been bitter opponents of anything that would help the Japanese expand in Western Europe, where they now have 11.4 percent of the auto market.
Volvo's success in dealing with these formidable challenges, analysts and competitors say, could determine whether it remains independent or follows in the footsteps of Jaguar of Britain and Saab Automobile, the smaller Swedish car maker. Both companies decided they could not make it alone; Jaguar was bought by the Ford Motor Company and Saab is now controlled by the General Motors Corporation.
"For Volvo to remain independent, it all has to work," said Philip Ayton, an analyst at Barclays de Zoette Securities Ltd. "By making their alliances, they have shown that they're aware they cannot make it entirely on their own."
 
Degrees of Efficiency
 Volvo executives point to their big assembly factory in Ghent, Belgium, as a sign that they can be competitive. About 40 hours of labor are required to weld, paint and assemble a car at the plant. That is fairly good compared with other European luxury car plants. And it is extremely good compared with the 60 hours needed at Volvo's main Swedish assembly plant in Goteborg.
But even Ghent looks horrible next to the mere 20 hours or so for Japanese assembly plants, a figure that comes from a study of the world car industry by the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. With the Japanese moving even more aggressively into luxury cars, they are the ones to beat, Volvo executives concede.
These competitive pressures and a deep recession gripping nearly all of Sweden's manufacturers may be the shocks needed to convince Volvo's Swedish workers that their future is on the line, Mr. Zetterberg said. He is also counting on recent changes in Sweden's generous social insurance system, which had made it easy for employees to skip work and still receive full pay. Indeed, absenteeism and turnover are now dropping.
He said Volvo could not abandon Sweden, where nearly half of its assembling capacity and the vast majority of its components factories are. "But future investment will go where it is the most profitable," Mr. Zetterberg said.
The venture with Mitsubishi, he added, should also enable Volvo to learn Japanese methods for improving productivity and developing products faster.
Mr. Zetterberg, 49 years old, became Volvo's president in 1990, after a career in the banking and forest-products industries. He is the heir apparent to Pehr G. Gyllenhammar, Volvo's longtime chairman.
 
The Currency Factor
 Like most big Swedish manufacturers, Volvo profited handsomely in the early to mid-1980's as a big devaluation in Sweden's currency, the krona, let it sell its products at competitive prices in markets like the United States. Volvo especially benefited from the booming world car market and the success of its 700 series of cars. Introduced in 1982, the 740 and 760, with styling that updated Volvo's traditionally severe, if solid, box shape, became de rigueur in prosperous American suburbs.
But by the late 1980's soaring labor costs, sluggish productivity increases and a weakening of the dollar against the krona forced Volvo to impose some large price increases in the United States, its most important market.
These developments happened as the demand for luxury cars weakened, competition from Japanese models grew and the need for capital investment surged. Last year the car division had an operating loss of $149.5 million on sales of $6.89 billion, its first loss in a decade.
 
Heavy Spending
 Volvo has spent $2.13 billion in the last five years on modernizing and expanding its car-manufacturing operations and undertaking the most ambitious product-development program in its history.
The new 850 sedan will probably cost at least $25,000 when it goes on sale in the United States. The new offering follows the introduction last fall of the 940 and top-of-the-line 960 models and a new six-cylinder engine to power the latter. The 960 is scheduled to go on sale in the United States this fall, probably for about $37,000.
Automotive analysts say the 900 and 800 series of cars signal Volvo's intent to move more deeply into the luxury segment and out of the upper end of the volume market, where price competition is much greater. They say that makes sense given Volvo's high manufacturing costs.
The 240, which was introduced in 1974, is Volvo's cheapest car in the United States, where it sells for about $20,000. With many other good cars to choose from in the $15,000 to $20,000 range, "the 240's audience has had to be tempted by price," said John K. Lawson, an analyst at Nomura Research Institute Europe Ltd. Its sales plunged to 69,800 last year from a peak of 232,000 in 1983.
Volvo has discontinued the 760. Mr. Zetterberg said there were no immediate plans to stop making the 240 and the 740. But others at Volvo, who insist on anonymity, say the 240 sedan is likely to be phased out, leaving the station wagon version.
Volvo is counting on new safety features on the 850, including a patented system for protection against side impacts, to help maintain the company's reputation for making especially safe cars. But over the longer term, this will be difficult, analysts and competitors say.
"All manufacturers are doing a lot more in safety and it will cease to become the exclusive domain of any one company," said Louis R. Hughes, chairman of Adam Opel A.G., the German-based division of General Motors.
Analysts criticize Volvo for taking seven to eight years to develop the 850. Mr. Ayton said the lack of a new model in this size and price range was a major reason Volvo lost market share last year in the United States, Britain and Sweden. But Volvo executives say much of the company's problem comes from a decision not to cut prices as much as competitors did and the fact that Volvo's conservative customers are more likely to postpone buying cars in a recession. They expect worldwide sales this year to be below the 359,600 sold in 1990, Volvo's worst year since 1982.
 
Trying to Cut Costs
 Mr. Zetterberg says Volvo's biggest problem remains high production costs. A program is under way aimed at cutting annual costs by three billion kronor ($476.7 million) by the end of 1992 and raising the productivity of Volvo's Swedish assembly operations to the level of the Belgian plant by mid-1993. Volvo is cutting the work force in its Swedish car operations by 4,500, or 15 percent.
But Mr. Gyllenhammar also realized that Volvo needed much greater economies of scale in product development and purchasing or producing components. That explained the complex deal completed in January that linked Volvo and the car, truck and bus operations of Renault. To cement it, Renault and Volvo took large equity stakes in each other, with Volvo paying Renault $1.17 billion more than it received.
At least in cars, some analysts and competitors question whether an alliance between two weak companies -- especially without a full merger -- can succeed. Some think the car business of Renault may rebound, but its group profits plunged last year, when its share of the European car market dipped below 10 percent.
Volvo and Renault say big benefits from cooperating in purchasing and developing components will come, though not before the mid-1990's.

HEADLINE: Walesa Seeks Special Economic Powers

BYLINE: By STEPHEN ENGELBERG, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WARSAW, June 11

 BODY:
Sharpening his confrontation with a Parliament still dominated by former Communists, President Lech Walesa asked legislators today to empower the Cabinet to rewrite the nation's economic laws by decree.
The move reflects growing tension over the effects of this country's pioneering economic program, and frustration within the Government over the lawmakers' failure to approve more than two dozen pieces of economic legislation pending since January. 
 "In view of the economic situation in our country, I see the need to undertake without delay effective action aimed at quick improvement in the functioning of our economy," Mr. Walesa said in a letter to his Prime Minister, Jan Krzysztof Bielecki.
"The Government is facing the problem whether it will be able to continue its reform program," said Andrzej Drzycimski, spokesman for Mr. Walesa. "The President and the Prime Minister both came to the conclusion that such powers are necessary."
 
Request for Debt Relief
 The request to Parliament came as Poland asked Western creditors today to reduce its $33 billion debt a further 10 percent and put the money into a fund for projects aimed at stemming pollution. Of the 17 countries that make up the so-called Paris Club of Government lenders, only the United States and France have endorsed the proposal, which was relayed to ambassadors here by Prime Minister Bielecki.
In his statement to Parliament, Mr. Walesa asked for constitutional changes that would allow Mr. Bielecki and his ministers to issue decrees "with the force of law" for one year. He said the specific areas to be regulated were up to the Council of Ministers, or Cabinet, which is led by the Prime Minister.
Poland was the first country in Eastern Europe to oust Communism, but it is the only one that has not yet held fully free Parliamentary elections.
This paradox stems from the terms of the 1989 "roundtable" agreement, under which the Solidarity movement agreed that only 35 percent of the seats in the lower house of Parliament, or Sejm, would be freely contested, with the remainder reserved for Communists and their allies. A newly created upper house, or Senate, was to be elected without any constraints.
The result of the vote in June 1989 was that candidates affliated with Solidarity won 99 of 100 seats in the Senate and all of the available positions in the lower house. Communists and associated parties retained the remaining 65 percent of the seats in the lower house, even though they had garnered few votes in the election.
Since he took office in December, Mr. Walesa has been pushing hard to get rid of the Parliament, thus far without result. His initial demand for a vote in May was rejected by the Parliament and a scheduled vote in late October now seems imperiled by Mr. Walesa's veto this week of election rules that he said were unclear and certain to produce a fragmented Parliament. The President also objected to provisions that barred campaigning in churches and limited rights of emigre Poles to return and run in elections.
Initial response to his call for economic decree powers was mixed. Mikolaj Kozakiewicz, speaker of the lower house, praised the proposal and said in a statement that he would do everything he could to speed its passage which, as a constitutional change, must be approved by a two-thirds majority.
Bogdan Lukasiewicz, a member of the Peasants Party, said the President should give the Parliament more time to act on economic legislation.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Semiconductor Semi-Success

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
THE Bush Administration negotiators who pieced together the new computer chip pact with Japan are proud as peacocks. And with reason: They managed to dismantle protectionist rules that were anathema to the President's free-trade principles.
But the victory may prove bittersweet. Japanese chip exporters remain vulnerable to retaliation under American laws that effectively prohibit foreign competitors from cutting a product's price near the end of its commercial life. More important, the deal in no way alters the sobering reality that America has lost its deft touch in translating advanced technology into jobs and profits. 
 The old chip pact, signed in 1986 when Japan-bashing had reached its apogee of respectability in Congress, gave the Commerce Department power to set minimum prices for Japanese exports of memory chips. It also guaranteed non-Japanese chip makers -- notably American producers of microprocessors, the number-crunching brains of computers -- 20 percent of the Japanese market for semiconductors.
The 1986 agreement did diffuse pressure for tougher protectionism. But the deal still proved an economic embarrassment, generating windfall profits for Japanese chip manufacturers at the expense of American computer makers, who are major users of imported memory chips.
To enforce the price floor demanded by Washington, Tokyo organized a memory chip cartel to restrict exports. The resulting shortage cost American computer makers dearly, hobbling production just when Asian-made PC's were beginning to challenge their dominance of the global market. This time around, the Bush Administration adroitly exploited the computer makers' experience with the chip cartel. The new pact jettisons the costly price restrictions. And it transforms the Japanese market share guarantee into an agreement to disagree over what counts toward the 20 percent target. Retaliatory tariffs, imposed in 1987 after Washington decided that Japan was not playing fair on market access, were also scrapped.
That is welcome news to free-marketers, who thought the old deal was just a special-interest grab camouflaged as strategic trade policy. But it still leaves American chip makers with a potent legal tool for protection.
Successful electronics innovators recoup their enormous development costs by charging an arm and a leg for new products during the first few years of sales. Thus, when an American maker manages to extend the life of a technologically aging chip by discounting the price to just pennies more than the cost of the silicon wafer on which it is etched, textbooks call it good business.
But under American law, the price of imports must fully reflect overhead costs: When a foreign maker sells the same nearly obsolete chip at the same slender markup, courts are apt to call it dumping.
This double standard irritates America's trade partners, who define dumping as selling at lower prices abroad than at home. If the comatose global trade talks are ever resuscitated, Washington may be forced to sacrifice cost-based dumping restrictions in return for concessions to American exporters. But in the meantime, American chip makers will retain a potent import fighter.
Gary Saxonhouse, an economist at the University of Michigan, thinks there is more to worry about here than eccentric American dumping rules. The White House, he acknowledges, has made it harder to shut out imported chips. But there has been no change in the economic fundamentals that made the protection of semiconductors so fashionable in the mid-1980's.
"We thought we had discovered the escape route to the 21st century," Mr. Saxonhouse noted. Everyone expected that knowledge-based goods ranging from microprocessors to superconductors would replace more mundane industrial products as a source of high-paying jobs and export profits.
American exporters have, in fact, made a big comeback in world markets in the last few years. But ironically, the gains have been made the old-fashioned way, as manufacturers have learned to make middle-tech products, everything from chemicals to construction equipment, with less labor and energy. Japan continues to gain in the markets that were once the exclusive turf of companies like Intel and General Electric.
Denying Americans the chance to buy cheaper, better products because they are imported is not (and never was) the answer, Mr. Saxonhouse argues. But until somebody comes up with a better answer, America's future prosperity will hang in the balance.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Issues Little Changed

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities were little changed and interest rates were stable in sluggish trading yesterday.
"We are in a trend to higher yields," one government bond trader said, "but nobody is going to do anything until they see what the inflation numbers look like when they come out on Thursday and Friday." 
 With long-term yields hovering around 8.50 percent, traders said that there were rumors of money shifting from the equity market to bonds. Based on price movements, that sort of trade has not yet taken place.
"I would say you would need to have yields of 8 5/8 percent or more to generate that sort of move," the trader said.
Prices did slide briefly early in the day, but recovered later on.
"When you look at the last two or three trading sessions, it is clear the market is getting temporary support when yields reach certain levels, like 8 percent on five-year notes and 8.50 percent on bonds," said William V. Sullivan Jr., a senior vice president at Dean Witter Reynolds. "But as we come to the end of the week, those levels will be challenged."
In keeping with the market's defensive psychology, most analysts are expecting that a raft of reports to be released tomorrow and Friday will provide further evidence that economic conditions improved in May, and that inflationary pressures increased somewhat. Statistics with that sort of cant are generally not well received by credit market participants.
A report showing that the United States ran its first quarterly current account surplus in nine years during the first three months of 1991 was ignored by traders. So too was testimony by Alan Greenspan, chairman of Federal Reserve Board. Mr. Greenspan, who appeared before the House Banking Committee, cited an increase in investors purchasing commercial property.
"Things are very quiet," the bond trader said.
 
The Secondary Market
 In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 8 1/8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021 were offered in late trading at a price of 96 1/4, up 1/32, to yield 8.47 percent, unchanged from late Monday.
Among note issues, the 8 percent 10-year notes were offered at 98 5/32, up 1/32, to yield 8.27 percent. The 7 5/8 percent five-year notes were offered at 98 23/32, unchanged on the day, to yield 7.94 percent. And the 6 3/4 percent two-year notes were offered at 99 19/ 32, down 1/32, to yield 6.97 percent.
Short-term Treasury bill rates were narrowly mixed.
Three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 5.55 percent, down three basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point. Meanwhile, six-month bill rates rose by one basis point, to a late offered rate of 5.77 percent.
Activity in the secondary market for investment-grade corporate bonds remained very sluggish. Traders said that prices of most issues were unchanged on the day.
An announcement by Bridgeport, Conn., officials that the city plans to honor debt service payments on outstanding bonds despite Bridgeport's decision to file for bankruptcy protection had no discernible impact on prices of the city's outstanding securities, traders said.
Bridgeport, which announced last Thursday that it intended to seek protection from creditors under Chapter 9 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code, has about $200 million of outstanding insured and uninsured bonds.
Elsewhere in the secondary market for tax-exempt municipal bonds, traders said that prices of most widely quoted securities were unchanged on the day.

HEADLINE: Salvadoran Leader in the U.S. To Seek Continued Arms Aid

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 11

 BODY:
With negotiations aimed at ending his country's decade-long civil war momentarily stalled, President Alfredo Cristiani of El Salvador began a three-day visit here today to press lawmakers and the Bush Administration for continued American military aid.
Hopes for a reasonably quick resolution to the war have dimmed in recent weeks with an upswing of violence that has prompted the Government and the guerrillas to accuse each other of bad-faith bargaining. 
 In an effort to press both sides to reach a peace accord by summer's end, House Democrats last week delayed placing any conditions on military aid to El Salvador at least until September. Democrats on the Senate Foreign Relations Committee are weighing a similar move as they work on a State Department spending bill this week.
The Administration and Congress are on touchy ground in trying to nudge the bitter foes the last few steps to a final peace pact, but not push so hard as to drive them apart.
Congress last year gave the Administration only half of the $85 million in military aid it had requested for El Salvador. The remainder could be used only if President Bush determined that the rebels were not making a good effort to negotiate peace.
In response to a rebel downing of an American helicopter in January and the subsequent killing of two of its crewmen, the Administration said it had cause to release the additional aid, but has not yet done so pending the outcome of the peace talks.
Military action in El Salvador has been unusually intense for the rainy season, but neither side has showed any sign of backing away from the United Nations-sponsored peace talks. In fact, diplomats in Washington and San Salvador say optimism over a resolution is greater now than it has been in several years.
Mr. Cristiani is to meet with Mr. Bush and his advisers on Wednesday and with nearly three dozen Congressional leaders in the next two days.
The Salvadoran President, who was elected in 1989, is expected to emphasize the strides his administration is making in the peace talks and in reforming the military -- steps he hopes will head off a repeat of the restrictions Congress attached to military aid last year.
Against these claims of progress, American lawmakers will be watching to see how quickly and how aggressively the Government's prosecutes eight soldiers charged in the killing of six Jesuit priests in November 1989.
Mr. Cristiani, who traveled here with several of his top ministers, is also expected to appeal to President Bush to release the $42.5 million in military aid the Administration has withheld pending the outcome of the peace talks.
Lawmakers who oppose delivering the aid have urged the White House to hold firm. "Release of these funds would take the pressure off the Government with respect to the negotiations, the Jesuits case, and human rights generally," nine House Democrats said in a letter they sent to Mr. Bush last week.
The Salvadorans will also meet with officials from the World Bank and International Monetary Fund, as well as private investors, to discuss increased economic aid and investment once a final peace accord is reached.
