HEADLINE: Bailing Out Soviets: Bush Is Cautious

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 11

 BODY:
President Bush demonstrated again today that the game of diminished expectations can be played to advantage in diplomatic affairs as well as domestic politics.
 In fact, he and his Secretary of State, James A. Baker 3d, seem to have chosen that tactic as a continuing element in their approach to the knotty problem of relations with the new, multi-polar Soviet Union, which bears about as much resemblence to the old monolithic totalitarian state of Stalin and Brezhnev as television-era American politics do to those of Tammany Hall. 
 Having hinted for weeks that it strongly opposed inviting President Mikahil S. Gorbachev to the economic summit meeting in London in mid-July, and thus having dampened whatever plans Moscow may have had for stampeding Western leaders into early commitments of enormous financial aid, the Administration dropped its objections to Mr. Gorbachev coming to London next month.
 
Naming of Strauss
 Having said again and again that before settling into a new business relationship with Moscow he wanted more dramatic evidence of the Soviets' commitment to changes leading to a free-market economy, Mr. Bush chose Robert S. Strauss, a symbol of free-market trade if ever there was one, as his new Ambassador to the Soviet Union.
Casting aside doubts as to whether the feeble Soviet economy still meets the legal definition of a credit-worthy buyer, the President has now authorized the $1.5 billion in agricultural credits Mr. Gorbachev has been seeking, and he has committed himself to sending to Capitol Hill in the next week or so the enabling measure that would grant preferential trade terms to Moscow.
The effect of this flurry of activity, which has also included the clarification of disputed terms of the new treaty covering conventional forces in Europe, has been to assist the Soviet leader in significant ways while the Administration and Congress ponder the larger question of how much money the United States should provide to help rebuild the Soviet economy.
 
'Big Bang' Ruled Out
 Mr. Baker said in a speech in Copenhagen last week that the United States has ruled out the so-called "big bang" approach to helping Moscow.
In each case, Mr. Bush has made himself look more flexible, more generous, than he might have seemed had he not at first held back. Relatively small, relatively inexpensive symbolic acts have assumed added weight. That suits his purposes, because while he is eager to help Mr. Gorbachev, whom he greatly admires, he is not eager to commit the United States too deeply too quickly.
Resources are scarce. Demands for domestic spending are rising. But most important of all, even the very near-term future in the Soviet Union is hard to read. On Wednesday, for example, Boris N. Yeltsin, Mr. Gorbachev's principal rival, is likely to win election as President of the Russian republic, putting a skilled political operator with a popular mandate at the helm of the most important consitutent unit of the Soviet Union, with all that implies for Mr. Gorbachev, who has no such mandate.
If he wins, Washington expects a visit from Mr. Yeltsin, an earthy populist, sometime next week. Mr. Bush is reportedly planning to meet with him in the Oval Office -- an act that will be widely and probably correctly read as a hedging of bets. Further hedging will be needed until it is clear what is going to happen in the Baltic states, the republics in central Asia and those along the sensitive southern border of the Soviet Union, all of which have been growing restive.
 
Arms Talks Stalled
 It seems reasonable to ask now whether Mr. Bush is doing the same thing in the long-stalled strategic missile negotiations, which constitute the last major impediment to a summit meeting in Moscow this summer. The White House said on Monday that the meeting would probably have to be held in late July instead of late June, as originally envisioned. Did that reflect a genuine substantive hang-up, an attempt to bring pressure on the Soviets to soften their arms-reduction position in the hope that a Moscow meeting would bring more economic relief, or an attempt to make an eventual breakthrough look more dramatic? Perhaps a bit of each.
Few in Washington will be suprised, given the startling cascade of events in recent weeks, if an arms agreement suddenly emerges from one of Mr. Baker's talks with his Soviet counterpart, Aleksandr A. Bessmertnykh, such as their meeting in Berlin next week. A summit date would almost surely be set shortly thereafter. But the Administration, ever loath to raise hopes too much, lest it appear to have failed, keeps talking about the difficult path ahead.
The agricultural credits are similar to those extended last December at a time when famine was a genuine threat in Soviet cities. Like those, they will cost the American taxpayer nothing unless Moscow defaults -- a major plus for the President, who can seem generous while not pushing himself further into a financial corner at home.
In the six months since December, even credits have become more controversial. The increasingly feeble Soviet economy makes a default seem more likely, and partisans of the Baltic states in this country, including Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the Republican minority leader, have expressed fears that grain bought with the credits might be witheld from the Lithuanians and other critics of the Gorbachev Government. But they are less risky, Mr. Bush clearly concluded, than most other gestures currently available to him.

HEADLINE: U.S. Companies in Japan Say Things Aren't So Bad

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, June 11

 BODY:
American companies operating in Japan say they face far fewer trade restrictions than in previous years, a long-awaited American-sponsored study released today concludes. Surprisingly, it also says that they often benefit from Japan's much-criticized practice of organizing companies in tightly linked exclusive groups.
Many companies also enjoy far more lucrative returns here than at home, although it may take years to reach that level of performance. 
 The survey of more than 300 American companies was conducted by the American Chamber of Commerce in Japan and A. T. Kearney, a management consulting firm. Although there are a number of problems for American companies here, it notes, the overwhelming majority of respondents painted a far different picture of the trade and investment atmosphere in Japan than the one usually described by American officials as they press Japan to open its markets.
Word of the study's findings touched off considerable debate within the Bush Administration and among trade specialists, even before the report was made public today.
At a news conference here today, the authors of the study said there was a wide gap between the perceptions of American executives working in Japan and their counterparts at home, who view Japan as all but impenetrable.
"While many American managers believe it impossible to succeed in Japan," said Edmund J. Reilly, the head of the chamber and the president of the Digital Equipment Corporation's subsidiary here, "in reality, a growing number of American companies in the market have come to prosper."
Though Japan is the second-biggest economy in the industrialized world, said William J. Best, vice president and managing director of A. T. Kearney International Inc., "it is amazing to me when you talk to American companies back home how little they still know about the Japanese market. Japan is still not on the agenda."
 
How Tokyo Might React
 Chamber of Commerce officers said one goal of the report was to help draw more American companies to Japan and to convince them that many of the barriers of the 1960's and 70's have been swept away. "We have a hangover effect," Mr. Best said.
United States officials, who were briefed on the results of the report in recent weeks, have said privately that they are concerned that the report may be seized by the Japanese to support their arguments that there is little need for more change from Tokyo.
These were among the highlights of the study:
*About 22 percent of the companies said that within six years of being established, subsidiaries in Japan were able to exceed the profit margins of their American parent companies. Nearly three-quarters said they could exceed the parent company's margins in more than 10 years. Only 27 percent said it was not possible to exceed profits made at home.
*More than half those surveyed said their biggest impediment was the cost of doing business in Japan and of hiring workers in one of the world's tightest labor markets. Only a third said Japanese Government regulations were a major problem, although many financial-services companies said they faced significant restrictions. More than half cited as a problem the short-term management outlook of their own companies -- echoing a Japanese critique of American business.
*Although the United States has repeatedly protested to Japan about "keiretsu" -- the interlocking corporate structures that favor the goods of member companies and exclude outsiders -- 32 percent of the American companies said they had benefited from the keiretsu system, presumably because they are now members themselves; 44 percent said keiretsu had no effect on their trade and investment, and 24 percent said they had been hurt by keiretsu.
*Only 38 percent of the American concerns operating here manufacture goods in Japan, and fewer than half of those describe manufacturing as a "primary activity" in Japan. At a time when many technologies have migrated to Japan, 22 percent said research and development was a primary activity for them here.
*Only 11 percent of those operating here said "major restrictions" still hinder direct foreign investment in their industries; 44 percent said some restrictions exist, and about the same proportion said none exist.
"These are not statistics that will be well received in Washington, and we knew that," said an American executive in Tokyo who was influential in preparing the report and who insisted on anonymity. "But we concluded that there was a lot of outdated thinking going on about Japan today."
The survey, which was anonymous, included virtually all of the biggest American companies operating here and many smaller ones. It named the companies that other American corporations regard as successful in Japan: IBM Japan, which has 25,000 Japanese employees; Du Pont; DEC Japan and Texas Instruments. Coca-Cola was identified as a company with a huge and successful retail business here.
 
Two From Wall Street
 Among financial-services companies, two that built huge empires in Japan in the 1980's -- Goldman, Sachs and Salomon Brothers -- were also identified as highly successful.
The results will be presented in detail in New York, Los Angeles and Chicago soon, as part of an effort by the chamber here to draw more companies to Japan. The Commerce Department recently began a similar program, planning to work with 20 American companies, but top executives of many of them dropped out at the last minute.
One reason, perhaps, that the results seem unusually positive, is that the more successful American companies in Japan were more likely to complete the detailed survey, which has an industry-by-industry appendix. The survey had a 40 percent response rate in Japan, with answers from 293 of 732 American operations surveyed here. The survey was sent to 479 companies in the United States but only 10 percent responded. To try to balance the results, many of the companies in the United States were interviewed, including a number that had failed in Japan.
Also, the respondents tended to be those with long experience here; more than 200 had begun operating here before or during the 1970's.
 
A Matter of Definition
 One difficulty in interpreting the results is that many companies have different definitions, including, for example, what constitutes a keiretsu. Technically, the term applies to well-defined groups of companies that are centered on a trading firm and a bank, like the giant Mitsubishi group. But it is commonly used generally to describe the tight relationships that often govern the conduct of business in Japan.
Another factor to consider is that the companies were asked to compare their financial results with their own expectations, rather than to objective measures. "A lot of companies here have diminished expectations," said one executive who was previously a trade official.
Some of the conclusions reached in the survey were familiar to readers of past studies. Executives said that it took longer to become a success in Japan than in virtually any other country. Many companies still refuse to modify their products for Japanese tastes -- the American auto makers were a frequently cited example -- because of the costs entailed. About half said that a big problem was Japan's strict product-quality requirements.
The complaint heard most often involved Japan's complex and carefully controlled distribution system. A huge proportion -- 84 percent -- said Tokyo's procurement practices still greatly favored Japanese concerns.
Many of the respondents were computer makers and construction and insurance companies.

HEADLINE: Weicker Says New Budget Is Compromise

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HARTFORD, June 11

 BODY:
Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. presented today what he called a compromise budget that he said included the best thinking from the legislature and the administration on how to resolve the state's revenue crisis.
But he left intact most of the core provisions and demands, including the income tax on wages, that have led the two branches of government to reject the other's best thinking so far. 
 Lawmakers resoundingly defeated the Governor's initial budget and last month he in turn vetoed their plan. This threw the state into a special legislative session and a race to pass a budget before the start of the fiscal year on July 1.
 
Room for Tinkering
 In presenting his revised plan at a news conference today at the Capitol, Mr. Weicker was both conciliatory and confrontational. He stressed that his revised budget had lots of room for give and take and suggested that lawmakers could do a good deal of tinkering without provoking another veto. But he also warned that he would vigorously oppose any effort to stretch budget talks past July 1, saying state residents will know who to hold responsible for the jarring cuts in services that could result if no budget is passed.
"If we don't, it's because we've chosen not to get ourselves out of the hole," Mr. Weicker said.
A third-party governor with no allies in the legislature, Mr. Weicker stunned lawmakers in February when he suggested imposing what the state has avoided for decades: an income tax on wages. His initial plan would have collected a flat 6 percent of all adjusted gross income above $12,500 for an individual or $25,000 for a couple filing jointly.
 
Revised Plan's Bigger Bite
 The revised plan would take an even bigger bite and collect an additional $115 million by raising the top rate to 6.75 percent. That rate would start at $24,500 for an individual, $40,000 for a head of a household filing alone and $49,000 for a couple filing jointly.
It would simultaneously lower the rate to 5.75 percent for the lowest income brackets, starting at $12,500 for an individual, $20,000 for a head of household and $25,000 for a couple. The old plan would have lowered the state's 8 percent sales tax, the highest statewide rate in the nation, to 4.25 percent. Under the new plan, the rate would be 4.5 percent.
The further tax increases, on top of what had already been by far the largest proposed one-year tax increase in state history, were mandated by the state's worsening economy and falling tax collections, Mr. Weicker said. "Since February, we have seen a precipitous deterioration in the economic condition," he said. "This state is bleeding -- and badly."
The revised plan includes many of the spending-control measures included in the vetoed legislative budget. The Governor said he would also agree to a provision that would give the income tax -- the entire revenue system, in fact -- a shelf life of only three years before it would expire on June 30, 1994.
Lawmakers said they expected no stampede to embrace the revised plan.
"It's a step forward in some respects, but it's also a step back," said Senator James H. Maloney, a Danbury Democrat against the income tax who helped lead the charge to defeat Mr. Weicker's first budget.
Mr. Maloney said that while Mr. Weicker's acceptance of the spending ceilings was a positive move, the public and the legislature should be disturbed that the lowered sales tax rate, a main element in selling the income tax, had risen.
"It shows that the imposition of an income tax does not guarantee a permanently lowered sales tax," he said. "It's already starting to creep back up."
The coalition budget of which Mr. Maloney is a co-author would have kept the sales tax at 8 percent and extended it to hundreds of millions of dollars in new transactions to resolve the nearly $2 billion shortfall expected in the preliminary $8.6 billion spending plan for next year. In his veto message, Mr. Weicker called that anti-business and cruel to the poor.
Mr. Weicker's new budget also extends his repeated objections to what he calls budget gimmicks. The legislature's plan, for instance, would have transferred the Department of Motor Vehicles from the general fund budget to a separate transportation fund, for a savings of $51 million. Mr. Weicker said today that the savings were illusory because the department's operations costs would just come from a less visible fund.
Mr. Weicker called that a gimmick and put the motor vehicles department back on the general fund budget. For the same reason, he also rejected a postponement of a payment to the state's teacher retirement fund that would have saved money only in the short run. The combined changes put his new $7.4 billion budget almost $400 million at odds with the legislative spending plan that many Republicans, in particular, had identified as inviolate, regardless of how the tax questions were settled.

HEADLINE: BUSH BACKS LOANS FOR SOVIET FARMS WORTH $1.5 BILLION

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 11

 BODY:
President Bush approved $1.5 billion in agricultural loan guarantees for the Soviet Union today, a major step toward helping President Mikhail S. Gorbachev bolster his country's economy.
The loan guarantees, which Mr. Bush had recently indicated he would approve after extending $1 billion in similar credits last December, will be made available in three installments starting this month with $600 million, said Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman. 
 The guarantees will allow American banks to lend money to the Soviet Union to buy badly needed farm products, primarily feed grain, with the assurance that the Federal Government would repay the money if Moscow defaulted.
 
Waiting for Results
 By month's end, Mr. Bush is also expected to send to Congress a Soviet-American trade agreement that was signed at the last full-scale Soviet-American summit meeting here in June, 1990. The accord had been kept on his desk until the Soviet Union passed a new emigration law. But a senior official said Mr. Bush could forward the document to the Senate as early as this week.
The treaty would remove the last barriers to granting the Soviet Union the tariffs extended to other friendly nations and is seen by Moscow as a critical first step toward expanding its economic contacts with the United States as well as the other industrial democracies.
The loan guarantees and the preparations to send the trade agreement to Congress represented an effort by Mr. Bush to begin to fulfill his promise to help Mr. Gorbachev institute economic reform. They also continue an active but not officially acknowledged effort to bolster the Soviet leader politically, while Mr. Bush makes up his mind how much direct financial aid he would be willing to extend to the Soviet Union.
 
'Positive Evolution'
 "The President's decision reflects the Administration's desire to promote a continued positive evolution in the U.S.-Soviet relationship," Mr. Fitzwater said in announcing the loan guarantees.
They were also part of a group of decisions that Mr. Bush has recently faced as he and Mr. Gorbachev move to clear up arms-control and trade issues in advance of a planned summit in Moscow this summer.
In a cable he sent to Mr. Gorbachev today about the loan guarantees, Mr. Bush also told the Soviet leader that he was assembling a team of experts to look into ways to develop a food distribution system for a country where food shortages are generally ascribed to a built-in inability to bring produce to consumers, not to lack of production.
"All of this is sort of a holding action while the President makes the far harder decisions about direct financial aid," an Administration official said. He added, "We help the Soviets a little on trade while they, we hope, work out the arms control problems we still have, and everything moves forward in the relationship."
Mr. Fitzwater said Mr. Bush directed Agriculture Secretary Edward Madigan to begin immediate discussions with Soviet officials about the details of the loan guarantees. After the first installment of $600 million, $500 million more would be available in October. A final $400 million would be available next February.
The guarantees will be good only for purchases of American products, but other details of the loans, including interest rates, are left to negotiations between Moscow and American banks.
 
Moscow's History on Debts
 Mr. Fitzwater said Mr. Bush, who is required by law to certify that the Soviet Union is capable of repaying loans before issuing Federal guarantees, based his decision on Moscow's history on debts to the United States.
"They have never defaulted on an official loan involving this country," Mr. Fitzwater said. "The President has discussed this with other experts and it is his conclusion that they do meet the test of credit worthiness and that they can and will repay the loans."
The President also acted on an assessment by a team of American specialists that the Soviet Union needs the loan guarantees to get through next winter and on "assurances from the Soviet Government that grain made available through the credit guarantees would be fairly distributed among the Soviet republics and the Baltic states," Mr. Fitzwater said.
Mr. Fitzwater said the money was broken up into three installments for accounting reasons; the Commodity Credit Corporation has already committed $4.2 billion of the $5 billion in guarantees available to it for fiscal 1991.
But Administration officials said that making the guarantees in segments would also permit Washington to monitor the distribution of grain purchased from the United States. If they are not fairly distributed, Mr. Fitzwater said, the United States "will have direct discussions with the Soviet leadership on that situation."
But he did not directly link the additional installments to that question, and officials said in private that the only recourse the United States would have if the food was not fairly distributed was to cut off the additional guarantees, a punitive move that they considered unlikely, given Mr. Bush's general reluctance to use economic sanctions as a political lever.
In a prepared statement that he read to reporters in the White House briefing room, Mr. Fitzwater sought to link the credit guarantees to a broader effort by Mr. Bush to use his personal relationship with Mr. Gorbachev to persuade the Soviet leader to institute free-market reforms.
"In addition to meeting the Soviet request for credit guarantees, the President today also expressed to President Gorbachev his continued interest in collaborating on a long-term effort to improve the food distribution system in the U.S.S.R., primarily through the introduction of market measures."
He added, "The United States is prepared to form a high-level team of Government and private experts to assist the Soviets in this effort."
Mr. Fitzwater said the makeup of that team was not decided and that there were no specific commitments by Mr. Gorbachev to remove centralized controls from Soviet agriculture or any other part of his country's economy.
"The President," he said, "has had a number of conversations with President Gorbachev in which he has emphasized his commitment to make changes in the system, to move toward a market economy."
Asked why Mr. Bush had agreed to help the Soviet Union buy more food if its primary problem was not one of production but distribution, Mr. Fitzwater said the loan guarantees were mainly intended to help the Soviet Union purchase feed grain for use at farms, not consumer food to fill empty store shelves.
"Without being able to purchase those feed grains from United States farmers, they could well have very serious shortages in those areas," Mr. Fitzwater said.

HEADLINE: Dow Up 10.51; 3,000 Mark Topped Briefly

BYLINE: By H. J. MAIDENBERG

 BODY:
After briefly surpassing the 3,000 barrier yesterday morning, the Dow Jones industrial average ended the day with a gain of 10.51 to close at 2,985.69.
Volume on the New York Stock Exchange rose to 161.6 million shares, from 127.7 million on Monday. 
 While 865 issues advanced and 693 declined, the blue-chip stocks again accounted for much of the gain in the Dow industrials and the 2.48 rise in the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, to 381.05.
The Big Board's composite index closed up by 1.09, at 208.83, while the Nasdaq composite index rose by 0.77, to 496.62.
"We are still in a bull market that is merely gathering strength for its next major advance," said Steven G. Einhorn, portfolio strategist at Goldman, Sachs & Company. "There are three reasons for our view: The economy is improving, however slowly; the inflation rate is low, and the Federal Reserve is friendly."
Mr. Einhorn said, however, that the market's sluggish behavior could be pegged to three reasons: Prices of long-term Treasury bonds have tumbled with the accompanying rise in interest rates; there has been a sharp decline in institutional cash reserves, and the volume of new stock offerings has been running at near-record levels.
Indeed, a secondary offering of 17.5 million nonvoting Reader's Digest Association shares propelled the stock to second place on the Big Board's most active list. The shares were sold at $33.25 each by 10 stockholder associations, with none of the proceeds going to the company. The stock closed up by 1 1/4, at 34 1/2, on a turnover of three million shares.
The most active issue was Pepsico Inc., which rose 1/4, to 30 1/2, on a volume of almost 3.2 million shares. Brokers said the only news on Pepsico was that its candidate for a seat on the board of the American Business Computer Corporation declined to accept the offer.
Pepsico owns two million of American Business Computer's 13.5 million shares and is entitled to a seat on the company's board.
 
Active Wal-Mart Up 1 1/8
 Elsewhere among the most active Big Board issues, price changes were in fractions either way with the notable exception of Wal-Mart Stores, which has been enjoying good sales. Wal-Mart rose 1 1/8, to 43 1/8, and was the 10th-most-active issue, on a turnover of 1.4 million shares.
Trading was also listless at the American Stock Exchange, where its market-value index edged up 0.03, to 369.80, and volume rose to 10.1 million shares, from 9.7 million on Monday.

HEADLINE: After Boom and Bust, Denver Enters Big Leagues

BYLINE: By DIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DENVER, June 11

 BODY:
While difficult for some to fathom, the organized play of costumed young men, who spit tobacco and scratch where it itches, adds a cosmopolitan flair to any American metropolis. Major-league baseball will soon confer that distinction upon Denver.
But even before the news on Monday that baseball will come to Denver as soon as the team owners take a formal vote, this old city at the edge of the Rocky Mountains was poised for a civic transformation. After going from cowtown to boomtown to bust, Denver is ready to come of age as a diverse, all-purpose city, with all the virtues and vices of urban America. 
 A new airport, one of the world's biggest, is to open in 1994, a year after the baseball team arrives. A huge new convention center has recently been completed. United Airlines is considering opening a vast maintenance center here that would employ 30,000 workers.
"Denver is being remade before our eyes," said Phillip Burgess, executive director of the Center for The New West, a research organization. "But people have been so caught up in the transformation that there isn't a real unified vision of where we're going."
The city's come-hither demeanor toward baseball and major employers like United stands in stark contrast to the heady, almost arrogant days of the early 70's, when Colorado voters, hoping to limit growth, rejected a bid for the Winter Olympics.
The challenge facing the city today, it seems, is to nurture a stable, manageable growth and yet avoid the traumas of the boom-and-bust rollercoaster. To find the right road, the city faces the difficult task of organizing a civic leadership, drawing an agenda and attracting the kind of decent, dependable jobs that guarantee residents a stake in the future.
Eight years after Federico Pena was elected as the city's first Hispanic mayor, the city's voters on Tuesday will choose between two black men to succeed him. Nearly seven decades after a member of the Ku Klux Klan was governor here and 20 years after school integration efforts led to racial strife, the transfer of the mayorality from Mr. Pena, who did not run for re-election, to a black man is seen by many here as a sign that this city has matured as a diverse urban center.
Almost a quarter of the population of 467,000 is Hispanic, making up the only major ethnic group showing steady growth. The others include some 58,000 blacks, maintaining a steady level since 1980, and a white population that has dropped about 4 percent since 1980 to 287,000.
The two candidates in the nonpartisan election -- Norm Early, the state's attorney, and Wellington Webb, the city auditor -- face worsening street-gang violence, the loss of its middle-class residents to the suburbs, a dearth of water and a haze of pollution hanging over the city that locals have nicknamed the "brown cloud."
 
From Boom to Careful Reflection
 For the past several years, Denver has not cut a prominent figure on the national scene. Following the boom-and-bust cycle of the 1970's and 1980's, it has been a time for the city to dust itself off and look both ways before crossing new avenues.
In the oil boom, Denver sustained a nearly mythic image, a place where entrepreneurs and developers, and not a few hucksters, came to town with billfolds open for quick profits. The ethos of growth and greed inspired, in an exaggerated form, the television series "Dynasty."
By 1986, the boom had fallen silent. And many homeowners suddenly carried deeds to houses worth tens of thousands of dollars less than when they had purchased them.
Many of the high rollers who came to Denver in the boom, including Bill Walters, the developer, and Marvin Davis, the oilman, left town soon after the party ended.
In Denver, boom has become a four-letter expletive, at least the kind of boom associated with quick growth and flimsy financing. The economic gospel of today preaches measured progress, stability, diversity.
The leading employer in the metropolitan region is U S West, one of the regional telephone companies, which counts about 13,000 workers in the region. Martin Marietta Corporation, the aerospace company, employs about that many workers. In recent years, several companies have placed telecommunications centers in the region, among them a division of American Express.
In an effort to broaden its base, the city and state have offered more than $320 million in incentives to United Airlines for the proposed maintenance center. Politicians have said the center would provide the kind of steady work base the city needs.
 
Diffuse Leadership
 But the Denver region has comparatively few major companies with headquarters here. And the absence of such corporate leaders, in the view of many Denverites, has meant a vacuum of civic leadership.
"The leadership of Denver tends to be diffuse, fragmented," said John Welles, executive director of the Museum of Natural History. "In Dallas or Minneapolis, if you want to get something done, you can get 20 or 30 people together for a meeting and make things happen. We can't do that. And I think perhaps that's because we're not a headquarters town."
Coordinated or not, Denver has been moving on several fronts. The most notable has been the apparent success in winning a baseball franchise. The largest single investor for the team is the Adolph Coors Corporation, the company based in suburban Golden known for its beer.
Like many American cities, an increasing affluence in the suburbs parallels worsening economic woes in the inner city. Almost all of the new corporate towers have been sprouting on suburban soil, mostly in the prosperous suburbs south of the city. The new airport, as well as the proposed United maintenance base, to be built northeast of the city, follow the suburban trend.
From 1970 to 1980, the Denver region saw a population growth of 24 percent. It grew 12 percent more in the past 10 years. Suburban Douglas County grew by 140 percent in the past decade, faster than all but Flager County in northern Florida. The Denver region now has about 1.8 million residents.
But the city itself saw population losses of 4.3 percent in the 1970's and 5 percent in the 1980's. And the city has yet to completely stem the loss of its middle class, which hemorrhaged with "white flight" after a Federal court ordered busing in 1974 to achieve racial integration.
In the recent mayoral campaign, in which two of the three leading candidates were black, race was almost never mentioned. The white candidate, Don Bain, a prominent lawyer here, finished third. Mr. Early, the frontrunner in the primary, now faces Mr. Webb in the run-off on Tuesday.
"I think the mayoral campaign has shown how Denver has really matured as a city of many cultures, especially in light of the clashes we saw over school integration in the 70's," said William H. Hornby, the 68-year-old former editor of the Denver Post, who now writes a column for the newspaper.
"Part of that owes to the kind of people who move here," he added. "They tend to be younger, well-educated people, who are open to new ideas. And often, they've often come from other large cities. And they're determined to see that things are better here."
These days, Denverites seem to have a palpable desire to show the nation that this is an exciting prosperous city, not a remote Western outpost.
But a tourism consultant hired recently by the city has urged Denver to make the most of its cowtown history and culture, rather than try to erect a miniature Chicago or New York.
"In Denver, you sometimes get the impression that they're ashamed of the cowtown legacy," said Jane Siegel, a senior associate of Longwood International, the tourism consultant in Toronto that conducted a study for Denver. "But that's what makes a place like Denver so distinctive."

HEADLINE: U.S. Bailout For Banks Predicted

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 11

 BODY:
The nation's senior auditor said today that the banking industry might be headed for a large taxpayer bailout.
Some members of Congress and analysts of the nation's commercial and savings bank industry have made such warnings before. But the prediction by the Comptroller General, Charles A. Bowsher, is significant because he is widely considered the most credible impartial voice in Government. His early assessments of the problems of savings and loan institutions and later of the huge costs in that bailout have proved prophetic. 
 Mr. Bowsher, speaking to reporters after appearing before a Congressional committee, did not suggest how large a bailout might be needed, but even the most pessimistic assessments have not seen the need for anything like the costly effort that is being made to salvage savings and loans. The Administration estimates that the savings bailout will cost taxpayers $130 billion, but Mr. Bowsher has said the total could be as high as $500 billion over 40 years.
 
Replenishing the Fund
 Bailing out the banking industry would involve replenishing the Government insurance fund that protects deposits and is used to cover the cost of bank failures. The fund has been battered by the growing number of large bank failures and is now at its lowest level since it was created in 1934.
Mr. Bowsher's latest assessment, which follows increasingly gloomy predictions and dire numbers about the state of the banking industry and the insurance fund, did not come totally as a surprise because he had previously urged Congress to provide some additional money for the fund.
"The odds are strong that the taxpayers are going to end up having to pay money to shore up the insurance fund," said Representative Charles Schumer, Democrat of Brooklyn, a member of the House Banking Committee. "But most of Congress would prefer to avoid the issue.
"I think Bowsher has been on target because he doesn't have an ax to grind."
Officials in the banking industry reacted differently to Mr. Bowsher's assessment.
Edward Yingling of the American Bankers Association, the largest trade group for the industry, said that if the recession ends soon, "this is a problem that can be handled by the industry, and it's our intention to do it within the industry."
Charlotte LeGates, a spokeswoman for the National Council of Savings Institutions, a trade group of about 350 banks and savings associations, said: "It's not clear how bad the banking industry's problems will be, but they will be very bad. It's not at all clear that the banks will be able to pay back if extremely large sums of money are borrowed."
The Treasury Department said today, as it has before, that no taxpayer bailout of the banking industry would be necessary if Congress adopted its plan to reorganize the industry and eliminate barriers to bank expansion into new businesses and across state lines.
Mr. Bowsher's prediction was prompted in part by a report issued today by bank regulators that while 90 percent of the nation's savings and commercial banks posted profits for the first three months of this year, the total size of banks with troubled loans had increased significantly, to $418 billion, from $399.7 billion less than three months ago.
On Monday, L. William Seidman, chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, once again raised his estimate of losses to the fund that protects bank deposits, to as much as $23.1 billion over the next 18 months, up from $14 billion. Mr. Seidman said today that most of the losses were more likely to occur in 1992, but denied that regulators were postponing the closing of ailing banks because the fund was so low.
The timing and political content of Mr. Bowsher's remarks are noteworthy. In April he called on Congress to impose cash assessments on the banking industry to shore up the insurance fund with $15 billion in cash. Neither the bankers nor Congress have rallied to this call, and it has also been denounced by the Bush Administration and senior regulators.
By raising the specter of a bank bailout, Mr. Bowsher was reminding Congress and the White House that he sounded similar warnings in the 1980's on savings and loans.
The bank fund has been depleted by a growing number of large bank failures, the latest of which was the Bank of New England, whose failure in January could ultimately cost the fund $2.5 billion.
Worried about the imminent insolvency of the bank insurance fund, the Bush Administration earlier this year asked Congress to overhaul the banking system and permit regulators to borrow up to $70 billion to protect depositors and shut down bankrupt institutions. The package threatens to become bogged down in Congress in the next few weeks, and today President Bush met with senior Democrats and Republicans from the House to push his legislation.
Treasury officials have said the prospective loans to the insurance fund will be repaid from industry contributions and the sale of assets from the failed banks.
But Mr. Bowsher told reporters after appearing before a Congressional committee that "it is far from certain" that the Government would be repaid under the Administration's proposal. "Some people have given the impression that Treasury's loans will all be repaid," Mr. Bowsher said. "I don't think that it is a foregone conclusion that they will be repaid."
In an interview this evening, Mr. Bowsher said he could not estimate how much a bank bailout would ultimately cost taxpayers.
"I can't quantify how much it will cost because we can't quantify how much the insurance fund will actually be borrowing," he said. "The regulators and Treasury have not been forthcoming with what they expect to borrow. But I don't think we should kid ourselves into thinking that the taxpayers will ultimately not be called upon."
Mr. Seidman had based his original estimates on a "short and shallow" recession and turnaround in the economy by summer. The consensus of Government and private economists is that the economy is fulfilling this prediction and is in the process of pulling out of the recession.
 
A Real Estate Recession
 Asked at a news conference about the fact that he had revised his prediction about the banks despite the apparent recovery of the economy, Mr. Seidman said: "What we're finding out is that there are two recessions. One is the general recession and the other is the real estate recession. We have not yet seen enough recovery in the real estate recession and that has the most important effect on the banks. We simply have not seen a recovery yet that is affecting the banking industry."
For the first three months of this year, the nation's 12,246 commercial banks posted profits of about $5.7 billion, compared with $1.1 billion in the prior quarter and $6.2 billion in the first quarter of 1990. The 463 federally insured savings banks posted losses of $170 million for the first quarter, compared with a loss of $1.2 billion in the fourth quarter of last year and a loss of $257 million for the first quarter of 1990.
Assets at troubled institutions continued to grow over the first three months of this year more rapidly than the two cushions used to absorb losses -- the amount of capital banks have raised and the amount they have placed in reserve in anticipation of losses. The F.D.I.C. said that troubled loans grew by $7.2 billion at the same time that capital increased by only $4.4 billion and reserves shrank by almost $500 million.
The actual value of the bank insurance fund is in dispute. Mr. Seidman has said the fund was worth about $8.4 billion at the end of last year. But Mr. Bowsher has said the fund is "virtually insolvent" because of the likely number of bank failures.
Mr. Seidman said there was little sign that the commercial real estate markets would turn around soon, and as a result, he expected 100 more bank failures from now to the end of 1992 over his earlier estimate of about 340 banks.
 
Greenspan More Optimistic
 A slightly more optimistic outlook on the commercial real estate outlook was suggested today by Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board. Questioned at a hearing of the House Banking Committee, Mr. Greenspan said that one indication that the markets might be turning around was that regulators had been noticing "the beginnings of what we call bottom fishing" by investors purchasing commercial property.
In his testimony before the Senate Banking Committee, Mr. Bowsher suggested that Congress consider separating into two posts the functions of chairman of the F.D.I.C. and chairman of the Resolution Trust Corporation, which oversees the savings bailout. Mr. Seidman, who under the law setting up the rescue effort holds both positions, is expected to step down this fall, and Mr. Bowsher said that might be an opportune time for the change.
The committee was given a report today by the General Accounting Office that detailed a host of problems at the trust corporation, which are expected to add billions of dollars to the overall costs of the bailout. On Monday, Resolution Trust reported that it had lost $6.4 billion more than anticipated for 1990, primarily because of a higher-than-estimated loss in fees to contractors and the sharp discounts offered for sales of assets including loans, real estate and "junk bonds."
The report prompted some lawmakers to suggest that Congress completely overhaul Resolution Trust when it considers providing new funds for the agency in the next few months.
But Mr. Bowsher cautioned against making too dramatic a change, saying that after two years, the trust corporation had made some progress in setting up a system for seizing insolvent savings associations and disposing of their assets.

HEADLINE: U.S. Posts a Trade Surplus From Gulf War Payments

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 11

 BODY:
The United States had a foreign trade surplus of $10.2 billion in the first three months of this year, the first quarterly surplus in almost nine years, the Government said today.
The Commerce Department attributed the surplus in the broadest measure of foreign trade, called the current account, to $22.7 billion in cash received during the first quarter from Saudi Arabia, Japan and other countries to help pay the costs of the Persian Gulf war. 
 Because of the war contributions, economists are forecasting that the current account deficit for the whole year should narrow to about $40 billion, far below the $92.12 billion deficit last year.
 
Gains Seen for U.S. Goods
 In addition to the contributions, the imbalance in the current account is expected to be narrowed by further gains in sales of American exports.
The current account is the broadest measure of trade because it includes not only trade in merchandise but also investment flows between countries and earnings on tourism and other services.
The $10.2 billion surplus was the first positive trade flow for the United States since a $3.61 billion surplus in the second quarter of 1982.
During the 1980's, the trade deficit soared to record levels as billions of dollars were sent abroad to pay for imported cars and television sets. That money returned to the United States in the form of foreign investments, transforming the nation from the world's largest creditor nation to the largest debtor country.
 
One Gap Shrinks
 For the first three months of the year, the country had a deficit of $18.37 billion in merchandise trade, the smallest deficit in this category in nearly eight years. The improvement in merchandise trade came as the recession dampened demand for imports while sales of American exports hit an all-time high.
Offsetting the merchandise trade deficit was a $6.99 billion surplus on services, a category that includes such things as foreign tourist spending in the United States. The United States also ran a surplus o $4.65 billion on investment income, indicating that Americans earned more on their foreign holdings than foreigners earned on their American investments during the first quarter.
The category known as unilateral transfers, including the foreign payments for the gulf operations, was in surplus by $16.94 billion in the first three months of the year. The cash contributions from the allies were offset somewhat by Washington's foreign aid payments and Social Security payments to retired Americans living overseas.

HEADLINE: Washington Talk;
Democrats Attack Bush Over 100-Day Deadline

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 11

 BODY:
Short of a legislative miracle, Congress will not pass transportation and crime bills by Friday. And no one seems more gleeful at the prospect that the lawmakers will not meet President Bush's personal challenge to act on his two most pressing domestic priorities in 100 days than the President himself.
Mr. Bush has scheduled a nationwide address from the White House grounds Wednesday night to chastise Congress for inaction. In case people do not see that or do not get the message, he plans to repeat it Friday at a commencement address at the California Institute of Technology. 
 As a onetime House member, Mr. Bush knows that lawmakers do not take well to deadlines, especially when they come from the White House. It does not take a cynic to suggest that his timetable was imposed as a public relations stunt.
Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman, denied that Mr. Bush was playing politics.
"Crime and transportation are extremely important and 100 days should have been enough time to pass legislation," Mr. Fitzwater said, adding, "I don't want to get into a political fight."
Whatever the President's intentions, a political fight is exactly what erupted today on Capitol Hill. Congressional leaders testily denounced the President, while House Republicans mocked their Democratic colleagues by sporting black-and-white buttons with the legend "100 Days."
The squabbling started when Senator George J. Mitchell of Maine, the Democratic leader, sounded unusually fierce as he suggested that Mr. Bush was behind "a new low in political cynicism."
"This 100-day business, the so-called 100-day deadline, is a completely arbitrary date picked by the President for what has become clear are political reasons," Mr. Mitchell added, spitting out each word. "It was established for the sole purpose of scoring political points."
Then he proceeded to propose a deadline of his own on Mr. Bush. He chided the President for not developing an adequate health care package after 872 days in office and challenged him to propose one in the next month. "I would suggest that before the 900th day of his Presidency he should submit to Congress his plan for dealing with one of the most serious, widespread problems facing the country," Mr. Mitchell said.
At lunchtime, Speaker Thomas S. Foley weighed in, with something more like his customary control.
"It is really, with great respect, not the President's business to attempt to organize the schedule of the Congress," he asserted. "I hope it is not just a political gimmick and the beginning of a period of 1992 Presidential campaigns that are centered around Congress bashing."
The bashing only escalated in Representative Newt Gingrich's response to the Democrats: "Senator Mitchell ought to go out and talk to the 6,500 families who were murder victims in the last 100 days. He ought to talk to the 40,500 women who were raped. He ought to talk to the 330,000 victims of robbery."
"I don't think they think it is cynical for the President to try to emulate Franklin Roosevelt and set some kind of deadline," said Mr. Gingrich, the House Republican whip.
When Mr. Bush addressed a joint session of Congress on March 6 after the end of the war in the Persian Gulf, he challenged Congress to act swiftly on transportation and crime legislation. "If our forces could win the ground war in 100 hours, then surely Congress can pass this legislation in 100 days," Mr. Bush said.
Told of Mr. Mitchell's comments about the 100-day deadline, Representative F. James Sensenbrenner Jr., a Wisconsin Republican, said: "His partisan slip is showing. When Franklin Roosevelt gave Congress a 100-day deadline for all of the anti-Depresssion measures following his inauguration in 1933, nobody complained that it was a cynical partisan effort."
Times, of course, are different. And so are intentions, as James A. Thurber, director of the Center for Congressional and Presidential Studies at American University, sees it.
A number of Mr. Roosevelt's measures were enacted to help restore confidence in the economy. Passage of legislation was never Mr. Bush's prime motivation, he says.
"Congress was not created to be efficient but to be representative," Mr. Thurber said. "When you press an institution to meet a deadline, it's easy for them to miss the deadline and easy for the President to blame them. It's a pretty good strategy on his part."

HEADLINE: Wine Talk

BYLINE: By Frank J. Prial

 BODY:
AGASSAC, Angelus, Angludet, Ausone . . .
"Back in the mid-1960's, my wife and I took up Bordeaux reds." Thus began a letter from a Connecticut reader that outlined a most unusual wine odyssey. The letter went on: 
 "Early on, we began a tradition of having a red Bordeaux chateau every Saturday at noon, choosing food (even pizzas) that tended to work well with a Bordeaux red. We've been so regular in this custom that by now we've enjoyed over 600 chateaus."
Beau-Site, Belair, Beychevelle, Brane-Cantenac . . .
Six hundred Bordeaux chateaus! How many Bordeaux chateau owners could match that: their own and 599 others? How many enologists, wine makers, growers, merchants or wine writers could make that claim?
The two heroic Bordeaux fans are Robert L. and Frances McLaughlin, of Cheshire, Conn., about halfway between New Haven and Hartford. He is an economic forecaster who publishes Turning Points, a newsletter; she, a high-school English teacher.
Cabannieux, Calon-Segur, Cheval Blanc, Clerc-Milon . . .
"I was strictly a six-pack beer man in my younger days," Mr. McLaughlin said in a telephone interview. "It was after I got my M.A. at Syracuse and was married that I first got into wine. Some of our Syracuse friends were teachers, and I remember them always bringing out the sherry. One fellow surprised us with a bottle of red wine. I'll never forget it; it was from Almaden.
"Once, on a trip to New York, I walked into the Sherry-Lehmann wine store. I told the clerk I liked the idea of trying something French. He recommended Chateau Gruaud-Larose. I brought it home and we had it that Saturday and it was better than a chocolate malted. That was my first real introduction to great wine. Oh yes, the Gruaud was a 1964."
Dassault, Dauzac, Desmirail, Doisy-Daene . . .
The Gruaud-Larose should have begun a beautiful friendship but it wasn't that easy. The McLaughlins were disappointed in many wines they tried in the early days. "We were in our early 30's," he recalled, "and we were buying mostly cheap stuff. I can remember saying to my wife that de Gaulle must have been sending us all the junk. We'd never even heard of tannin."
Tannins are astringent substances that come from the skins and seeds of grapes and give structure and longevity to the best wines. When the wines are young they can taste harsh.
Eglise, Enclos, Escadre, Evangile . . .
The McLaughlins have made their Bordeaux drinking into a pleasant ritual. Saturday lunch -- outdoors in summer -- is planned around that week's chateau. While drinking the week's selection, they pore over their collection of Bordeaux books, reading about the wine and comparing it with others they recall from the same Bordeaux region or commune.
"With Feret, Johnson, Parker, Peppercorn, Penning-Rowsell and Hubrecht Duijker, you can really have fun on a Saturday, studying the one chateau you're drinking that day," Mr. McLaughlin said, referring to some of the better texts.
Their Bordeaux bible is the huge 1,867-page "Bordeaux and Its Wines," published in Bordeaux by Feret et Fils and known throughout the wine world simply as Feret. Now in its 13th edition, Feret can be traced back to the first major Bordeaux reference work, "Bordeaux, Its Wines and the Claret Country," published in 1846 in London by Charles Cox. "We pick our wines out of Feret," Mr. McLaughlin said, "then buy them at our favorite wine shop in Hamden, Bob and Ben's."
Bob and Ben's is more formally known as Mount Carmel Wines and Liquors, but not to the McLaughlins. "Bob and Ben's is a fantastic place," he said. "They have a magnificent selection." Often, when his choice from Feret is not available, Bob McLaughlin lets himself be steered to something that is, like the 1987, and later the 1988, Chateau La Lagune.
Figeac, Filhot, Fourcas-Hosten, Franc-Mayne . . .
As they forge ahead through Feret, the McLaughlins still find time to revisit old favorites. "I'd say we're on a five-year cycle with the classified growths," he said. The classified growths are the 61 wines selected by the Bordeaux brokers in 1855 for a fair in Paris and classified by them. These are among the top Bordeaux wines, starting with the five first growths, including Chateaux Latour, Margaux and Lafite-Rothschild.
The McLaughlins do enjoy other wines, but usually in restaurants. Recently they have been drinking more California wines. "For years, we were opposed to California reds," Mr. McLaughlin said. "But in recent years, we think they've improved. And we're actually drinking some of them, mostly in restaurants."
Gaffeliere, Giscours, Gloria, Greysac . . .
In spite of their unalterable loyalty to Bordeaux, the McLaughlins sense a loss of quality in recent years. "Bordeaux in the past few years has gone downhill," Mr. Mclaughlin said. "We used to enjoy so many chateaus that had full bodies, almost a syrupy thickness. We rarely find them anymore. We're also surprised by the lack of complexity. We think Bordeaux is made now for quicker drinking. It simply isn't as good as it used to be."
That does not mean for an instant that the McLaughlins plan to change their wine-drinking patterns. "We tried to stretch the thing so as to include Burgundy," he said, "but we never got too far. Bordeaux really takes you in and holds you."
The couple have visited Bordeaux several times and have even met a few chateau owners, but outside of a few tastings run by Bob and Ben, they have had little to do with the so-called wine establishment in this country.
Hanteillan, Haut-Batailley, Haut-Brion, Issan . . .
Despite their considerable experience with fine wines, the McLaughlins are not collectors. "We have a rack that holds about 300 bottles," he said, "but we live on a flood plain and a couple of times the water has come in and covered the bottom two-thirds of the rack. There we were with 200 bottles with no labels." Now their wine collection amounts to about 100 bottles, all of them, it is hoped, above the high-water mark.
Mr. McLaughlin was concerned lest revelations about his modest obsession give the wrong impression to friends and neighbors. "I have a business here and my wife teaches school," he said. "We wouldn't people to think we were, you know, alkies or something." He was assured that a couple of bottles of wine a week would shock none but the most hard-shelled teetotaler; that in fact, by almost any standard, he and his wife henceforth would rate as authentic connoisseurs.
"Oh, I don't know about that," he said, "but we do enjoy our little hobby. Which is just as well. There are more than 6,000 chateaus in the Bordeaux wine region." The McLaughlins have a long way to go.
Lafite-Rothschild, Lafon-Rochet, Lascombes, Latour, Leoville-Barton, Lynch-Bages . . .
 
TASTINGS
Pavillon Rouge de Chateau Margaux, 1987; about $15.
The Bordeaux chateaux known as premiers crus, or first growths, Latour, Margaux, Lafite-Rothschild, Mouton-Rothschild and Haut-Brion, guard their reputations jealously. They are on top and they know everyone is watching them. Consequently, they spend fortunes making sure that nothing second rate appears under their names. The 1987 vintage in Bordeaux has been written off by many because it did not match up to the rest of the extraordinary vintages from 1985 through 1989. In any other company it almost certainly would have fared better. It was a year when the early ripening merlot grapes came in in fine condition, but the later ripening cabernet sauvignon and particularly the cabernet franc suffered from harvest rains. Chateau Margaux produced a fine first wine by severe selection. But, because it is Chateau Margaux, the second wine was quite good, too. This is the wine known as Pavillon Rouge. The 1987 has good body and a surprisingly long finish. It's probably not a long-lived wine and should be drunk over the next few years. This is a chance to sample a wine from a great property at an extremely reasonable price.

HEADLINE: Seeing Beyond Burgers and Soapsuds

BYLINE: By FLORENCE FABRICANT

 BODY:
FOR some, an entry level job in a restaurant may only mean serving fast food or washing dishes. For others, it may be the beginning of a lucrative and challenging career.
But now a number of professionals in the food service industry are devising training programs for those who might otherwise have no prospects beyond the burgers and dirty dishes, enabling them to rise through the ranks in the food business. 
 Citing both a need to fill jobs in the industry and a desire to help people, they are tapping a pool of high school students, residents of youth shelters, people with emotional disabilities and nonviolent prison inmates. They hope to offer not only job training but some emotional support to ease the way.
Take Randolph Scott. A native of Malone, N.Y., near the Canadian border, Mr. Scott, a 21-year-old high school dropout, came to New York in 1987 and worked as a fast-food cook. He drifted into drugs and became homeless, entered Covenant House and took part in the shelter's cooking program. Fourteen months ago, Dan Kobin, the chef and owner of Restaurant Dano in Greenwich Village, hired him to be his assistant.
Mr. Kobin said he wanted someone "who I felt had potential but who, like myself, did not have culinary school training." At the suggestion of his father, Howard, a supporter of Covenant House, Mr. Kobin asked the group if it could suggest anyone. Mr. Scott was the choice, and he is now Mr. Kobin's right-hand man.
As a result of Mr. Scott's success, Mr. Kobin started a program last spring at the Covenant House residence on West 17th Street to teach some of the residents to bake. Mr. Kobin has started serving their breads in his restaurant.
A Covenant House resident in the baking program who did not want his name to be used said he was planning to go into the food business, "to start slow, move up and some day have my own restaurant."
Dan Gescheidle, president of the Educational Foundation of the National Restaurant Association in Chicago, said, "I don't think the industry has done enough to tap some pockets of the population." He said young people and parents sometimes had to be convinced that these are not just subservient jobs.
"This is an industry with an extremely high turnover," he said. "We have to fill 400,000 new managerial positions a year nationwide." Mr. Gescheidle said his group has been working with 20 of the 60 high schools in Chicago to build interest in careers in food service.
Despite the recession and a tightening of the job market in the restaurant industry, especially in New York, there is still plenty of opportunity.
Dorothy Cann, owner of the French Culinary Institute in Manhattan, which supports a training program in the New York City high schools, said that what restaurants are looking for are people with enough training to step right in and become line cooks and assistant restaurant managers.
Since members of the food service industry, including restaurant owners and chefs, have helped organize the programs and are willing to capitalize on their contacts, those who complete the various courses now have excellent prospects of being hired or continuing their training in fine professional schools.
"Until some of these programs got started," said Alma Pickett, supervisor of home economics for the New York City Board of Education, "we did not have access to the industry and we don't have enough staff to set up the liaison you need, so we couldn't be of much help in the real world.
"Some of the individuals who have become involved with us recently have helped bridge the gap. It's about time they tapped the pool of black and Hispanic high school kids in the city instead of always hiring groups from other places."
In San Francisco, physically and emotionally disabled adults at a residence called Conard House have opened an espresso bar as a training program for food service.
"We hope they will be able to go out and get jobs," said Leslie Gravino, the director of vocational services. "But until we get some kind of hook-up with the food service industry, they may not be able to do that."
They may need someone like Marilyn Sachs, a placement and recruiting specialist for the restaurant industry in New York. Ms. Sachs has helped place people from drug rehabilitation programs at Phoenix House in Manhattan and Phoenix Academy in Yorktown Heights, N.Y., who have been given lessons in basic dining room service and cooking by Stuart Levin, the former owner of Top of the Park and Le Pavillon in Manhattan.
Mr. Levin set up the program four years ago when multiple sclerosis forced him to retire from the restaurant business. He now devotes himself to this program.
Most students, he said, "have no notion of the numbers of different jobs in this industry for which they could become qualified, not just in the kitchen and dining room but in purchasing, maintenance and management."
Ms. Sachs has also organized a summer internship program in restaurants for New York City high school students. She said restaurants employing apprentice students, among them Ferrier, Harvey's Chelsea House and Vince and Eddie's, train them in various aspects of the operation and not merely use them as extra help.
Kerron Pringle, 16, is a ninth grader at Erasmus Hall High School in Brooklyn and works part time at Gage & Tollner under the tutelage of Edna Lewis, the chef. She started waiting on tables on weekends about a year ago and now helps with the cooking and baking.
"My other friends are working at places like hospitals, but I have learned so much more working with Edna Lewis," she said.
A number of public high schools in New York, among them Erasmus Hall and Prospect Heights in Brooklyn, have fairly sophisticated vocational cooking programs. But these are often in need of more advanced instruction and better equipment. That's where Richard Grausman stepped in last year.
He devised a program, approved by the Board of Education, to broaden the culinary horizons of the students. Within a few months it became a pilot program for vocational traininginvolving about 700 students throughout the city.
Last week several scholarships were awarded to students who distinguished themselves in the program, including one worth more than $12,000 to the French Culinary Institute.
School systems in other states are considering using Mr. Grausman's program. In Waukesha County, Wisc., outside Milwaukee, several schools have started using his program on a trial basis.
Compared with training the eager students in Mr. Grausman's program, the professionals who have become involved with Fresh Start face a monumental challenge. They teach a program in food service training for inmates at Rikers Island who are serving sentences of less than one year for nonviolent crimes.
The program was started in 1989 by Barbara Margolies, the former commissioner of protocol in the Koch Administration.
A number of restaurateurs and chefs and others in the food industry, including Joyce Steins, owner of Cafe Iguana and Le Bar Bat, and Lawrence Forgione, chef and owner of An American Place, have conducted classes for inmates in the 12-week sessions.
Classes are held in the kitchens of one of the buildings at the men's House of Detention and as part of the curriculum, the men must complete a one-week food handlers' course.
"They're all sad and sorry cases we want to give some hope to," said Xenia Krinitsky, a legal assistant at Proskauer Rose Goetz & Mendelsohn, who helps coordinate the program. It has been completed by 54 prisoners, 50 of whom are out of jail, some for nearly a year.
"Normally I would have expected to see all of them back by now," said James B. Kane, the warden. He would like the program to triple in size and accomodate 60 prisoners at a time. "What makes this program so good is the follow-through, the extension from the inside to the outside," he said.
Weekly group support sessions are held among the graduates with some of their mentors from the industry attending to give advice.
"We don't encourage them to get a job immediately," Ms. Krinitsky said. "They need to get their lives together and to receive counseling. A lot of these men have never really held a job before."
About a dozen of them are currently employed and one, Benjamin Marcanos, who started as a busboy at Cafe Iguana, is now rising through the ranks: he is the head busboy and is helping to organize the staff for Le Bar Bat.
Another former prisoner, Rayon Henry, expects to be working part-time with Mr. Marcanos at Le Bar Bat. "Fresh Start gave me the experience to get a job like this, so I can work while I go to school," he said.
Charles Huston, another graduate of Fresh Start who is working in a senior center to prepare meals for the home-bound elderly, said that with what he has learned he can go beyond preparing food in a hospital kitchen and get a job in a restaurant.
These programs offer not only practical training but the kind of self-esteem that is necessary to sustain a vocation. "With food you see a finished product that you can be proud of and that impresses people," said Robert McGrath, a Covenant House spokesman.
But none of the programs will succeed in the long term, those who have organized them say, without the willingness of the food service industry to hire people who have been trained.
"The business community needs to take the next step," Mr. Kobin said. "The industry that is devoted to feeding people has a rich vein of charitable impulse to tap and it's time to give back to people who haven't had the opportunities."

HEADLINE: Food Notes

BYLINE: By Florence Fabricant

 BODY:
Guinness for Bloomsday
Sunday is Father's Day. It's also Bloomsday. June 16, 1904, was the day in the lives of Leopold and Molly Bloom, Dubliners, that was recounted by James Joyce in "Ulysses." Nowadays the date is usually celebrated with marathon readings of Joyce's works; sometimes that monumental novel is read in its entirety. The Guinness flows like water. 
 This year, for the 10th celebration of "Bloomsday on Broadway" at Symphony Space, Broadway at 95th Street, the activities include a re-creation of Barney Kiernan's Pub, which figured in the novel, at the back of the theater. It will sell Guinness, wine, soda bread, scones and other appropriate fare starting at 5:30 P.M.
The pub will remain open throughout the readings and music, which will run from 6 P.M. to midnight. Those in need of refreshment will not miss any of the program by performers like Geraldine Fitzgerald, Malachy McCourt, Phyllis Newman and John Rubinstein; it will be piped into the pub. Alison Armstrong, who wrote "The Joyce of Cooking" (Station Hill, 1985), a cookbook based on Joyce's works, is helping organize the pub.
Tickets are $8. Members of Symphony Space, students and people 65 and over pay $7. Tickets are available at the box office or by calling (212) 864-5400.
 
More CAFE in Providence
Johnson and Wales College in Providence, R.I., which has 2- and 4-year degree programs in the culinary arts and food management, has announced a $3 million expansion of its culinary arts division. The Culinary Arts and Food Exposition, or CAFE, with 21,000 square feet, will combine kitchens, dining rooms, an amphitheater and exhibition areas. The expansion is to be finished in September 1992.
 
Goat Cheese Ravioli
Fairway Market , 2127 Broadway (74th Street), is selling ravioli stuffed with tangy goat cheese and sun-dried tomatoes. It is made for the store by Riviera Pasta in the Bronx. The price is $6.99 a pound (about 25 pieces).
 
Cordon Bleu Connection
For information about cooking courses at Le Cordon Bleu in Paris, there is now a toll-free number, (800) 457-2433.
 
Kentucky Cooking in '39
"The Kentucky Housewife" by Lettice Bryan was published in 1839. A hefty tome of some 1,300 recipes, it was squarely in the tradition of Southern cookbooks started by Mary Randolph with "The Virginia Housewife" in 1824. "The Kentucky Housewife" is now available in an excellent facsimile edition from the University of South Carolina Press ($19.95).
In his appreciative introduction, Bill Neal, a cookbook author, remarks that Mrs. Bryan's contribution to the literature of Southern cooking is her thoroughness. Not only are there more recipes than in other books of the period, but the ingredients, techniques and results are also described more completely than was typical at the time. As Mr. Neal indicates, this precision makes the recipes relatively easy to use today without explanations and annotations.
The description of heating fat for frying perch is right on the mark. "Put some lard into a frying pan, set it on the fire, and when it boils up, and then becomes still, put in your fish." Modern cooks may be astonished to find recipes for pineapple ice cream and for rape, and also at the frequency with which Mrs. Bryan suggests tomato ketchup as a seasoning.
 
Recession Cookout
Instead of studying the job market or housing construction or sales of appliances, economists can simply look at the backyard grill to see if we're in a recession. When times are tough, hot dog sales increase.
That's what the people at National Foods , who make Hebrew National Hot Dogs, are saying. In the first quarter of this year sales rose by 17 percent. Sharp growth in sales was also recorded in 1974 and 1982, two other recession periods.
 
RED-HOT AND BLUES
PICTURE a cook strumming a guitar and singing the blues between riffs at the stove and you have some idea of what a 24-minute cooking-and-blues video called "Sauce Boss" is all about.
Bill Wharton, a musician from Monticello, Fla., cooks gumbo and smoked mullet dip, plays with his combo, the Ingredients, and pitches his product, Liquid Summer Hot Sauce. It's an amusing, engaging mixture. The music segments have a late-night, low-key, smoke-filled-club feel and the cooking is decidedly informal. The commercials for the sauce that appear periodically on the videotape are strictly hard sell.
The video is $20 from Bill Wharton, Route 3, Box 124 L, Monticello, Fla. 32344. An audio cassette with just music is $10. Two eight-ounce bottles of the peppery, vinegary sauce are $7. There is a $4 shipping charge; telephone, (904) 997-4359. The sauce is also sold at Canard & Company, 1292 Madison Avenue (91st Street), for $3.99.

HEADLINE: The President's Petulance

 BODY:
On March 6, President Bush appeared before Congress to celebrate victory in the Persian Gulf and to challenge the assembled legislators to convert triumph abroad into progress at home. Mr. Bush trotted out a crime bill and a transportation bill and said, "If our forces could win the ground war in 100 hours, then surely Congress can pass this legislation in 100 days."
Short of a miracle, Congress will not make the 100-day deadline on Friday. Mr. Bush knows this. He thus plans a series of speeches, starting tonight, chiding Congress for sloth. 
That seems more than slightly inappropriate. First, the President's legislation is so shallow that Congress can hardly be blamed for taking time to improve it. His crime package, for example, is largely a sop to death penalty advocates and would do nothing about the gun-running now terrorizing cities. The Senate will soon vote on an imperfect Democratic measure that would at least try to stop that traffic.
Likewise, Mr. Bush's transportation plan would build new highways but shortchange mass transit -- exactly the wrong priorities for a country that would be better served by incentives to curb pollution and gasoline consumption. The Senate is now debating a more balanced substitute.
But there's an even stronger reason to ignore the President's petulance: He, more than anyone, has squandered this postwar opportunity to address urgent domestic needs. True, he's been ill. True, he's been preoccupied with the Middle East and Mikhail Gorbachev's problems. True, there's not a lot of money available. But that's all the more reason to ask for a sharper sense of priorities from the White House.
The big problems are not hard to identify: a medical care system spinning out of control, states and cities burdened by social costs and drowning in debt, deteriorating schools that surely require more urgent attention than Mr. Bush proposes to give them in his plan for the year 2000. That's a program for 100 months, not 100 days.
Mr. Bush's instinct is to deal with the politics of these problems, not the substance, and to worry issues for partisan gain. The most telling example is his harping on the "quota" issue, even though the civil rights bill passed with Democratic sponsorship in the House would specifically prohibit quotas. His relentless complaints suggest that he is less interested in achieving a sound bill than in demonstrating how stubbornly he opposes remedial action for minorities.
Mr. Bush obviously feels no pressure to behave differently. The polls remain favorable. His 75 percent approval rating in the last New York Times/ CBS News Poll is down 13 points from March and 6 from May, but it's still very high. Further, despite disenchantment with Mr. Bush's handling of the economy -- only 41 percent approve his performance -- and deep concern about medical costs, few issues seem to have a strong cutting edge.
Even so, as the postwar euphoria dwindles a window is closing, a chance to wrench America's attention homeward is passing. Mr. Bush can still keep that window open. But that will require more than carping, more than partisanship, more than stagey deadlines for empty initiatives.
