HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
Memo For Mr. Bush

BYLINE: By LESLIE H. GELB

 BODY:
Many who support you and wish you well are trying to tell you something that goes to the heart of your speech this evening on domestic affairs. Here is their message:
 1. Our nation is falling apart, even if we pull out of the current recession and even if the Dow Jones average continues to hover around 3,000. 
 2. Only you can lead and bring us together, first by reordering your priorities and paying more attention to America than the world.
 3. If you fail to restore America's internal strength, our power to protect our interests abroad will wane as well.
 What alarms and disheartens is that none of this seems to touch you. When you traveled recently to promote your education programs, a youngster asked what you liked best about being President. "I love coping with the problems in foreign affairs," you responded, and then added a few words about education and drugs.
 Listen to what Jack Kemp, your Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, is saying: "There are problems of poverty and despair and economic decline in many people's neighborhoods which the President has both a moral and political obligation to address." His point by inference is that you are not doing so.
 Listen to Kevin Phillips, a conservative Republican who helped shape the G.O.P.'s winning Presidential strategy for the last 20 years. His data show that the richest 2.5 million Americans earn as much as the bottom 100 million, and that consequently the American Dream is fading.
 Listen to Ross Perot, a hard-headed industrialist. Domestic problems, he says, are "controversial. They're difficult to resolve. It's kind of like cleaning out the kitchen or taking out the trash or cleaning out the barn." Seeing the decay and decline all around him, he asks you to put your "primary focus on cleaning up our problems here at home. . . ."
 Listen to William Hyland, editor of Foreign Affairs and a former senior national security adviser to Presidents Ford and Nixon. "The U.S. has never been less threatened by foreign forces than it is today. . . . Taking on new commitments in the Middle East and Persian Gulf while maintaining most of the old ones in Europe and the Far East cannot be justified in the face of a disastrous domestic agenda."
 Listen to Robert Hormats, now at Goldman Sachs, who served Ronald Reagan as a top foreign economic adviser. The Persian Gulf war, he writes, was "the first U.S. military operation in this century that America felt unable to pay for by itself." He concludes that "If America's economy does falter, so will the underlying source of its international power. Thus this nation's central foreign policy priority in coming years and its central domestic priority must be the same: strengthening the American economy."
 Listen to Bill Moyers, who probably knows as much about what is going on in this country as anyone: "Beneath the euphoria of the moment much of our society is in shambles." Between 30 and 40 million Americans live in poverty, more than the populations of eastern Germany and Hungary combined. More Americans are without health insurance than all the people in Central America. Half the children in urban primary schools will drop out before graduation.
 Listen to the Time/CNN public opinion survey published this week. Only 39 percent approve of your handling of the economy, and 71 percent say you are spending too little time on domestic affairs.
 In your only recent foray into general domestic concerns, you condemned President Johnson's Great Society programs as ineffective. Yet as this week's editorial in The New Republic (which likes you more than it does most Democrats) points out, these programs included Medicare and Head Start, and your "domestic policy rhetoric has no substance."
 Your friends and allies and the American people are not demanding that America withdraw from the world. They want our country to play an active, powerful and constructive international role.
 They are not saying they have the answers to the domestic ills, or that new efforts will escape mistakes and waste. Rather they ask that you consider these thoughts: We cannot sustain our power abroad unless we are strong again at home, and we cannot be true to our heritage unless you mobilize the nation to beat back the internal rot.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Eritreans Want Independence From Ethiopia;
Now Tyranny Reigns

 BODY:
To the Editor:
As an Ethiopian and a scholar of Ethiopia of many years, I am appalled by the outcome of the so-called London talks, supposedly mediated by the United States and Herman J. Cohen, Assistant Secretary for African Affairs. The United States actually failed to mediate between the Ethiopian Government and the rebel groups. The only mediation was a ceasefire agreement reached by all parties May 27. Subsequent talks were held between Mr. Cohen and the rebels. The Ethiopian Government was not represented. 
 Ethiopia's Prime Minister Tesfaye Dinka boycotted the talks to oppose Mr. Cohen's approval for the rebels to enter Addis Ababa despite the ceasefire agreement. Mr. Cohen's justification was that "law and order" was breaking down in Addis Ababa, and he had to invite the rebels to enter Addis Ababa despite the calm and discipline shown, according to most eyewitness accounts, by the citizens. Mr. Cohen's decision did not lead to law and order, but to the spilling of blood of Ethiopians in the streets of the city. This still continues in Addis Ababa and elsewhere despite the media coverup.
On May 28, Mr. Cohen delivered Ethiopia to the rebels as he announced the decisions he reached with the rebels. Peace and democracy cannot be created in Ethiopia by shoving United States-backed rebel decisions down Ethiopian throats.
How can ethnic nationalists, who have no interests in the Ethiopian nation-state, create peace and democracy for all Ethiopians? The anti-Ethiopian stance of the rebels is no secret. For instance, one of the rebel decisions is the dismantling of Ethiopia by allowing Eritrea to secede through Eritrean referendum, rather than a nationwide referendum. Mr. Cohen endorsed this decision, ignoring the 1952 United Nations resolution that federated Eritrea with Ethiopia and reversed the longstanding United States policy on the inviolability of Ethiopia's territorial integrity.
When state power is taken by force, tyranny reigns. Sooner or later, other ethnic groups will also raise arms to overthrow their newly installed ethnic overlords. Mr. Cohen opened a can of worms in Ethiopia that also has implications for the rest of Africa.
 
DANIEL TEFERRA
Big Rapids, Mich., May 29, 1991
 
The writer is an associate professor of economics at Ferris State U.

HEADLINE: Return Tompkins Sq. Park to Those Who Live in Neighborhood;
History of Unrest

 BODY:
To the Editor:
As I found in research for my book "The New Bohemia," published in 1966, Tompkins Square Park was from the first a scene of civil unrest.
Three hundred years ago, the East Village was Peter Stuyvesant's bouwerie, or farm. According to one source, his original home stood on what is now the south side of East 10th Street, 200 feet west of Second Avenue. Tompkins Square Park was part of a salt marsh, originally known as Stuyvesant Swamp, which extended to the East River. 
 In 1812, under the leadership of Daniel Tompkins, the area was transformed into a defense post against the British. This extraordinary man financed the fortification mainly because the Government's credit was not sound enough to cover an issue of bonds for it. The British overlooked Stuyvesant Swamp in the War of 1812, and the Scarsdale-born Tompkins went on to become an extremely progressive Governor of New York. He tried, among other things, to have slavery abolished in the state and ultimately became Vice President under James Monroe. His last years were fraught with political, financial and emotional setbacks. He died an alcoholic in 1825, and lies buried at Saint Mark's Church in the Bouwerie.
In 1833, the Stuyvesant family gave 10 1/2 acres, now known as Tompkins Square, to New York City on condition that it be maintained as a public park. This condition was only sporadically observed. At one time it became a military parade ground; during the Civil War, it was converted into a recruiting camp. It was also the scene of mass meetings, draft riots, hunger and unemployment strikes. It was again a place of riot in the panic of 1873.
 
JOHN GRUEN
New York, June 4, 1991

HEADLINE: Immigration Brings New Diversity To Asian Population in the U.S.

BYLINE: By FELICITY BARRINGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 11

 BODY:
Unusually large waves of immigrants from Southeast Asia and South Asia in the 1980's transformed the Asian community in the United States, setting off an explosion of diversity among Asian-Americans, the nation's fastest-growing minority, figures made public today by the Census Bureau show.
The political upheavals and economic hardships that beset Asian nations from Sri Lanka and the Philippines to China and South Korea have sent more than two million immigrants across the Pacific Ocean in the past decade, according to Federal immigration figures. 
 As a result, the fastest-growing subgroups under the Asian-American umbrella were Vietnamese (134.8 percent growth in the past decade), Indians (125.6 percent) and Koreans (125.3 percent).
 
'Different From Earlier Ones'
 "These immigrants are different from earlier ones because of their enormous diversity," said Lawrence H. Fuchs, a professor of American Civilization and Politics at Brandeis University. "We had Japanese, Chinese and Filipinos. The variety now is just enormous. You have variety within variety -- more variety of class, more variety of skill, more variety in origins."
In 1965, Asian-Americans numbered barely one million; a quarter of a century later, the census counted 7.3 million Americans of Asian and Pacific Islander background. Immigration represented about 54 percent of the increase; the remainder represented children born to Asian parents here.
While Chinese-Americans are still the dominant Asian group in this country, they, too, have seen profound changes in the past 25 years.
Since 1965, said Ronald Takaki, a professor of Ethnic Studies at the University of California at Berkeley, the number of Chinese immigrants has equaled or surpassed the number who came here in the first 80 years of Chinese immigration.
He said that more than 60 percent of the 1.6 million Chinese-Americans here had been born overseas and that the figure had climbed to more than 80 percent in an area like New York City's Chinatown. The population of Monterey Park, a Los Angeles suburb, is more than half Chinese, mostly immigrants from Hong Kong and Taiwan.
 
Breakdown by Ethnicity
 Nearly 23 percent of Asian-Americans are of Chinese heritage, and about 19 percent, or 1.4 million people, trace their roots to the Philippines. Japanese-Americans, who 30 years ago represented 52 percent of the Asian-American population, now represent 11.7 percent, just ahead of East Indians, at 11.2 percent, and Koreans, at 10.9 percent.
These figures from the 1990 census represented the most detailed breakdown to date for the nation's Asian minority. The figures also included breakdowns for some Hispanic subgroups, including Mexicans, Puerto Ricans and Cubans. These figures show that Mexicans remain the dominant group among Hispanic residents. The 13.4 million Americans of Mexican heritage make up 60 percent of the 22.3 million Hispanic people counted in the 1990 census, roughly the same proportion as in 1980.
The 53 percent increase in the Hispanic population in the 1980's largely reflected a rise in groups that had already established themselves in this country. But among Asians, many of the new immigrants had little cultural connection to the earlier Asian immigrants.
 
More Cultures Represented
 Some parts of the country have been settled by ethnic groups whose very names are unfamiliar, like the Hmong, the agricultural people from the mountains of Laos who have moved by the thousands into communities like Eau Claire, Wis., and Fresno, Calif.
Almost 40 percent of all Asian-Americans, or 2.4 million people, live in California, while New York and Hawaii each have slightly more than 9 percent.
Dr. Fuchs and Dr. Takaki said Asian-Americans had become a more economically stratified group, with a highly visible and successful layer of professionals -- doctors, engineers and scientists -- a strong commercial middle-class that includes grocers, nurses and government workers, and a less-visible group of immigrants, many still on welfare.
Dr. Takaki said he had found welfare rates as high as 80 percent among some Hmong communities. The Hmong, whom the Central Intelligence Agency recruited from their rural homes to help fight the North Vietnamese in the 1960's, "are in many cases illiterate in their own language," and are ill-equipped to find a place in the American economy, Dr. Takaki said.
Filipinos, while no longer one of the most rapidly growing Asian minority groups, still increased their numbers by 81.6 percent , or more than 600,000 people, in the 1980's, according to the 1990 census. But, like a smaller and faster-growing minority, the East Indians, Filipinos tend to have less difficulty adapting to a new culture, in part because most arrive speaking English.
"The Indians are a more integrated group," Dr. Takaki said. "They are betwixt and between -- Asians, but English-speaking. They come here with a certain degree of Westernization and language proficiency."
As a result, he said, they are less likely to congregate in easily identifiable ethnic enclaves.
"This is true for Filipinos too," he said. "Filipinos also represent a critical mass, but you don't often find the establishment of 'Manila-towns.' Filipinos and Asian Indians tend to be much more in the mainstream economy than other immigrants."
But the large existing population of Filipinos and the long backlogs that keep would-be-immigrants waiting for five or even 10 years have slowed that community's growth rate to 81 percent, well below the 107.8 percent that Asian-Americans as a whole have experienced in the past decade.
"You can't get the percentage growth for Filipinos any more," said Dr. Fuchs. "In the case of Indians and Koreans, you have a large percentage of people who are fairly well-educated and have a perception of the opportunity here, a vision of the future. They have friends, connections and relatives already here. The base isn't as large as the Filipinos', so they're in a growth spurt. Once their population base is larger, their growth rate will fall back like the Filipinos' did."
Dr. Fuchs and Dr. Takaki predicted that the 1990's would see an Asian immigration as large as that of the 1980's, thanks, in part, to revised Federal immigration legislation enacted last year.
Other figures from the census released today show the Japanese-American population -- most of them second- third- and fourth-generation Americans -- stands at 847,000. The Korean-American population has risen to nearly 800,000 and the East Indian population stands at 815,000. The Vietnamese population in the United States is about 615,000. Laotians number 149,000, Cambodians 147,411, Thais 91,000, Hmong 90,000 and Pakistanis 81,000.

CORRECTION-DATE: June 22, 1991, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article on June 12 about the diversity of the Asian-American population misidentified one group. Figures from the 1990 census show that 11.2 percent of Asian-Americans are of Indian descent, not "East Indian."

HEADLINE: Lindsay to Leave Post At Lincoln Center After 37 Productions

BYLINE: By MERVYN ROTHSTEIN

 BODY:
John V. Lindsay, who played a major role in bringing Lincoln Center Theater back from the dead, is to retire in November as chairman of the nonprofit theater company. Linda LeRoy Janklow, a vice chairman, is to replace him.
Mr. Lindsay, Mayor of New York City from 1966-73, took over as chairman of the theater in 1984. He is to retire on Nov. 24, his 70th birthday. 
 When Mr. Lindsay assumed the job, Lincoln Center Theater had not presented a play since the 1980-81 season. In 1985, Gregory Mosher was named the theater's director and Bernard Gersten its executive producer. Since then, Lincoln Center Theater has produced 37 shows that have played more than 3,000 performances for an audience of more than 3 million people.
 
Adding to the Theater Economy
 Its productions include the current hit play "Six Degrees of Separation," by John Guare; David Mamet's "Speed-the-Plow," with Ron Silver, Joe Mantegna and Madonna; the South African musical "Sarafina!"; the musical revival of "Anything Goes," with Patti LuPone, and the revivals of "The House of Blue Leaves," with John Mahoney, Swoosie Kurtz and Stockard Channing, "Our Town" with Spalding Gray, and "Waiting for Godot" with Robin Williams, Steve Martin and F. Murray Abraham.
"I'm tremendously proud of the achievements of our theater over the last six years," Mr. Lindsay said in a statement. "We've earned $95 million at the box office and the board has raised $30 million in grants and contributions. And we've taken that $125 million and paid the salaries of hundreds of actors, playwrights, directors, musicians, stagehands and the artisans, technicians and everybody who makes the theater a key industry in this city. Adding $125 million to the theater economy over six years is one hell of an accomplishment."
Ms. Janklow has been a director of Lincoln Center Theater since 1978. She was acting chairman in 1984 when she invited Mr. Lindsay to take over. She is also chairman of Arts Connection, an arts-in-education organization, and is a founding trustee of the American Museum of the Moving Image.
Ms. Janklow said that following Mr. Lindsay would be "a great challenge" and added that "the most important thing is to have a smooth transition and to keep the excitement that has been built over these last few years."
In January, Andre Bishop, the current artistic director of Playwrights Horizons, is to replace Mr. Mosher, who will become Lincoln Center Theater's resident director. Mr. Lindsay has been appointed chairman emeritus.

HEADLINE: Havel, in Rebuff to Paris, Backs U.S.-Europe Ties

BYLINE: By HENRY KAMM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PRAGUE, June 12

 BODY:
President Vaclav Havel today strongly affirmed Europe's ties with North America, which he said should be maintained regardless of political changes across the Continent after Communism's collapse.
Calling the American-European linkage "inevitable, logical and legitimate," Mr. Havel made the issue a main theme of his opening address at a meeting sponsored by Czechoslovakia and France here on a future "European confederation." 
 Czechoslovak officials and journalists interpreted the President's insistence on a continued close relationship between the United States and Europe as a polite rebuff to President Francois Mitterrand. At a meeting in Paris in April, the two Presidents were reported to have disagreed on the issue.
Mr. Mitterrand put forward a largely undefined vision of confederation in a speech on Dec. 31, 1989, just after the overthrow of Communist rule in Eastern Europe. He was said to have envisioned today's meeting as a formal conference limited to Europeans, presided over by the two Presidents.
Mr. Havel, however, backed by his Foreign Minister, Jiri Dienstbier, and other foreign-policy advisers, has made clear that he believes strongly in placing any all-European grouping within the framework of the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe, which includes the United States and Canada as full members.
The Czechoslovak leader also told Mr. Mitterrand that while Prague was not seeking membership in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization or participation in its military activities, it was eager to be involved in its political, industrial and ecological actions. On that issue, too, Mr. Mitterrand was said to have been unenthusiastic, preferring an orientation of the newly democratic countries toward European rather than Atlantic groupings.
The meeting between the two Presidents reportedly was further strained by France's refusal to go as far as Mr. Havel would have liked in endorsing future Czechoslovak membership in the European Community and an earlier association agreement to ease access for Czechoslovak exports.
Czechoslovak officials are said to have come away with a feeling that France was offering Mr. Mitterrand's "confederation" to Prague as a temporizing substitute for a more rapid and profitable European association.
As a result, Prague agreed only to a meeting that Mr. Havel would open today and Mr. Mitterrand would close on Friday; the Presidents will neither chair sessions nor take part in deliberations. At Czechoslovakia's insistence, American, Canadian and Japanese academics, journalists and economic experts were included in the more than 150 invitations that were sent.
Apparently responding to Mr. Mitterrand's reticence over America's share in Europe's future, Mr. Havel made explicit his conviction that links across the Atlantic be close and permanent.
"It seems to me that the link uniting Europe and the North American continent in security matters is and will remain inevitable, logical and legitimate on the historic and geopolitical level," Mr. Havel said.
"Even if it proves, with time, that it is possible to loosen it, even if the alliance transforms itself into a looser treaty, even if one day there is no reason for a last American soldier to remain in Europe, this will change nothing in the spiritual, cultural, political and economic closeness between Europe and the United States and Canada and their civilizations," he said. "It will change nothing in the vital need of the two partners to maintain a fruitful connection.
"I believe that any move leading toward the European confederation must not be conceived or understood as an attempt to separate two continents whose civilizations are closely interlinked or to drive a wedge between them."
Mr. Havel also stressed that NATO should continue to be "the principal pillar of European security" and raised the possibility that it might some day transform itself "into a pan-European structure, growing out of the soil of the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe." This, again, would include the United States.

HEADLINE: CONSUMER RATES;
Money-Market Fund Yields Down Moderately in Week

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Yields of money market funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report were down moderately for the week ended yesterday.
IBC/Donoghue's analysts said the short end of the fixed-rate market continued to trend down, affecting money-market fund yields. 
 In the weeks ahead, rates should be unchanged with a slight bias toward going up, the analysts said.
 
Tax-Exempt Funds
 With the Fed doing nothing, said Walter S. Frank, IBC/Donoghue's chief economist, there is some upward pressure on short-term interest rates, but all the action continues in the long maturities. "Because the bond market is in disarray it is exerting upward pressure on interest rates in general," he said.
Tax-exempt money fund yields declined for the week. The average number of days to maturity of securities held in portfolios slipped one day, to 43.
 Analysts said total assets of tax-exempt funds fell by $1.4 billion for the week ended yesterday, to $90.2 billion.
For the seven-day period ended yesterday the average tax-exempt compounded and simple yield each fell 18 basis points, to 3.79 percent and 3.72 percent, respectively.
The average 30-day compounded yield and 30-day simple yield each fell 10 basis points, to 4.01 percent and 3.93 percent, respectively.
For investors in the 28 percent tax bracket the taxable equivalent of the current seven-day compounded yield is 5.26 percent, while the equivalent in the 31 percent tax bracket is 5.49 percent.
For the fifth consecutive week the best-performing exempt fund with assets of better than $100 million, monitored by IBC/Donoghue's, is the Strong Municipal Money Market Fund, distributed by Strong/Cornelison Capital Management Inc. of Milwaukee. The return was 5.15 percent.
The Dreyfus Worldwide Dollar Money Market Fund announced yesterday that it planned to phase in a management fee beginning in July.
Assets of taxable funds fell by $1 billion, for a total $453 billion, with the assets of institutional funds down $1.9 billion, to $112.5 billion. Analysts speculate that institutions may be going directly into securities sold in open-market operations, like Treasury bills and commercial paper. Assets of consumer money funds grew by $900 million, to a total of $340.6 billion.
The average seven-day compounded taxable yield was down 3 basis points, to 5.63 percent, while the 7-day simple yield fell a similar amount, to 5.48 percent. The 30-day compounded yield fell 3 basis points, to 5.68 percent, and the 7-day simple fell a similar amount, to 5.56 percent.
The taxable fund with the best return on investment was Olde Premium Money Market Series, with a yield of 6.71 percent, up from its best- performing 6.52 percent last week. The fund's distributor is the Olde Discount Corporation of Detroit.
By comparison, bank money market accounts, which compete with the money funds, were down 2 basis points, to 5.30 percent, according to The Bank Rate Monitor's national index.

HEADLINE: PRETORIA GAINING TRADING PARTNERS

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HARARE, Zimbabwe

 BODY:
On most mornings, Nico Nel, the director of the South African Trade Mission here, can look out of his downtown fifth-floor office and see hundreds of Zimbabweans lining the sidewalk.
Last year 240,000 Zimbabweans came for short-term visas that entitled them to cross the border, buy South African-made goods and hurry back to earn a profit on consumer products that are scarce in this struggling economy. 
 Despite the harsh talk by the Zimbabwean President, Robert G. Mugabe, about the need for the United States and others to maintain economic sanctions against South Africa, Zimbabwe has always, as a matter of survival, traded with its southern neighbor. That trade has gathered momentum in the last year -- a 25 percent increase, with the entrepreneurs on his doorstep forming a small part of the $200 million relationship.
"Trade has gone from good to better and shows signs of improving further," Mr. Nel said.
 
Trade Ties Growing
 Zimbabwe is only the most visible in a growing list of South Africa's trading partners in black-ruled Africa. As President F. W. de Klerk has moved to scrap major parts of the apartheid system, poor countries to the north and east of South Africa have found it more acceptable to think about doing business with Pretoria.
Nigeria, with the largest economy in black-ruled Africa, gave indications recently about normalizing relations. The intention is clearly for Nigeria, which produces the petroleum South Africa lacks, to get a foothold in the South African market and to allow Nigerians access to South African goods.
Other African countries see South Africa as a possible answer to their deteriorating economies as foreign aid is diminishing from both the West and the Soviet Union. Mr. Nel said South Africa's attitude, at least under the current setup in Pretoria, would be in contrast to that of the traditional Western donors: "Trade not aid," he said.
 
Investment Sought
 Mozambique, which was once aligned with the Soviet bloc, is now actively seeking, and receiving, South African investment in minerals, timber and tourism. Madagascar, which until last year had a closed Government-dominated economy trading mostly with Eastern Europe, recently signed a trade and airline agreement with Pretoria, allowing goods to arrive directly.
In Kenya, the glimmer of a South African presence has arrived in the last several months with a once-weekly flight by South African Airways. In a new policy, previously banned South African tourists can now pick up Kenyan visas at the Nairobi airport.
But the Government of President Daniel arap Moi, apparently feeling pressure from the deputy leader of the African National Congress, Nelson Mandela, has discouraged Kenyan trading authorities from doing business in South Africa. The Government has refused permission for Kenyan Airways to fly to Johannesburg, a route that would help the ailing airline.
 
Nearest Neighbors
 Financial experts predict the heart of the economic relationship between South Africa and the rest of the continent will lie with what have been known as the front-line states. Until Mr. de Klerk took office in 1989, South Africa seemed intent on subduing these countries -- Zambia, Zimbabwe, Botswana, Angola, Mozambique and Tanzania -- with military assault rather than encouraging them as trading partners.
In a telling sign, the phrase front-line states is disappearing from the lexicon here and being replaced with Southern Africa, which incorporates South Africa and Angola, Botswana, Lesotho, Malawi, Mozambique, Namibia, Tanzania, Swaziland, Zambia and Zimbabwe. This is the most economically productive region in Africa south of the Sahara, with a wealth of natuaral resources ranging from Angola's oil to Botswana's diamonds to deep water ports.
"As South Africa is integrated into the region, there will be more trade among all the countries," said Michael Humphrey, the chief economist of the Confederation of Zimbabwe Industries.
Zimbabwe hopes to improve its current unfavorable trade balance, Mr. Humphrey said. About 20 percent of Zimbabwe's imports, including steel, chemicals and machinery come from South Africa, with only 8 percent of Zimbabwe's exports going to South Africa, he said.

HEADLINE: S.& L.'s Have First Profits in Four Years

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 12

 BODY:
The battered savings and loan industry may be slimming down to its healthy core. The Government reported today that the industry had posted its first quarterly profit in four years.
"Clearly, there is a segment of this industry that will survive," said T. Timothy Ryan Jr., director of the Office of Thrift Supervision, which regulates savings associations that are not in Government hands. "These have been some of the toughest years that anyone has encountered, and some of these institutions have been able to do quite well." 
 The $626.8 million profit for the first three months does not include the huge losses at hundreds of savings associations that have been seized by regulators. But officials said those losses, expected to be released on Thursday, will be lower than the $904 million posted in the last quarter of 1990.
The Government's senior auditor, Charles A. Bowsher, said this week that the rescue of those institutions was in such disarray that the General Accounting Office was unable to calculate its ultimate cost to taxpayers but that the total would be far more than the $130 billion projected by the Bush Administration last year. Since the bailout began in 1989, the regulators have spent almost $80 billion; Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady is expected in two weeks to ask Congress for $50 billion more to continue the process into next year.
Congress delayed for months on voting more money the last time the Treasury asked for it, and Mr. Bowsher's assessment has heightened the Administration's political difficulties now. The chairman of the House Budget Committee, Leon Panetta, said today that he would oppose any additional funds until the General Accounting Office is able to complete an audit of the rescue effort.
"It is increasingly clear that the Federal effort to resolve the savings and loan debacle is a debacle in itself," said Mr. Panetta, Democrat of California. "Dreadful mismanagement by the Federal Government has been the hallmark of this entire scandal."
The encouraging news about the profits in the savings and loans in private hands was tempered by a significant increase in the amount of delinquent loans over the first three months of this year and by the continuing slump in many commercial real estate markets around the nation.
 
More Bank Failures Expected
 The real estate recession is also plaguing the nation's commercial and savings banks, leading regulators this week to raise their estimates of bank failures over the next 18 months to as many as 440 from an earlier estimate of 340.
Officials attributed the savings industry's profit to the sharp increase at the beginning of the year in the difference between the rates that savings associations pay depositors and what they charge borrowers and mortgage holders. The increase in this spread was caused by the drop in short-term interest rates that was not matched by lower loan rates.
Most of the largest bankrupt savings associations have already been taken over. But the figures released today on 2,283 private savings associations include the results from at least 125 institutions that the Government expects to seize and either close or sell by the end of the year. The industry lost $1.4 billion in the last quarter of last year and $372.9 million in the first quarter of 1990.
 
In Less Dire Straits
 Regulators say they have begun paying closer attention to the group of unhealthy savings associations that are in less dire straits. The group includes institutions that are not meeting regulatory standards but are still posting profits, and those that are meeting standards but are not recording profits. The group consists of 378 associations, or about 17 percent of the industry, holding more than a quarter of the industry's assets.
Mr. Ryan said officials were considering a new policy, which would not require a change in law, under which the Government would both provide financial assistance to these associations and encourage them to merge with stronger institutions. He said the Treasury officials and other regulators had not decided whether to switch to such open assistance.
How the borderline institutions are handled is crucial to the ultimate costs of the bailout. Treasury Secretary Brady has predicted that as many as 1,000 institutions may ultimately need to be rescued. In the last two years, the Government has rescued 408 savings associations. An additional 210 are now in Government hands.

HEADLINE: Bush Hails Salvador Chief, Saying Rebels Block Peace

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 12

 BODY:
President Bush praised President Alfredo Cristiani of El Salvador today for strides taken to end that country's decade-long civil war, and blamed leftist guerrillas for blocking the final path to peace.
After a two-hour meeting between Administration and Salvadoran officials, the State Department's senior Latin American specialist, Bernard W. Aronson, amplified Mr. Bush's remarks, accusing the rebels of "stalling deliberately" on a cease-fire plan while stepping up their violence. 
 Mr. Aronson said the Administration would probably begin the process of disbursing $42.5 million in American military aid to El Salvador that the White House had withheld this year pending the outcome of United Nations-sponsored peace talks.
"How many more Salvadorans must die before the guerrillas understand that Salvadorans want peace and freedom, not violence and war?" Mr. Bush said, joining Mr. Cristiani in a ceremony on the White House south lawn.
 
Rebels Denounce Comments
 The Administration's remarks reflect a strategy to increase pressure on the rebels to quit fighting and iron out the last remaining differences on a settlement.
The comments drew sharp criticism from representatives of the guerrillas, who say the Salvadoran Government bears equal blame for the faltering peace talks, and United States lawmakers, who warned that disbursing the remaining 1991 military aid now could remove the Administration's leverage over the Government to conclude a speedy peace settlement.
Ramon Cardona, a spokesman for the rebels in New York, said the Government was, among other things, trying to renegotiate terms already settled.
Mr. Aronson, who is Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs, did not say when the lengthy disbursement process might start, but said it could be halted if the rebels quit fighting and bargained in good faith.
 
Talks Set to Resume
 American officials, as well as all sides in the negotiations, said that despite the invective and stepped up fighting, prospects for peace were not permanently damaged. Government and rebel negotiators are set to resume talks under United Nations mediation in Mexico City this weekend.
In addition to meeting with Administration officials today, Mr. Cristiani sought to persuade members of Congress that uninterrupted military aid would hasten the peace process.
The House and the Senate are considering foreign aid bills that would give the Administration only half of the $85 million in military aid requested for El Salvador in fiscal 1992. The rest could be used only if Mr. Bush determined the guerrillas were not negotiating in good faith.
The Senate Foreign Relations Committee today narrowly rejected a Democratic attempt to impose restrictions on the aid package, but the issue is likely to return when the full Senate votes on the bill later this summer.
Since 1987, the United States has authorized $440.5 million in military aid and $1.5 billion in economic aid to El Salvador, according to the State Department.
By comparison, Panama received $447.4 million in economic aid in the same period, most of it since Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega was ousted in the United States invasion of December 1989. Nicaragua has received $487.7 million in economic aid since President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro took office in April 1990. Neither country received American military aid during that time.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Hits a High for 1991 Against Mark and the Yen

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
The dollar surged to a new 1991 high against the mark and yen yesterday, lifted by the hope for a faster economic recovery in the United States and the absence of any central bank intervention to slow the rally.
The surge yesterday brought the dollar to a high of 1.7945 marks in trading during the day, which meant the United States currency had risen by 24 percent since this rapid rally began in early February. The dollar rose to 142.10 yen during the day, up 11 percent since February. 
 Profit taking and worries about central bank intervention in the future pared some of the gains in the afternoon. But the dollar was still at 1.7880 marks in late trading, above the previous high of 1.7830 hit on April 29 and above the Tuesday close of 1.7740. The close in New York yesterday was also a new high for the year.
Against the yen the dollar closed at 141.50, up from 141.25 on Tuesday and a new high for the year. The dollar had set its previous high against the yen in Monday trading.
 
Rally Expected to Continue
 Some analysts said that the surge of the dollar to new highs against the mark and yen would mean that the rally would continue.
But other analysts argue that the new weakness of the yen against the dollar means that officials at the Bank of Japan are less likely to cut interest rates there very soon, a move that would weaken the yen further and add to inflation pressures by raising import prices.
The Germans have the same concern about the inflationary impact of a weaker mark and some analysts think a further dollar rally could lead to an increase of interest rates there.
Both these facts, analysts say, could help slow the dollar rally as would well-timed central bank dollar selling.
"I think it will probably trade higher," said Robert A. White, vice president at First Interstate Bank in Los Angeles. But, he also warned that "we are making a lot of assumptions on the first day of a breakout." He added, It may need a little more watching to see if it really is a new move."
Several important economic indicators on inflation and the pace of the economy are scheduled to be released today and tomorrow and that could affect the course of the dollar.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Issues Tumble in Price

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities fell sharply and long-term interest rates rose to their highest level in nearly seven months yesterday, as the pessimism that has enveloped the credit markets in recent days deepened.
Market participants said there was no single reason that caused the selloff. The move was a defensive reaction in advance of coming reports on inflation and the economy, they said. 
 Today the Government is expected to release information on retail sales activity and producer prices for May. Those reports will be followed on tomorrow with industrial production figures as well as the Consumer Price Index.
 
May Employment Data
 In keeping with the May employment report, which showed the first increase in payroll employment in 11 months and a rise in hours worked, most analysts expect the economic numbers due out today and tomorrow to show more strength than in recent months. The analysts also anticipate that inflation, which was very benign in March and April, picked up a bit in May.
Rumors circulated yesterday that the numbers would be even worse than the forecasts. Given the very negative climate, those rumors led to selling.
"There is a lot of fear," said Jay Goldinger, a principal at Capital Insight, a bond brokerage firm in Beverly Hills, Calif. "The market is in the mood where any sort of news is seen as a reason to sell."
Joseph Liro, a senior vice president and economist at S.G. Warburg & Company, said that "if the numbers are no worse than expected it will come as a relief."
 
Inflation Numbers Outlook
 Most analysts are expecting the inflation numbers to show that prices rose by about three-tenths of a percentage point last month, slightly higher than the very small increases recorded in March and April.
"The market has already priced in that sort of news," Mr. Liro said. "As a consequence, it may rally some out of relief if those numbers are actually reported."
Long-term bond prices bore the brunt of the market's decline yesterday.
In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 8 1/8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021 were offered in late trading at a price of 95 15/32, down 3/4 point, or $7.50 for each $1,000 face amount of securities, to yield 8.54 percent, up from 8.47 percent late Monday. It is the highest yield on the benchmark issue since Nov. 19, when long-term bond yields reached 8.56 percent.
Among Treasury note issues, the 8 percent 10-year notes were offered at 97 5/8 late yesterday, down 17/32, to yield 8.35 percent. And the 6 3/4 percent two-year notes were offered at 99 14/ 32, down 5/32, to yield 7.06 percent.
Short-term Treasury bill rates were narrowly mixed.
Three-month bills were offered in late trading at a discount rate of 5.54 percent, down one basis point, or one one-hundredth of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates rose by a similar amount, to a late offered rate of 5.78 percent.
The slide in Treasury prices had an adverse impact in the corporate and tax-exempt municipal bond markets.
In the investment-grade corporate bond market, market participants said that prices of most issues declined by anywhere from 1/4 point to 1/2 in thin trading.
The slide was even worse in the tax-exempt municipal bond market, where prices of most widely quoted issues fell by 3/4 point.

HEADLINE: In One City, Signs of an Upturn

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: READING, Pa., June 9

 BODY:
If the chief characteristic of emerging recovery is that the various individual economic signals are mixed, Berks County is now watching a recession fade into history.
Fitfully, sometimes almost imperceptibly, business here is gradually improving, accompanied by growing confidence that, by summer's end, a rebound -- most likely a modest one -- will be obvious, to all. 
 "We see some signs that things are starting to turn," said Harold R. Johnson, regional personnel manager here for the Glidden Company. It is not yet the burst that usually marks spring for the Cleveland-based paint maker, but a series of "spurts and starts" in recent weeks that hints of something solid.
Over at Herbert Cook's Midas muffler shop, things seem even better. Slack business had forced him to put 20 employees on short hours between mid-February and the end of April.
"Customers are coming back in," a relieved and smiling Mr. Cook said, adding that most of his workers were back full time and that the rest would soon be offered full-time jobs.
 
Some Softness Remains
 Still, some parts of the local economy remain weak. And there is some question whether a bit of an upswing represents anything more than the usual seasonal rise owing more to favorable weather than a turn in the business cycle.
Nearly 7,000 Berks County residents are delinquent in paying property taxes, 27 percent more than a year ago, estimated Virginia Lilley, acting director of the Tax Claims Bureau at the county courthouse. Jobs are also scarce. Although both initial claims for unemployment insurance and the number of people drawing unemployment benefits fell in May, only a quarter of the 130 workers who lost their jobs with the gradual closing of the Sonoco Fibre Drum Inc., plant had found new ones as of mid-May, and many of these were at lower wages.
In short, Reading appears to be displaying a textbook pattern of the early stages of recovery: various predictive and coincident indicators of economic health, like real estate sales, show improvement, while those that tend to move only on a delayed basis, like specialty steels for auto makers, are lagging.
Reading, with a population of 78,300, has no dominant company or industry and many employers remain nonunion. The area has about 30 percent of its jobs in manufacturing, compared with about 20 percent for the United States at large.
Reading makes a wide variety of products, ranging from Quaker Maid kitchen cabinets to Luden's cough drops, from pretzels to printing presses. Since late last year, The New York Times has been tracking business activity in this blue-collar town on the edge of the Pennsylvania Dutch country, every other month. Last April, there were early signs of a recovery, especially at the Glen-Gery Corporation, the nation's third-largest brick maker, which was benefiting from the surge in new-home sales and residential construction. "We continue to see a good pickup," said Steve Matsick, Glen-Gery's vice president for finance.
Surveying things two months later, with Reading and its environs a sort of proxy for the whole economy, Bernard M. Markstein, chief economist for Meridian Bancorp Inc., a banking company based here, has little doubt that the nation's ninth postwar recession will prove no longer -- and probably less severe -- than the 11-month average of its postwar predecessors.
"The turn is clearly occurring," he contended. "At worst, we're going through the bottom now."
The Abraham Lincoln Hotel, a downtown landmark that was for sale in December, has been sold for conversion to rental housing, though commercial real estate is still in the doldrums.
Even the weak areas do not seem grounds for alarm. The unemployment rate, which has climbed above 7 percent this spring, often keeps rising well into recoveries and basic-industry companies are often last to join in. That is what's happening at the venerable Carpenter Technology Corporation, a 102-year-old maker of steel products that was founded the day after the fabled flood in Johnstown, Pa., spewed tons of pig iron through the town. James H. Carpenter, who founded the company in 1889 after a Navy career that he began at 14, took pride in paying his workers in gold.
But Robert W. Cardy, president of Carpenter Technology, said he saw no hard evidence of rebound for his company. "I don't see any signs of it picking up," said Mr. Cardy, whose company's products are found in every major Pentagon weapons system and account for six or seven pounds of every car produced by Detroit's Big Three.
Mr. Markstein, the bank economist, believes that Reading's recession probably began a few months later than July, which now marks the beginning of the national downturn, and has been limited by exceptional adaptability.
Some businesses, of course, thrive on recessions, and the huge Kiwi Brands plant out in Douglassville, source of perhaps two-thirds of American shoe polish, is a notable example. "People tend not to purchase shoes as frequently so they take better care of the shoes they currently own," said Steven P. Stanbrook, executive vice president of Kiwi, whose polish lines also include Esquire and Cavalier.
Generally, however, Berks County is a place of budding optimism that, in sharp contrast to last November, each new week will be better than the last rather than worse.
John C. Rinehart, executive director of the Reading Regional Airport, finds business travelers "out and about a bit again" and people talking about the shape of the recovery, not whether it exists. Passenger traffic at the airport, which in February tumbled to 16 percent below levels a year earlier, was still down 14 percent in March but by April had recovered to just 1.8 percent below April 1990.
Frank Borek made 38 sales at his suburban used-car lot in May, the fourth straight monthly advance, while activity at the 51-store complex of factory outlets in a renovated textile mill west of town nearly kept pace with inflation by running about 2 percent above comparable 1990 levels during the 10 days straddling June 1.
"I'd say it bottomed out at the end of February, early March," said Jay Titsworth, president of VF Factory Outlet, which owns the complex, adding that such "core" items as jeans and linens were doing markedly better than such nonessentials as toys and luxury goods.
 
Chocolates Doing Well
 But Godiva's Reading chocolate plant, its only one in the United States, has been virtually unaffected by recession, according to Kevin Lowery, a spokesman for the Campbell Soup Company, Godiva's parent. That is because this is a superpremium product, the "essence" of fine chocolate, Mr. Lowery said.
The local real estate market has clearly brightened but Robert Noonan, president and general manager of Quaker Maid in Leesport, said his operation was only "holding steady" because home building in most of the Northeast remained at a low ebb.
Quaker Maid must rely on remodeling these days but this, too, has suffered because most of it is done in the first few years of moving into an older house and fewer people these days are moving. "You need the new construction business to drive the remodeling business," Mr. Noonan said.
The jobless do not yet seem particularly encouraged.
"Pretty lean," was the assessment of Leonard Dombroski Jr., a 35-year-old equipment operator at the Dana Corporation plant making car and truck frames. Since January he had been working a bobtailed 32-hour week, but last week he was enduring his first, presumably brief, furlough.
"Let's hope," Mr. Dombroski said dubiously as he left the unemployment office, "that we're going in the right direction."

HEADLINE: Report on Fed Sees Optimism

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
Some officials of the Federal Reserve Board think the economy could bounce back more strongly than generally expected, according to a confidential report by a respected consulting firm in Washington.
"Senior officials make clear the 'increasing possibility' that the next three quarters could show quite strong U.S. production," said the report, prepared by Johnson Smick International. 
 A copy of the report, dated Tuesday, was obtained by Reuters yesterday. The report said the officials based their opinions on data indicating that manufacturers made deep cut in inventories during the recession, meaning that as the economy recovered, they would need to expand production quickly to meet demand.
"Clearly, officials now question whether inventory reinvestment could be the main engine for a stronger-than-expected U.S. take-off," said the report.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
The National Sports Daily Closes With Today's Issue

BYLINE: By ALEX S. JONES

 BODY:
After 16 months of trying to make a success of being the nation's first daily paper devoted to sports, The National Sports Daily announced yesterday that the clock had run out. Today's issue will be the last.
"The payoff was too far down the road," said Frank Deford, the celebrated former sportswriter at Sports Illustrated who is The National's editor and publisher. "It just became a very prudent business decision." 
 Stephen Hammond, a spokesman for The National, said that about $100 million had been invested in the venture by the National American Sports Communications L.P., a limited partnership whose principal owner is Emilio Azcarraga, chairman of Televisa, a Mexico-based media conglomerate. Mr. Hammond said that Mr. Azcarraga was not available for comment.
Mr. Hammond said the National's circulation was at one point almost 250,000, but had declined to about 200,000 since the paper raised its price to 75 cents a copy from 50 cents in January. The paper has 278 employees at its Manhattan office, about two-thirds of them involved with the editorial product and the rest with business operations.
"I thought it was an uphill battle from stage one," said Edward J. Atorino, a vice president of Salomon Brothers Inc. who specializes in analysis of media companies.
Based on interviews with several National executives, some of whom insisted on anonymity, the publication's failure was caused by a combination of erroneous expectations about who would read the paper, distribution problems and a weak economy that throttled advertising sales.
From the time The National started publication on Jan. 31, 1990, Mr. Atorino and many other media analysts had predicted its early demise because, with sports coverage a staple of all daily papers in the United States, the potential demand for a new sports daily was limited.
Mr. Azcarraga decided to underwrite The National after he was approached with the idea by Peter O. Price, former publisher of The New York Post. Mr. Price has said that he was fascinated that most European and South American countries have successful sports dailies and that he believed one could succeed in the United States.
The two made a deal in April 1989 that made Mr. Price operating head of the new paper. But Mr. Price left the newspaper in January and Mr. Azcarraga took over more direct control through Jaime Davila, who was named president.
 
1 Million Circulation Sought
 A National executive who insisted on anonymity said the paper's original expectation was that most of its readers would be men who read sports pages in newspapers but wanted more. The initial projection was that the paper could break even with 500,000 circulation, and show a handsome profit when circulation reached the expected 1 million.
But an executive who demanded anonymity said that those buying the paper were not regular newspaper readers hungry for more sports statistics, but young men who were rabid fans and spent much of their leisure time watching sports on television, seldom reading daily papers. And there were not as many readers as had been expected. About 85,000 copies were sold in New York City, while target circulation was 125,000.
Mr. Deford was able to attract many of the nation's best-known sports writers and editors, including Mike Lupica, a columnist for The Daily News who has since returned there.
But The National's sophisticated writing talent was somewhat unsuited to its audience, and this spring, USA Today added to The National's problems by starting a weekly devoted to baseball.
The executive who declined to be identified said that the paper had expected to attract an average of six pages of advertising an issue the first year, and eight an issue the second. Mr. Hammond, The National spokesman, said yesterday that advertising had averaged from four to five pages an issue.
By midway through 1990, the full force of an advertising recession struck all publications, and was particularly devastating to newer, less established publications. When The National's existing advertising contracts, at lower introductory rates, expired at the end of the year, replacing them proved difficult.
Mr. Deford placed most of the blame for The National's failure on frustrations associated with distribution. "Essentially, that was from day one the problem we faced," he said.
Dow Jones & Company, owner of The Wall Street Journal, was retained to distribute The National using its network of wholesalers who haul truckloads of The Journal to distribution points all over the nation each day.
 
Missing the Trucks
 But Mr. Deford said that the trucks often could not wait for The National's late press run to be completed to begin their routes. Consequently, The National sometimes went out without the late scores, or copies of the paper with the late scores were left on loading docks, having arrived too late to make the trucks.
In addition, in Los Angeles and some other cities, thousands of The Nationals left in newspaper racks were stolen and resold by thieves.
Roger B. May, a spokesman for Dow Jones, said that The National was delivered to 75,000 outlets through 400 wholesalers, at the direction of Dow Jones.
This spring, Mr. Deford said that he spent much of his time studying the practicality of The National's creating its own delivery system with its own trucks. He said that there were talks with The Boston Globe, The New York Times and some other papers about making The National available through their home delivery networks. But none of the plans proved practical.
 
Bias for Local Sports
 Could The National have worked under different circumstances?
Mr. Atorino of Salomon Brothers said he thought that the United States was too diverse for a national sports daily because most people care mostly for local sports, which a national paper cannot provide as well as local papers can.
But Mr. Deford disagreed.
"Yes, it can be done, but it couldn't be done by a stand-alone company like this," he said, adding that a successful sports daily would have to be published by a company with its own distribution network and the money to wait years for a profit.
Mr. Deford said that Mr. Azcarraga had lived up to every promise and that the staff would be given 60 days' pay.

HEADLINE: Mesa Partnership Raises $616 Million

BYLINE: By THOMAS C. HAYES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DALLAS, June 12

 BODY:
The Mesa Limited Partnership, the big natural-gas producer headed by T. Boone Pickens, eased its bulging debt troubles today by raising $616 million in long-term debt from several insurance companies and other large institutions in a private transaction.
Mr. Pickens pledged more than half of Mesa's total reserves, including 1.2 trillion cubic feet in the Hugoton field of Kansas and Oklahoma, as security for the notes. Mesa has 2.1 trillion cubic feet of total reserves. 
 As a result of the deal, Mesa will be able to stretch out payments on its $1.2 billion debt at slightly higher interest rates. The deal also temporarily removes the threat of forced auctions of reserves to pay lenders. Earlier this year, bankers forced Mesa to sell 17 percent of its reserves for $440 million in cash.
 
Tough Road Ahead
 But gas prices are depressed, at $1.25 per 1,000 cubic feet, and with yearly interest expenses of $140 million, Mesa faces a tough road back to profitability. The partnership lost $204 million last year, dividend payments were eliminated and the price of its common units, which traded above $16 in 1987, have plunged. They closed unchanged at $3.25 today on the New York Stock Exchange.
In a telephone interview, Mr. Pickens said Mesa needs gas prices to recover to near $2 per 1,000 cubic feet before it can make a profit again. He said that was not likely before 1993, but that the new financing meant that Mesa would not face another debt crunch until 1996, when $300 million in notes mature. "We bought ourselves a lot of time," he said.
Gambling in 1988 that gas prices would rise to $3 by 1990, Mr. Pickens added $700 million to Mesa's debt load when he acquired some of the gas reserves of Tenneco Inc.
 
Fast Recovery Called Unlikely
 The purchase made Mesa one of the nation's largest independent gas producers, but now some analysts believe gas prices are not likely to rise fast enough for Mesa to meet debt payments and develop new reserves even with the new financing pact.
"While this deal buys Mesa time, it does not change Mesa from a liquidating entity," said Timothy J. Curro, an energy analyst at UBS Securities Inc. in New York. He said gas prices are not likely to reach the $2.50 per 1,000 cubic feet that Mr. Pickens is hoping for by the mid-1990's, and that Mesa will fall short of cash needed to replace its yearly production.
Mesa received an average price of $1.61 per 1,000 cubic feet for its gas last year, "and we don't think it will be any better than that for 1991," Mr. Pickens said. A combination of unusually warm winter weather and discoveries of abundant new reserves have depressed gas prices to the lowest level in 15 years. But Mr. Pickens asserted that the new financing package gives Mesa the flexibility to "ride out these bargain-basement natural gas prices."
The transaction, managed by Salomon Brothers Inc., raised the $616 million from approximately 30 insurance companies, pension funds and other large institutions. The Cigna Companies, a large insurer, acquired 24 percent of the notes through various subsidiaries. Other institutions were not identified.
The notes were issued with 15 different maturities extending through the year 2012, with yields between 7.5 percent and 11.3 percent. They were secured by unusually long-lived producing fields owned by Mesa, where the average life of a well exceeds 15 years. The Standard & Poor's Corporation gave the notes an investment-quality rating of A.
Rights to the reserves involved in the transaction were placed in a new Mesa subsidiary, the Hugoton Capital Limited Partnership, which issued the secured notes. Guaranteed payments on the notes were fixed according to production rates and prices, with the lowest price set at $1.35 per 1,000 cubic feet and ranging higher, Mr. Pickens said.
 
Extra Revenue Possible
 The terms require Mesa to make up the difference if gas prices are lower than the fixed price agreed to by the note holders. But Mesa can retain the extra revenue if market prices for gas are higher than the guaranteed payments on the notes.
Mesa estimated that about $175 million of the notes would be paid by June 30, 1996, and that the remainder would be paid by 2005. If production falls below projections, payments on the notes can be extended to 2012.
Mr. Pickens said $550 million of the money raised today replaced short-term bank debt, and that $66 million was designated for a cash reserve for the new subsidiary. Mesa also signed a new bank credit line of $150 million arranged by Societe Generale of France.

HEADLINE: Savings Seen by Using Millions to Study Aging

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 12

 BODY:
Spending $312 million more each year for medical research on aging could save the nation billions of dollars and significantly improve the quality of life for America's elderly, a new Institute of Medicine report says.
The report, issued today, said the United States spends about $600 million on research into relieving the ailments of aging each year, while the cost of treating health problems of the elderly is more than $162 billion annually. The nation needs to increase research on the elderly to at least $913 million, the report said. 
 The Institute of Medicine is affiliated with the National Academy of Sciences, which is chartered by Congress to provide the Government with technical advice.
"There are economic gains to be made by this research," said Julius R. Krevans, chairman of the committee that produced the report. "But greater gains would be in the quality of life."
The report said that the number of Americans 85 years old or more is growing six times as fast as any other grup and that the cost of caring for older people will double in the next decade unless ways are found to prevent or delay disabling illnesses.

HEADLINE: Dropout Rate In New York Shows Decline

BYLINE: By JOSEPH BERGER

 BODY:
The tide of dropouts from the New York City school system may finally be rolling back.
The Board of Education's annual dropout report shows that fewer high school students are dropping out before their original graduation date and more are staying in high school for five, six or seven years. 
 School officials hailed the trend as evidence of the success of a decade of dropout-prevention programs -- everything from a more determined badgering of truants to the creation of small alternative high schools.
But outside economists like Emanuel Tobier of New York University argued that the improvement might be a perverse benefit of the city's recession, which has eliminated many retail and factory jobs that entice some students to leave school without diplomas.
 
Class of '90
 And fewer students graduated on time last year than in the previous four years. At least one entering class had a higher dropout rate three years after its original graduation date than an earlier class.
But the class that entered the ninth grade in 1986 had the smallest number of dropouts in the four years since the board began conducting rigorous dropout studies.
Of the 78,936 students in the class of 1990, who entered the ninth grade in 1986, 19.2 percent dropped out before their scheduled graduation. By contrast, 20.9 percent of the class of 1989 left school before graduation day; 20.8 percent of the class of 1988 dropped out before graduation, as did 22.4 percent of the class of 1987 and 21.8 percent of the class of 1986.
More than one of every four members of the class of 1990 stayed in school beyond their scheduled 1990 graduation date, a rate higher than that of previous classes. And follow-up studies of the classes of 1989 and 1988 also showed that students who had not graduated on time were dropping out in smaller numbers and staying in school.
The dropout rate has been one of the most closely watched indicators of the health of both the school system and the city itself. A large number of dropouts would mean the city could have trouble filling the increasingly skilled jobs that its economy is creating. But until 1986, when the board began keeping track of students class by class, the figures were in dispute.
School officials said New York is the only city that conducts such long-range dropout studies. Other school systems, like New York before 1986, depend on projections -- now regarded as unreliable -- based on the number of students who left the system during a given year. The board defines a dropout as someone who left school without enrolling elsewhere.
In the class originally scheduled to graduate in 1990, 15.3 percent enrolled outside the New York public school system and were classified as discharges. In addition, 37.6 percent of the class graduated on time, and 27.8 percent were still enrolled in the current school year. The remaining 19.2 percent were classified as dropouts.
But school officials say the four-year figure is not the best measure of the rate of students who never complete high school. That is because many of the students who stay in school beyond four years eventually drop out. Thus by 1990, the system lost 29.4 percent of the students who started the ninth grade in 1983 hoping to graduate in 1987.
Others like Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, regional commissioner of the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics, say that if dropouts among the ranks of students transferring to schools outside the city's public school system could be calculated, the dropout rate would be even higher -- closer to 33 percent. Board officials reply that it would be extremely costly to keep track of students in so many locations.
The national dropout rate, which uses projections rather than the board's precise tabulation of diplomas and dropouts, is 30 percent. New York City's rate is roughly average for large cities.
At a briefing on Tuesday, Schools Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez, who took office six months before the class of 1990 graduated, hailed the trends as promising and said they validate a series of programs that his administration has begun to reduce the number of students left back, to provide bilingual classes for the influx of immigrants and to bolster mathematics requirements in high school. He warned that an impending budget cut of $505 million might imperil those gains.
"The message is obviously getting out that they have to stay in school and get a high school diploma," Mr. Fernandez said. "The trends are all going in a positive direction."
The news was not completely bright. The 29.4 percent dropout rate of the class of 1987 -- the second group studied for seven years until the age of 21 -- was higher than that of the class of 1986, which had a 28.3 percent rate.
The proportion of students in the class of 1990 who graduated after four years -- 37.6 percent -- was smaller than those of who both the 1989 and 1988 classes. Board of Education officials said those figures show that students, more burdened by jobs or children of their own than their predecessors were, are taking longer to finish school.
There were also some indications in statistics for individual high schools that strong principals can make a difference. Thomas Jefferson High School in the East New York section of Brooklyn has long had a dropout rate among the worst in the city, but that reputation is changing since a new principal, Carol Burt-Beck, went to the school several years ago. It has seen a steady decline in its four-year dropout rates, from 39.7 percent in 1987 to 33.9 percent in 1990.
Because of changes in the methods of calculations, the city's figures do not reflect changes among individual ethnic or racial groups. A recent survey by the Census Bureau showed that, nationally, blacks were finishing high school in greater numbers than ever before.

HEADLINE: Stocks in Broad Slide; Dow Falls by 23.92

BYLINE: By H. J. MAIDENBERG

 BODY:
Rising long-term interest rates, fears of renewed inflation and sell programs slashed stock prices yesterday. But the day's largest losses were softened by some bargain hunting late in the session and by the relatively low volume of trading.
The Dow Jones industrial average closed down 23.92, to 2,961.99. Volume on the New York Stock Exchange rose to 166.2 million shares, from 161.6 million the day before. There were 364 Big Board stocks up on the day and 1,238 issuesthat declined. 
 Among the other market gauges, the Standard & Poor's 500 index closed off 4.40, at 376.65; the New York Stock Exchange composite index fell 2.25, to 206.58; the Nasdaq composite index lost 5.57, at 491.05, and the American Stock Exchange's Market Value Index dropped 3.09, to 366.71.
"The decline in Treasury bond prices at the opening triggered the selloff in the equities market," said Bernard Spilko, senior vice president at the New York branch of Bank Julius Baer of Zurich, which manages European pension funds.
"What caused bond prices to fall with the resultant rise in long-term interest rates," Mr. Spilko continued, "was more optimistic statements about the economy by the President and some present and former Federal Reserve officials Tuesday and early today."
Because rising long-term interest rates could reignite inflation, many investors moved to the sidelines to await the Government reports on May wholesale prices, which is due this morning, and last month's Consumer Price Index, which is scheduled for release early tomorrow. In addition, a number of other economic reports are expected this week.
Mr. Spilko also noted that the recent strength of the dollar had attracted only a modest amount of foreign investment in the domestic stock market, and that this unexpected development might have inhibited some domestic portfolio managers as well.
In any event, the wide market swings left most of the Big Board's most actively traded issues with fractional gains or declines. Pepsico was the most active issue, off 3/8, to 30 1/8, on a turnover of 3.2 milion shares.
Johnson & Johnson, the 10th-most-active issue, was an exception. It lost 1 5/8, at 85 1/4, on a volume of 1.3 million shares. Brokers said the decline in Johnson & Johnson might have been in reaction to news that the company was involved in a deal to sell 250,000 shares it owns in Medchem Products Inc. Medchem itself proposes to sell 1.75 million of its own shares. Another 250,000 Medchem shares would be offered upon exercise of warrants held by the Itel corporation's Signal Capital Corporation. Itel slipped 1/2, to 16 1/2, and Medchem was unchanged at 11 7/8.
Stocks of semiconductor companies were battered after an industry association said in effect that shipments in May had exceeded new orders. Among the larger declines were Applied Materials, down 1 3/4, to 30 1/2; Intel, 1 7/8, to 49 3/8; Motorola, 1 1/8, to 63 1/2; Texas Instruments, 1 1/4, to 34 1/2; Telxon, 1, to 17 3/8. Among the rare gainers in this sector were Wang Lab B, up 1/8, to 3 1/2; VLSI Tech, up 3/8, to 9 3/8.
