HEADLINE: Bush Outlines an Attack on Domestic Ills

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 12

 BODY:
In response to accusations that he lacks a domestic policy, President Bush tonight blamed Congress for failing to meet his legislative schedule and sketched his approach to unleashing the "magic of America" to cure serious social problems.
The philosophical underpinning of Mr. Bush's speech, delivered on the White House South Lawn but not broadcast live on television, was a significant departure from the views of his predecessor, Ronald Reagan, as Mr. Bush called for a synthesis of Reagan-era economics with government and community-based social action. 
 He said both the unfettered market policies of Mr. Reagan and the "bigger government was better government" philosophy of President Jimmy Carter had been inadequate. But he suggested that elements of each could be combined with his brand of Mr. Reagan's voluntarism to produce "an America whole and good."
Mr. Bush criticized Congress as blocking what he said were his efforts to "tackle the urgent problems on the home front."
The speech offered no new programs to back Mr. Bush's vision beyond a restatement of the modest domestic proposals he has already given to Congress.
Instead, Mr. Bush said he was setting forth his philosophy of "the shared strength and promise of America," which he said did not have to settle for a society in which "there must always be those who are left behind."
In an important passage, Mr. Bush paid tribute to the economic boom of the 1980's. But he said it had left the nation with intractable social problems. "We began a decade of exceptional economic growth and created 20 million new jobs," he said.
"And yet, let's face it, many of our streets are still not safe, our schools have lost their edge and millions, millions, still trudge the path of poverty. There is more to be done and the marketplace alone can't solve all our problems."
Mr. Bush stated his idea like this:
"There is a better way, one that combines our efforts -- those of a government properly defined, the marketplace properly understood and service to others properly engaged. This is the only way to an America whole and good."
 
A Campaign Slogan for 1992
 With that last phrase, the President clearly seemed to be reaching for a slogan that he can carry into the 1992 Presidential election, in which Democrats are sure to strike at his most vulnerable point: domestic issues.
Today's speech suggested that Mr. Bush is planning to stress his record as a diplomat and wartime leader while offering assurances that he can also lead the country on economic and social issues and painting the Democrats as offering a gloomy vision of America while he "is confident about what lies ahead."
We must "carry forward the magic of America," Mr. Bush said. "We must carry forward what is good and reach out and embrace what is best."
But if today's speech was intended to build a defense against Democratic criticism and serve as a springboard for the 1992 campaign, it was oddly presented.
The White House, which has been struggling for two and a half years to coordinate its message, presented the speech as a major address on domestic policy when it was announced on Monday. But it never asked the television networks for live coverage of the event.
Then for two days, White House officials sought to play down expectations, specifically ruling out any chance that Mr. Bush would announce new policy initiatives.
White House officials, who argue that Mr. Bush has been unfairly maligned for lacking vision, said the point was not to offer new proposals but to "put things in perspective" on the calculation that if Americans heard Mr. Bush's own words, they would understand his philosophy.
 
Attack Before Delivery
 But the result of the White House's handling of the speech was that the four networks decided not to carry it.
The Democrats, meanwhile, assailed Mr. Bush's speech before it was ever delivered. Representative Richard A. Gephardt, the House majority leader and a possible Presidential contender, issued a statement critical of Mr. Bush's speech more than eight hours before a text was made available.
"Tonight, the next photo opportunity in Mr. Bush's 'Polaroid Presidency' will occur on the White House lawn," he said. "This is a President who prefers rhetoric to action, symbols to substance, vetoes to progress and campaigning to governing."
The White House had taken pains during the day to say that Mr. Bush would "not bash the Democrats," as one official put it.
But the President's remarks began with a strong assault on the Democratic-controlled Congress that focused on his request that Congress pass his anti-crime bill and highway construction measure within a 100-day period, which ends on Friday.
"I thought a hundred days was fairly reasonable," he said. "I's now clear that neither will be on my desk by Friday. And look, I'm disappointed, but frankly I'm not surprised.
"It would help if Congress would do what the people are asking of them. And I'll keep working with the Congress. My hand remains extended. But we cannot let Congress discourage or deter us from meeting our responsibilities."

GRAPHIC: Photo: President Bush greeting some of the supporters who arrived to hear his speech last night on the South Lawn of the White House. (Paul Hosefros/The New York Times)
 
Chart: "The President's Legislation: A Status Report"
 
Energy
 In February the Administration proposed an energy strategy that would open portions of the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge to oil and gas drilling, remove obstacles to the construction of nuclear power plants, deregulate natural gas pipelines and repeal a 50-year-old law that limits who can enter the wholesale electric generation market. The proposal includes measures to increase the use of alternative motor fuels like ethanol and several modest measures to encourage the use of mass transit and increase the energy efficiency of homes.
On May 23, the Senate Energy Committee approved its energy blueprint, which includes the Arctic refuge drilling and other Administration measures. The committee voted against imposing higher economy standards for automobiles, a provision that was opposed by the Administration. It is uncertain when the measure will reach the Senate floor, where it is likely to face vigorous opposition from those who complain that it emphasizes production over conservation. The House has taken no major action.
 
Education
 In April the President offered a broad education plan for improving schools. The plan included national student testing, school choice for parents, a Federal program of research and development contracts to invent new kinds of public schools and a plan for schools to provide children with a range of social services. The proposals were introduced in the Senate and House in May, and some are expected to be added to other bills when the Senate considers education legislation, probably next month.
 
Crime
 In March the Administration sent Congress an anti-crime bill that revived proposals that died last year. Like the previous bill, the new legislation would expand the number of Federal crimes punishable by death, limit appeals by death row inmates and lift restrictions on the use of illegally obtained evidence in criminal trials if the police acted in good faith.
 Debate on a Democratic crime bill and the Administration plan is expected to begin next week. The White House said it would consider a bill imposing a seven-day waiting period on handgun purchases from dealers if it is part of a package that includes the President's crime proposals. A House subcommittee is holding hearings on the overall proposal.
 
Transportation
 In February the Administration proposed a five-year, $105 billion program of Federal aid to the states for highways and mass transit. The proposal would create a 150,000-mile national highway system consisting of new and existing highways and would earmark nearly two-thirds of all Federal highway aid for the new system. It would also require states and local governments to pay more highway and transit costs.
 The Senate is considering its own measure this week. It calls for the same amount of overall spending as the Administration plan but earmarks less money for highways and allows states more flexibility in spending Federal funds on surface transportation programs of their choice. The House Public Works and Transprtion Committee has finished hearings on the Administration's proposal, but no legislation has been introduced.
 
Banking
 The Administration has proposed revising Depression-era laws governing the nation's banking system. The plan would let industrial enterprises own banks, allow the mergers of commercial banks and investment banks, and eliminate barriers that now limit banks' ability to open new branches across state lines. The House Banking Committee will take up the bill next week.
 The plan's core provisions remain after subcommittee review. But a proposal to consolidate four existing agencies into two has been replaced with one that would increase the regulatory authority of the Treasury Department and the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation and decrease the power of the Federal Reserve. The bill will also be considered by two other House Committees: Energy and Commerce , where it faces considerable opposition, and Ways and Means. The Senate Banking Committee has not yet begun drafting legislation.
 
Civil Rights
Mr. Bush proposed legislation to undo some 1989 Supreme Court decisions, but has insisted he would not go as far as House Democrats, whose proposal he called a "quota bill." Before the House passed the bill on Mune 5, he threatened to veto it. House Democrats insist the bill would actually declare hiring quotas illegal. Nine moderate Senate Republicans have introiduced a compromise measure, closer to the House bill than to Mr. Bush's, and the Administration says it is studying the counterproposal.

HEADLINE: Dinkins and Unions: Money Is Turning Friends Into Foes

BYLINE: By JOSH BARBANEL

 BODY:
The shouts of a furious Barry Feinstein, the teamsters' union leader, rang out from a conference room where a handful of New York City officials and union leaders last gathered in vain to discuss union concessions that could head off deep cuts in the city's budget -- and the layoffs of 20,000 city workers.
"Back stabbing" and "double dealing" were among the less salty gibes that were heard, interrupted at times by an angry retort from Milton Mollen, in ordinary times the most unflappable of Mayor David N. Dinkins's deputy mayors. And when it was all over two hours later, union leaders stormed out, complaining that the city had been duplicitous, disrespectful and incompetent. 
 Since that meeting almost three weeks ago -- the last negotiating session between the Dinkins administration and the municipal union leaders -- tempers have cooled. But the talks, perhaps the most far-reaching in years, with the city's fiscal stability at stake, have remained stalled.
And as the impasse drags on toward the June 30 deadline for a new city budget, it becomes increasingly likely that at least some of the dire cuts proposed by the Mayor -- from turning off street lights to closing hospital pharmacies -- will indeed go forward.
What makes this turn of events so odd is that these are the same union leaders who were the heart, soul and legs of Mr. Dinkins's election campaign, who stood at the Mayor's side on election night to celebrate their common conquest. That they seem so far apart today is perhaps the cruel, central irony of Mr. Dinkins's administration.
The municipal unions had achieved considerable economic might during the booming 1980's, adding members by the thousands and winning strong wage settlements that were the envy of their hard-pressed brethren in the private sector.
But just as the unions gained more political clout, they were losing the economic power that sustained them during the 1980's, with a recesson now ravaging the local tax base.
These polar forces -- economic weakness and seeming political strength -- are more than anything else shaping the brooding conflict between the unions and the Mayor, contributing to a sense of unease and drift as the Dinkins administration confronts the city's worst fiscal crisis since its brush with bankruptcy in 1975.
 
A Lose-Lose Situation
 When it comes to money, union leaders are in a lose-lose situation. If they do nothing, thousands of their members could be laid off. If they make concessions, giving back benefits or deferring wages, they risk angering their constituents who remain on the city payroll.
The choices are so bleak that most union leaders, remembering hard lessons of the city's last fiscal crisis -- when union leaders agreed to concessions to avoid layoffs, only to see layoffs occur anyway a few months later -- have simply found reasons to stay away from the negotiations.
Those who agreed to sit down and talk, recalling another lesson from the 1970's, are willing to talk only if they are treated as statesmen searching for far-reaching political solutions -- partners with politicians, the Mayor, the Governor, the City Council, as well as business leaders, in solving the city's fiscal problems.
"The pain must be shared" has become their slogan.
 
Stymied on Concessions
 Mr. Dinkins, too, has little choice but to cut the cost of the work force. But despite his closeness with organized labor, or perhaps because of it, the Mayor has been unable to figure out how to wrangle concessions from the unions.
Union leaders complain that the administration has been unable to fashion a coherent labor strategy. The administration has been by turns conciliatory and confrontational -- granting wage increases that business leaders said the city could not afford, then drafting state legislation that would short-circuit collective bargaining and let the city unilaterally furlough city workers, a dagger in the heart of union power.
Mr. Mollen, the Deputy Mayor who was put in charge of labor negotiations after Mr. Dinkins dismissed his chief labor negotiator in a policy dispute several months ago, acknowledged that the Mayor had been "stymied" in his efforts to avert $1.4 billion in proposed service cuts.
"I am hopeful, I don't know if I would characterize it as optimistic, that the unions will act in ways which we think will be in the best interest of the city," Mr. Mollen said.
 
Cautious About Raising Taxes
 In many ways, the city's current situation is similar to that of troubled industries in the American Rust Belt in the early 1980's. Faced with growing foreign competition, managers could no longer raise prices -- or in the city's case raise taxes without limit -- to meet increased costs and union demands. Instead, they struggled to increase productivity and lower the cost of labor. In the city's case, it risks losing business and taxpayers to the suburbs and other parts of the country if it raises taxes too much.
At stake in the negotiations, according to this view, are the means, not the ends. Will the cost be cut through layoffs, concessions in health and welfare benefits, wage deferrals, productivity improvements or, if all else fails, a long-term freeze for city wages that will eventually lower real labor costs after taking inflation into account?
"Labor costs are going to fall, they are going to fall big -- the question is how they fall," said Raymond D. Horton, president of the Citizens Budget Commission, a research group supported by businesses. So far, "the Mayor is proposing making them fall by firing a lot of workers," he said. "There may be a better way."
 
'Underhanded and Back Stabbing'
 At the last negotiating session, union leaders were furious at the Mayor for consigning the talks to his regular labor negotiating team, rather than taking charge personally, and for allowing his staff to draft furlough legislation.
"There was no substance," Mr. Feinstein of the teamsters said. "We view secret discussion on furloughs as being duplicitous, double dealing, underhanded and back stabbing."
And Stanley Hill, executive director of the largest municipal union, District Council 37 of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees, said that even in private conversations, discussions have not moved from general approaches to specifics.
"There is no such thing as a specific proposal," he said. "The lead still has to come from the Mayor."
Mayor Dinkins argues that he can hardly be blamed for sweeping economic winds that have hit cities across the country, whether they have strong union movements or not.
 
Wage Increases for Teachers
 But many business leaders and public officials say it is clear, at least in retrospect, that Mr. Dinkins is paying a price for not reading these dire signs sooner. Overruling objections raised by his own budget director, the Mayor agreed to give substantial wage and benefit increases to city teachers last October, and later offered lesser increases to 140,000 other nonuniformed city workers -- members of the same unions that backed him for mayor.
Now, they say, even if his high-stakes negotiating strategy is successful, he will in effect win concessions only to cover the cost of wage increases he has already granted.
"Once you ring a bell, you can't unring it," observed State Comptroller Edward V. Regan. "It's hard to say to a union leader: 'Remember what I told you at that great rally back in October? Well, forget it.' They won a wage increase fairly and squarely and now someone wants to undo it."
 
Paying for Success
 The city's unions are paying a political price not only for the wage increases granted by Mayor Dinkins but also for their success throughout the 1980's, when they won signficant wage gains, after accounting for inflation, while private-sector unions lost members and influence.
City health-care costs have more than doubled, after accounting for inflation, since 1984, while union welfare fund payments, for dental and other benefits, increased by 40 percent in the 1980's, including a 12 percent increase approved by Mayor Dinkins.
But union officials say the gains in purchasing power made by city workers in the 1980's merely offset losses in the city's fiscal retrenchment in the 1970's. And while city teachers and police officers are well paid compared to other parts of the country, their salaries lag behind those paid in nearby suburbs.
In seeking concessions from the unions, the Dinkins administration is confronting a movement that is far from monolithic, with clashing personalities and interests -- there are more than 100 bargaining units among the city's workers -- but with leaders who, after years or even decades in office, are highly skilled politicians and professional negotiators.
 
Nothing to Talk About
 They know from experience that even raising the possibility of giving up wage increases can be a dangerous proposition and that promises made today by the administration can be invalidated if the fiscal situation worsens.
The Patrolmen's Benevolent Association says it has nothing to talk about since talks on a contract that expired last year broke down in a dispute headed for binding arbitration. James Boyle, president of the firefighters union, says he has plenty of ideas about how to help, but cannot even get the hard-pressed city negotiating team to begin talks.
City teachers, led by Sandra Feldman, president of the United Federation of Teachers, say they have already done more than their fair share -- agreeing to a onetime deferral of more than $30 million in wages to postpone layoffs proposed in January.
That leaves a union negotiating team headed by the unlikely combination of Mr. Feinstein, whose teamsters are one of the smaller city unions, and Mr. Hill, from District Council 37, the largest municipal union, with 140,000 members.
 
Often Defers to Feinstein
 By dint of numbers alone, Mr. Hill should be the central labor leader in the city. But Mr. Hill, an earnest hard-working administrator who spends hours each day working the telephones to keep together the unruly coalition of 57 local presidents in his council, often defers to Mr. Feinstein.
"I can't let ego get in the way of a fiscal crisis that could cost people their jobs," Mr. Hill says.
Mr. Feinstein, a brash union leader who had headed the teamsters local for more than two decades, relishes his role at center stage, alternately attacking the Governor and the Mayor, both of whom he has supported on Election Day. The visibility in the city cannot hurt his current campaign for a vice presidency in his international union.
 
Early Retirement
 As they press their case, the union leaders say they want the city to step up attrition, offering older workers early retirement to reduce the need for layoffs. They say they want to work with the city to improve productivity and might consider other concessions, but only if the city can guarantee that layoffs will not occur.
With the Mayor and the City Council at odds on the taxes he wants to balance his current budget, and with the state falling short so far in providing the aid the Mayor says he needs to balance it, the union leaders say they have little incentive to act now.
Mr. Dinkins has taken to blaming his predecessor, Edward I. Koch, for huge growth in the city's labor costs. But Mr. Dinkins surprised many when, with the negotiations floundering, he brought in a consultant, Edward Silver, a labor lawyer with a reputation as a tough professional bargainer -- who helped Mr. Koch shape the city's labor policy during the 1980's.

HEADLINE: NBC 'Nightly News' To Move to 6:30 From 7

BYLINE: By BILL CARTER

 BODY:
The NBC "Nightly News" with Tom Brokaw will be moved to 6:30 P.M. from 7 P.M. in New York starting in September in favor of the syndicated show "Love Connection," officials at WNBC, the network's station in New York, said yesterday.
WNBC, Channel 4, announced the move as part of a reorganization of its evening programming. On Sept. 9, the station also plans to cut back its local 6 P.M. newscast to a half-hour from an hour to make room for "Love Connection." Channel 4 will also add a new program called "Ruckus" at 7:30 P.M., replacing "Family Feud." 
 The shift of the newscast means that all three network newscasts will now be broadcast at 6:30 P.M. each weekday in New York, the nation's largest television market. As recently as 1987, all three newscasts were broadcast at 7 P.M., when television viewing levels were much higher than they are today.
The national trend has been to move the network newscasts to earlier times to accommodate syndicated game and magazine-format programs, which make greater profits for stations than news programs. National ratings for the network newscasts have been in sharp decline.
 
'I Think This May Help Us'
 "I have very mixed feelings," Mr. Brokaw said yesterday. "I don't think anybody likes to give up a half-hour of news, but just in terms of raw audience I think this may help us. We have to remember these are very rough times economically."
NBC News executives did not oppose the move to 6:30 P.M., said Peggy Hubble, a spokeswoman for the network news division. She said NBC News thought the newscast would benefit from going head-to-head with the ABC and CBS newscasts in New York. She also cited positive ratings results for stations that have recently moved the NBC newscast back a half-hour.
In May, the NBC newscast had a 5.5 rating at 7 P.M. in New York. ABC's newscast had a 9.3 rating at 6:30 P.M., well ahead of CBS, which had only a 5 rating at 6:30 P.M. for its newscast. Each rating point represents 70,438 households in the New York area.
William G. Moll, the vice president and general manager of Channel 4, said yesterday that the economic advantage of broadcasting an entertainment show at 7 P.M. was the main reason the station decided to cut back on its news programming.
"There are more homes using television at 7 than there are earlier," Mr. Moll said. "So you can make a lot more revenue."
The move was long overdue, he added. "We were out of sync with the other network stations," he said of not having two entertainment shows from 7 to 8 P.M.
The reason WNBC was finally making the move away from news to entertainment, he said, was, "We have the shows to do it now."
 
Ups and Downs of Dating
 He praised "Love Connection" as a "fun show about relationships." The syndicated show features couples who discuss the high and low points of their recent dates.
"Ruckus" is a show produced by the Merv Griffin Company, which also created such syndicated hits as "Wheel of Fortune" and "Jeopardy." WNBC will carry the show exclusively; it will not be syndicated to any other stations, at least initially, Mr. Moll said.
Mr. Moll said he was not permitted to disclose any details about "Ruckus," but a pilot made by Mr. Griffin included game and giveaway elements and featured a comedian called the Amazing Jonathan as its host. Mr. Moll said "Ruckus" was not a game show and would not confirm the name of the host.
Channel 4 will try to compensate for the half-hour cutback in local news by changing the format of its "Live at Five" newscast, Mr. Moll said. "That newscast has been built mostly on celebrity interviews," he said. "It will become a harder news show, more a newscast of record."
The news cutback will not mean layoffs in the Channel 4 news staff, Mr. Moll said. "This move is not about head counts," he said.

HEADLINE: Home Video

BYLINE: By Peter M. Nichols

 BODY:

A Rush of Delays
For reasons related mostly to a soft economy, delays in the release of videos are becoming more frequent. Perhaps the most noteworthy recent example was "Avalon," Barry Levinson's film from RCA/Columbia, which was due out on May 1, but was put off at the last minute until May 15. 
 The reason for the delays is that many stores are waiting until the last minute to order movies from the studios' distributors. As the order cutoff date for stores approaches, the studios occasionally extend deadlines in hopes of getting more orders.
 This means, of course, that movies don't get to the stores as promised. "It happens all the time," said Rich Thorward of Home Video Plus in Glen Rock, N.J, and president of the New York-New Jersey chapter of the Video Software Dealers Association. "We let people know when titles are going to arrive and then the date is wrong."
 Studios also shift dates to avoid competition from other videos, much in the way they juggle opening dates for theatrical releases. Besides "Avalon," recently delayed films include the upcoming "Almost an Angel" from Paramount , "Mr. and Mrs. Bridge" from HBO and "Not Without My Daughter," from MGM/UA , all of which have been moved from June to July.
 For video stores that don't put off their orders, Mr. Thorward said, delayed releases can derail budgets. They also cut into whatever head start video has over pay per view on cable television. When a movie is released on tape, there is a stipulated window of time, usually about 30 days, before it is available for pay per view. A delayed release date shortens that advantage. "It's in the studios' best interests to give a longer window to home video," Mr. Thorward said. "A longer window gives them a decent return on their investment."
 
'Bell Telephone' Redux
 Vintage television buffs will get a bonanza over the next month. On June 25, Kultur will release "Birgit Nilsson," a 45-minute tape culled from her four appearances on the "Bell Telephone Hour," the television performance series of the late 1950's and early 60's. Kultur has obtained rights for 100 hours of Bell programming and plans to use it as a base to create its own series of videos.
"We'll edit the footage and put it together with other material," said Dennis Hedlund, the president of Kultur. "For example, we'll edit Maria Callas's four appearances, perhaps add wraparounds of commentary from opera people and introductions by our own host." Upcoming programs will feature performances by Rudolf Nureyev, Richard Tucker, Joan Sutherland, Louis Armstrong and Benny Goodman.
 In July, Kultur's White Star division will release "The Best of Ernie Kovacs," five one-hour cassettes taken from the comedian's television appearances from 1950 until his death in 1962. The release date is July 23 and the price is $19.95 a tape.
 
 
New Video Releases

 
Green Card
1990. Touchstone. $92.95. 1 hour 47 minutes. Closed captioned. PG-13.
Prim, health-obsessed botanist seeks partner for a marriage of convenience so she can qualify for tenancy in a tree-filled apartment. Raffish Frenchman (Gerard Depardieu), a consumer of beef and cigarettes, needs a wife in name only for the purpose of obtaining the document of the title. But then an Immigration and Naturalization Service investigation forces the couple actually to live together and act married, cause enough for "airy, high-concept comedy" (Janet Maslin).
 
Around the World in 80 Days
1991. Public Media. $49.95. Four cassettes. 5:36. Not rated.
Michael Palin as Phileas Fogg in a 20th-century BBC update of Jules Verne's 19th-century novel. Travel these days, comments Mr. Palin, is something one reads about on an airplane. To alter his perspective, Mr. Palin accepted a challenge from the British Broadcasting Company to circle the globe in 80 days like Fogg, the hero in Verne's novel on which Mike Todd based his 1956 movie.
As in the book and movie, Mr. Palin and a BBC film crew set out from the Reform Club in London, traveling through Europe down to Alexandria, Egypt, then across the Arabian peninsula to Dubai. From there they cross the Arabian Sea to Bombay, traverse the subcontinent to Madras, and then sail down the Bay of Bengal to Singapore. They steam up the South China Sea to Hong Kong, and the East China Sea to Shanghai, then across to Yokohama, Japan. From there they cross the Pacific Ocean to Long Beach, Calif., and take Amtrak across the North American continent to New York. From there, London is just one more ocean away.
 Some trains and ships move faster than in the 19th century (although others don't), but Mr. Palin's main problem is that there are fewer of them. Much of his time is spent in shipping offices begging for passage on whatever vessel might be headed to the right place at the right time. By Shanghai he has fallen about 10 days behind.
 Through delays and missed connections, Mr. Palin stays calm, never imparting too much urgency to his statements to the camera that all is lost if he misses this or that freighter. Along the way he takes time for puckish bits of travelogue. In Venice, for example, he tours the city on a trash collection barge. The six-day voyage from Dubai to Bombay on a dhow is also memorable.
Back in London just in time, Mr. Palin and the BBC crew race to the Reform Club, only to find that it has closed for the day and won't let them in.
 
To Sleep With Anger
1990. SVS. $89.95. 1:35. CC. PG.
A black Southern sharecropper with a winning smile and eyes as cold as death (Danny Glover) moves into the home of old friends, where he jogs their comfortable lives with his harsh judgments and resentment of hard times. Small in scope, Charles Burnett's film is "a comedy of unusual substance . . . a big movie, full of big comic scenes" (Vincent Canby).

HEADLINE: New York's Ordeal: The Tax Exit

 BODY:
New York State's budget ordeal is as misleading as it is endless. No matter how stubborn the confrontation between Gov. Mario Cuomo and the Legislature, New York does not have to choose between savage service cuts and an irresponsible, unbalanced budget. Like other states hit by the recession, it has a third option: more tax increases.
Recommending higher taxes is rarely a favorite political strategy. Assembly Speaker Mel Miller tried that earlier this spring and was shot down by the Governor and the Senate majority leader, Ralph Marino. But if raising taxes is unpopular, so is hacking school aid, state police and support for embattled New York City. New Yorkers can avoid, or at least soften, anguishing choices with moderate tax increases, preferably of the broadest-based, fairest kind: income taxes. 
 Right now, the state's highest rate is 7.875 percent of taxable income. That's hardly extortionate. The rate was 15 percent in the early 70's, and 10 percent when Mr. Cuomo took office in 1983. So if it went up even a full point, the rate would still be less than just a few years ago.
Even in New York City, which has its own income tax, people would pay a lower combined income tax than 10 years ago, whether the city tax stays where it is (3.9 percent) or goes to 4.3, as City Hall now proposes.
Speaker Miller's plan would raise the highest rate from 7.875 to 8.663 percent. That would yield the same $700 million now anticipated to come in from regressive new energy taxes. Those taxes so trouble the business community that even the president of the state's Business Council, Daniel Walsh, says that anything -- including a personal income tax increase -- would be better.
An even higher income tax increase than Mr. Miller suggests -- the Citizens Budget Commission recommends a full point, for instance -- would yield enough to avoid some of the cuts that both the Legislature and the Governor have been running away from. The lawmakers, unable to make painful choices, approved a budget that almost certainly fails to balance. Mr. Cuomo was right to respond with line-item vetoes.
But the fact is, he also wants his spending rather than their spending. There is a way to have some of both: taxes.
The Governor's argument that raising income taxes will hurt New York's competitiveness is less compelling now that neighboring states face the same fiscal problems. Moreover, poor services and a decline in the quality of life also hurt competitiveness. For Mr. Cuomo to stick to his no-income-tax pledge, which has always smacked of national ambition, ignores those realities.
The budget crisis demonstrates that the state still has failed to make sufficient structural changes in the way it operates, restructuring services and reorganizing its bureaucracy. But that takes time. Tax revenues can buy that time while avoiding deep, disruptive budget cuts. It's not a perfect solution, but it's better than allowing the monumental mess to go on.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Salomon Official Going To Development Bank

BYLINE: By STEVEN PROKESCH

 BODY:
Jacques Attali, president of the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development, had great difficulty finding an American banker to head the merchant banking division of his institution. When the bank opened for business in April, the important position was vacant.
But for Ronald M. Freeman, the head of European investment banking at Salomon Brothers Inc., who accepted the position last week, the job was welcomed. "I did not have to be wooed," he said, even though the move meant a big pay cut. 
 Carrying out the bank's task of helping the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe convert state-owned enterprises to investor-owned companies "seemed like the most interesting and exciting job a banker could have in the world today," Mr. Freeman said. He hopes to be working full time at the new job by the end of summer.
The United States, which provided 10 percent of the bank's equity of $11.6 billion, is its largest shareholder. The Bush Administration insisted that the institution focus on developing the private sector in the former Eastern bloc and that it hire a senior American banker to carry out that mandate. The 51-year-old Mr. Freeman, who has discussed the job with Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady, is such a person.
He was a consultant for McKinsey & Company in Paris in 1973 when he jumped to Salomon. He moved to the project finance unit in New York, headed the corporate finance department that worked with energy companies, and became co-leader of the American mergers and acquisitions department in 1986. He moved to Europe two years ago. His clients have included Gulf Oil, Chevron, Mobil, Atlantic Richfield, A.T.& T., Michelin and Eurotunnel.
Mr. Freeman, who has a French mother, speaks French fluently and studied Russian while earning a law degree at Columbia University. He also has business experience in Eastern Europe, having been involved in complex deals like swapping East European bonds for Soviet commodities and then swapping the bonds for consumer goods for the Soviets. He has helped take public several state-owned companies, including Fotex, a Hungarian photo processor.
He shares Mr. Attali's goal of using the new bank's money and expertise as a "catalyst" to bring private investment into Eastern Europe.
"When Henry Kravis says, 'I want to put my equity next to yours'; when John Gutfreund says, 'I want to syndicate a piece of that deal,' or when Dennis Weatherstone says, 'We want to lend to that credit you structured,' I'll know we are going in the right direction," he said, referring to the leaders of Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company; Salomon Brothers, and the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company, respectively.
Mr. Freeman and his wife, Helen, have two young daughters.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Continues to Gain While Gold Prices Tumble

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar continued its advance on world currency markets yesterday, posting additional gains against the mark after the release of some important data on the United States economy.
Gold prices were mostly lower worldwide. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold for current delivery settled at $370.20 an ounce, unchanged from Wednesday. The Republic National Bank said gold slipped 15 cents, to a late bid of $369.10. 
 The dollar's gains followed release of reports that showed a better-than-expected 1 percent gain in retail sales during May -- led by a 1.7 percent advance for autos -- and that new claims for unemployment benefits declined for the fourth straight week.
In addition, wholesale prices advanced an unexpectedly strong six-tenths of 1 percent last month. Traders dismissed the number as having been distorted by big, probably temporary, one-time increases for gasoline, vegetables and tobacco.
 
Evidence of Recovery
 The reports were widely interpreted as evidence the economy was on the road to recovery and sent the dollar higher in active trading.
"Even though inflation was higher than expected, in a perverse way that means the Federal Reserve" will not cut interest rates, and that is favorable for the dollar, said Earl Johnson, a vice president at the Harris Trust and Savings Bank in Chicago. Higher interest rates in the United States make dollar-denominated securities more valuable to investors.
The dollar continued to perform solidly against the German mark, advancing to 1.7985 marks, a 19-month high, from 1.7905 marks on Wednesday. The dollar settled off its peaks after a bout of profit taking amid rumors the central banks had intervened to stem the dollar's rise.
 
Was There Intervention?
 "People were very nervous when the dollar got above its previous highs," said John McCarthy, chief dealer at Algemene Bank Nederland. "The market behaved as if there were intervention." No central bank confirmed the intervention.
In Tokyo, the dollar rose to 141.75 yen, from 141.50 yen on Wednesday. In London, it fell to 141.35 yen. In New York, the dollar settled at 141.25 yen, down from 141.50 yen on Wednesday.
In London, the pound fell to $1.6380, from $1.6463 late Wednesday. In New York it cost $1.6345 to buy one pound, less than Wednesday's $1.6450.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Wednesday's rates, included: 1.5390 Swiss francs, up from 1.5310; 6.1030 French francs, up from 6.0720; 1,338.00 Italian lire, up from 1,330.50, and 1.1434 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1438.
Gold fell in London to a late bid of $369.50 an ounce, from $371.75 late Wednesday. In Zurich, the closing bid was $369.50, down from $371.90. Earlier in Hong Kong, gold fell $2.52 to close at $368.90.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Bank Stocks' Outlook Debated

BYLINE: By Michael Quint

 BODY:
THE market for bank stocks has been a world of extremes recently, shifting from deep gloom in the year ended in October 1990, when prices fell more than 50 percent, to euphoria in the last seven months as prices have increased more than 70 percent.
But because bank losses on commercial real estate loans continue to rise, and problems with delinquent borrowers are spreading to consumer and business loans, some analysts are questioning whether the market's optimism is justified. Securities dealers, who have already sold nearly $5 billion of new preferred and common bank stocks this year, hope the positive mood lasts long enough for them to complete several more large financings. 
 "I couldn't be more optimistic about bank stocks," said Thomas Brown, banking analyst at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Inc. Besides lower interest rates, which have helped many banks widen the spread between the interest rates they pay on deposits and the rates they collect on loans, Mr. Brown said that investors expected a lessening of problems with bad loans.
"The positive surprises have begun to outnumber the negative surprises," Mr. Brown said, forecasting that many banks would be reporting fewer problem loans by the end of the year.
Expectations of mergers among large banks have also attracted investors, who hope for either better profits when banks in the same market merge and cut costs or a high price for stocks of banks that are acquired.
Nevertheless, some anlaysts are not optimistic. They note that delinquent loans do not normally begin to decline until about six months after the end of a recession.
"The problems in commercial real estate are not going away, and there is more blood to be let at many banks," said Harry Keefe, chairman of Keefe Managers Inc., a partnership investing in banks and savings institutions.
George Salem, a banking analyst at Prudential Securities who was quicker than many to spot the banking industry's woes in 1990, calls the recent rally in bank stocks overdone. "It is premature to say the problems are over and earnings will be normal," he said, adding that loan quality was still the most important determinant of a bank's health.
Among the 23 banks that Mr. Salem follows most closely, he noted that nonperforming loans rose 12 percent in the first quarter, compared with increases of 17 percent in the fourth quarter of 1990, 14 percent in the third and 16 percent in the second. He added that bank filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission and bankers' comments indicated that nonperforming loans would continue to increase in the current quarter, which ends June 30.
Although speculative selling of bank stocks exaggerated the industry's weakness in 1990, Mr. Keefe said that several large companies still faced serious problems from their heavy lending for commercial real estate. Among them are the Southeast Banking Corporation; MNC Financial of Baltimore; Midlantic of Edison, N.J., and Shawmut National of Boston.
Consequently, many analysts are recommending only high-quality banks, like the Banc One Corporation of Columbus, Ohio, and the Wachovia Corporation in Winston-Salem, N.C. Morgan Stanley & Company recently added the National City Corporation of Cleveland and Boatmen's Bancshares of St. Louis to its recommended list, saying that both companies had ample capital, low exposure to loss from bad loans and managements that were unwilling to accept risky loans to gain a few cents profit per share.
"I think investors have discounted the fact that loan quality is not improving," said Charles M. Vincent, a bank stock investor at Provident National Bank, Philadelphia. "There is a feeling that strict examinations by regulators forced banks to anticipate their difficulties."
The reserves large banks have for loan losses, however, have become smaller relative to the growing volume of nonperforming loans and real estate owned as a result of foreclosure. Among the 35 largest banking companies, reserves for loan losses have fallen to 57 percent of nonperforming assets in the first quarter, from 60.7 percent in the fourth quarter of 1990 and 74.5 percent a year ago.
A decline in the level of reserves relative to troubled loans can be worrisome for investors, since further increases in bad loans could cause a bank to dip into its profits to increase the size of its reserve or to write off bad loans as a loss.
Kenneth F. Puglisi, senior vice president at Keefe, Bruyette & Woods Inc., said that while there was no evidence that banks' bad-loan problems were declining, many bankers had been predicting that their nonperforming loans were nearing a peak. But he warned that the optimism could quickly evaporate if "it becomes obvious that the recession will drag on into 1992."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Issues Climb in Price

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities moved higher yesterday, as analysts and traders reassessed a set of figures that on the surface suggested the recession had clearly ended and that inflation was at worrisome levels.
Initially, market participants reacted to a further drop in weekly unemployment claims, a healthy 1 percent rise in retail sales and a surprisingly sharp six-tenths of a percentage point increase in the May Producer Price Index by selling securities and pushing long-term bond yields above 8.60 percent. 
 Excluding food and energy, the index rose by a more modest four-tenths of a percentage point.
After sifting through the numbers, economists said that the rise in the so-called core rate was an aberration, since virtually all of the increase was a result of big increases in the price of tobacco and civilian aircraft.
"If you exclude those two items, the core rate was flat," one government bond trader said. "That made a lot of people feel better about buying bonds."
 
Some Worries Are Soothed
 Remarks by Robert Parry, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco, may also have soothed worries that a rebound in the economy will be accompanied by accelerating inflation.
Speaking in Anchorage, Mr. Parry, who has been a forceful advocate of tight monetary policy to curb inflation in the past, said he expects inflation to fall to a 3 percent annual rate in 1992 from a pace of 3.5 percent to 4 percent this year.
Mr. Parry added that the economic downturn appeared to have hit bottom.
"The Fed has to be very happy with these numbers, because they tell them the recovery is under way, and there is no reason to believe that inflation is accelerating," said Raymond W. Stone, a managing director at Stone & McCarthy Research Associates, a Princeton, N.J. firm that provides research and commentary on developments in the foreign exchange and credit markets.
Along with many other analysts, Mr. Stone does not expect the recovery to be very robust. Nor may it be long-lived.
"This is when the numbers are going to look the firmest," he said. "But after a few months we are in for a period when the economy will underperform the expectations of the market and of the Fed. It just does not seem that the factors that supported recoveries in the past, like fiscal stimulus or strong consumer balance sheets, are present this time."
 
The Secondary Market
 In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 8 1/8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021 were offered late yesterday at a price of 95 7/8, up 13/32, to yield 8.50 percent, down from 8.54 percent late Wednesday. Following the release of the producer price and retail sales numbers, prices on the benchmark issue fell as low as 94 22/ 32, to yield 8.62 percent.
Among Treasury note issues, the 8 percent 10-year notes were offered at a price of 97 7/8, up 1/4 point, to yield 8.31 percent. And the 6 3/4 percent two-year notes were offered at 99 1/2, up 2/ 32, to yield 7.02 percent.
Short-term Treasury bill rates were mixed.
Three-month bills were offered at a discont rate of 5.57 percent, up three basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates rose by one basis point, to a late offered rate of 5.79 percent. But one-year bill rates fell by three basis points, to a late offered rate of 5.99 percent.
Chase Manhattan's $1 billion offering of asset-backed securities highlighted new-issue activity in the investment-grade corporate bond market. But a number of other companies also priced new securities.
Among the issuers was Coca-Cola Enterprises, which offered $250 million of medium-term notes through an underwrting group led by Lehman Brothers.
The 6.80 percent notes were offered at various prices, initially at $99.957, to yield 6.85 percent, 48 basis points over the prevailing bond equivalent yield on one-year Treasury bills.
The notes, which are noncallable for life, mature June 19, 1992. The securities are rated A-2 by Moody's Investors Service and AA-minus by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
In the secondary market for investment-grade corporate bonds, traders said that prices of most issues were unchanged to up about 1/8 point at the end of a volatile session.
In the secondary market for tax-exempt municipal bonds, prices closed higher after being down early in the day. According to traders, prices of most widely quoted issues rose by about 1/4 point.
In other developments, the Federal Reserve Board reported that all three measures of the nation's money supply fell during the week ended June 3.
The declines were in line with market expectations, and the report had no impact on prices in the credit markets.

HEADLINE: Japan's Rising Trade Surplus Alarms Competitors

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, June 13

 BODY:
Despite years of pledges to open its markets to foreign goods and slow its powerful export machine, Japan's trade surplus is soaring to politically dangerous levels again after three years of decline.
Government officials have been struggling to play down the trend, particularly after new figures were released this week showing a big jump in sales of Japanese goods abroad, although exports to the United States were down slightly. 
 The officials are saying that it is still too early to tell if the trade imbalance will widen for the year. But private economists say the trade imbalance appears likely to widen in coming months, as American consumers emerge from the recession and begin snapping up Nissan cars, Panasonic stereos, Toshiba computers and other Japanese products.
 
Ready to Move Quickly
 "Japan's competitiveness has been maintained at a very high level," said Yoshihisa Kitai, chief economist at the Long-Term Credit Bank. "If a foreign market opens or improves, we are prepared to increase our exports very quickly."
In May, Japanese exports to the European Community rose 19.4 percent, to $4.9 billion, and those to Asia increased 28.4 percent, to $8.6 billion. Exports to the United States, however, declined 1 percent from a year earlier, to $6.75 billion, according to Government figures.
The statistics point out a crucial difference in the current surge: Japan has become less dependent on exports to the United States, which many Japanese are looking upon as an increasingly unreliable and often irritable trade partner, but sales to Europe and other Asian nations are growing much faster.
"What the figures show is that Japan's surplus should have been even larger in 1990, but it was depressed just by high oil prices," Mr. Kitai said, referring to the large imports of crude oil, mostly from the Persian Gulf. "The high oil prices, which have now ended, concealed the strength of the trend."
Japan's trade surplus with the European Community shot up 79 percent in May from the year earlier, to $2.2 billion. The surplus with Asia rose 43 percent from May 1990, to $2.4 billion. That is a sore point with countries like South Korea, which complain that Japan exports machinery, parts and consumer goods, but is stingy in sharing the technology behind its manufacturing prowess.
By contrast, the surplus with the United States slipped by 20 percent, to $1.95 billion, in May, a result of the recession.
It is a sign of the resilience of Japan that even with its single largest market in recession, it has succeeded in cultivating and exploiting new markets to more than make up for the loss. One trend that is continuing is that Japan's exports consist largely of manufactured goods, on which profits are high, while the growth in its imports is coming largely from raw materials, like crude oil. After declining to $63.5 billion last year, a 34 percent decline from the peak in 1987, Japan's trade surplus is expected to top $70 billion this year. Some economists, surprised by the sudden vigor of Japan's export machine, predicted it would reach $80 billion.
The recent trade figures also show that some types of imports that have grown smartly in recent years are vulnerable to changes in taste; for instance, there was a big decline in Japanese imports of French paintings and German luxury automobiles in May, as a decline in real estate and stock prices here cut back on purchases by affluent Japanese.
"I had expected some growth in the surplus, but this is quicker and bigger than I'd expected," said Paul Summerville, the economist here for Jardine Fleming Securities. "We're back where we started essentially, before all the market-opening measures. The Japanese are ready to strike again."
 
Trade Frictions Expected
 The rising surplus is expected to provoke a new round of potentially bitter trade frictions, especially with the European Community. Edith Cresson, the new Prime Minister of France, has harshly criticized Japan's export policies and what she contends are its closed markets.
Japanese officials have generally responded that the problem is the competitive ability of Japanese companies, not unfair practices. They say that in general the answer is not to protect markets but for foreign governments to act to improve the efficiency of their industries.
The latest surge in the politically sensitive trade surplus underscores the fact that even after some important adjustments to its economy over the last five years to force companies to cater more to the domestic market, Japanese companies are becoming only more efficient in competing around the globe.
 
Huge Sums Are Invested
 Throughout the late 1980's, Japanese corporations poured unprecedented sums into research, new technologies and new factories. They are now beginning to reap the rewards of that capital investment.
There was another stunning figure released here this week -- in the first five months of this year, Japanese auto companies shipped more cars back to Japan from their American plants than American auto makers sold in Japan.
It was the first time that Japan's American factories had out-exported their American rivals, General Motors, Ford and Chrysler, but probably not the last.
"This all adds up to greater acrimony ahead," Mr. Summerville said.

HEADLINE: Newly Profitable, Post Plans To Share With Its Unions

BYLINE: By ALEX S. JONES

 BODY:
Peter S. Kalikow, the owner of The New York Post, said yesterday that the paper would turn a profit this year, for the first time in decades. As a result, he said, the paper is returning to its unions up to $8 million of the $21 million in concessions they granted in September to keep the newspaper alive.
"If I eat, everybody should eat; if I don't eat, that's another story," Mr. Kalikow said, adding that he expected to see some improvements in productivity in exchange for the "partial givebacks." 
 The paper announced yesterday that members of the Newspaper Guild, which represents news, advertising and clerical employees, would now be guaranteed pay equivalent to a four-and-a-half-day work week. Last September the Guild agreed to a four-day work week to avoid layoffs.
Mr. Kalikow said The Post had retained much of the bounty of circulation and advertising that it won during The Daily News strike and predicted that, with the givebacks, The Post would show a profit in 1991 of about $14 million on revenues of about $120 million. Should that happen, it would be the first time in many years that the chronically unprofitable paper ended a year in the black.
 
Alternatives to Equity
 "If that's what he does, we certainly expect to get a piece of it," said George E. McDonald, president of the Allied Printing Trades Council, which includes all the paper's unions. In September, as part of the agreement, Mr. Kalikow promised to give unions 20 percent ownership in The Post, but negotiations on a plan to do so have stalled.
Mr. Kalikow said he believed that the unions "are entitled" to share the paper's success and suggested that profit sharing or bonuses might be more appealing to the unions than an equity stake.
In April, the first month after The News strike ended, The Post had a 29.4 percent increase in advertising compared with the same month a year earlier, according to LNA Newspaper, a company that tracks newspaper advertising.
By comparison, The News's advertising in April was down by 61.6 percent compared with 1990, The New York Times declined by 25.3 percent and Newsday, which includes New York Newsday, was down by 7.2 percent.
Mr. Kalikow said the paper's circulation was about 575,000, compared with a high of 690,000 during the News strike and about 500,000 before the strike, which lasted from October to March.
 
Large Cut in Jobs
 Barry F. Lipton, president of the Newspaper Guild local, said that employees would work an extra 2 hours and 20 minutes a week but that the added time would be considered overtime and paid at time and a half, giving them the equivalent of a half-day's pay.
Mr. Lipton said the increases were justified because the number of guild jobs had declined by about 75 since September to about 300, although the September agreement required a reduction of only 40 jobs. Temporary workers were hired to fill the gap, and Mr. Lipton said far fewer temporary workers would now be used.
Mr. McDonald said that by structuring the increase as overtime rather than by simply adding half a day to the work week, the existing contract was not broken. Extending the guild's actual work week would have broken the contract and obligated management to give the same improvements to all the other unions.
But Mr. Kalikow said other unions would get similar increases, either in the form of restored jobs or added hours. In September, in the face of an ultimatum from Mr. Kalikow, who threatened to close the paper, unions were given the choice of reducing jobs or reducing hours to cut costs. The guild chose to reduce hours, but other unions, like the Newspaper and Mail Deliverers Union of New York and Vicinity, which represents the drivers, elected to take most of the cuts by reducing jobs.
Mr. Kalikow said that about 90 drivers lost jobs in September and that about 20 had been rehired.
 
Real-Estate Company
 Mr. Lipton said he would seek the restoration of a regular five-day work week and other changes during negotiations for a new contract, which will begin this summer. The existing contract expired on March 6 but remains in effect.
Mr. Kalikow is also the owner of H. J. Kalikow & Company, a real-estate company whose holdings include 4,000 residential apartments in Manhattan, office buildings and a hotel to be called the Millenium, now under construction near the World Trade Center.
Mr. Kalikow has been under pressure from banks because of $130 million in short-term debt. He said yesterday that he thinks his creditors, which include many New York banks, will be willing to extend the payback period rather than requiring him to sell assets at the current depressed prices. The recession and concerns about the failure of many savings and loan organizations has made lending institutions very reluctant to refinance debt.

HEADLINE: In Quaint Nyack, Not-So-Quaint Condos and G-Strings

BYLINE: By LISA W. FODERARO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NYACK, N.Y.

 BODY:
When this antiquing center on the Hudson courted a developer years ago to build waterfront housing, residents envisioned some tasteful condominiums in keeping with the village's Victorian character.
What they have instead are pink and blue monoliths at the foot of Main Street that seem to scream modern-day Miami Beach more than whisper mid-19th century New England. "It cuts us off from the waterfront and it's visually intrusive," said Nyack's Mayor, Kieran Quinn. "This has just been a disaster." 
 Nyack is not alone, of course, in feeling overwhelmed by development. But to this one-square-mile village, quaintness is more than quality of life; it's also a bread-and-butter issue. The economy hinges on tourism and the village's ability to attract weekend shoppers wishing to take a step back in time.
 
Topless Dancers and a Drug Center
 The frustration over the condominiums and how they grew is just one symptom of a growing identity crisis for Nyack, once a down-at-the-heels village victimized by the creation of a nearby mall and now a thriving town. There is, for example, the new bar with bare-breasted dancers -- a dubious symbol of Nyack's distinction as the entertainment capital of Rockland County. Another newcomer getting a mixed reception is a 250-bed drug-treatment center.
Clermont, the unfinished condominiums on the riverbank, was approved in 1985 by officials who have since been voted out of office for just that reason. Phase One, with 41 condominiums, is occupied; only a few floors high, it remains relatively unobtrusive.
But the second phase, with eight floors, looms as a veritable skyscraper. Although virtually complete, the apartments sit empty without generating tax revenue because the developer, Nyack Waterfront Associates, went broke after defaulting on its loans.
Phase Three is unbuilt and tangled up in court. After seeing the size of the second portion, the Village Board of Trustees rezoned its riverfront, limiting the height of buildings to 45 feet.
The financier, the United Brotherhood of Carpenters and Joiners of America, which is trying to foreclose, has sued the village, saying the zoning change drastically reduced the number of apartments it could build -- and thus its potential profits.
 
2 Views, One of Them Lovely
 The residents of Clermont's completed condominiums do not know how long they will have to live next to a construction site. "They look out one window and see the beautiful Hudson River," said Terry Hekker, a village trustee, "and then they look the other way and see a tangle of weeds, rubble and puddles."
As part of Nyack's metamorphosis over the last 15 years, restaurants, theaters and music clubs moved in, bringing night life to a community that used to close when the sun went down.
For many residents, that night life became a nightmare in August in the form of Fantasy Island, a bar with mirrors, neon and a half dozen women in G-strings gyrating from noon to 4 A.M. Worse, it opened right on Main Street -- across from a Baptist church.
The bar books only top-flight entertainment; a Penthouse cover girl danced there last month, as did Miss Poland of 1990. Most Nyackers seem unimpressed.
 
'It Just Doesn't Belong'
 "I think it's disgraceful," said Lorraine Buono, a village postal clerk. "It just doesn't belong in a small town."
Village officials agreed, and are drafting an ordinance that will control where adults can be entertained in the future.
The village is struggling to reconcile itself with another newcomer: a major drug-treatment center. "The consensus is that it's a wonderful thing, but why does it have to be in our backyard?" said Todd Retallack, who owns a computer graphics business here.
In early 1990, Daytop Village Inc., a nonprofit corporation with 18 drug-treatment centers in New York, bought an ailing motel and banquet hall and undertook a $350,000 renovation.
A few months later, the village won an injunction preventing Daytop from admitting addicts. Nyack argued that Daytop, which is licensed by the state, could not override local zoning laws. "The zone is commercial, and residential-treatment centers are clearly not commercial," Mayor Quinn said.
Late last month, though, the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court ruled in Daytop's favor, and Daytop immediately started accepting clients. Nyack is planning to appeal, and is claiming that Daytop is in contempt because it is operating before the issue is settled.
The village government is concerned because the town has lost a major employer; the banquet hall provided about 150 jobs, while Daytop will provide 30 or 40.
Nyack also has a decades-old drug trade, with dealers openly peddling crack at the notorious corner of Franklin Street and Depew Avenue. Some believe that it could prove too great a temptation for those in the treatment center.
"It's like putting a Weight Watchers next to a Ben & Jerry's," said Mrs. Hekker, who is also president of the Nyack Chamber of Commerce.
But for Monsignor William B. O'Brien, the president of Daytop Village, the location is ideal. "It's an isolated site, and that's why the place never flew as a motel," he said. "Across the state, local zoning will not let in any drug-treatment center unless it's on an island with sharks in the water."

HEADLINE: Vehicle Sales Rose 9.4% In Early June

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, June 13

 BODY:
An especially strong performance by the General Motors Corporation helped raise sales of domestically built cars and light trucks 9.4 percent in early June.
Although sales are still relatively weak and analysts predict that auto makers may be forced to trim their third-quarter production schedules, the latest numbers suggest that the United States automotive market continues slowly to gain strength. 
 "These numbers give greater confidence that sales may have bottomed, and we're on our way up," said Harvey Heinbach, automotive analyst for Merrill Lynch & Company in New York.
Tom Webb, an economist for the National Automobile Dealers Association, called the numbers "very encouraging."
The seasonally adjusted annual rate of car sales for the June 1-10 period was 6.3 million, compared with 6.4 million during the corresponding period last year and 6.6 million in late May. Because of variations in seasonal-adjustment factors, comparisons of the annual sales rates do not necessarily correspond to changes in periodic sales figures.
The nine auto makers, made up of American companies and Japanese concerns with North American plants, sold 266,250 vehicles in the period, compared with 243,297 a year ago. This year's total includes an estimate for sales of the Chrysler Corporation, which reports only once a month. Overall car sales were 166,318, a 10 percent increase over last year's 151,157, and light-truck sales were 99,932, an 8.5 percent increase over last year's 92,140.
G.M., the industry leader, posted a 17.8 percent gain in car sales, to 84,570, from 71,810 last year, and an 11.4 percent rise in truck sales, to 41,111, from 36,906 last year.
Arlene Reindel, a spokeswoman for G.M.'s Chevrolet division, said the company sees "a glimmer" of recovery in retail sales, as well as increased fleet sales. She noted that Chevy's 10.6 percent gain partly reflected a comparison with a weak period last year and recent increases in buyer incentives.
The Ford Motor Company's car sales were down 1.4 percent, to 43,017, while truck sales were down two-tenths of 1 percent, to 33,103. Joel Pitcoff, a Ford sales analyst, said sales remained far from robust and showed few signs of a quick recovery. "We're still in a channel, although on the top side of the channel," he said. "I'd feel better when we have a period with a seven million" seasonally adjusted annual rate of car sales. Light-truck sales, he said, are showing steady, but slight, improvement.
The Honda Motor Company, the Nissan Motor Company and the Toyota Motor Corporation each had strong gains in sales of American-produced cars. Honda was up 14 percent, to 10,321; Toyota was up 28.7 percent, to 4,943, and Nissan was up 23.5 percent, to 1,874.
A statement from Toyota said sales of its new 1992 Tercel subcompact and new Lexus SC 400 coupe were particularly strong.
 
Need for Cutbacks Is Seen
 Ronald Glantz, automotive analyst for Dean Witter in San Francisco, said that at the current sales rate, auto makers must cut 200,000 vehicles from their scheduled production of 2,234,000 in the three months starting in July.
"Sales are on an upward curve, but not on a vigorous enough rebound to justify what the auto makers are planning," Mr. Glantz said.
Still, Ward's Automotive Reports said the inventory of cars and light trucks had fallen below three million for the first time in eight months, allowing auto makers to keep factories running at a fast pace. This week, for example, 4 plants are idle and 18 are on one-shift operation, out of 80 North American car and truck plants; of the 4 idle plants, 3 were closed for model change-over.
So far this year, auto makers have assembled 4,342,831 vehicles, compared with 5,125,982 last year, a decline of 15.3 percent.

HEADLINE: Producer Prices Rose 0.6% in May

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 13

 BODY:
Inflation at the wholesale level rose a sharp six-tenths of 1 percent in May, the steepest rise since October, the Labor Department said today.
A 2.4 percent spurt in energy costs, after five months of falling prices, accounted for much of the gain. 
 The sharp increase followed a gain of two-tenths of 1 percent in April and was the highest since a 1.2 percent gain in October.
The May rise brings the wholesale inflation rate for the last 12 months to 3.4 percent; the increase for all of 1990 was 5.7 percent.
After subtracting food and energy costs, which can vary widely each month, the Producer Price Index for Finished Goods still rose at a moderately fast clip of four-tenths of 1 percent, compared with a two-tenths rise in April.
The figures were much higher than expected. Wall Street analysts had generally been predicting a rise of three-tenths of 1 percent in the overall index and two-tenths in the core rate that excludes food and energy.
The acceleration in wholesale inflation as the recession winds down may send warning signals to the Federal Reserve Board, although a change in its monetary policy seems unlikely, analysts said.
The central bank, after easing earlier this year to stimulate growth, has held interest rates steady in recent weeks as evidence mounted that the economy is poised for recovery.
 
Variety of Factors
 Companies resumed hiring in May, car sales turned up again late last month and the housing market is strengthening. The pickup in the inflation rate may be another sign that recession is all but over, as demand arises again, adding to price pressure, analysts said.
But the May report held out some hope for moderation in wholesale inflation in coming months.
The cost of goods in need of further processing fell one-tenth of 1 percent in May after a drop of four-tenths in April. Crude goods, those just entering the refining process, were unchanged after a decline of five-tenths of 1 percent in April.
These declines may provide some relief in the next few finished-goods reports. Still, the biggest influence on the finished index is labor costs, and wages have not retreated notably during this recession.

HEADLINE: Summit Meeting Is Not Expected Before the Fall

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 13

 BODY:
President Bush's summit meeting with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union, originally scheduled for June, is now unlikely to take place until fall, a senior White House official said today.
The talks, which would be held in Moscow, are contingent upon a strategic arms agreement, and the official said that was not yet in sight. 
 If, unexpectedly, Moscow were to accept American proposals in the next few days, Mr. Bush could still travel to the Soviet Union late next month, after the leaders of the Group of Seven industrial democracies meet in London in mid-July and he visits Turkey and Greece, aides said, but they described that as highly improbable.
Mr. Bush will be on vacation in Maine for much of August.
By indicating that the timetable was again slipping for the Moscow meeting, at which Mr. Gorbachev hopes to gain further American aid for his foundering economy, the White House brought new pressure on the Soviets to make an acceptable deal on strategic arms.
 
Meeting With Yeltsin
 At the same time, the White House spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, announced that Mr. Bush would meet next Thursday in the Oval Office with Boris N. Yeltsin, who this week became the first popularly chosen president of the Russian republic. He is coming at the invitation of Congressional leaders, so as not to embarrass Mr. Gorbachev, with whom he has publicly clashed, but the senior official said Mr. Yeltsin's conversations with Mr. Bush would be substantive, not perfunctory.
Mr. Yeltsin, a swashbuckling populist who quit the Communist Party, now advocates much more far-reaching reform than Mr. Gorbachev.
"President Gorbachev of course leads the Soviet Union and all the republics and Yeltsin now becomes President of the Russian republic," Mr. Fitzwater said, trying to play down any suggestion of conflict. "Their relationship is pretty well established by law. We don't want to get into a comparison of the two men, but in terms of the process, this election is very important."
But the situation facing Mr. Bush is in fact more complicated than that.
Although the two men have for the moment patched up their differences, a deadly rivalry persists, and President Bush, who has made clear his determination to help Mr. Gorbachev survive, does not want to seem to be favoring Mr. Yeltsin. But at the same time, he cannot appear to snub a man who has just won a stunning popular mandate.
"The fundamental issue," a senior White House aide said, "is that you don't want to weaken the capacity of the system to move forward toward reform. You don't want to undercut the process leading to change, and that process is of course run by the central Government."
The annual conference of the leaders of the seven most powerful industrial democracies -- the United States, Japan, Germany, France, Italy, Canada and Britain -- will begin on Monday, July 15, and endwith a joint briefing on Wednesday, July 17. Then, according to an announcement made in London today by Prime Minister John Major, Mr. Gorbachev will have lunch and meet informally with the leaders.
Thus Mr. Gorbachev will not be an official participant in the conference. The United States and Britain at first opposed inviting him at all, but their partners wanted to, and the senior White House official said today that "at some point, the absence of an invitation threatens to skew the agenda more severely than the invitation itself would skew it."
