HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Air War in the Credit Card Battle

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ

 BODY:
In its latest counterattack against growing challenges from Visa and Mastercard, the American Express Company said yesterday that it would sharply expand the ways travelers could accumulate frequent-flier credits.
As do competing bank "affinity cards" with ties to airlines, American Express will give its card holders one frequent-flier mile for every dollar they charge on their Green, Gold, Platinum, Optima and Corporate cards. Any purchase, whether it be flowers, sweaters, college tuition or vacations, earns the miles, which are redeemable for free airline tickets or ticket upgrades to first class. 
 But American Express's program, the company's first ever, hopes to spur both business travel and consumer spending, slowed by the recession, by offering some extras. For example, card holders could pool into a kind of "bank" the credits they buy with any version of the American Express card. Charges made on cards of the members' spouses and families count as well. Perhaps most significantly, the card holders could then allocate the pooled credits to as many as seven airlines, instead of one per card, as with present bank-card programs.
The Membership Miles program, as its called, will be free the first year, but will cost $25 the second year.
The arrangements between bank cards and airlines have proved to be one of the most effective marketing tools in the sharply competitive travel and credit card businesses. Competition among credit card issuers of all kinds has risen in recent years, as a glut of cards and a similarity of services, like rental-car damage insurance, have forced issuers to offer more and more incentives for using their particular form of plastic. The recession's effects on both consumers and businesses have intensified that trend.
As the slump hurt the restaurant business, for instance, restaurateurs began to complain about the fee American Express charged merchants who accepted its cards because the percentage was generally higher than that of Visa and Mastercard. Earlier this year, American Express reduced the fee for some merchants.
American Express has not been alone. Last March, Citibank, the nation's largest issuer of Visa and Mastercards, said it would guarantee, through a form of rebate, that purchases of most items using its cards were at the lowest available price.
 
Profits Down
 In April, American Express announced a quarterly profit drop for the Travel-Related Services, which is mainly the credit card business, to $162 million, from $215 million a year earlier. Quarterly charge-card volume fell 1.3 percent, to $25.4 billion.
Company officials cited a white-collar recession that slowed consumer spending and raised bad debts among its generally middle- to upper-class card holders.
"It will be expensive, but necessary," said David F. Robertson, president of the Nilson Report, a credit card industry publication. "American Express needs to increase sales from their upscale customers."
American Express, which once enjoyed nearly all of the market for airline tickets, has been steadily losing business to bank cards affiliated with major airlines. Frequent-flier programs, which flourished in the 1980's, were designed to build customer loyalty to airlines.
The air carriers in the new American Express program are Delta Air Lines, Northwest, Continental, Southwest, MGM Grand Air, Midway and Pan American. They carry nearly half of United States air traffic. In addition, they have 24 affiliated airlines, many of them foreign carriers like KLM Royal Dutch Airlines and Singapore Air, which could yield additional travel awards under existing programs.
Delta, which did not previously have an affinity card, said the structure of the American Express program was attractive. "We've always resisted entering these programs, because we just didn't think it was right to get tickets by charging tires and what all," said Neil A. Monroe, a Delta spokesman, "But the difference here is that we're getting paid, which is nice, and we're only one of seven."
 
'Premier Affinity Card'
 American Express program does not include American Airlines and United Airlines, the nation's two largest carriers. Still, experts on frequent-flier incentives hailed the American Express program. "American Express has instantly become the premier affinity card with this program," said Randy Petersen, editor of Frequent, a Colorado Springs, newsletter for frequent travelers.
Joe Brancatelli, executive editor of OAG Frequent Flyer magazine, agreed, but said, referring to the absence of American and United, "Thirty-six percent of my readers won't be able to cash in on it."
Referring to his company's affiliation with American Airlines, James L. Bailey, senior executive in charge of Citibank Visa and Mastercard, said: "This is a marriage. We expect it to be monogamous."
American Airlines agreed. "We're happy with the relationship," said Martin P. Heires, a spokesman for American. Sara Dornacker, a United spokeswoman, said the carrier considered the American Express program a competitor to its own card with First Chicago bank and therefore did not want to participate.
Today, American Express has a nearly 42 percent share of the market for airline tickets, while Visa has nearly 20 percent, according to the Nilson Report.
 
Big Spenders
 The affinity cards appeal strongly to frequent fliers, who tend to spend many times more than typical credit card holders. The Nilson Report estimates that United Airlines' affinity cardholders spend as much as three times more and American Airlines card holders as much as seven times more than a typical gold Visa card holder who spends $2,600 annually.
"Our new program will encourage people to spend as much as possible with American Express," said Kenneth I. Chenault, president of the consumer card group.
Typically, under these programs, a bank buys frequent-flier miles, at a penny or less per mile, from the airlines. American Express may pay cash but could also trade services, like cooperative advertising, to reduce expenses for the program, which analysts said could be costly in its first years.
Mr. Chenault would say only that "American Express is not structuring this program as a loss leader," meaning a money-losing incentive.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Predicting When Upturn Will Start

BYLINE: By Leonard Silk

 BODY:
ECONOMISTS once thought that by using computers and large-scale econometric models, they could develop tools for more accurate forecasting. But such hopes have given way to the more humble belief that the best they can do is to state what they think are the odds on various possible developments ("scenarios" in the current economic jargon). The problem of macroeconomic forecasting has been made even more difficult by the complex interactions between national economies and the world economy.
Prof. Rudiger Dornbusch of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology says the world economy is now in the midst of a "significant slowdown," with outright recession in the Anglo-Saxon countries and minimal growth in Europe, except Germany. Only Asia is keeping up the momentum of world growth, but even there Japan's growth rate is slipping below 4 percent. 
 The most important questions about the world economy, he says, focus on the United States and Germany: Will the United States come out of the recession in the next few months, and can Germany resolve its inflation problem before a sharp slowdown sets in and topples the rest of continental Europe? He lays out three "plausible scenarios:"
*Optimistic: The American recession touched bottom in the April-June quarter and the recovery is starting. Germany cuts its interest rates this summer and Europe enters an upswing by late fall. (30 percent probability).
*Pessimistic: The United States recession is far more durable than the consensus of economists expects, because taxes are too high, debt keeps consumers and businesses from buying durable goods and the Federal Reserve is too slow and provides inadequate stimulus to turn the economy around. Germany's inflation proves a hard nut to crack. There's a serious chance of world recession by fall and no turnaround before the middle of next year. (20 percent probability).
*Central scenario: The United States recovery is about ready to start. Germany, preoccupied with inflation, lets Europe slip to the edge of recession. The disparity between a recovering United States economy and a declining Europe puts upward pressure on the dollar, complicating Europe's inflation problem and slowing American growth down the road. (50 percent probability).
These three add up to 100 percent, implying that no other outcome is possible. For different combinations of United States recession and recovery, Professor Dornbusch sets up a grid of four probabilities: deep recession-weak recovery, 5 percent; shallow recession-weak recovery, 50 percent; deep recession-strong recovery, 15 percent; shallow recession-strong recovery, 30 percent.
Most other economists' forecasts fall within the shallow recession-weak recovery scenario. Thus, Blue Chip Economic Indicators' June 1991 survey of 52 economists finds more than 8 out of 10 predicting an end to the recession by August (with nearly 4 out of 10 saying it ended in April or May). And the Blue Chip consensus forecasts a 1992 growth rate of real G.N.P. of just 2.7 percent, a recovery so weak as to mean virtually no change in unemployment. The top 10 of the Blue Chip forecasters average real economic growth of 3.5 percent next year, and the bottom 10 average 1.9 percent growth. None of the 52 surveyed see either a boom or a crash in '92.
The world economy appears weak but not hopeless in the eyes of its beholders. The Conference Board, drawing on indexes compiled by Columbia University's Center for International Business Cycle Research, finds that the global business cycle continues to show "widespread but moderate recessionary trends." The board's composite leading index for 11 major industrial countries is declining at an annual rate of 3 percent.
But that rate of decline represents a one percentage point improvement from three months ago. "You have to look carefully, but there are a few signs of optimism scattered among the data," says Edgar R. Fiedler, vice president and economic counselor of the board. "The indications of a turnaround are not strong enough to suggest that a recovery in the global business cycle is around the corner, but they do relieve the gloom somewhat."
For the developing countries, the World Bank offers three scenarios: a "baseline scenario" that is moderately better than the "lost decade" of the 1980's; a "low-case scenario," with turbulence in international trading and financial systems and a much higher level of real interest rates, and a "high-case scenario," in which challenges are successfully met, reducing uncertainty and spurring further integration of the global economy.
"The plausible range of growth estimates for the developing countries in the 1990's is therefore wide: from less than 3 percent a year to well over 6 percent," says the World Bank report on Global Economic Prospects. "This range translates into a 40 percent difference in the level of real income by the year 2000."
That's a big spread, like those in other probabilistic forecasting scenarios. Given the economic, financial and political interests of most forecasters, their collective bias is toward minimizing anxiety and maximizing hope. But there are the constraints of the facts. The real payoff in forecasting is to be right.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
J. C. Penney Fires Ayer After 8 Years and Hires Bozell

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott

 BODY:
THE J. C. Penney Company yesterday abruptly dismissed Ayer Inc., its agency for eight years, and hired Bozell Inc.
Executives of the nation's fourth-largest retailer said the change, effective Oct. 1, was unrelated to the quality of Ayer's award-winning work. Instead, they said, they were drawn to the abilities of Bozell/Southwest, as Bozell's Dallas office is known. 
 While "we've been very pleased over the years with our relationship with Ayer," Robert B. Gill, Penney's vice chairman and chief operating officer, said in a telephone interview from Dallas, "the main thrust is that the resources down here available to us through Bozell are substantially larger and more in depth than what we could have."
At 450 employees, Bozell/Southwest's office is 10 times the size of Ayer's office in Dallas, which opened in 1988 to serve Penney after the retailer moved its corporate headquarters from New York.
Though Mr. Gill said the recession was not a factor in Penney's decision to change agencies, the soft retail environment is slowing Penney's ambitious program to change the company's image among shoppers. Once a plain-vanilla merchandiser of everything from ties to tires, Penney has in the last decade strived to transform itself into a modish national department-store chain concentrating on apparel. But during the recession, Penney's same-store sales growth has been hurt as many of its present or potential customers turned to discount retailers.
Penney's sales this year "have been disappointing, as have those for most of the recession-sensitive retail industry," said a memo distributed to Ayer employees. "At times like this, an advertising agency's prior record of success is easily forgotten."
A national image campaign that Ayer created soon after it became Penney's agency in 1983, "You're looking smarter than ever," is credited by retail analysts as helping change consumer perceptions of Penney. A replacement campaign, "Fashion comes to life." was introduced last year.
Penney's billings this year were to total $45.6 million, said Ayer's New York-based top executives, who are deeply disappointed by yet another large account loss. And the timing could not have been worse: Penney's announcement came as another client, The National Sports Daily, announced that it was going out of business.
"We've had nothing but praise from Penney," Jerry J. Siano, Ayer's chairman and chief executive, said at a news conference in his Manhattan office. "It's discouraging. It's just not understandable. What else can I say?" Mr. Siano and Thomas F. Maxey, vice chairman, deferred questions about the fate of their Dallas employees, who might seek additional accounts there to add to a now bittersweet recent addition, the Dallas Chamber of Commerce.
Penney's shift brings to an estimated $600 million the value of the important national accounts being reassigned, or placed in review, since the recession began in July. Almost every client involved in this unusual spate of switching finds itself fighting fiercely for ever-scarcer consumer dollars. Among them: American Isuzu Motors, Avis, Club Med, Reebok, Subaru of America and Vons supermarkets.
At Ayer, Penney's loss is the latest in a skein exceeding $200 million, including Burger King, Continental Airlines and Citicorp's New York branch banking.
"It's no secret that Bozell has been courting the business ever since Penney moved from New York to Dallas," Mr. Maxey said. Bozell last year was named Penney's agency for a cable television shopping channel that was later discontinued.
 Liener Temerlin, Bozell's chairman, chuckled at a characterization of Bozell as nipping at Ayer's heels for Penney's favor. During a telephone interview from Dallas, where he is based, Mr. Temerlin described Bozell as having tried "to let them know who we are and what we can do." The cable account "gave us a chance to flex some creative muscles," he added. The Penney victory gives Bozell/Southwest the accounts of four of the five largest corporations with Dallas headquarters, Mr. Temerlin said, including American Airlines and Texas Instruments. And it brings Bozell/Southwest billings to $380 million, he added. That is very close to the billings of the largest of Bozell's nine full-service United States offices, the New York headquarters office.
In addition to the spending coordinated through Penney's agency, the retailer also spends an estimated $275 million a year on advertising, like circulars, created in-house. Penney's total spending, at around $320 million, makes it the nation's 27th-largest advertiser.

HEADLINE: Some Signs Of Rebound In Economy

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR

 BODY:
Consumers came back to the malls in May, and fewer people filed unemployment claims in the third week of the month, according to Government reports released yesterday. Many economists reacted by declaring that the recession had ended and that the economy had begun to recover.
"Consumers led the economy into recession," said James E. Annable, chief economist at First National Bank of Chicago. "They almost certainly led us out this spring," 
 President Bush's chief economic adviser, Michael J. Boskin, was more circumspect: "It appears that we have begun to see early signs of a recovery, but we will need to see continued improvement in the data before we can be absolutely sure. The recovery won't occur at the same time and pace for all sectors of the economy."
 
Some Inflation Worries
 The auto sector showed signs of health in early June, with sales up nearly 10 percent. But the upbeat mood was dampened by some inflation worries arising from a report yesterday that wholesale prices increased six-tenths of 1 percent last month, about twice the rate analysts had expected. [Page D4.]
Still, now that the burning question of when the recession will end has been settled in many economists' minds, attention has abruptly shifted to the probable strength and durability of a recovery.
The consensus leans toward a rather benign outlook: a moderate upswing for the first several quarters of the expansion. Growth would be far slower than in the average recovery but speedy enough to whittle down the unemployment rate.
A bit of dissent has come from Federal Reserve officials, including Alan Greenpsan, the chairman, who have suggested in recent days that the chief risk to the consensus forecast is that the economy could bounce back more robustly.
 
Fear of Sluggishness
 A more widespread worry, however, is that growth will be so sluggish that joblessness will continue creeping up into 1992, said Martin S. Feldstein, president of the National Bureau of Economic Research. That could happen if annual growth is much below 2.5 percent or 3 percent, and if, as typically happens when the economy emerges from recession, many more Americans start hunting for jobs.
"I am concerned that the recovery may not be sustainable," Mr. Feldstein said.
For now, however, confident consumers are reaching into their pockets again. According to the Commerce Department's preliminary report on May retail sales, spending surged 1 percent before adjusting for inflation.
Consumers spent freely on clothing and furniture, two categories not strictly considered necessities, said James S. Fralick, an economist at Morgan Stanley & Company. Spending on clothing shot up 2.4 percent; furniture, 1.5 percent, and on department-store items, seven-tenths of 1 percent.
The implication of all these figures is that consumer spending, in inflation-adjusted terms, turned positive for the first time since last summer.
 
Analyzing the Price Data
 The weekly report on unemployment claims showed a sharp drop, to 401,000, the lowest since January. The report was yet another sign that the labor market has stabilized and that consumers' income is rising, said Mr. Annable of First Chicago.
Yesterday's report on producer prices was not as dreadful as it looked at first glance. Most of the six-tenths of 1 percent jump in May reflected a surge in energy and food prices, the Government reported.
The core rate, which excludes food and energy costs, was up four-tenths of 1 percent, but about half of that could be traced to a seasonal rise in tobacco prices that Mr. Boskin and several private economists called a one-time increase.
Nevertheless, the price report disappointed those seeking evidence that the recession had cooled inflation, which has been bobbing around an annual rate of 4.5 percent for several years.
Until there is evidence that such price increases will not be repeated in coming months, the Federal Reserve is unlikely to ease monetary policy further. The central bank last eased in late April.

HEADLINE: NCR Revamping A.T.& T. Computer Unit

BYLINE: By EBEN SHAPIRO

 BODY:
The dismantling of A.T.& T.'s computer business began yesterday, as Gilbert P. Williamson, the president of NCR, told the American Telephone and Telegraph Company's computer systems sales force that the companies' combined computer business would be based on NCR computers introduced last fall.
Mr. Williamson said no decisions had been made on how many jobs would be cut because of the merger of the companies. Last month, after a five-month takeover battle, NCR agreed to be acquired by the phone company for $7.48 billion in stock. 
 Although the deal is not expected to be completed until the fall, the companies have been working aggressively to meld their operations. A.T.& T. has lost several billion dollars in the computer business in the last six years, and NCR, the nation's fifth-largest computer company, was expected to dominate the computer operations.
"For this merger to work, these guys have to move fast and make decisions quickly, and they are doing that," said Wes Melling, an analyst at the Gartner Group in Stamford, Conn.
People who follow the computer industry said the phone company was allowing NCR executives a considerable degree of control in setting the strategy.
"It is interesting to see how NCR has been able to hang on to a lot of key technologies at the expense of some of the A.T.& T. technologies," said Stuart Woodring, an analyst with Forrester Research in Cambridge, Mass.
For instance, both the phone company and NCR have actively been promoting software systems designed to manage the flow of data at large corporations. The NCR software package, called Cooperation, will be offered by the combined company; A.T.& T.'s Rhapsody software will not. Cooperation, however, will incorporate some elements of Rhapsody, which A.T.& T. spent years developing.
"It is surprising that a parent who is essentially acquiring another company would agree to such a drastic change of long-term strategy," Mr. Woodring said.
NCR said it would continue to support existing A.T.& T. computers, while converting customers to NCR systems over the next several years. But analysts said some customers might choose to switch suppliers.
Several A.T.& T. products, including the Safari, a recently introduced and well-regarded laptop computer, and some A.T.& T. equipment for building data networks, will play a role in the combined company.
Merging high-technology companies has not always gone well, but so far, analysts said, the phone company was doing a good job.
"There is the question of the emotional investment in products as well as political ramifications," Mr. Woodring said. "A.T.& T. did a great job of keeping those things to a minimum."

HEADLINE: Bargain Pitched to the West: $100 Billion for Soviet Reform

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL

 BODY:
If the West really wants the Soviet Union to plunge into democratic capitalism, a team of Soviet and American scholars says, it should be prepared to cushion the shock with at least $100 billion in aid over five years.
The team's proposal for a "grand bargain" -- large-scale aid tied to a radical transformation of the Soviet Government and economy -- is to be delivered to the White House and the Kremlin this weekend. 
 A group of experts on revamping socialist economies cobbled the plan together over the last few weeks at Harvard's Kennedy School of Government. They have no formal ties with their governments, and neither President Mikhail S. Gorbachev nor the leaders of the Western alliance have even endorsed the concept.
But with the Soviet economy in a free fall and the nation fracturing along a dozen ethnic lines, this initial detailed version of the grand bargain is bound to be the subject of spirited debate at the economic summit meeting of the leading Western industrialized nations in July.
 
Pressure for Democracy
 The proposal, parts of which were outlined in the Financial Times, requires the Soviet Union to honor its commitments to democracy and decentralization to qualify for aid. The Government has promised to hold democratic elections next year and to seek a division of political authority acceptable to republics that choose to stay in the union.
Jeffrey Sachs, one of two American economists in the group and an architect of the "shock therapy" plan adopted by Poland, said in an interview that no reform would work unless the republics conceded a need to adopt a common currency and guarantee free movement of people, goods and resources across the nation.
Moscow would also need to retain its power to control the money supply, regulate foreign trade and raise revenue.
Soviet policy makers would also be encouraged to move promptly to prevent economic chaos. The Harvard group wants the Kremlin to raise consumer prices now to relieve chronic shortages and to reduce ballooning budget deficits. The group also wants a speedy Soviet commitment to privatize small businesses, which could fill some of the needs no longer met by collapsing state enterprises.
No Western aid would be provided for six to nine months while the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank studied the Soviet economy in detail. Once international lenders can collect reliable economic statistics, they would provide cash to cushion the blow of overnight changes. A critical first step is to break inflation by cutting Government subsidies and preventing state banks from printing money to cover the deficits of Soviet enterprises.
 
Market Reforms
 With a few exceptions, notably in the energy sector, price controls would be lifted. Subsistence living standards would be guaranteed by rationing very limited quantities of consumer staples at heavily subsidized prices. Those who wanted more than, say, a few pounds of sugar a month, would have to pay the full cost in rubles.
The ruble would be made freely convertible into foreign currencies at an exchange rate that would give Soviet enterprises at least a chance to compete in global markets. To prevent a run against the ruble, international lenders would back the Soviet currency with a multibillion-dollar line of credit.
Stanley Fischer, the former chief economist of the World Bank and the other American economist in the planning group, sees this dash to convertibility as crucial to broader reforms. Early access to imported goods, he said, would send signals on realistic prices to the country's domestic producers, who have never been able to calculate their costs. Competition from imports would also help deter huge Soviet enterprises from exploiting their monopoly power.
 
Loans at Competitive Rates
 State banks would be required to act like profit-making institutions, offering loans at competitive interest rates to public and private enterprises. In most cases, enterprises that were not creditworthy would be allowed to fail.
The planners assume that such shock therapy would lead to a sharp fall in production. And with the Government out of the business of wholesale distribution, some of what is produced might never make it to market. Much of the Western aid provided in the first few years would be needed to fill the gaps, for example, through imports of consumer staples and scarce industrial parts.
With all of the major reforms adopted, the initial shock would last about two and a half years. Then the emphasis would shift to nurturing the market economy through its infancy.
While some industrial giants might be privatized in the first few years, Eastern Europe's experience suggests that the process is far too difficult and politically sensitive to complete rapidly. To end monopolies, the largest enterprises would be broken up before their shares were parceled out to the public.
 
Loans for Nation's Arteries
 The focus of aid would change by the third year from covering deficits in the Soviet balance of payments to providing project loans. Much of the cash would support improvements that could not attract private capital from abroad, like pollution control, transportation and telecommunications projects, Mr. Sachs suggested.
The appeal of a dramatic rescue effort has grown in the last few months as the Soviet economy has unraveled and half-measures have failed. But the grand bargain still faces bitter opposition from many quarters.
Senator Bill Bradley, Democrat of New Jersey, an influential voice in the legislative debate on Soviet issues, sees it as throwing good money after bad. It would be "an act of delusion," he said last week, to send more American wheat to Moscow when less than half of the grain grown in the Soviet Union reaches consumers.
Like many academic specialists, Padma Desai, an economist at Columbia University's Harriman Institute, thinks the grand bargain is "neither feasible nor necessary." She wonders why the dying Soviet empire rates such generosity. Ms. Desai believes that large-scale aid would come at the expense of more worthy developing economies in Latin America, Africa and Asia.
 
Penny-Wise Objections?
 Graham Allison and Robert Blackwill, political scientists at the Kennedy School and members of the planning group, dismiss these arguments as penny-wise.
"The Soviet Union is and will remain a great power," they write in the current issue of Foreign Affairs. They argue that the cost of the grand bargain pales beside the costs of defending American interests against a hostile military giant.
In any case, Mr. Sachs said, the costs of the plan must be put into perspective. A $100 billion package amounts to roughly the same amount of aid per person as the current Western aid commitment to Eastern Europe.
He argues that only small results can be expected if Western aid amounts to small change. A dribble of cash here, a trade benefit there, he thinks, will only delay the commissars' day of reckoning.

HEADLINE: NEWS SUMMARY

 BODY:

International A3-11

HEADLINE: Bill Is Passed To Extend Regulations For Rents

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, June 13

 BODY:
Resisting a strong push from landlord groups to revise the laws that limit rent increases on one million apartments in New York City and some surrounding counties, lawmakers approved a bill today that simply extends the current regulations for two years.
In what has become something of a spring ritual here every two years, the extension of the rent-stabilization law remained in limbo until the 11th hour. Officials said there were never any serious questions about the protections remaining in force for the vast majority of rent-stabilized apartments. 
 But this year there was more discussion than in the past about "luxury decontrol" of certain higher-priced apartments, like those renting for more than $1,000 a month.
Landlords have lobbied strongly for such changes, arguing that the current laws give an unnecessary subsidy to many wealthy New Yorkers and that decontrol would help the city's budget problems by bringing in more tax revenue from higher rents.
 
Bitter Opposition
 "There's $100 million out there," John J. Gilbert 3d, president of the Rent Stabilization Association, a landlord group that has sued to end some of the rent laws, said, referring to his estimate of the increased taxes. Under decontrol, landlords would be free to charge whatever the market would bear.
But such proposals have run into bitter opposition from tenant groups and the Democratic-led State Assembly, who say many New Yorkers living in $1,000-a-month apartments would not qualify as wealthy.
Noting the declining economy, the Assembly's Housing Committee chairman, Alexander B. Grannis, a Manhattan Democrat, said, "This is not the year to be playing chicken with people's security in their homes."
Although there seems to be some sympathy for landlord concerns in the Republican-controlled State Senate, the six Republican Senators from New York City argued vigorously for the extension. Senator Roy M. Goodman, Republican of Manhattan, said there might eventually be consideration of decontrol but only "for those who are clearly of the Rolls-Royce-Country Club set" who do not need the benefits of rent stabilization.
The regulated rent market is divided into two categories: controlled and stabilized. The great majority of apartments are rent-stabilized, with the state setting a percentage limit on annual rent increases based on an operating-costs index. The regulations give tenants broad rights on renewing their leases. Besides New York City, the stabilization law applies to Nassau, Rockland and Westchester Counties.
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo said he would sign the measure into law, meaning that tenant protections like caps on rent increases would continue. Without legislative action, the regulations would have expired this weekend.
Partly because of the high emotions that surround the issue, the issue of extending the rent regulations has virtually always remained unsettled until the last moment.
Six years ago, in fact, lawmakers acted so late that Governor Cuomo had to use the hood of a state trooper's car that rushed to an Albany airport runway, where he had just arrived, to sign the extension into law minutes before the regulations would have expired.

THE ECONOMY
The F.C.C. adopted rules that give more local governments the power to roll back prices for basic cable service. But many urban areas, including New York, will remain unregulated. [Page A1.]
Consumers returned to the malls in May, and fewer people filed unemployment claims, according to Government reports. Preliminary data on May retail sales show a 1 percent gain. [D1.] Inflation at the wholesale level rose six-tenths of 1 percent in May. [D4.] 
 A strong performance by G.M. helped raise sales of domestically built cars and light trucks 9.4 percent in early June. [D4.]
Individuals can use the same provision of Federal bankruptcy law that corporations use to reorganize while continuing to operate, the Supreme Court ruled. [D1.] The decision will enable individuals to emerge from bankruptcy with investment assets intact. [D5.]
The S.E.C. voted to seek public comment on two proposals intended to make it easier for shareholders to communicate with each other about proxy votes. [D5.]

HEADLINE: Restaurants

BYLINE: By Bryan Miller

 BODY:

Le Cygne
 These are tough times for restaurants like Le Cygne. It is not a hip inexpensive bistro, a cool jet-set roost, a cultish hangout or a splashy media darling. Le Cygne has been simply a fine -- and expensive -- French restaurant that attempts to fly the flag high in this economic tempest.
 
 Le Cygne is one of the most underrated haute dining spots in New York City. For those who appreciate classically rooted contemporary French cuisine, it deserves to be high on the list. Such an exemplary performance is not surprising, for Le Cygne has been cosseted by its founding partners, Gerard Gillian and Michel Crouzillat, for 22 years. The kitchen is under the direction of Jean-Michel Bergougnoux, formerly of Le Regence and Lutece.
 The restaurant is in a two-story town house with a cheerful post-modern decor. The main dining room is in cool tones of gray and blue highlighted by white columns and ceiling trim; Impressionistic flower murals are softly illuminated, adding a blaze of color. One upstairs room has a similar theme; a brick-walled wine den is used for private parties. Noise is rarely a problem.
 Mr. Bergougnoux's spring-summer menu has an engaging Provencal accent. For starters, there is soupe au pistou, the country-style vegetable soup. In his city-slicker version, which is as thick as a stew, there are fresh peas, tomatoes, carrots and potatoes. Surprisingly, it is garnished with shrimp. Authentic? No. Delicious? Yes.
Two other light and flavorful starters are haricots verts with crushed hazelnuts and excellent shrimp salad, and a salad of heavily smoked duck and a slice of foie gras over mixed greens. Ravioli filled with mushrooms and lobster float on a luxuriant sauce flavored with rosemary, garlic, mushrooms and olives, and smoked salmon is sublime atop a pancake of potatoes and candied onions with creme fraiche and salmon caviar. With such delicate triumphs on the menu, it was surprising to taste forgettable crab cakes and zucchini flowers stuffed with a bland mixture of mushrooms and chicken mousse.
 The captains and waiters at Le Cygne remain a sharp, intelligent team. They never hover, but they are always in the neighborhood when you need them. The wine list, moderate in size, is well chosen but expensive.
 Mr. Bergougnoux has conjured up some spring seafood dishes that are not to be missed. In one, he takes thin slices of tuna and alternates them with layers of sliced potatoes flavored with vinegar and liberal doses of pepper. It is all enhanced with a wonderful sauce of black trumpet mushrooms. A lunch dish was was equally good: broiled salmon paillard over a sauce of periwinkle brine and olive oil, garnished with fennel, diced tomatoes, chopped dill and coriander.
A special, roasted sea bass, was flappingly fresh, crisp-skinned and moist, presented over savoy cabbage with a tasty salad of cellophane noodles and seaweed.
 On the meat side, a superb composition is medium-rare lamb medallions wrapped in seaweed and seasoned with cardamom. They are set over a rich lamb stock embellished with toasted almonds, along with an almond flan and sliced artichokes. Filet mignon comes in a heady white-truffle sauce, and roast chicken comes with creamy mashed potatoes and cepes. Duck is expertly prepared, too, its blistered skin concealing succulent pink meat. Spatzle and carrot puree seem to be wintery accompaniments, but beguiling ones.
 As you order appetizers and main courses, a captain hands you a dessert menu to consider certain sweets that take time to prepare. I have never liked this practice, necessary though it may be, for it strikes me as asking a college freshman to declare his major before he has taken his first class. Souffles, which are nearly all airy egg white, are worth pre-ordering, whether Grand Marnier, chocolate or raspberry. Something called warm bitter chocolate and mint tart is the kind of dessert you dream about, while the fragile-crusted apple tart, glistening and browned at the edges, is one of the best I have ever tasted. What is called a clafoutis, traditionally a custardlike base with fruit, is a buttery round cake with pineapple in the center -- delicious nonetheless.
For more than two decades, Le Cygne has been a place for romance, for celebration and for blissful indulgence. That is more true today than ever.
 
Scaletta
 In some other parts of town, the two-and-a-half-year-old Scaletta would be another inconspicuous local spot. But on the Upper West Side, where quality Italian dining is as rare as Buddhist temples, it has achieved some prominence.
The step-down dining room is incongruous in this neighborhood, both for its large size and for its appearance. Scaletta is awash in soothing colors like dusty rose and cream. It has faux frosted windows, beige upholstered chairs with turquoise cushions, arches, pillars and plenty of elbow room. As one fellow diner remarked, "It looks like the breakfast room of a fancy California hotel."
 Appetizers are particularly good. Baked clams, so often a wad of oil-drizzled bread crumbs, are lightly breaded here, full of clam flavor and well seasoned. Calamari is superior, too, floured and cleanly deep-fried. I rarely order baked oysters, for almost invariably they are dehydrated and tasteless. An exception is Scaletta's baked bluepoint oysters garnished with a thin slice of salmon and pimento. The flavors meld nicely, and all the briny oyster juices remain.
 A salad of haricots verts, mozzarella and pimentos could not be faulted for quality of ingredients, but it needed a jolt of salt and pepper or herbs to enliven it. The cheesy, garlic-laced Caesar salad is better. And carpaccio of beef is a paragon, lean and thin sliced, cool but not icy, served over arugula salad with mustard dressing.
 I don't know if it has something to do with the weather or the season, but in the last few weeks I have encountered some extraordinarily sluggish service all over town. Several of the friendly but phlegmatic crew here, dressed in blue shirts and dark ties, consider a diner's first request for an item merely rhetorical. A second request usually gets (leisurely) action.
 Pastas sound appealing, but most sampled fell short for lack of seasoning or inaccurate cooking time. Green and white fettuccine with tomato, spinach and chunks of fresh salmon was a harmonious combination, but the pasta was starchy. The same fault was evident in a special of black pasta with tomato and shrimp, and in the fettuccine with salmon in a vodka-spiked tomato-cream sauce.
 While the kitchen goes down swinging in the pasta department, it does turn out top-notch gnocchi, light and resilient in a seductive Bolognese sauce. Seafood risotto is arresting, too, the firm-cooked rice replete with perfectly cooked scallops, shrimp and clams in a light basil-tomato base. Seafood entrees are reliable, among them broiled salmon steak and swordfish Livornese (with capers, parsley, black olives and tomato). Charcoal-broiled tuna, though, looked as if it had been cooked at the barbecue by a gregarious dad who was paying more attention to his guests than to his cooking. You would do well with the breast of chicken with garlic, lemon and balsamic vinegar, or the special of chicken breast topped with eggplant and mozzarella. If you want veal, the scaloppine with butter and lemon is better than the veal with a pesto sauce with whole pine nuts and sun-dried tomatoes, whose flavors clash.
Scaletta's selection of mostly Italian and American wines is modest but adequate and fairly priced.
 Coffee semifreddo, flavored frozen whipped cream, is the best way to end a meal here. Chocolate Parisien cake, made with a chocolate sponge cake, is a second option. Also available are creamy lemon sorbet, served in a hollowed-out lemon, and a wonderful pastry layered with fresh berries. Most of the other desserts are cloyingly sweet.
 Scaletta is the kind of place where you can do very well by learning the menu and sticking to favorites. It's not the ideal way to dine, but in this part of town, one should be grateful for small blessings.
 
Le Cygne
***
55 East 54th Street, 759-5941.

Wine: Moderate-size list, expensive.

HEADLINE: Rocking or Relaxed, It's Still the Blues

BYLINE: By KAREN SCHOEMER

 BODY:
BLUES clubs in New York City are a strange breed, many generations removed from the music's ancestral home in the plantations and juke joints of the rural South. Back in the 1930's and 40's, blues was an expression of social, political and economic disenfranchisement; it was music primarily about sadness and anger and pain, and it was structured, worded and performed as an explicit antidote to those emotions.
Like many American traditions, blues has since been adopted and reshaped by and for mass culture; it has been modernized and technologized and commercialized into something that's perhaps more about style than about feeling. While some blues musicians of the 1940's and 50's still tour today, performing the music much as they did decades ago, young bar bands play a kind of blues that's hopped up with rock-and-roll rhythms, good to dance to and fun to listen to -- the archetypal music to hear live on a Saturday night on the town. 
 New York blues clubs retain this juxtaposition of the old and the new, the historical and the contemporary. On any given night on Bleecker Street's club row, you're just as likely to find a hot young band doing a tribute to the blues-influenced Eric Clapton as a solo performer onstage with a bottleneck slide doing a 1930's Robert Johnson song like "Crossroads." Blues clubs don't want to forget the roots of blues, but they also don't want to forget that people like to go out and stomp and holler and drink fancy drinks through colored straws, maybe even shoot a game of pool -- the only real diversion from the music in most of these clubs. Owners know that blues, in any of its incarnations, can be the ideal sound track for such an evening.
On page C22 is a selection of six blues clubs catering to these varying needs. Some allow a brush with the past; others create no more than a good time in the present. But all, in one way or another, recognize that basic impulse to conquer sadness by celebrating it in song.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The Bobby Radcliff Band performing recently at Manny's Car Wash, a blues club in Manhattan. (Michelle V. Agins/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Needless Bankruptcy in Bridgeport

 BODY:
When a city like Bridgeport, Conn., goes bankrupt, the failure is as much political as financial. Like many cities, Bridgeport is in deep trouble. Some of the causes are local, some not. But Bridgeport's petition for court protection is extreme. Public officials are elected to solve problems, not walk away from them.
Federal law lets municipalities file for bankruptcy when state law allows that. Congress did not intend this as an easy way out but as a last resort. Unlike corporate bankruptcy, municipal bankruptcy leaves a city government largely in control. But for populous cities, this is uncharted territory. 
 While bankruptcy might help solve Bridgeport's short-term problems, it would damage the city's creditworthiness. Meanwhile it casts a shadow on creditors and suppliers, city employees and residents, the state and other troubled cities.
In the 13 years since the municipal bankruptcy code was updated, dozens of entities have taken this route, mostly water and utility districts and a few school boards. Cities have rarely done it, and none the size of Bridgeport. Fearful of the financial and political risks, city fathers tend to back off; usually they scare themselves and their creditors and unions into negotiating sustainable new arrangements. Indeed, Bridgeport may be bluffing now. State officials argue that it exaggerates its crisis.
The city's problems are not new. All of southwestern Connecticut once thrived on manufacturing, now mostly gone. Recently, like central cities elsewhere, Bridgeport has also suffered from shrinking Federal and state aid, white flight to suburbs, rising welfare and the recession, which has hit the Northeastern states hardest.
Cities need more help, from Washington and the states. But Bridgeport's government has failed, too; financial management has been slipshod. Since 1988 it has been under the surveillance of a state-imposed financial review board -- but has ignored the board's warnings and advice.
Court approval of Bridgeport's filing is by no means certain; the state is fighting it, on grounds that no city may file without state approval. If the Federal bankruptcy court approves, the city's fate will be carefully tracked by troubled communities nationwide. Municipal bankruptcy is an experiment fraught with risk.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: What Potential Presidential TV Debates Have!

 BODY:
To the Editor:
I strongly disagree with Tom Wicker's assertion in "High Noon, Low Hype" (column, May 22) that Presidential debates have little or no value to the American voter. 
 Without debates, a voter's only exposure to Presidential candidates is through television commercials, bumper stickers and 10-second sound bites on the evening news. True, voters will receive this superficial campaign publicity anyway, but without debates, there may otherwise be no opportunity for the candidates to confront important issues directly.
Without debates candidates could just as easily avoid issues altogether. Would-be Presidents could simply address the importance of "family values," the necessity of a "strong economy" and the evils of his opponent. Debates, however, force candidates to define their national agenda and defend that agenda in front of the entire nation.
Past Presidential debates have not answered my every question about the candidates. Indeed, they often generate more questions about candidates and issues than they seem to answer. But at least they challenge the candidates to address national issues, while challenging the public to face these issues as well. When voters are only exposed to television smear ads or "feel good" commercials, featuring images of grandchildren or waving flags, neither the public nor the candidates are challenged.
Mr. Wicker concludes that from 1960 to 1976 the United States "got along quite well without Presidential debates." The Vietnam War, however, was never debated publicly between the Presidential candidates in 1960, '64, '68 or '72. I think it should have been. And in 1972, Richard M. Nixon was never forced to defend his bombing of Cambodia or the corruption in his Administration by participating in a debate with George McGovern. He should have been.
The worst our nation could have suffered from such debates was a better understanding of the candidates and issues. And had those debates taken place, our recent history might have been spared the damage that the Vietnam, Cambodia and Watergate episodes have since inflicted.
Then again, maybe Presidential debates in those years would have had little or no affect on history. All we know is that the potential benefit of Presidential debates to the American people, whether that potential is fully realized or not, is of great national value.
 
CHARLES HARDER
Santa Cruz, Calif., May 22, 1991

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
A Change in Top Post For Marine Midland

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
Marine Midland Banks, hurt by losses from bad loans, announced yesterday that John R. H. Bond, a top executive of the Hongkong and Shanghai Banking Corporation would replace Geoffrey A. Thompson, who was resigning, as Marine's chief executive.
Marine Midland, which has been controlled by Hongkong and Shanghai since 1980 and is the largest foreign-owned bank in the United States, has long been a source of vexation for its parent company. John M. Gray, deputy chairman of Hongkong and Shanghai, said recently that "we still believe that our strategy of buying an American bank is correct" but acknowledged that the execution "was very bad." 
 Mr. Bond, an Englishman who is 49 years old, is an executive director of Hongkong and Shanghai. He is generally regarded as the third-highest-ranking officer in the bank and as a specialist in corporate lending. Since joining the bank in 1961, he has spent time in Singapore, Thailand and Indonesia and was the chief executive for the Americas from 1987 to 1990.
As chief officer for the Americas, Mr. Bond became familiar with Marine Midland's operations but was not in control of the bank. He plans to live in Buffalo, Marine Midland's headquarters, with his wife and three children.
Between 1980 and 1988, when Hongkong and Shanghai owned just 48 percent of Marine Midland, Mr. Gray noted that the American managers were slow to abandon their hope of becoming a larger bank with major operations overseas and across the United States. Soon after Hongkong and Shanghai acquired 100 percent of the company in 1988, "we were hit by the recession and all the problems that caused."
Last year, Marine's problems with bad loans led to a $295 million loss, which required Hongkong and Shanghai to supply $300 million of additional capital. In the first quarter of this year, Marine announced another loss of $72.3 million.
Under Mr. Thompson, an American who became chairman in 1988 after joining the bank in 1981, Marine Midland had been retrenching and pulling back from many businesses outside its consumer banking and lending to medium-sized companies.
"At the moment, Europe is our key effort, and developing our presence there has a higher priority than expanding our U.S. business," Mr. Gray said in an interview.
The sale of nonessential businesses plus the reluctance of Hongkong and Shanghai to pay for big new acquisitions have reduced Marine Midland's assets to just under $19 billion, from $27.1 billion at the end of 1989.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Lockheed Unit Sets 800 More Job Cuts

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: SUNNYVALE, Calif., June 14

 BODY:
The Lockheed Missiles and Space Company will cut 800 more jobs this year than it had expected and warned that further reductions could occur. The military contractor, hurt by cancellations and reductions of orders on several programs, said Thursday that cuts would probably include 470 layoffs. The remainder would come as retirements and resignations.
Most cuts will occur in Silicon Valley, where the company is the largest employer, but operaions in other states would also be affected, a company spokesman said. The Lockheed Corporation, based in the Los Angeles suburb of Calabasas, has nearly 21,000 employees in its Sunnyvale division, the largest within the company. 
 At the start of the year, Lockheed predicted it would cut 1,200 jobs in 1991 and so far it has cut 950 positions. Additional cuts would bring the total to 2,000, the company said.

HEADLINE: Your Taxes;
I.R.S. Maps Out Big Leap Forward

BYLINE: By Robert D. Hershey Jr.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Although grandiose plans often go awry, even partial success for the Internal Revenue Service's $8 billion modernization effort, disclosed this week, will bring visibly big improvements for the nation's 100 million-plus taxpayers.
Did you misplace the copy of the return you filed last year ago just when you need to document an application for college financial aid? The I.R.S., which now has a 45-day target to respond to such requests but misses it in one case out of three, expects to be able to supply a copy within 24 hours. 
 Does it drive you into a frenzy to respond properly to an I.R.S. request for additional information or money only to get a computer-generated enforcement notice three weeks later about the same issue? The service proposes to eliminate 95 percent of such erroneous dunning.
Are you weary of being shunted around from one place to another to resolve a problem, dealing with I.R.S. personnel with ready access to only 2 percent of your account information? The agency anticipates that in 95 percent of cases a single employee will be able fix things.
But not right away.
The master plan, three years in development, will be phased in throughout the 1990's, replacing a system designed in the late 1950's and using the technology of the 1960's. The way the I.R.S. receives, processes and manages tax data has remained basically unchanged since.
At the news briefing on the plan, Commissioner Fred T. Goldberg Jr. called it a revolution. And for the I.R.S., long been critized by the General Accounting Office and others for failing to produce a detailed modernization program, it surely is.
Yet in some respects the I.R.S. is proposing to do by the end of the century what credit-card companies, retail stores and banks now do routinely.
There are various reasons that this has taken so long, including the now-admitted error of allowing rapid technological improvement to paralyze planners seeking grand solutions. The I.R.S. also cites a backwash concern for privacy arising from the Watergate scandal, an issue to which it remains sensitive.
The agency says privacy and confidentiality will actually be enhanced under the modernization plan, which calls for data, encrypted into unreadable code, moving over telecommunications systems -- rather than in shipments of computer tape and paper files.
There is, however, at least one area where for taxpayers the bad may outweigh the good: quicker audits. But even here the agency finds a bright side. "You don't like being called on your 1988 tax return just after you filed your 1990 return," said Larry Westfall, the modernization director.Family Lending
A decade ago, the Government began to insist that family members who lend each other money charge market-oriented rates of interest, the idea being that the newlywed who borrows, say, the down payment on a house from parents gets a taxable benefit. Some such loans were also sham transactions aimed at evading gift taxes.
Now the issue is loan guarantees, routinely used by many parents to help finance children's tuitions, businesses, cars and houses. The I.R.S., in a quasi-authoritative letter ruling that has stunned specialists, says such guarantees are taxable gifts.
The service does not detail how it would calculate the value of a guarantee-gift, suggesting only that it might be related to the interest savings.
Even more troublesome, says Carlyn S. McCaffrey, a tax partner at the law firm of Weil, Gotshal & Manges, is that a loan guarantee can wreck estate planning. A Q-TIP, or qualified terminable interest, trust that contains a loan guarantee by a deceased parent is not eligible for the marital deduction that allows husbands and wives to transfer some assets tax-free.
 
 Footnotes
 State tax collectors are paying a personal price for slumping revenues. Only about 400 members of the Federation of Tax Administrators have registered for its annual convention in Indianapolis next week, about 25 percent fewer than the 1989-90 average. "The financial condition of the states is cutting into our attendance," said Harley T. Duncan, the group's executive vice president.
In a defeat for the I.R.S., the Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia has upheld the Tax Court's decision broadening the circumstances for deducting expenses for home offices.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Declines as Traders Cash In on Recent Advance

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar settled mostly lower on world currency markets yesterday as traders cashed in on the currency's recent run-up.
Traders spent the session selling dollars, but analysts said the action should be seen more as profit taking rather than a reaction to the latest economic statistics from the United States. 
 The economic data provided additional evidence that the recession was lifting. The Government said industrial production rose a seasonally adjusted five-tenths of 1 percent in May, while the Consumer Price Index was up just three-tenths of 1 percent in the same month.
"The numbers were actually quite good," said Marc Chandler, an analyst with the financial advisory firm IDEA.
"They usually would have supported the dollar because they indicate more economic activity," he said. But the dollar's behavior had "nothing to do with fundamentals."
Instead, traders were reluctant to push the dollar higher because they feared such a move would be met by intervention from central banks. "Traders aren't ready to challenge the central banks," Mr. Chandler said.
Still, the underlying sentiment toward the dollar remains bullish, said Randolph Donney, research director at Pegasus Econometric Group in Hoboken, N.J. He attributed the selloff to "normal end-of-the-week profit taking."
In Tokyo, the dollar fell 0.68 yen to close at 141.07 yen. Later in London, it was quoted at 140.50 yen. In New York the dollar settled at 140.70 yen, down from 141.25 on Thursday.
In London, the British pound rose to $1.6395, from $1.6380 late Thursday. In New York, a pound cost $1.6325, down from $1.6345 on Thursday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Thursday's rates, included: 1.7940 German marks, down from 1.7985; 1.5395 Swiss francs, up from 1.5390; 6.0970 French francs, down from 6.1030; 1,337.25 Italian lire, down from 1,338.00, and 1.1432 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1434.

HEADLINE: COMMENCEMENTS;
City College Awards 1,900 Degrees, Belatedly

 BODY:
The City College of New York awarded more than 1,900 bachelor's and graduate degrees yesterday at its 145th commencement exercises.
The commencement was held later than usual because of a student protest in April over tuition increases in which students took over buildings and obstructed classes. 
 In his valedictory address, Emmanuel Gautreau, an English major, spoke of the increases and their effects. "The fact that many of our colleagues may not be able to continue their education as a result of tuition hikes and reductions in financial assistance disturbs me deeply," he said. But he denounced "exercises in futility like the takeover of administration buildings on our campuses."
Four honorary degrees were awarded. Three of the recipients are City College alumni: Faith Ringgold, an artist and teacher, Herbert Robinson, a business lawyer, and Edwin Torres, a New York State Supreme Court justice. Also honored was Erich Bloch, the former director of the National Science Foundation.
 
California Institute of Technology

At the California Institute of Technology's 97th commencement in Pasadena yesterday, President Bush urged graduates to "push beyond today's horizons" toward a 21st century when knowledge will determine America's role as a world power.
"Ours is an age of microchips and MTV," the President told 186 graduating seniors and 314 graduates receiving master's or doctoral degrees. "Ours is an economy increasingly dependent not on our natural resources, or geographic location, but upon knowledge."
Hecklers interrupted Mr. Bush's address with shouts, whistles and calls for abortion rights and help for AIDS victims, and the police escorted 15 demonstrators from the ceremony.

HEADLINE: U.S. Output Climbed 0.5% Last Month

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 14

 BODY:
Factories in May increased production of autos, furniture, appliances and other consumer goods, the Government reported today.
Production at factories, mines and utilities increased a seasonally adjusted five-tenths of 1 percent in May, the strongest gain in 11 months. 
The report, by the Federal Reserve, follows previous statistics showing increases in employment and retail sales last month.
 
 A Bottoming-Out Is Seen
 "These are all starting to paint a picture of an economy that has bottomed out," said Martin Regalia, an economist at the National Council of Savings Institutions. "If we don't have a relapse, we can say the patient is coming out of intensive care."
Today's report also revised the April production figure to show a rise of three-tenths of 1 percent, instead of the gain of one-tenth originally reported. The April advance ended a six-month string of declines, the longest since the 1981-82 recession. But even with the latest gains, production is still 3.3 percent below a year ago.
"The industrial sector is making the turn at this point, but it's not an explosive turn," said Stephen S. Roach, an economist at Morgan Stanley & Company.
Much of the overall increase was accounted for by a 3.9 percent burst of output by utilities, with the electricity part of that component surging by 4.7 percent. Warmer-than-usual May weather in the East led to early use of air-conditioners.
Manufacturing was up two-tenths of 1 percent in May after a five-tenths of 1 percent rise in April. Mining output, which includes oil and gas wells, fell one-tenth of 1 percent.
The strength in manufacturing came in auto production, up 4.6 percent; appliances, television and air-conditioners, up 2 percent, and carpeting and furniture, up 1.1 percent.

GRAPHIC: Graphs: "Industrial Production," tracks index of total industrial production, Dec. 1989-May, 1991; "Capacity Utilization," tracks total ouput as a percentage of capacity, seasonally adjusted, Dec. 1989-May 1991. (Source: Federal Reserve Board)

HEADLINE: Tax Repeal Bill Introduced

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: TRENTON, June 14

 BODY:
Democratic lawmakers said today that they want to repeal the controversial sales tax on disposable paper products, which last year turned toilet paper into a symbol of New Jersey's anti-tax movement.
Senate Democrats quietly introduced a bill yesterday to remove the sales tax on paper products, which was part of the $2.8 billion in tax increases that drew voter wrath in 1990. 
 The bill's sponsor is Senator Laurence Weiss, Democrat of Middlesex, who heads the powerful Senate Appropriations Committee. The Senator said he would like the tax to be repealed before lawmakers adopt a new state budget by the end of the month.
A bill to repeal the tax has sat dormant in the Assembly since September.
"This tax has been offensive to a lot of people," said Mr. Weiss, who acknowledged that he does not want Republicans to use the tax as a campaign issue in the legislative elections this fall. "It's been a symbol, even though it came out to only about 3 1/2 cents a roll for toilet paper," he said.
Senator Weiss said today that the sales tax on paper products raises between $20 million and $30 million for the state annually. He acknowledged that repealing the tax "is going to make it a heck of a lot more difficult" to balance the state budget, especially given the current economic climate.
The Assembly minority leader, Chuck Haytaian, Republican of Warren, said he believed politics and voter anger had "forced the Democrats to see the light."
Nancy Kearney, a spokeswoman for Gov. Jim Florio, said the Governor would support any repeal as long as alternative funding is found.

HEADLINE: Long-Term Interest Rates Decline

BYLINE: By H. J. MAIDENBERG

 BODY:
A late burst of buying yesterday lifted prices of Treasury bonds to their best levels of the day in what dealers described as unusually active Friday trading. As a result long-term interest rates fell, contributing to the late rally in the stock market.
The market in long-term debt issues opened strongly following the release of Government reports showing a modest rise of three-tenths of 1 percent in the Consumer Price Index for May, and a five-tenths increase in industrial production last month. 
 While the rise in industrial output would normally be bearish for the fixed-income market, the gain was discounted because May's record hot weather stimulated sales and production of summer-related items, as well as the decline of five-tenths of 1 percent in inventories that the Government also reported.
 
 Yield Down to 8.45 Percent

The economic data caused the price of the benchmark Treasury long bonds, the 8 1/8 percent issue maturing in May 2021, to rise by about 18/32. Subsequent selling and pre-weekend book squaring shaved the gain by 4/32 before the midafternoon rally began. Late in the day, the long bonds were being offered at 96 14/32, up by 20/32, causing the yield to drop to 8.45 percent, from 8.50 percent the day before and 8.47 percent a week ago.
"The bond market interpreted the day's flow of economic reports as being neutral to slightly positive, which is why the early price rise and subsequent profit taking were relatively moderate affairs," said Allan R. Leslie, chief economist at the Discount Corporation of New York.
But as market participants prepared to leave for the weekend, Mr. Leslie added, many of those who had sold Treasury bonds short the day before as insurance in case Friday's economic reports were negative decided to buy out of their positions.
 
Strong Close in Futures
 Also contributing to the late surge in prices was the strong close of the Chicago Treasury bond futures market at 3 P.M., Eastern time. The spot June bond contract, which will expire on Tuesday, closed up 16/32 at 93 26/ 32.
There was also some speculation that some German portfolio managers had placed substantial buy orders for Treasury debt issues after their markets closed. German financial markets will be closed Monday for a holiday.
Among other representative Treasury issues traded in the secondary market, the 6 3/4 percent notes of 1993 rose 4/32, to 99 20/32, for a yield of 6.95 percent, and the 7 5/8 percent notes of 1996 jumped 9/32, to 98 27/32, to yield 7.91 percent. On Wednesday the Treasury is scheduled to announce the sizes of its monthly auctions of two- and five-year notes, which would take place the following week.
The Treasury's long notes, the 8 percent issue maturing in May 2001, soared 13/32, to 98 8/32, for a yield of 8.26 percent, the same as a week ago. The yield on the long notes is often compared with those on the 10-year Japanese and German "long bonds." The yield on the Japanese bonds is 6.88 percent; that on the comparable German issue is 8.33 percent.
At the shorter end of the Treasury market, the discount rate on the 90-day bills was unchanged at 5.59 percent; six-month bills declined three basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, to 5.78 percent, and the one-year bills slipped four basis points, to 5.97 percent.
 
Reserves Drained by Fed

The Federal Reserve intervened in the money market to drain reserves from the banking system. The move came as the Federal funds rate that banks charge each other for temporary loans was at 5 5/8 percent, below the Fed's perceived target of 5 3/4 percent for this key interest rate.
In the Government agency sector, the Resolution Trust Corporation, charged with bailing out failed savings institutions, priced a three-part $480 million mortgage pass-through offering through a special purpose vehicle termed the Resolution Trust Corporation 1991-1. The securities are backed by adjustable-rate mortgages from the Columbia Savings and Loan Association, Beverly Hills, Calif., one of the agency's conservatorship institutions. The interest rates were set at 175 basis points over various Treasury maturities.

HEADLINE: Democrats Meet To Plot Strategy For '92 Election

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MIDDLEBURG, Va., June 14

 BODY:
Several of the Democratic Party's most likely Presidential hopefuls retreated to an estate in the exclusive hunt country here today to begin plotting how they might wrest the White House from the Republicans in 1992.
Although the overnight meeting included 21 of the party's most reliable contributors, and although some promises were made, Democratic party officials said afterward that it was less a fund-raising event than a strategy meeting intended to give Democrats an "early start." 
 "It is clear to us that President Bush is very vulnerable in 1992, because this Administration has absolutely no domestic agenda," said the Democratic National Committee's chairman, Ronald H. Brown.
 
One Declared, Several Maybes
 The meeting, held at the home of Pamela Harriman, a Democratic fund-raiser and activist, about an hour west of Washington, drew the party's one declared candidate, Paul E. Tsongas, the former Massachusetts Senator, and a number of possible candidates for 1992 or 1996: Senator Lloyd Bentsen of Texas; Senator Bill Bradley of New Jersey; Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas; Representative Thomas S. Foley of Washington, the Speaker of the House; Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the House majority leader; Senator Tom Harkin of Iowa; Senator Bob Kerrey of Nebraska; George J. Mitchell of Maine, the Senate majority leader, and Senator John D. Rockefeller 4th of West Virginia.
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York, Senator Al Gore of Tennessee, the Rev. Jesse Jackson and Gov. L. Douglas Wilder of Virginia, all of whom are considered possible candidates, were invited to today's meeting but said they could not attend.
Mr. Brown and others emerged from the meeting to say that they had arrived at a "preliminary strategy" and that they had agreed that Democrats should put aside intraparty rivalries and focus on organizing for the general election rather than for the primaries. They declined to give details of their new post-primary strategy.
The party's last Presidential nominee, Michael S. Dukakis, the former Massachusetts Governor, suffered in 1988, several of those present said, because there was no organized effort in place to carry his candidacy out of the Atlanta convention.
"There was not in place a coordinated campaign strategy post-convention," said Steve Grossman, who was co-chairman of Mr. Dukakis's finance committee and is the co-chairman of the new fund-raising effort, called the Democrats' Victory Campaign '92. "You can't decide on a national strategy when the Republicans were planning Willie Horton, the Pledge of Allegiance and Boston Harbor 12 to 18 months before."
Party leaders have said they hope to at least match their 1988 fund raising but they would not disclose any goal that has been set. The Democrats raised about $50 million for the 1988 general election campaign, in addition to the $46.1 million provided by the Federal Government.
 
Looking at Opinion Polls
 The Democrats have also taken heart from recent public and private polls that show a significant disparity between the numbers of Americans who say they approve of President Bush's overall performance, especially on foreign policy, and those who say they are content with the nation's domestic health.
In a New York Times/CBS News Poll conducted last week, 75 percent of those surveyed said they approved of the way Mr. Bush was handling his job. But 57 percent said they thought the economy was fairly bad or very bad.
Mr. Clinton said party leaders hoped to seize on these perceived weaknesses in Mr. Bush's armor of popularity to regain the White House. He said they must capitalize on working people's concerns about health care, the economy and education.
"They're worried that their schools aren't very good and when they get out of them they won't be able to afford to send them to college," Mr. Clinton said.

HEADLINE: S.I. Toddler Dies And Her Mother Faces Charges

BYLINE: By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr.

 BODY:
A 32-year-old Staten Island woman was arrested yesterday after her severely bruised daughter was found dead in her apartment, the police said.
When paramedics arrived at the apartment early yesterday morning, in response to a call from the mother, Selena Walker, they discovered the child, Chardasia, 16 months old, lying on a couch, without a pulse. The girl had a fractured skull, a broken left ankle, burns on the left hand and right foot and multiple bruises on the head, the police said. 
 She was taken to St. Vincent's Hospital on Staten Island, where she was pronounced dead shortly after 8 A.M.
Ms. Walker, who is unemployed, was charged yesterday afternoon with endangering the welfare of a child, the police said. Her four other children, all younger than 8 years of age, were placed in a foster home. Investigators said they would seek murder charges if a medical examiner rules the toddler's death a homicide.
"The hospital couldn't give us anything definite on the cause of death," said Lieut. William Quinn of the Staten Island Detectives. "So we don't want to jump and assume this is a homicide."
 
Mother's Call
 An autopsy had not been performed on the toddler last night, said Ellen Borakove, a spokeswoman for the Medical Examiner.
At 7:43 A.M., Ms. Walker called the police and told them her toddler was not breathing, said a police spokesman, Sgt. Peter Berry. The 911 operator put the call through to an operator for the Emergency Medical Service, who gave Ms. Walker instructions for giving the child mouth-to-mouth resuscitation, said a spokeswoman for the service, Lynn Shulman.
An ambulance arrived at 7:53 and paramedics immediately took the toddler to the hospital, while the police took Ms. Walker to the 122d Precinct station house. She requested a lawyer and made no statements about the child's death.
Because Ms. Walker will not say what happened to her child, the police were unsure last night whether the child's injuries came from a beating or from some other mishap, Lieutentant Quinn said. "She was surprised when we told her about the injuries," he said.
The four other children living in the apartment -- three boys and a girl -- were also taken to St. Vincent's and given examinations, but doctors found them to be in good condition, the police said. Ms. Walker also has a 16-year-old daughter who lives with her grandmother in the Bronx.
Citing state confidentiality laws, a spokesman for the Human Resources Administration, Earl Weber, refused to comment on whether Ms. Walker had been the subject of child-abuse investigations in the past.
