HEADLINE: St. Petersburg Journal;
No Hits, No Runs, One Error: The Dome

BYLINE: By RONALD SMOTHERS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ST. PETERS BURG, Fla., June 14

 BODY:
Like a base stealer who risked the game and got caught in a rundown between third and home, this city on Florida's Gulf Coast was picking itself up and dusting itself off this week.
It risked $139 million to build a domed baseball stadium, although it had no major league team to occupy it and pay to maintain it. 
 It still doesn't.
Last weekend a National League committee bypassed St. Petersburg and its shiny new stadium, which opened early this year, and recommended Miama and Denver for two new franchises. A final vote by all major league owners is expected to ratify the choices.
In Florida the quest for the legendary Fountain of Youth has often merged with the state's quest for development or renewal. For many people, the construction of the domed stadium on speculation is a new version of the same wild-eyed vision.
The stadium, the Florida Suncoast Dome, now joins a $200 million downtown retail development project as symbols of the city's frustrated efforts to reinvigorate itself. The development project was intended to attract fashionable stores to Mediterranean-style buildings downtown.
But retail space sits unused, a victim of the recession. And now the dome seems doomed to house little more than the occasional concert, tractor pull and trade show.
To be sure, the failure to get a team is not likely to bankrupt St. Petersburg, but it does mean that taxpayers will have to pay much of the $1.7 million annual operating cost and most of the estimated $8 million annual debt service for a stadium that was not only supposed to pay for itself, but was also expected to make a profit.
"If it is not seriously fought, a psychological depression could set in along with the economic depression which has hurt our efforts," said David Carr, a former member of the City Planning Board, who supported the stadium project.
On Thursday, Mayor David J. Fischer helped pull together a larger group of local business leaders to form a stronger local ownership group in an effort to "steal" a team from another city.
For Dennis McDonald, a local businessman and unsuccessful mayoral candidate who has long opposed the dome, the baseball committee's decision was an unwelcome vindication of what he had been saying all along. The dome was a speculative project, he said, and voters in this city of 240,000 people should have been given an opportunity to decide whether they wanted to change the city's image in this way and at this cost.
Raymond O. Arsenault, a history professor at the University of South Florida here, who wrote "St. Petersburg and the Florida Dream, 1888-1950," said building the stadium and the city's unsuccessful quest for a major league team were consistent with the city's history.
In the 1930's St. Petersburg's claims of perpetually sunny days and leisure activities were relentlessly hawked to Depression-racked Northerners seeking a retirement haven and tourist attractions like James Earl "Doc" Webb's pharmacy, billed as "the world's most unusual drug store," which mixed commerce with entertainment that included talking mermaids and dancing chickens.
But St. Petersburg constantly lost out in its perennial competition with its cross-bay neighbor, Tampa. That city, with its cigar factories and commercial shipping, became the industrial giant of the area.
As a retirement haven St. Petersburg was once the butt of jokes, with its ubiquitous green benches and blood pressure machines for the elderly. But in the last 20 years, said former Mayor Robert Ulrich, the average age of the city's residents has dropped from 58 to 42, and the city has been trying hard to change its image as "heaven's waiting room."
While even opponents of the domed stadium say the city has few options now but to continue to pursue a team, they hope there will be some re-examination of how the city arrived at this point.
"I think we were blinded by the goal of becoming a major league city and changing our image from that of a sleepy retirement community," said Darryl Poulson, a political scientist at the University of South Florida who has opposed the stadium.

HEADLINE: Consumer Index Up Only 0.3%; Output Higher

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
In another batch of favorable data, the Government reported yesterday that the economy appeared to be growing again without pushing up the inflation rate. Most economists consider that combination essential if the nation is to shake off the recession.
The Consumer Price Index rose in May by only three-tenths of 1 percent, the Labor Department said. When combined with other modest increases this year, the May rise suggests an annual inflation rate below 3 percent, or less than half of last year's 6.1 percent. 
 "From a policy maker's point of view, the inflation numbers are good, and they look to continue good for the foreseeable future," said Patrick Jackman, chief of the group of economists who gather inflation data at the Labor Department's Bureau of Labor Statistics.
 
 Effect on Interest Rates
 His reference was to the Federal Reserve's 5 sitting governors and 12 regional bank presidents, a policy-making group that tends to raise interest rates and discourage economic activity -- provoking or prolonging a recession -- whenever inflation appears to be rising. The Federal Reserve had lowered rates through April, to stimulate the economy, but has not acted since.
The favorable economic news helped push up stock prices yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average rising 35.33, to 3,000.45. [Page 35.]
The Government also reported yesterday that industrial production rose in May for the second consecutive month, by a hefty five-tenths of 1 percent, and business inventories declined in April, as retailers, wholesalers and manufacturers sold more than they bought.
Declining inventories suggest that industrial production will keep rising as companies replenish their stockpiles. This happened in May. Rising auto production was a big reason for the production increase, but economists said that if auto sales fell back from the annual rate of more than 6 million vehicles reached in early June, production might taper off as well, threatening the recovery.
The May consumer price data showed mild price increases in almost every sector. Only gasoline prices were up noticeably, along with medical costs and apparel prices. Inflation in the service sector, a problem until late winter, rose in May by less than half the rate that prevailed for several months until February. Similarly, shelter costs -- that is, rent, the monthly cost of home ownership, and hotel rates -- rose by only a fraction of previous increases.
 
 Another Mild Reading
 The "core rate" of inflation -- the price index minus food and energy costs, which can fluctuate sharply -- rose at a similarly mild two-tenths of 1 percent, roughly the level of the last three months.
"With oil prices under control and wage costs knocked down by the high unemployment rate, we will see mild inflation for the rest of the year," said Roger E. Brinner, president of DRI/ McGraw Hill, an economic consulting service. Unemployment is 6.9 percent.
On the face of it, the consumer price report seemed to contradict Thursday's inflation news. The Labor Department had reported that producer prices for finished goods -- the prices that factories charge wholesalers, retailers and distributors for goods coming off the assembly line -- had risen a sharp six-tenths of 1 percent in May. But that was mostly from big increases in gasoline, tobacco and aircraft prices, economists noted. What is more, the prices of intermediate and crude goods, the prices manufacturers pay for steel, raw cotton and the like, were either flat or fell in May, for the fourth straight month.
 
 Talk of Recession's End
 Viewing yesterday's data, which came on top of Thursday's report of rising retail sales, most economists agreed with Peter L. Bernstein, a New York economics consultant, who said, "The signals are coming from too many different places not to conclude that the recession is coming to an end."
But there were caveats, including one from Vice President Dan Quayle. "The question is: How vigorous a recovery are we going to have?" he said yesterday, adding, "and there is now a question being raised about the monetary supply" and whether it will grow sufficiently to underwrite a recovery.
The nation's money supply -- essentially, the total amount of money held by people in currency and in various forms of savings -- has been growing weakly for more than two months. Changes in money supply are a gauge of the level of borrowing to finance economic activity, with a shrinking money supply indicating weak borrowing.
Raising another concern, Mr. Brinner said that until there was a clear pattern of job creation, Americans would not have enough income to sustain greater consumption. Mostly because of layoffs, jobs disappeared each month from July through April, with the employment rolls finally starting to grow in May.
For Robert Hall, a Stanford University economist, the issue is whether the upturn will become strong enough that the recession can be declared over. Mr. Hall is chairman of a committee of seven economists who fix for the nation the dates when recessions start and end. In April, the committee set last July as the recession's starting date.
The committee's next debate, Mr. Hall said, might be similar to the one that absorbed it in late 1980. A recession that started in January of that year appeared to have ended by August, but the committee was not sure the recovery had been strong enough to qualify as a change of direction in the economy, Mr. Hall said.
 
 Reaching a Decision
 In early 1981, the committee finally declared that the recovery had indeed been strong enough and that the recession had ended the previous July. A new recession began a year later, in July 1981, and was recognized by the committee early in 1982.
"Our general philosophy is to ask: Has the economy gotten back to the previous peak?" Mr. Hall said, referring in this case to the level of the nation's economic activity that existed last July. By that standard, industrial production and some other activities are still well below par, he noted. If the current upturn brings them back to July's levels, then the committee would presumably say, in hindsight, that the recovery began this spring.
For the time being, consumer prices are cooperating with this goal. Sharp increases in energy and food prices had artificially pushed up inflation in January and February and a sharp decline in energy prices made inflation seem unusually low in March and April, Mr. Jackman said. But the May rise seems to reflect the underlying trend, he said.

HEADLINE: New Tools for States Bolster Collection of Child Support

BYLINE: By TAMAR LEWIN, Special to The New York Times

 BODY:
Aided by new laws and an infusion of Federal money, state child-support enforcement agencies around the country have become far more aggressive at collecting child support.
Since the enactment of the Family Support Act of 1988, states have become more aggressively involved in collecting court-ordered child support awards, taking in a record $6 billion in 1990. And, according to one recent survey, the average amount of court-ordered child support has increased about 50 percent, to $60 a week. New mechanisms are in place for garnisheeing the wages of parents who owe child-support payments, and most states have started issuing their own "Most Wanted" lists, or staging roundups to arrest parents who fail to pay. Such tactics generate a wave of payments not only from the people singled out but also from others who wish to avoid negative publicity. 
 All states must now report delinquent parents' debts to credit agencies. A few states are experimenting with reporting child-support debts to the state licensing boards that regulate doctors, lawyers, plumbers, hairdressers and others.
But there is still a long way to go before children whose parents divorced, or never married, can be assured of receiving support from their noncustodial parent -- the father, in 9 out of 10 cases.
 
Delinquent Almost Captured
 The odyssey of Gregory Morey Sr. is a case in point.
Mr. Morey was ordered to pay $600 a month to support his three small children when he and his wife divorced 10 years ago. But he never paid a penny, Arizona child-support officials say, and he has repeatedly foiled their efforts to find him and recover what has become a $74,000 debt.
"He's a perfect illustration of the problems we face," said Ray Weaver, director of Arizona's child-support enforcement office. "He's changed his Social Security number four times, he's changed the spelling of his name, and he's worked in six different Western states."
Last month, after a national organization of child-support officials put out a "Most Wanted" poster of the worst child-support offenders from 22 states, Mr. Weaver almost caught Mr. Morey.
"We opened our doors at 8 A.M. on the day that USA Today ran a story on the national 'Most Wanted' list, and by 8:30 we knew where he was," said Mr. Weaver. "He was working as a restaurant manager in Utah, and we got a call from his employer. We tried to move quickly, but by the time we got legal process up there, he was gone. We do have some new leads to follow, though."
As of the end of 1989, more than $18 billion in accumulated support, covering more than 16 million children, was still unpaid.
The Census Bureau estimated that in 1987, the last year for which it has analyzed the data, almost a third of all court-awarded child support, or $4.6 billion, went unpaid, and experts say the soon-to-be-released 1989 estimate will show little change.
Child support is an issue for millions of families: one in four American children under the age of 18 now lives in a single-parent family. And with one in five American children living in poverty, politicians and social policy experts alike have become increasingly concerned with trying to assure that both parents assume financial responsibility for their children.
 
Crucial for Dependents
 "Child-support payments can be the difference between dependence on welfare and economic independence," said David Siegel, a spokesman for the Administration for Children and Families, the Federal agency that oversees child-support enforcement in public assistance cases and those where the custodial parent has requested help in collecting an award. "Our goal is to support parental responsibility and make sure that children get the support they're legally entitled to."
In the Morey case, as in many others, the father's failure to pay child support pushed the family into poverty, and, for a while, onto welfare. Mr. Morey's former wife, Susan Aldrich, said she and the three children -- Heather, 16, Greg Jr., 14, and Adrieanne, 12 -- had never received a penny of the $600-a-month child support Mr. Morey was ordered to pay when the couple divorced in 1981.
"We were evicted and the utilities were cut off, and I was so down on my luck that I was afraid I would have to give the children up for them to eat and have a home," said Mrs. Aldrich.
She remarried six years ago. "Now my husband supports us all, and his own son," she said, "but he's a technical instructor, which is not a high-paying job, and even with him working two shifts, the budget's tight. I've located Greg eight or nine times in the last 10 years, but each time he's been made aware that he's been located, he picks up and moves."
 
Major Enforcement Hurdle
 Collecting child support from delinquents who have crossed state lines is now one of the biggest problems in the system, according to enforcement officials and children's advocates.
Margaret Campbell Haynes, chairwoman of the United States Commission on Interstate Child Support, estimates that as many as 30 percent of all cases may involve an out-of-state parent, although less than 10 percent of all money collected comes from out of state. The commission, created by the Family Support Act, plans to offer recommendations early next year on improving the system.
Meanwhile, Representative Henry J. Hyde, Republican of Illinois, and Senator Richard C. Shelby, Democrat of Alabama, have introduced legislation that would make it a Federal crime to flee to another state to avoid child-support obligations.
Over the last six years, Congress has pushed the states to improve child-support enforcement, largely in an effort to reduce welfare payments to poor children who are not receiving support from their parents.
Federal laws now allow child-support enforcement officials -- who are welfare officials in most states, but part of the attorney general's office or the tax department in others -- to intercept tax refund checks and garnishee the wages of parents who owe child support.
 
Problem With Garnishment
 But these tactics have not been entirely successful: garnishment, for example, tends to break down as soon as the parent leaves one job and takes another with an employer who is unaware of the child-support obligations. Tracing the parent becomes particularly difficult if, as in the case of Mr. Morey and millions of others, he switches jobs frequently and crosses state lines.
In 1989 the noncustodial parent's wages were being garnisheed in only one in five cases in which this should have been done under the law. And while more recent statistics are not available, child-support officials and advocates say they doubt that the proportion has increased much since then.
"If the father changes jobs three or four times a year, which lots of them do, there's no way to find them immediately," said Harry Wiggins, a Virginia enforcement official who is president of the National Council of State Child Support Enforcement Adminstrators.
Mr. Wiggins and others maintain that the child-support system will never work properly without a national data base, and some kind of universal screening for new employees, to see whether they have child-support obligations. But such a system is generally acknowledged to be a long way off.
In many states the caseloads are so large, and staffs so small, that when a family reports not receiving court-ordered child support, it can be as much as a year before any action is taken.
 
Need to Establish Paternity
 Many cases never get as far as an order for child support: more than a quarter of all children in the United states are born out of wedlock, and for such children, child-support officials must formally establish paternity before support can be collected.
The Family Support Act requires that states try to obtain Social Security numbers from both parents at the time of each birth, and there is now Federal financing to help the states in identifying or tracking down fathers, and giving blood tests if necessary. But most states have failed, because of the slowness of bureaucracy, to establish paternity in about two-thirds of their out-of-wedlock cases.
The Family Support Act of 1988 also requires each state to adopt specific guidelines for setting child-support awards, so that judges faced with the same situation would order the same payment.
The guidelines differ substantially from state to state, with some states requiring that the noncustodial parent pay a flat percentage of earnings, while others looking at both parents' earnings and requiring each to pay a proportionate share of the children's expenses.
 
Guidelines for Awards
 Under the law, the guidelines are to be used to compute the award unless a parent in a particular case can show that because of the family's special circumstances, the guidelines would produce some unusual hardship or unfairness.
A survey of 375 members of the Association for Children for Enforcement of Support, a nationwide advocacy group, found that the average support order had gone from $40 a week before the guidelines to $60 a week after. In Virginia, Mr. Wiggins said, the average order has doubled in the 18 months since the guidelines went into effect, to $270 a month.
But Geraldine Jensen, president of the association, said many judges were still ignoring the guidelines and setting unrealistically low awards.
"The guidelines have helped a little bit," Ms. Jensen said, "but what I would really like to see would be national guidelines, so that the award you get doesn't depend on whether you're in Ohio or Alabama."

HEADLINE: Citizenship For 6,000 In Ceremony In Queens

BYLINE: By DONATELLA LORCH

 BODY:
In the largest naturalization ceremony in New York City since 1954, more than 6,000 people from 100 different countries crammed a Queens auditorium yesterday and pledged allegiance to the United States.
The pipes and drums of the New York City Police Department Emerald Society band brought roars of approval from the crowd. And when the keynote singer did not arrive to sing the national anthem, half a dozen immigration lawyers improvised a chorus and asked the 6,050 new American citizens to sing along. 
 The hourlong swearing-in ceremony was the largest since 1954 when 9,000 new Americans were sworn in at the Polo Grounds in upper Manhattan. The crowd yesterday was a result of immigration housekeeping. In one fell swoop, the Immigration and Naturalization Service cleaned up a backlog caused by the increasing numbers of qualified applicants in the Eastern District of New York, which encompasses Brooklyn, Queens, Staten Island, Nassau and Suffolk Counties, immigration officials said.
 
Auditorium at St. John's
 "We figured 9,000 would wipe out our backlog but we couldn't find a place to do 9,000," said Charles Troy, a spokesman for the I.N.S. Officials did not want to risk inclement weather by having the ceremony outside. The largest auditorium they could find held 6,000 people and was at St. John's University in Hillcrest, Queens.
Such ceremonies are not uncommon in other parts of the country. Joe Flanders, an information officer for the I.N.S. in Southern California, said, "We average ceremonies with 7,000 to 8,000 people, two or three times a year."
Most of the immigrants yesterday were from Brooklyn and Queens, two boroughs that have come to embody a changing New York City, reshaped in the last decade by a large immigrant influx. The New York City branch of the I.N.S. interviews an estimated 60,000 immigrants a year, Mr. Troy said. Most become citizens.
Immigration requires all citizens to hold resident green cards for at least five years before becoming American citizens. Yesterday's crowd was a mixture of races and religions and reasons for becoming citizens. Becoming an American made it easier to get a job and travel and made it possible to vote, they said. They all planned to celebrate: dinners with family, a barbecue bash in upstate New York, a date with a new boyfriend.
 
Flags Are Distributed
 "Most probably came here through other family members," Mr. Troy said. "They may have come for economic reasons. When they become citizens it's easier under immigration laws to turn around and petition for other immediate relatives."
As the thousands poured into the auditorium dressed as if they were going to a fancy reception, they were all given miniature American flags. The largest representation was 547 people from Guyana. The next largest groups were from China, Barbados, Jamaica and the Dominican Republic.
Dressed in a brown suit, holding an American flag, Iftikar Aziz Nazmi, 27, had trouble letting his not-yet so nimble English express his emotions. Mr. Nazmi, a printing product manager in Brooklyn, left Bangladesh six years ago and is the first of his family -- seven siblings and his parents -- to get citizenship. His father had worked in the United States embassy in Dacca for 38 years before coming to this country, he said.
"Today, I am finally free," he said. "Sometimes I miss Bangladesh. But today I am an American. I am a passport holder."
Yesterday evening, the entire family planned to go out to dinner.
Won Ju Kim believes his greatest privilege will be to vote. A native of Seoul, South Korea, Mr. Kim, 31, arrived as a student eight years ago. Since then he has moved from Illinois to Brooklyn where he works in a Korean importing business. Aside from economic incentives, his reasoning for becoming an American is simple and straightforward. "I can now do what I believe," he said. "My life is more wide open."
Victoria Eugenia Nieto left Barranquilla, Colombia, when she was 25. She did not speak English, had few friends and no job. She did not even know how to drive a car. Now, six years later, she works at Macy's at Roosevelt Field on Long Island as a sales associate.
Miss Nieto said she brought her values from Colombia and that she will never forget where she came from. First thing yesterday morning, she called her father in Colombia to tell him the news. "Tonight," she said, opening her eyes wide and laughing, "I have a date! We're going out for sushi."

HEADLINE: Profits Drop at Maxwell

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: LONDON, June 14

 BODY:
Maxwell Communication Corporation P.L.C. said today that its profit fell 9.2 percent in its latest fiscal year.
Robert Maxwell, chairman, who owns The Daily News in New York separately, said the company's core publishing and information services interests continued to do well, particularly in North America, despite the difficult economic climate. 
 The company said its net profit for the year ended March 31 fell to 125.1 million, or $218 million, from 137.8 million in the corresponding period a year ago.
Maxwell Communication said its pretax profit fell 16 percent, to 145.5 million, or $253 million, from 172.3 million a year earlier.
Sales fell 20 percent, to 996.9 million, or $1.73 billion, from 1.242 billion a year earlier.
In April, after the close of the financial year, Maxwell sold its Pergamon Press business to the Dutch publisher Elsevier N.V. for $766 million. Most of the proceeds will be used to reduce Maxwell Communication's debt and "represents substantial progress," the company said.

HEADLINE: NEWS SUMMARY

 BODY:

The Economy
A former senior Pentagon official pleaded guilty to Federal conspiracy and bribery charges in the four-year-old investigation into a conspiracy to rig the bidding on military contracts and defraud the Government. Melvyn R. Paisley, who was an assistant Navy secretary from 1981 to 1987, faces up to 30 years in jail and up to $750,000 in fines. [Page 1.] 
 The economy appears to be growing again without pushing up the inflation rate. The Consumer Price Index rose in May by only three-tenths of 1 percent, the Labor Department said. When combined with other modest increases this year, the rise suggests an annual inflation rate below 3 percent, or less than half of last year's 6.1 percent. [1.]
 Production at factories, mines and utilities increased a seasonally adjusted five-tenths of 1 percent in May, the strongest gain in 11 months. [46.] Business sales rose 1.2 percent in April while inventories fell five-tenths of 1 percent, to a seasonally adjusted $815.2 billion, the lowest level since June 1990. [46.]
 Washington must give back more than $20 million of duties collected on imports of Canadian pork, the highest appeals tribunal under the United States-Canadian trade agreement decided. [35.]
 The National Labor Relations Board announced a decision that could make it harder for companies to relocate factories to low-wage areas. [35.]
 The cable television industry enhanced its reputation for effective lobbying when the F.C.C. adopted exceptionally tame rules on local regulation of cable prices. But the cable industry may have been too clever for its own good. News Analysis. [35.]
 
 Companies
Groupe Axa said it had reached an agreement with the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States to obtain a major stake in the New York insurer. But later in the day the French company backed off from the remarks saying that a definitive agreement had not been worked out. [35.]
 Advertising's equivalent of the Academy Awards turned into something akin to a grade-school graduation run amok, anguished industry executives say. [35.]
 A Federal judge blocked an offer by T.W.A. to buy a vast portion of its estimated $1.37 billion debt at a discount, a move that could push the troubled airline closer to bankruptcy. [37.]
 I.B.M. said it believed it would be the first to produce the next generation of computer memory chips, which will make I.B.M. computers faster and smaller. [37.]
 Lionel filed for protection under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code, its second such action since 1982. [37.]
 
 Markets
Stocks bounded ahead with the Dow again surpassing the 3,000 level. With volume the heaviest it has been all week, 169.3 million shares, the Dow closed at 3,000.45, up 35.33 points for the day and 23.71 for the week. [35.]
 A late burst of buying lifted prices of Treasury bonds to their best levels of the day in what dealers described as unusually active Friday trading. As a result, long-term interest rates fell. [38.]
 The dollar settled mostly lower on world currency markets as traders cashed in on the currency's recent run-up. [43.]
 Platinum futures prices dropped to their lowest levels in more than five years largely because of overseas selling. [43.]
 
 Today's Columns
Although grandiose plans often go awry, even partial success for the I.R.S.'s modernization effort will bring big improvements for the nation's 100 million-plus taxpayers. Your Taxes. [36.]
 A nutcracker that can yield whole walnuts almost every time has been patented. Patents. [36.]

HEADLINE: U.N. AIDES SAY IRAQ MAY BE CONCEALING NUCLEAR MATERIAL

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, June 14

 BODY:
United Nations officials said today that they had intelligence information indicating that Iraq has tried to mislead the United Nations by understating its nuclear weapons program and the amount of weapons-grade nuclear material it possesses.
As a result, the special commission appointed by the Security Council to oversee the destruction or removal of Iraq's chemical and biological arms and its nuclear weapons materials has ordered its experts to make new inspections of undisclosed nuclear sites in Iraq next week. 
 The inspections were ordered after the United States provided the commission with fresh intelligence from an Iraqi nuclear scientist who defected more than a week ago to American forces occupying an enclave in northern Iraq.
 
Information From Defector
 In Washington, Government officials who follow the Iraqi nuclear program said the defector had reported that Iraq had eight primary sites for nuclear research and development, three of which were bombed extensively by the American-led military coalition in the Persian Gulf war.
Most of the defector's reports remain unproven and will require additional investigation, the officials said.
United Nations officials said they had been told that the Iraqi defector reported that Iraq has been trying to manufacture weapons-grade uranium using an old-fashioned technique called magnetic isotope separation, which the United States experimented with but abandoned while it was developing the world's first atomic bomb toward the end of World War II.
 
Plant Near Mosul Reported
 A plant for this purpose was said to exist in a secret underground site in the mountains not far from the northern Iraqi city of Mosul.
The defector also said there were several other secret nuclear sites unknown to outsiders, officials here said.
A United States official, citing intelligence reports, said Iraq's nuclear weapons program had nevertheless been judged by analysts to have been more primitive than many feared.
Some of the eight sites may have been spared extensive bombing because they were not regarded as critical to the nation's nuclear-weapons effort, an official said today. Still, he said, "it's a very major concern that we didn't find all the sites" for nuclear and chemical weapons research.
Iraq also removed an undetermined amount of equipment from its nuclear-weapons centers before the allied air campaign began, officials said today, but they added that that action was not unexpected.
Under the terms of Security Council Resolution 687 that set conditions for lifting economic sanctions against Iraq, the Baghdad Government is required to provide inventories of all material in its possession that could be used for nuclear weapons as well as chemical and biological arms and ballistic missiles to the special commission, which will then remove or destroy them.
Iraq told the Security Council in April that it possessed only the 45 kilos, or nearly 100 pounds, of highly enriched uranium that it had declared to the International Atomic Energy Agency.
In Washington, Paul L. Leventhal, president of the Nuclear Control Institute, which studies nuclear proliferation issues, said Administration officials had told him that the defector said Iraq had manufactured an additional 40 kilos -- about 88 pounds -- of weapons-grade material using magnetic isotope separation.
In a statement, the Nuclear Control Institute said J. Carson Mark, retired director of weapons design at the Los Alamos National Laboratory, has estimated that this amount would be sufficient for two atomic bombs of the kind dropped on Nagasaki in 1945.
 
'Ominous Failures' Seen
 If confirmed, the Nuclear Control Institute said, the defector's reports would highlight "ominous failures," both in American intelligence gathering and in the international efforts to control the spread of atomic weapons.
Iraq has signed the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty, pledging not to acquire nuclear arms and opening its declared nuclear sites to inspection by the Vienna-based Atomic Energy Agency.
In May, inspectors sent by the commission placed some of the 45 declared kilos of enriched uranium under tamper-proof seals at Iraq's Tuwaitha nuclear site but said the rest was buried under the rubble of a plant bombed by the allies during the war.
At the same time, the inspectors visited a nuclear site at Tarmiya, north of Baghdad. Although they found nothing incriminating, officials say, the inspectors had the impression that the plant had recently been stripped of its equipment in a hurry.
Members of the special commission have also expressed doubts about the accuracy of Baghdad's inventories of its chemical and biological weapons and its stocks of ballistic missiles.
 
More Than What Was Declared
 United Nations officials said that under questioning from the commission, Baghdad recently admitted that it has substantially more chemical weapons than it declared on April 18.
At that time, it told the commission that it had about 11,000 shells, bombs and rockets filled with paralyzing nerve agents and poisonous gas as well as about 1,000 tons of chemicals used in the manufacture of such weapons.
Iraq also has acknowledged that it has more ballistic missiles than the 52 it reported on April 18.
The first chemical weapons inspectors are now in Iraq cataloguing stocks at the Muthana base near Samarra, some 50 miles north of Baghdad.
Later this month the commission will send experts to examine ballistic missiles and suspected biological weapons plants. Iraq says it has no biological weapons.
The exact size of Iraq's arsenal of weapons of mass destruction is important because the Security Council is seeking both to destroy those now in inventory and to prevent Baghdad from acquiring any more in the future.
Once the commission has completed its survey, it will determine the best way of destroying them. Commission officials say dangerous chemicals are likely to be burned locally in special incinerators.
The more difficult task is destroying chemical munitions. The commission, which has established a regional headquarters in Bahrain, is considering borrowing mobile destruction plants developed by the Soviet Union or building a special destruction plant.

HEADLINE: Allies and East Bloc Back Arms Accord

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 14

 BODY:
The United States' NATO allies and five Eastern European countries today formally approved a Soviet-American compromise to end a dispute over a treaty limiting conventional armies in Europe.
The Bush Administration will now send the treaty to the Senate for its approval. It is not expected to meet much opposition, considering that it will require the Soviets to withdraw thousands of pieces of military equipment from Europe to bring their forces down to levels roughly equal to those of NATO's and will require the Soviets to destroy some 20,000 tanks, artillery and armored vehicles. 
 Even without the treaty, the Soviets were withdrawing their forces from Eastern Europe. But the treaty will insure that they do it in a timely, verifiable fashion.
The treaty on conventional forces in europe was signed at a Paris summit meeting last Nov. 19. But its ratification by the 16 NATO and 6 Warsaw Pact countries covered by the agreement, among them the Soviet Union, had been held up because of a last-minute attempt by Moscow to reinterpret the pact in a way that would enable the Soviet military to spare some of its equipment.
 
Prompt Senate Action Expected
 "After months of concern that the Soviet military might be trying to undermine the treaty, President Gorbachev seems to have reasserted control," said Senator Joseph R. Biden, the Delaware Democrat who as chairman of the subcommittee on European Affairs will manage the ratification hearings and the floor debate. "With the interpretation dispute now resolved, I expect the Senate to act promptly to bring this historic accord into effect."
The Soviet backtracking since November was widely viewed as an attempt by the Soviet military to try to win back some of the concessions made by Soviet diplomats during the negotiations. But the Bush Administration refused to send the treaty to the Senate for ratification, or to consider another summit meeting, until the Soviets backed down.
Two weeks ago, during a meeting in Lisbon, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d and the Soviet Foreign Minister, Aleksandr A. Bessmertnykh, hammered out a compromise in which the Soviets essentially agreed to the NATO interpretation of the treaty, but with some minor concessions by the West to bring the Soviet military along.
At today's meeting in Vienna, the members of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and the Warsaw Pact, which has disbanded its military command but retains its political structure, delivered binding declarations accepting the Soviet pledges as the basis for a treaty ratification.
The main dispute was over 933 tanks and other armored pieces assigned to Soviet naval and coastal defense units. The Kremlin insisted that these units were not covered by the treaty because it technically covers ground forces and not navies. But NATO insisted that the Soviet Union's naval infantry -- equivalent to the United States Marines -- and coastal defense forces were essentially ground troops.
Under the compromise, NATO agreed that the Soviets could keep the equipment belonging to their naval and coastal defense forces, provided that Moscow promise not to increase their size and that it withdraw an equal amount of equipment from other units.
In an additional concession, Moscow agreed to destroy or convert to civilian use roughly a quarter of the 57,000 pieces of armored equipment that it had withdrawn from the treaty zone, which stretches from the Atlantic Ocean to the Ural Mountains, before the Nov. 19 signing.
In a concession to Moscow, NATO agreed to the Soviet demand to exclude 1,700 armored personnel carriers assigned to strategic nuclear rocket forces by treating them as internal security units, not ground forces.

BUSH STILL WARY ON AID TO MOSCOW
 LOS ANGELES, June 14 (Special to The New York Times) -- Restating his contention that it is too early to talk about massive economic aid to the Soviet Union, President Bush said today that there was "general agreement" on the issue among the leaders of the Group of Seven industrialized democracies, who are to meet in London in July.

HEADLINE: In Tight Times (Shh!) Haggling Can Be A Status Symbol

BYLINE: By ANDREE BROOKS

 BODY:
Bargaining. People are doing it everywhere. But it's not something they're talking about much.
If you catch someone at it and know the person well enough to ask why they're trying to get a pair of tennis shoes for $2 less than the tagged price, they'll have a host of ready excuses at hand. Mostly they add up to the fact that tennis shoes have got to be pretty expensive, that there is a recession and that most sellers will give a little to get a little. But lots of people won't admit they enjoy the give and take. 
 There are many countries where haggling has always been a way of life. In the United States, only certain categories of goods, like antiques, for example, were always thought to be fair game for bargaining. That, after all, is what a flea market is all about. But now people are trying for lower prices almost everywhere, including department stores and speciality food shops.
 
Paying the Price
 Still, bargaining is not for everyone. A good many Americans shudder at the prospect. "We have been conditioned in this country to think of haggling as not possible, or inappropriate," said Vivian Walker, a sociologist who was raised in Little Rock, Ark., where Southern graciousness seemed to outlaw bargaining.
Dr. Walker, who has researched cultural differences in negotiating methods, has found that a good many people simply retreat or go along and pay the asking price. "And that's a shame," she said, "because once you test the boundaries, you can be quite surprised."
So how do you get over any discomfort you might feel to get that new shirt you wanted for $20 less than the ticketed "bargain" price? The key, said Prof. Jeanne Brett, who teaches negotiating skills at the Kellogg Graduate School of Management at Northwestern University in Evanston, Ill., is to start by legitimizing the act in your own mind.
 
Timing Is Crucial
 She mentioned, for example, how she had been out shopping for a pair of shoes a few weeks ago. The pair she liked had a defective buckle. Although she knew she could still wear the shoes without the defect showing or making a difference to comfort, she also felt she was entitled to a markdown.
"It meant that I had to ask for something off," she said. "But the manager agreed right away."
Timing is also crucial. Dr. Brett recalled how her husband, Stephen, an arbitrator by profession and another consummate haggler, had been eager to buy a large can of walnut oil in a specialty food market in a Chicago suburb. "But the price just seemed too high," she said.
Two months later, when the can was still sitting on the shelf, he told the manager he was willing to buy it -- provided something was knocked off the price. The manager refused. But six weeks later, with the can still unsold, the manager agreed to a discount.
"It's like going to a farmer's market," Dr. Brett said. "You'll pay full price if you go in the morning. But wait until late in the day and most merchants will be delighted to give you a break."
Most consumers might not want to wait as long as Mr. Brett for walnut oil, but the longer a consumer is prepared to wait the more likely he is to get what he wants for less. Of course, it is always easier if you stop to figure out how you can benefit the vendor and then make that point in your argument, said Robert Prus, a professor of sociology at the University of Waterloo in Waterloo, Ont.
Dr. Prus spent nine years studying consumer behavior for two books on sales and purchasing techniques. "Most people only think about what they will get out of it," he said. "But it pays to consider the vendor's viewpoint."
This is the approach favored by Neil Levy, a lawyer in San Francisco. Mr. Levy said he learned his haggling skills from his Uncle Ben who once took all his nephews and nieces to a basket market in the Caribbean as a sort of final examination in the genre.
As an example of capitalizing on the vendor's needs, Mr. Levy explained how he was recently approached at his home by a chimney sweep looking for business. The sweep, a respected man, quoted a price for cleaning and repair. Rather than accepting the quote, or seeking another sweep, Mr. Levy decided he wanted to court this man's service.
"He obviously needed the business or he wouldn't have come by," said Mr. Levy. "I also knew that if I let him do the job in his slow season he would gain something by reducing the price. So I told him he could choose his own time provided he reconsidered what he was charging."
Similarly, Mr. Levy said it helps to be aware that some storekeepers may be more interested in giving you something extra than reducing a price, "because they don't want other customers to demand a similiar break." This is often true in appliance stores, he said. "Ask them to throw in something with the purchase instead. And they often will, especially when they are slow."
 
Keep Asking
 Seymour Mund of Westport, Conn., who polished his haggling skills in the 1970's as a union negotiator, confirmed the value of this approach a few months ago when he was looking for a clip-on light for a music stand. The floor sample was the only one in stock. So he asked for a reduction because it had obviously been opened and handled. The manager refused. So Mr. Mund asked for an extra replacement bulb since the light required the use of a miniature, expensive size. The manager agreed.
Dr. Prus said it is crucial to make your pitch only to the person who has the authority to make a price change. It also makes a big difference if the store manager or vendor is approached unobtrusively -- "not when there are lots of other people around to see."
Knowing something in advance about prices for similar items or services elsewhere is also important. "Do your homework," Mr. Levy said. Check around to see what constitutes a really good -- but fair -- price. That will help to prevent you from insulting the vendor by heavy underbidding. That's the mistake that most often spells goodbye to the good buy.
